title: 'Fantastic Job This Summer' - Summer School Program to Expand Next Year
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
'Fantastic job this summer' - Summer school program to expand next year

 September 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 919
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Based on the success of the 2023 summer education program and continued grant funding, Caroline County Public Schools' leaders are aiming to teach 400 more students next year.Presenting statistics and anecdotal comments about the program at the Sept. 5 meeting of the Board of Education, Lindsey McCormick, director of College and Career Readiness, gave "huge shout-outs and kudos" to the 75 certified teachers, 15 instructional assistants and seven site coordinators who "chose to give up portions of their summer and continue to work with our students." Instructional assistants also received additional training this year.Caroline County School Superintendent Dr. Derek Simmons praised McCormick's leadership."Lindsey has done a fantastic job.Her team has done a fantastic job this summer, he said. "This (report) is an absolute testament to that."McCormick said 100 Caroline County Recreation and Parks staff helped with the 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. elementary summer camp called Jurassic Jamboree, which attracted 50 more students this year than in 2022."They're a tremendous partner," she said.The summer lessons and activities were designed for elementary, middle and high school students, with special programs for students with disabilities and multilingual learners.McCormick said the five-week time frame for summer programming was essentially the same as last year's, running from June 23 to July 27. Altogether, 916 students participated.Elementary students numbered 747 and attended sessions at four elementary schools (Federalsburg was closed for renovations). The average attendance was 14 days of the 19-day program.Participating in the elementary programming were 70 multilingual learners, 49 of whom attend Greensboro Elementary School.In the morning, students participated in both Reading Eggs and Moving with Math or Agile Mind; the Agile Mind math program was introduced for fifth grade students. When the teachers left, students had lunch, and in the afternoon, Recreation and Parks staff led enrichment activities.Secondary students attended only morning sessions. McCormick said one of the goals was to "boost our middle school program.""We raised our numbers to 40 students, and I was thrilled with that," she said. She praised after-school coordinator Deja Thompson for implementing what McCormick envisioned."Our middle school students had 45 minutes a day where they could rotate through, by choice, some CTE (Career and Technology Education) mini-sessions," McCormick said, adding that "one of the large pushes" in the Blueprint For Maryland's Future is more career exploration starting in middle school through high school.McCormick added comments from both teachers and parents to her PowerPoint presentation. One parent noted, "My seventh grade son didn't want to 'give up' his summer but over the course of five weeks, he only missed three days. He was extremely excited about the CCTC programs he was able to see.""I thought it was just great that our students had the opportunity to be exposed to some of our different CTE programs," she said. "The CTE teachers themselves came to the middle schools to do that."Middle school students attended a tri-county, career enrichment day in Dorchester County that McCormick called "amazing."Simmons explained the that Dorchester program is funded by the Mid-Shore Regional Council and is led by People for Change, "an organization out of Prince George's County of largely minority business owners and professionals who run STEM sessions."High school students were offered summer "credit recovery" courses, and 131 participated and passed the courses, 92 from North Caroline and 39 from Colonel Richardson."It was less students this year, which you could say is a good thing because if you are doing credit recovery, you want less students," McCormick said. Students can take credit recovery courses during the school year, as well as repeat courses to earn credits needed for graduation.The program for students with disabilities from elementary through high school increased by 30, with 127 students participating, 102 at the elementary level, and 25 secondary students.CCPS Food Service provided breakfast and lunch for all students, as well as lunch for elementary students, or nearly 15,000 meals. Health rooms were staffed with nurses and health assistants, and School Based Wellness Centers were open.McCormick expects next year's program to be the same duration."Nineteen days is amazing.It's not too short, and it's not too long," she said.Because some classrooms had waitlists, McCormick said her "goal is to increase summer programming by 400 students, so I have to have about 1,200 to 1,300 students next summer."A 21st Century Grant is pending to help fund the program.This year's program was funded by the American Rescue Plan Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief (ARP ESSER) Fund, food services and in-kind in use of buildings, according to CCPS Communications Officer Sandi Barry."We have this funding for one more year, and we want to make sure we maximize it.," Simmons said. "We will continue to look for grant opportunities working with our partners, with Recreation Parks, with the YMCA, if possible.""We will continue working with our partners, but we're going to maximize everything we can to make it make it work, make it sustainable, and then have the great data to then go to the grant sources to keep the funding coming in," Simmons said. 
 
 Caption: A big bounce house and slippery slide cool off Preston Elementary School students who attend the 19-day summer program.
 
A little game of checkers is a great way to connect during summer camp at Greensboro Elementary School.
 
Lindsey McCormick, CCPS director of College and Career Readiness, presents results of the Summer School program.
 
These two friendly Greensboro Elementary School Hornets are not in a stinging mood during summer camp.

title: Raskin Leads Recognition of Banned Books Week
author: Josie Jack; Capital News Service
content:
Raskin leads recognition of Banned Books Week

 September 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josie Jack; Capital News Service | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 466
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - Rep. Jamie Raskin, D-Mary-land, and Sen. Brian Schatz, D-Hawaii, introduced a bill Wednesday calling for the national recognition of Banned Books Week, which is Oct. 1-7, and the condemnation of banning books in school libraries.The bill recommends that local governments and schools "protect the rights of students to learn and the ability of educators and librarians to teach" and calls for upholding the First Amendment but does not include a unified national protocol for dealing with book bans."You know, the proper response to hating a book in a free society is you don't read the book," Raskin said at a Capitol Hill press conference Wednesday.The bill, which has 40 co-sponsors in the House and 15 in the Senate, echoes bills the lawmakers introduced in the last session of Congress but neither measure passed.Instances of book banning increased by 33% from the 2021-2022 school year to the 2022-2023 school year, according to the nonprofit PEN America. Books such as "The Bluest Eye" by Toni Morrison and "Gender Queer: A Memoir" by Maia Kobabe repeatedly have been targeted by critics. Many titles that receive so-called requests for review involve themes of race, sexuality and sexual abuse.Between July 1, 2022, and June 30, there were 3,362 instances of book banning in public libraries and in schools, according to PEN America.Florida accounted for 40% of the book bans. Top states where book bans were instituted were Texas, Utah, Missouri and Pennsylvania.The Senate Judiciary Committee earlier this month held a hearing on book bans, where senators and five witnesses discussed balancing the freedom of speech of parents and taxpayers with those of students, teachers and librarians. The hearing examined book ban policies at the state and local level.The debate did not include the introduction of federal policies on book bans nor a tangible, federal solution. Sen. John Kennedy, R-Louisiana, asked witnesses Cameron Samuels, a student at Brandeis University and co-founder of Students Engaged in Advancing Texas, and Illinois Secretary of State Alexi Giannoulias to provide a clear solution; neither did."The discussion we've been having for me, it's a little too conceptual, or I don't know, metaphysical," Kennedy said.The federal government has not passed legislation to create a unified procedure on book bans. Book ban and review policies and decisions are currently made at the local government level.On June 12, Illinois passed a law that makes libraries that ban books ineligible for state-funded grants. It is the first state in the country to take such action and could pave the way for future federal legislation."It's my hope that other states, that others may look toward Illinois and see the value in adopting our legislation as a model to stop banning booksin its tracks and to protect the right to read freely without fear of retribution," Giannou-lias said at the legislation's signing. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Counties Ponder Money for College Building - Financial Commitment Worries Many of the County Officials
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Counties ponder money for college building - Financial commitment worries many of the county officials

 October 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 675
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Talbot and Queen Anne's counties came together virtually recently to discuss a $79 million project to build a new Technical Center at Chesapeake College?Each county must decide whether or not it wants to submit a letter of intent to the Maryland Higher Education Commission to provide local funds for the facility before a Sept. 28 meeting at the Department of Budget and Management. The meeting, according to Chesapeake College President Cliff Coppersmith, is an opportunity to get the project "to the next level" by getting it put on a state list of capital projects.The state has agreed to pay for 75% of the capital project. With these letters of intent, each county would agree to providing local funds for the other 25%. In an email, Coppersmith said that once state funding has been allocated and approved, each supporting county would need to pass appropriations to fund the local share of the capital project.The facility would be more than 90,000 square feet. Of that total, 52,000 square feet would be assignable space. Currently, construction is set for 2026. The center will be located next to the Eastern Shore Higher Education Center."Our problem right now is we've got so much equipment crammed in these spaces, there's not a lot of room for students," Coppersmith said of the current Queen Anne's Technical Building during the meeting.According to meeting documents from a Queen Anne's County Commissioners meeting Sept. 12, the new facility "will house programs such as electrical, welding, HVAC, culinary, skilled office/administrative support and marine and construction trades training."Kent County Commission President Ron Fithian chaired the meeting between counties Monday evening. Fithian said that while the new facility would be great to have on the Eastern Shore, Kent County does have concerns about the financial aspect of the project.Caroline County Commission Vice President Larry Porter said the cost of building the new facility is what strikes him most."I would really like to have a little bit more information about where that number is coming from," he said.Coppersmith said the estimated cost includes furnishing the building. He added that the equipment is not a part of that estimate."Existing equipment that's useable and still in date, we would just move into the new building and obviously we would raise money - private funding, public grants, etc. - to upgrade our equipment once we get the building built and we're ready to move in," Coppersmith said.Queen Anne's County Commissioner Jack Wilson Jr. acknowledged that the price of the project is a concern, but said he feels confident they will be able to receive more money from the state for the project.Later in the meeting, Wilson said that the Queen Anne's County Commissioners had already voted last week in favor of providing letter of intent.Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said Dorchester County would have to vote against sending a letter of intent at this time. Pfeffer acknowledged that it is a "great project" but said that fiscal responsibilities in the county are keeping them from being able to send a letter of intent. Pfeffer said Dorchester County commissioners would be willing to send a letter of support for the project without a binding fiscal commitment.Fithian said each county is going to have to make its decision individually."We're all going to have to sit down with our finance office and really see what we can do," he said.During the meeting there were talks of possibly submitting a letter, signed by all five counties, detailing the benefits of having this new facility in order to obtain addition funding from the state.Toward the end of the meeting, Talbot County Council member Keasha Haythe said she will be voting in favor ofTalbot County submitting a letter of intent."As a Chesapeake College alum, I believe it's very necessary and needed," she said. "And considering how the labor force is doing a dive right now, this labor force is needed. We definitely have to be forward thinking to be able to accommodate the future needs of our children and those that are in high school currently."

title: Counties Sue Social Media Over Mental Health in Schools - Talbot Among 10 Counties Claiming Classroom Distraction
author: Christina Walker; Capital News Service
content:
Counties sue social media over mental health in schools - Talbot among 10 counties claiming classroom distraction

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Christina Walker; Capital News Service | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1088
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A "boring and pointless" education.That's what students at Henry E. Lackey High School in Indian Head, in Charles County, tell their English teacher Nicholas Gray they're receiving while they distract themselves with TikTok videos, "snaps" on Snapchat and endless scrolls through Instagram during class."It is difficult to convince [students] that learning is more impactful and important than the brand new video that will entertain them," Gray said.With that thought in mind, Charles County this month joined nine other Maryland school districts in a lawsuit against the world's social media giants: Google, Meta, ByteDance and Snap Inc. Other school districts in the state that have joined the court action are Anne Arundel, Baltimore City, Carroll, Cecil, Harford, Howard, Montgomery, Prince George's and Talbot."Hopefully this lawsuit provides pressure for some action in terms of how to better create products that are geared to children," said Maria Navarro, superintendent of Charles County Public Schools.CLASSROOM DISTRACTIONThe lawsuit accused several social media platforms of targeting and manipulating youth so they stay engaged for excessive amounts of time - and that's exactly what educators see in Charles County classrooms."(Social media is) a huge distraction in our schools and in our classrooms," said Cheryl Davis, principal of Henry E. Lackey High School.The teachers do their part to plan effective, instructional uses for technology in the classroom, Davis said, but personal devices get in the way.Gray said he prohibits the use of cell phones during instructional times and tries to create engaging lessons so that students will not be tempted to use their devices or go on social media.However, he said, the biggest problem plaguing his students is self control and their failure to regulate personal behavior."Students are lacking the ability to express their emotions in a positive way," Davis said. "We see a lot more negative expressions."Students have gotten more angry and aggressive, Davis said. In a developmental part of their lives, they often fail to pause for a moment and look for resources or constructive ways to express their emotions."There is no respite," Gray said. "Students leave for the day and the talking/anger continues onto Instagram or Snapchat, and then the students come to school upset over what is on social media."Several Charles County educators said more physical altercations have occurred because of social media conflicts."Snapchat scares me," said Brian Street, a father of two Piccowaxen middle schoolers."I've seen several fights at school on Snapchat."On top of that, two staff members at St. Charles High School were injured Thursday after they intervened in a physical altercation between students that started over a social media post, according to a letter that Principal Tammika Little sent out to parents."Please monitor your child's electronic devices and social media accounts," Little said.MENTAL HEALTHNot surprisingly, school officials in Charles County and elsewhere are alarmed at how social media affects child development and mental health. That concern is also reflected in the lawsuit, which alleges that companies are aware of the negative impacts the platforms have on children's mental health, but they choose to prioritize profit.Students go through developmental changes from elementary school to middle school, where their focus shifts from their parents to their peer group. Navarro said this is when children start pushing their own boundaries and understanding how to become an adult.As students become more self-sufficient, they begin building confidence - but social media usage during this stage can interrupt a child's growth, Navarro said."A fake reality, at those pivotal developmental ages, has more of an impact on behavioral health," Navarro said. "It also isolates you."Navarro said social media augments the insecurities children face at pivotal ages, and research seems to prove that point. Researchers at Facebook found that Instagram, in 2021, made one in three girls feel worse about their bodies, according to the Wall Street Journal.Moreover, the COVID-19 pandemic further isolated children and left many in a more fragile mental state.According to the Centers for Disease Control, in 2021, suicide was the second leading cause of death for people ages 10 to 14.Charles County educators said social media contributes to the mental health crises that some young people endure. Inappropriate social media interactions continue to create disruptions in the buildings all over the county because children these ages are not developmentally ready for the responsibility, Davis said."Students lack the maturity to be able to handle social media," Davis said.That being the case, Davis said schools must make mental health a priority or else their true purpose will not be achieved."We are here to educate students," Davis said. "If students are not in the right mindset, then it's much more difficult for them to access education."Searching for solutions While voicing support for the lawsuit, Charles County educators are looking elsewhere for more prompt solutions to the problems social media causes in the classroom.Davis pushed for parents to be a part of the solution."You pay for the phone, you own the phone, put some apps on there that allow you to control access," Davis said.Parents should be monitoring their kids' devices to make sure they're safe, Davis said, and it is not just her who feels this way."It's not a school thing, it's a parent thing," Street said.He said that while he does monitor his kids' social media usage, it is a parents' decision on how active they want to be in controlling it.Navarro said Charles County Public Schools has many resources for parents to learn how to be tech savvy so they know how to keep their children safe. In addition to limiting screen time, she said parents should be encouraging their kids to physically play, talk and participate in sports and extracurricular activities with other kids.Navarro said when to allow children to have devices is a parent's choice."My job is to inform and educate them about the implications of those decisions," Navarro said. She said she wants students to reach their full potential, but right now social media makes it harder for them to do that.That's where the lawsuit could help.Navarro said that if the district gets any compensation from this lawsuit, the school system intends to expand resources for the growing needs of behavioral health.And even in these early stages, Navarro said, the lawsuit serves an important purpose."It sends a message," she said.The message: that everyone - from social media companies to educators to parents to students - must be alert to the harm that social media can do to young people. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on school districts filing a lawsuit over social media's impact on classroom distraction and student mental health, making it primarily about education policy and school environments.

title: Dorchester Schools Gain Proficiency on Tests
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester schools gain proficiency on tests

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 901
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Dorchester County Public Schools saw an increase in English language arts scores on the spring 2023 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program, or MCAP, assessments compared to the year before.Math data showed a few significant increases along with some slight changes in proficiency compared to the year before.During a Dorchester County Board of Education meeting, Jodi Colman, director of curriculum, instruction and assessment for Dorchester County Public Schools, shared data from the spring 2023 MCAP assessments.The MCAP assessments are statewide and administered to students starting in grade three through high school.Data broken down by individual schools is not yet available to the public.ENGLISH LANGUAGE ARTSFor grades three through six, there were significant increases in the percent of proficient learners in English language arts from the year before.The MCAP assessment uses four levels to measure student performance."Proficient learner" is the third of four levels. Level one is a "beginning learner," level two is a "developing learner," and level four is a "distinguished learner."Students who fall into levels 3 and 4 are considered proficient in the subject. In Dorchester County, the percent of students that fall into level 4 for the English language arts and math categories are between 0 and 5%.For the level three proficient learner category in English language arts, compared to Spring 2022 data:▪ Third graders increased to 31% from 26.4%.▪ Fourth graders increased to 32% from 27.6%.▪ Fifth graders increased to 33% from 26.8%▪ Sixth graders increased to 33% from 22.2% - a 10.8% increase.▪ Seventh graders decreased to 20% from 24.1%.▪ Eighth graders decreased to 27% from 29.2%.Along with seventh and eighth graders, there was a drop in the percent of proficient learners for the English 10 assessment compared to the previous year. The percentage dropped from 36.4% to 35%.Colman said the state average growth for English language arts was 2.9 percentage points.Dorchester County's average growth was 4.1 percentage points, she said."So we grew significantly, or doubled, the amount that the rest of the state did," she said. "It put us at the eleventh spot [in the state] as far as growth is concerned."Laura Aberg, DCPS supervisor of reading and English language arts for K through 12, spoke after Colman presented on the English language arts data."I'm excited to see all the growth for our younger students," she said."Our secondary students, we need to do some work to get back to the levels of growth that we like to see."Aberg said the district has implemented more diagnostics at the beginning of the year to identify those "reading gaps" so they can be addressed sooner for secondary students. She also talked about getting ready to enroll students in grades six through eight, as well as tenth graders, in MCAP tutorials.Aberg said she hopes to see even greater growth for younger students in the future since the district has implemented a foundational reading program that aligns with the science of reading, or the research behind how students learn to read.Board Member Theresa Stafford asked Aberg what the district did differently last year that might be attributed to the growth in proficiency for elementary students.Aberg mentioned multiple changes including the use of DIBELS test data to "help drive instruction" and getting teachers trained in the science of reading.MATHWhen it came to MCAP math assessments, grade seven and Algebra I saw significant increases in proficiency. The percentage of seventh graders that were considered proficient learners increased to 11% from less than 5% the year before. The percentage of Algebra I students that were considered proficient learners increased to 10% from less than 5% the year before.For grade six, there was a decrease in proficient learners, compared the year before, from 10% to less than 5%.For the other math assessments in the county, there was a mix of slight increases, slight decreases and constants in the percentage of proficient learners compared to the previous year. These include:▪ Third graders decreased to 20% from 20.3%▪ Fourth graders increased to 15% from 14.6%▪ Fifth graders increased to 14% from 12.2%▪ Eighth graders stayed at less than 5%▪ Geometry students stayed at 0%▪ Algebra II students decreased to 0% from less than 5%Colman said that while the state average growth for math was 2.5 percentage points, Dorchester County grew 2.0 percentage points.DCPS is focusing on improving math scores for third graders, sixth graders and Algebra I students this year, she said."Those were kind of the focus areas as far as the data," Colman said.She said there is a focus on third grade because it is the first group of students to take the MCAP assessments and there is a need for those students to gain a better understanding of the assessment.At the middle school level, Colman said the math coach is working with teachers and modeling lessons. The math coach is also working and planning with Algebra I teachers."So she's kind of targeted certain grade levels to try to impact some of this data," Colman said.After Colman's presentation on the math data, Board Member Chris Wheedleton talked about the importance of recognizing the data, good and bad, and talking about how the data can be improved for next year."I'm really pleased to see what you all are doing with this, how you've organized it," he said. "But then, it's really about the action." 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Carey Wright Appointed Interim State Superintendent
content:
Carey Wright appointed interim state superintendent

 October 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 540
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland State Board of Education voted unanimously on Wednesday evening to appoint Carey Wright as the interim State Superintendent of Schools for the remainder of the current term through June 30, 2024. Wright will begin her service as state superintendent by Oct. 23, 2023, pending the completion of onboarding logistics.Most recently, Wright served for nine years as the state superintendent of schools in Mississippi."I am honored to be appointed to this position and am excited to work on behalf of the teachers, leaders and students of Maryland. Maryland is well-positioned to provide a world-class education system for all its students and to ensure each student's success," Wright said. "I am confident that by establishing strong relationships and partnerships across the state we will witness strong, equitable educational outcomes for our students. I welcome the opportunity to be an active participant in this endeavor."Under Wright's leadership, Mississippi's Quality Counts grade for education improved from an F to a C, improving its ranking from 50th to 35th. Her work reform efforts to improve literacy instruction for children Pre-K through third grade produced significant improvements in literacy rates in Mississippi, with the largest gains in fourth grade literacy on the National Assessment for Educational Progress."I am thrilled to welcome Dr. Carey Wright as Maryland's Interim State Superintendent. She is an exceptional leader who will guide Maryland's education system into its new chapter," Gov. Wes Moore said. "Dr. Wright brings exemplary expertise to this role and I am confident that she will be a dedicated leader committed to transparency, accountability, and partnership to improve education outcomes in every corner of Maryland, just as this state deserves."Wright has long been an enthusiastic advocate for early childhood education and in Mississippi implemented the first publicly funded Early Learning Collaborative program, which earned the state recognition from the National Institute for Early Education Research as one of only seven states in the nation that meet all or most quality standards for early childhood education.Wright brings to the position decades of service as a Maryland educator with stints in Prince George's, Howard, and Montgomery County Public Schools as a teacher, principal, director of special education, and associate superintendent. Prior to serving as superintendent in Mississippi, Wright served as the chief academic officer in DC Public Schools. Wright obtained her bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees from the University of Maryland, College Park."Dr. Wright is a Maryland educator and a national leader of education reform. She has the experience and expertise to lead Maryland through implementation of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and through our state's commitment to educational equity and improving outcomes for all students," State Board President Clarence Crawford said. "We are confident in her ability to lead our school system through this transition period, to be focused on transparency and accountability, and to continue building towards the improvements in results in our schools that we all know are necessary."Wright will receive a salary at an annual rate of $350,000, which will be prorated to the amount of time she serves from now through June 30, 2024. The joint State Board and MSDE Transition Team will support Wright as she is onboarded, and the national search for a permanent state superintendent of schools will continue in the coming months.

title: 'We will celebrate some of the books that have been challenged' - Library director 'shocked' by efforts nationwide to remove controversial books
author: Laura Tayman
content:
'We will celebrate some of the books that have been challenged' - Library director 'shocked' by efforts nationwide to remove controversial books

 October 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 791
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Kent County Library's Executive Director Arnessa Dowell participated in "7 Questions to Ask the Library's Executive Director," while traveling to the branches of North County, Rock Hall and Chestertown and sharing her ideas with county citizens and answering questions they had. Kent County News had the opportunity to ask her questions as well.Dowell was hired in early 2021, when the Kent County Library, like everything else across the country, was trying to adapt to the new norm of living with Covid.Q: What has been your biggest challenge as Executive Director?A: "I got acclimated to everything very quickly," said Dowell. "I oversaw the return of the senior team, putting library staff in place, and finally opening the branches back up." Dowell thanks the community for their support and was pleased that the library has since increased its growth."We've definitely seen an increase in library patrons, with over half the residents now owning a library card," she said.As the world began to get back to the new normal, Dowell and her team shifted focus to upgrading technology and making more of it available to county residents. Today, she and the library's board of directors are now working on improving their current program offerings; developing solutions to the issues raised by patrons in a recent survey; and focusing on how the library is identified in the community today.Q: What are you focusing on currently?A: "I want residents to feel we are inclusive," said Dowell, "like our libraries are really for everyone." New programming, a new website, and more technology for increased access to information for residents are planned for 2024. There are also ongoing discussions about future plans for the Rock Hall branch location.Q: Why did you become a librarian and why did you come to Kent County?A: Dowell says she was born in Mississippi, but grew up in Germany with her military family.Most of Dowell's extended family lived in Maryland, and she moved back and started working at Goucher's and then Towson's libraries. When her mother became ill, it was her librarian friends that got her through it. "They were wonderful and really made me want to work in that profession," said Dowell.Her commitment to increasing the opportunities for residents of a rural area is why she took the Executive Director position in Kent County. She cited examples that have been put in place to support that goal, like the Kent County free laptop program and expanding the e-library offerings.Q: What has been your greatest success so far at Kent County Library?A: Dowell was very excited about the results of this year's summer reading program. Over the course of nine weeks, registered summer readers embraced the "All Together Now" theme at 75 summer library events."Last summer, readers logged over 700,000 minutes, so this summer we set our sights even higher at 850,000 minutes," said Dowell. "The final count for this summer was over 900,000 minutes read!" Q: What is coming up in the fall for Kent County Library?A: Dowell said all county libraries of Maryland have partnered with Maryland Humanities in the "One Maryland One Book" program that aims to bring communities together through the shared experience of reading, discussing, and exploring the themes in a single book. This fall's chosen features author Tommy Orange's work "There There." Released in 2018, the book tells the stories of twelve Native Americans as they converge toward the Big Oakland Powwow. Critics have called it "a riveting portrait of the urban Indian experience." I'm excited to share that the Kent County Library will hold a special presentation with Chief Donna Wolf Mother Abbott, the first Female Chief of the Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians," said Dowell, "She will be speaking about the past, present, and future of the Nause-Waiwash on Maryland's Eastern Shore." Q: What is your feeling about the movement to ban books in other areas of the country?A: "I am just shocked," said Dowell. In fact, Kent County Library will be participating in the American Libraries Association's Banned Books Week this fall. "We will celebrate some of the books that have been challenged that are still on our shelves. Books help people learn and open a door to creativity," Dowell said. "I believe that everybody deserves a voice, and I feel like representation matters." Q: What is your favorite book?A: Dowell said the answer was a simple one-"Oh, the Places You'll Go" by Dr. Seuss. "It's really the theme of a library's purpose," said Dowell. "A really good book or technology at your fingertips can take you anywhere in the world." 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
Arnessa Dowell, executive director of Kent County Library, visited all branches last week to provide information for and to get input from library patrons. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Caroline Schools, Grounds Spruced Up Over Summer
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Caroline schools, grounds spruced up over summer

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 2A | Section: News 
 
 450

 DENTON - While students and teachers took time off during the summer, Caroline County Public Schools Department of Operations personnel were busy sprucing up buildings and grounds.At the Board of Education's Sept. 5 meeting, Director of Operations William Mengel presented a slide show featuring the projects completed over the summer of 2023.Mengel said the operations teams "did a remarkable job getting these buildings ready for for today and beyond." They include:▪ ADA-compliant ramps for the tech center's transition portable, Colonel Richardson High School and the Denton Elementary School portable and sidewalks at Greensboro Elementary School.▪ Refinished high school gym floors with new mascot logos.▪ Cafeteria remodeling, which included four kitchens upgraded with new line serving equipment; two kitchens redesigned for increased student flow and better line service efficiencies; painted ceiling grids, new ceiling tiles, walls, doors and LED lighting in six cafeterias; and a fullsize wall mural mounted in the Federalsburg Elementary School cafeteria.▪ Smoke and vapor sensors installed in all secondary schools.▪ Safety clean-ups, which included tree removals at North Caroline High School and Lockerman Middle School.▪ CCPS branding, including 3-D logos and taglines on administration buildings and selected district vehicles.▪ New concrete pads and sheds at the Greensboro and Federalsburg Judy Centers.▪ Electronic systems installed at Preston Elementary School allowing remote access to HVAC systems at the building level. Personnel will be able to access via their computers or iPad devices from anywhere.▪ Visitor bleachers at Colonel Richardson High School with seating capacity up to 150 people; will last for at least 80 years without safety concerns or compromise.▪ CCTC Agriculture Room: custom designed and built in-house wall cabinetry with locking doors made with recycled materials.▪ Purchase of two athletic field mowers.▪ Roof replacements: Federalsburg Elementary School-58,000 square feet and 98% complete; North Caroline HS - 178,000 square feet; phase 1 is 95% complete.▪ Unexpected projects: Colonel Richardson High School visitor bleachers foundation, severe flooding in the front of Colonel Richardson Middle School in two different places, fire sprinkler pipe; leak in the front lobby at the Family Support Center, removed Lockerman Middle School portables; and Ridgely elementary school next-door white house and property donated by William Moore and used for fire training by Ridgely Volunteer Fire Department.

title: 'You Are a 10!' - Speaker Motivates, Inspires at Talbot Schools
content:
'You are a 10!' - Speaker motivates, inspires at Talbot schools

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 350
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - International motivational performer, speaker and author Alex Boyé visited Talbot County Public Schools last week to inspire students in healthy thinking and interactions with others.ParentGuidance.org, a company that offers parents guidance and therapeutic support for youth mental health and suicide prevention efforts, partnered with TCPS to bring Boyé to speak with students in fifth through 12th grade."Alex Boyé was phenomenal," said TCPS Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi."We are so grateful to be able to share his wisdom with our students. His energy, enthusiasm, and talent are the perfect combination to deliver such an important message." On the "You Are a 10!" school tour, Boyé talks with students about his experiences of being the son of a single Nigerian immigrant mother in the United Kingdom, his challenges growing up and succeeding as an international motivational performer and author.He also performs many of his hit songs to amplify his message of hope, optimism and self-worth."With the current youth mental health climate across the world, and as a father of eight, it is important to me that our youth understand their worth, and they are a 10," Boyé said. "It is a privilege to tell my story of being the ultimate underdog, coming out on top, and helping students get through their struggles." Boyé's "You Are a 10!" book and video was recently released with overwhelming success, garnering positive reviews from school districts and students from across the nation.Boyé is known for his dynamic African-infused music and covers that have garnered millions of views on YouTube.He competed on "America's Got Talent" in 2015 and was named Rising Artist of the Year and grand prize winner in a music contest sponsored by Pepsi & Hard Rock Café in 2017.The "You Are a 10!" school tour is provided by the Cook Center for Human Connection and ParentGuidance.org, and was funded by the MD Aware II grant. Representatives from ParentGuidance.org were on hand during the tour to support teachers, parents, and students with additional

title: Talbot Mentors Celebrates Recent College Graduates
author: Contributed
content:
Talbot Mentors celebrates recent college graduates

 October 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 550
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Three long-time participants in the Talbot Mentors mentorship program graduated from college during the 2022-2023 school year.Tabius J. Wilson, Jr., who joined Talbot Mentors in 2013, graduated Cum Laude from Hampton University last spring. During his time at HU, Wilson majored in liberal studies, minored in leadership studies and took on several leadership roles, including serving as president of the Hampton University Student Government Association and as vice president of the Eastern Regional Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity.He was named a merit scholar and a W.D.C.Harvey scholar, as well as receiving the First Annual Gamma Lota Darrell K. Williams Leadership Award. This fall, Wilson will be attending George Mason University's Antonin ScaliaLaw School, where he has been awarded a full-ride scholarship.Randei Collins, who also joined Talbot Mentors in 2013, is a proud Washington College graduate.When applying to WAC, Collins was accepted into the esteemed Washington Scholars Program and received a full-ride scholarship.She went on to major in communications and media studies with a concentration in business and organizational communication.She also completed minors in both writing and marketing.Collins was very involved in campus life, serving in the Beta Pi chapter of the Alpha Chi Omega sorority, the Black Student Union, Cleopatra Sisters, Rotaract Club and the American Marketing Association.She received many honors for her academic achievements, including membership in the National Society of Leadership and Success, the Marketing Honor Society and the National English Honor Society.Collins also interned for the Library of Congress Publishing Office, the Cherry Tree Young Writers Conference, and in the fields of integrated communications and analytics.She is currently pursuing career leads and, after a much deserved gap year, plans to enroll in the Emerging Media graduate program at Loyola University.Taylan Brooks joined Talbot Mentors in 2016 and graduated from Morgan State University in the fall of 2022.Brooks earned his bachelor of science degree in information systems with Summa Cum Laude honors and was proud to be titled the Fall 2022 class salutatorian with a GPA of 3.94. He was also the Fall 2022 recipient of the President's Second Mile Award for his outstanding leadership and participation in student affairs.During his undergraduate experience, Brooks served in various leadership roles and organizations including: vice president of the MSU's Association of Information Technology Professionals, Morgan's Male Initiative on Leadership and Excellence, the National Society of Collegiate Scholars and the Clara I. Adams Honors College Honors Society. His motivation and hard work landed him a full-time position as an associate IT business partner at Textron Systems, a leading defense and aerospace technologies and services corporation located in Hunt Valley.Additionally, Brooks has been accepted in the graduate program at the University of Maryland Global Campus, where he plans to pursue his master's degree in cybersecurity technology.Talbot Mentors applauded Wilson, Collins, and Brooks on their achievements and expressed gratitude for their mentors, Mr. John Strickland, Ms. Anne Davis, and Mr. Jordan Loyd, who supported them on their academic journeys."Mentorship is a gift to both the mentee and the mentor," said Talbot Mentors Executive Director Kentavius Jones. "Both parties benefit greatly.Graduation provides a special opportunity to celebrate the accomplishments of our youth and the contributions of our mentors.Maintaining such lasting relationships takes real dedication and these occasions are testaments to the impact of those bonds."

title: Howie Sworn into Vacant Board of Education Seat
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Howie sworn into vacant Board of Education seat

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News

 EASTON - Anna Howie was sworn in as the newest member of the Talbot County Board of Education at a work session Monday evening.The swearing in came nearly a week after Howie was appointed to the seat by Gov. Wes Moore following the resignation of Susan Delean-Botkin, the previous District 5 board member.Howie will serve on the board until early December 2024, when a newly elected member is sworn in.After being sworn in by Talbot County Circuit Court Clerk Kathi Duvall at the work session on Monday, Howie took her seat at the table and the board went into a closed session.Before the board went into closed session, Board President Emily Jackson welcomed Howie to her new office."We're all excited that you're here," Jackson said."And we've got a lot of work to do, so roll up your sleeves." Howie is the curriculum supervisor of career and technical education for Dorchester County Public Schools as well as the interim principal at Mace's Lane Middle School.According to a press release from Talbot County Public Schools, the Talbot County native, who lives in Easton with her husband and children, has 21 years of experience in K-12 education.Howie has a bachelor of industrial engineering from the Georgia Institute of Technology and a master of arts in supervision and administration from the University of Phoenix. She is currently pursuing a doctorate in organizational leadership from the University of Maryland Eastern Shore, according to the press release.The Talbot County Education Association endorsed Howie for the appointment."We submit this recommendation without reservation and with our heartfelt belief that she is an ideal candidate who will serve our community well," Andrew Burke, TCEA president, said in a letter to the governor.

title: Making History - Students Work Towards National History Day Competition
author: Laura Tayman
content:
Making history - Students work towards National History Day competition

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 486
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE - When Queen Anne's County history teachers Thomas Hayman and Andy Anders first began recruiting students for National History Day years ago, there wasn't a lot of convincing students to participate."We knew we had to up our game," said Anders. "Now the Upper Shore region is second in the state for participation." National History Day is an event that encourages students to develop research, analysis, presentation, and social skills while working on a historical project. Open to students across the Shore, including Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot, working individually or in groups, Junior Division (grades six-eight) and Senior Division (grades nine-12) students select a topic related to an annual theme. Information on the competitive event is distributed to students by their history teachers.The 2024 NHD theme is "Turning Points in History." There are five different types of projects that students complete: documentaries, exhibits, performances, and websites that can be done as a group or individually or papers that may only be done individually.Research is key, so the two teachers partnered with the public libraries in the participating Upper Shore counties of Queen Anne's, Kent, Talbot, and Cecil."Schools have limited research options," said Hayman, "so we turned to the county libraries who have more resources." During the fall season, as students begin picking a theme and looking for information, the teachers make themselves available at libraries across the region on specific dates so that librarians and History Day staff can provide assistance with finding research options, accessing online databases, or browsing materials.Hayman said the students learn valuable skills "like how to analyze information, to make sure sources are reliable, and to form their own opinion." Last weekend, Hayman and Anders visited Queen Anne's Library on Kent Island. Next up is the Talbot County Free Library in Easton on Oct. 21 from 9 a.m. 1 p.m.; Queen Anne's County Library in Centreville from 9 a.m. 1 p.m. on Nov. 4; and the Learning Resource Center at Chesapeake College on Nov. 12 from 1 p.m. to 5 p.m.The actual contest is March 23, 2024, at Chesapeake College. Judges from the Upper-Shore community include teachers, professors, and museum staff. Students who place are then able to participate in the state finals on May 4 at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County.The hard work of Hayman and Anders has paid off. "We saw that at the beginning the winners were always from the western shore," said Anders."Now we send more students to the state event than everyone but Baltimore County." Hayman said the program helps make history more real and interesting to students."You don't usually have students thrilled to be in history class," said Hayman. "Students who participate sometimes find their true passion." 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
Thomas Hayman and Andy Anders, both history teachers at Centreville Middle School, visit Queen Anne's County Library Kent Island branch on their first stop helping students from the Upper Shore with their History Day project research.

content:
Washington College receives $54.7 Million from Hodson Trust - Guarantees $30k+ scholarships for students with a 3.3+ GPA

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 492
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - Washington College announced the largest gift in the College's 240-year history: a $54.7 million gift from The Hodson Trust to provide financial support for students. The Hodson gift will grow the College's scholarship endowment to approximately $170 million and its overall endowment to $325 million, strengthening the College's ability to make a college education more affordable to students from all backgrounds."This generous gift from The Hodson Trust is truly transformative for Washington College," said President Mike Sosulski. "Access to an outstanding educational experience is a pressing issue for many families today. The Trust's support of our students' financial needs expands our ability to ensure access to a wide range of potential students, particularly those who are first-generation or come from underserved communities." As a result of the Hodson gift, Washington College will guarantee a minimum scholarship of $30,000 per year ($120,000 over four years) to any incoming student with at least a 3.3 grade point average who applies by Dec. 1. Students may qualify for more aid based on their academic performance. The Hodson Trust Washington Scholars endowment, which provides full tuition, fees and the cost of room and board for students with significant financial need, will also benefit from this gift."We are excited to be able to offer this scholarship opportunity to deserving students," said Vice President for Enrollment Johnnie Johnson. "It will allow us to continue to grow the diversity of our campus community and enhance the intellectual environment of the College. These scholarship funds will help us recruit more of the best and brightest students to Washington College from Maryland, the mid-Atlantic region, and beyond." Support for financial aid opens new opportunities for students and their families who think an education at a private college is out of reach.Because private colleges like Washington provide significant student financial aid when compared to public universities, the cost of a private education becomes more affordable. For the current academic year, Washington College provided $40.6 million in total financial aid with the average student aid totaling $45,745, compared to the University of Maryland, whose published average student aid is $9,074.The gift is part of the dissolution of The Hodson Trust. Established in 1920 by Colonel Clarence Hodson, the Trust has been a longtime supporter of Washington College and its largest benefactor, having now donated more than $150 million to the College since 1935.For almost 90 years, The Hodson Trust has contributed to Washington College in a number of ways, including establishing or contributing to endowments that support student scholarships; undergraduate research and internship stipends; faculty chairs, salary enhancement, and professional development funds; and the College's signature academic centers. In addition, The Hodson Trust contributed to the construction of Hodson Hall, Hodson Boathouse, the John Toll Science Center, and the Lelia Hynson Boating Park.The Hodson family has a long and illustrious legacy at Washington College.Colonel Hodson, his daughter, Lelia Hodson Hynson, and granddaughter, Sally Hynson Hopkins, served on the Washington College Board of Visitors and Governors.

title: Chapel District Elementary Renovation Design Plans Move to State for Review
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Chapel District Elementary renovation design plans move to state for review

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 568
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Talbot County Board of Education approved the design development submission for the Chapel District Elementary School renovation and addition at a Board of Education meeting Wednesday evening.The design development plan needs to be submitted to the state for review by Nov. 1. TCPS Director of Operations Kevin Shafer said this submission is the next milestone in the design process.Before the board voted unanimously to submit the design development plan, Shafer and Adam McDonald, project manager and architect from design firm Hord Coplan Macht, gave a presentation to update the board on plans for the project, including the schedule and estimated project costs.McDonald explained that the project includes a full renovation of the existing building and 16,600 square feet of additions.Three total additions at different corners of the building will add additional learning space."The additions are also going to help us enhance the overall design of the building," McDonald said.Since the board's last update on project plans, McDonald said they have made changes to the addition on the north corner of the building to "work better with the existing utilities" during construction.A traffic pattern has been formalized, and a first submission has been made to the State Highway Administration to create an additional curb cut to separate the parent entry loop from the bus drop."To help alleviate some of the traffic concerns that come with a shared entrance," McDonald said.The design plans for outside also include an extension to the parking lot to provide more space for parents dropping off students.Inside the building, McDonald said that most spaces will remain in the same areas as they are pre-renovation.The main change, he said, is that the media center will move to the front of the building and the art classroom will take over where the current media center is.Currently, bidding for the project is expected to take place in April and May of 2024. Construction would begin in June of 2024 and is estimated to take about two years.The estimated cost of construction and site work is $25.18 million. State and county funding for this will come out of FY2025 and FY2026 budgets. With additional expenditures, for things like design costs, the project is expected to cost $29.97 million.Shafer said this estimated cost is $1 million less than the state projection for the project."So I feel like we're within where we want to be," he said, adding that this is still just a projection and the real numbers will come when they bid the project out.After the presentation, board members asked questions.Board Member Deborah Bridges asked about the plan for the school's roof."The slanted roofs really have me worried," she said, expressing concern about drainage.Shafer said the pitched roof is not near the courtyard."The architect will make sure that any kind of drainage that's coming off the roof, whether it's roof drain or exterior drain, is properly sized to accommodate that water shed," he said. 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Adam McDonald, project manager and architect from design firm Hord Coplan Macht, updates the Talbot County Board of Education on design plans for the Chapel District Elementary School renovation and addition project at a Board of Education meeting Oct. 18.

title: It's in the Family - Anna Howie Speaks on Joining Board of Education
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
It's in the family - Anna Howie speaks on joining Board of Education

 October 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 551
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Education is in Anna Howie's blood.Specifically, Talbot County education is in Anna Howie's blood.Her grandfather and mother taught in the district.Her mother was even her sixth grade language arts teacher at Easton Middle School.When Howie, the newest member of the Talbot County Board of Education, went to college, she wanted to be an engineer.However, a career in education just kept chasing her.In college, she became involved with something called 'The Algebra Project,' where she taught students algebra concepts.For a college internship, she worked with students at a middle school.At a college ministry meeting, Howie remembers the speaker saying, "someone in here, you're an engineering student.And you know God told you you're supposed to be a teacher.'" Although she graduated from the Georgia Institute of Technology in engineering, she unsurprisingly found teaching eventually. Her first job in education was teaching at a middle school.Now, Howie is the curriculum supervisor of career and technical education for Dorchester County Public Schools as well as the interim principal at Mace's Lane Middle School.Monday, she was sworn in to the Board of Education after being appointed to the District 5 seat by Gov. Wes Moore. The appointment comes after the resignation of Susan Delean-Botkin, the previous District 5 board member.W hen she learned of the appointment, Howie told her husband first. He was so excited he switched a flight he had for a conference so he could watch her get sworn in on Monday.Howie herself was excited and honored."A little scared at the same time, because this is a huge undertaking and it's extremely important," she said.Howie talked about the importance of being able to support students' social and emotional and mental health, especially after COVID-19."Schools are safe places for a lot of our students," she said. "If I'm hungry, if I'm angry, if I don't know where I'm going to go to sleep tonight, I can't learn." Social and emotional learning is one of the Board's priorities this school year. Its other priorities are increasing academic achievement and teacher retention."There are teacher shortages everywhere right now, and it's so important that we retain the teachers," she said."Because when you have to continually hire new teachers, there is that onboarding process and there is that learning curve." Joining the board, Howie is continuing her mother and grandfather's legacy in Talbot County Public Schools.When Howie was 18, her mother died from breast cancer. She remembers the funeral being "packed" with former students and teachers from the district."There are teachers in this school district that knew my mom when she was here and they come up to me all the time and they're like, 'Your mother would be so proud,'" Howie said, tearing up.With two meetings under her belt so far - a work session on Monday and a regular meeting on Wednesday - Howie is feeling welcomed by her fellow board members.She appreciates the organization of the meetings."Everything went very smooth," she said.Although she's been on the board for less than a week, Howie has already been thinking about whether she will run for the position when her seat is up next year. She doesn't have an answer yet, though."I have definitely, definitely put a lot of thought into that," she said. "This is such a wonderful opportunity." 
 
 Caption: ANNA HOWIE

title: For All Seasons Welcomes Mental Health Interns
author: Contributed
content: For All Seasons recently welcomed three interns, Meghan E. McPherson, Brianna Mench, and Kevin Nugent, who come from various clinical settings to participate in the internship program. Undergraduate and graduate schools utilize For All Seasons for students who need clinical experiences in social work to meet the requirements of their programs. These hands-on experiences are preparing the next generation of social workers. McPherson is currently the family services case manager and truancy reduction court program intern at the Maryland Judiciary in Cambridge and a care associate in health information management at PinnacleCare. She is pursuing her master's degree in social work at George Mason University and is a graduate of Washington College in Chestertown. Mench joined the For All Seasons Medical team as a preceptor, supervised by Kristen Gordy, RN, MSN, CRNP, psych nurse practitioner. Mench is working as a registered nurse with the Christiana Care Health System and is currently working towards becoming a psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioner while attending Walden University. Nugent was a psychiatric rehabilitation professional at Channel Marker in Cambridge before becoming a graduate student in the Counselor Education Program at the University of Maryland Eastern Shore in Princess Anne. He completed a bachelor of arts degree in psychology at St. Mary's College of Maryland. For All Seasons provides mental health and victim services to children, adults, and families across Maryland's Eastern Shore. Services are offered in both English and Spanish and include therapy, psychiatry, victim advocacy, 24-hour crisis hotlines, outreach, and community education. For information about For All Seasons and walk-in hours, contact 410-822-1018 or visit ForAllSeasonsInc.org.

title: STEM Festival Engages Youth in Science, Math and More
author: Eric Sylvia; Special to the Star Democrat
content:
STEM festival engages youth in science, math and more

 November 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Eric Sylvia; Special To The Star Democrat | Page: 10 | Section: News 
 
 488
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS - This past weekend, Chesapeake College in Wye Mills, hosted the sixth annual STEM Festival in the Eastern Shore Higher Education Center.What is STEM, you ask?It's the acronym for Science, Technology, Engineering and Math.The festival was open to youth of all ages, and admission was free. Sessions were offered for a myriad of STEM related topics, including 3D printing and the makerverse, Python coding, and lego robotics GeoCaching, a CDL simulator, a tour of the Health Professions laboratory and an Art and Sciences tour were also offered. The event has seen steady growth since its inception in 2017.Part of the Maryland STEM Festival 2023, sponsored by University of Maryland Extension, 4-H, and Family & Consumer Sciences, Navonne Owen, UME/4-H educator for Caroline County, heads up the event, along with a crew of dedicated educators from the Mid-Shore and the college.Owen estimates this year's attendance topped approximately 250 students and adults. She was happy to say, "Many of the attendees come year after year, especially the younger folks who have an interest in STEM related topics." "We hope to offer topics here to augment what students are exposed to in school, or topics which might ignite an interest - maybe prompting students to go out and discover more about a topic on their own," she said.When asked about the role Chesapeake College was playing in the event, Owen was quick to say "Chesapeake College has really grown a lot in recent years. It's a hidden diamond here on the Shore - a resource which is sometimes overlooked. There are so many options here now for local students, with cost effective options for completing various fields of study." Maryland 4-H has long been a champion of STEM education, offering comprehensive support to engage young people in these critical fields.The program's commitment to fostering STEM skills and interests is evident in a variety of initiatives and activities designed to inspire curiosity, innovation and lifelong learning.To this extent, 4-H offers a wealth of STEM-focused clubs and projects, providing youth with opportunities to explore their interests in subjects like robotics, computer programming, environmental science and more.These clubs allow for hands-on, experiential learning that goes beyond the classroom.4-H hosts STEM camps and workshops that immerse young participants in the world of STEM through engaging and interactive activities.These programs not only educate but also excite and encouraging youth to pursue further studies and careers in STEM.With the help of educators like Owen, 4-H organizes and supports various STEM competitions and events, such as science fairs, robotics challenges, and engineering contests. These competitions promote critical thinking, problem-solving, and teamwork.For more information on similar events or for the 2024 STEM Festival, contact the University of Maryland Extension for Caroline County 4-H Office at 410-479-4030 or by emailing Navonne Owen at nowen@umd.edu. 
 
 Caption: ERIC SYLVIA
 
Emory Woods examines a slide through a microscope while mom Stephanie and Vicki Burchfield of the Caroline County Public Library look on.

title: Elks Provide Veterans Day Assembly for Easton Elementary
content:
Elks provide Veterans Day assembly for Easton Elementary

 November 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 12 | Section: News 
 
 480
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Local veterans representing all branches of the military shared their personal experiences and perspectives with fifth grade students at Easton Elementary school on Wednesday, Nov. 8.Michael Feehley, who served in the Army, coordinated the event on behalf of the Easton Elks Veterans Affairs Office.He began by explaining that Veteran's Day is celebrated on Nov, 11, which was originally recognized as Armistice Day. The date is significant because fighting between the Allied countries and Germany ended on the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month in 1918, marking the end of World War I."Stop and think about this day, Veterans Day, celebrating all the service and all the sacrifice of the U.S. Military Veterans," Feehley said to the students. "Veterans sacrificed so that you and I have the freedoms we enjoy today." Each of the seven fifth-grade classes at the school provided one question for the veterans to answer.Brian S. asked "what advice would you give an individual who was considering entering the military?" Jasiah P. asked "what is the most positive thing that happened to you because you served in the armed forces?" "The military gave us the chance to do something we had never done or would never do, like go to the Philippines, or for me, to learn about C-4 and other demolitions, fly in planes and helicopters, or be on a ship." said Mike Detmer, a former Marine and member the Dorchester County Council."It also gives you a chance to grow close to people. When you go through training and hardship or danger with other people, just like when you're on a football or soccer team, you feel a closeness with them. I have brothers who I love a lot, but I feel extremely close to my Marine brothers." "When you have served in the military, you know that you've accomplished something," Detmer said, "and you are serving something much bigger than yourself.You can see how proud all of these gentlemen are about what they've done. But it's not as much pride in what they personally have done, as it is pride in what they have been a part of. That is why I would encourage you to think about it." At the end of the assembly, the students presented cards to the veterans, which will be delivered to patients in a Maryland VA hospital during the holidays."Students in fifth grade across Talbot County write letters to veterans as part of their fifth grade service learning project," said Jeff Bell, Easton Elementary fifth grade teacher. "It is only appropriate that we get those letters to veterans at this time of the year."

title: Board of Education to Create Special Education Committee
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Board of Education to create Special Education Committee

 November 17, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 317
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Talbot County Board of Education has created a new committee to address updating, modernizing and funding special education in Talbot County Public Schools.In a unanimous vote, the board directed Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi to lead the charge in the creation of this new Special Education Committee. Board President Emily Jackson introduced the motion at Board of Education meeting Wednesday."I would like to create a committee focused on special education," she said. "As we all know, looking at Blueprint, the way that we are doing our budget and our funding is going to change."The Blueprint for Maryland's Future is a statewide plan to increase public education funding, improve student outcomes and improve the quality of public education. Jackson said this change in the way the budget is done means that there would not be a lot of specific line items "directly applicable to special education" in the budget."Combine that with the fact that our special education population has been growing rapidly," Jackson said to explain why she sees a need for this committee.Jackson said she would like the committee to do a holistic deep dive into what TCPS is currently doing regarding special education as well as what they could be doing. She said she would like the committee to look into modernizing the district's practices and come up with a full proposal for modernizing and funding special education in the county."I think that we all have talked a lot about how we need to approach special ed," she said.Jackson said she would like this committee to spend the year gathering information and come back next year, before budget season, with a proposal that includes what it would cost to modernize special education programming and how the district could fund it. 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Talbot County Board of Education President Emily Jackson speaks about the need for a Special Education Committee at a Board of Education meeting Nov. 15.

 CENTREVILLE - The Queen Anne's County Library is excited to announce the first-anniversary celebration of its Mobile Library, an initiative dedicated to bringing the joy of reading and learning to communities in and around the county.The celebration took place Nov. 1, at Crumpton Park, where attendees gathered to commemorate this incredible year of community outreach and literacy.Tamar Sarnoff, representing the Maryland State Library, graced the event as a guest speaker, sharing insights on the importance of libraries and reading in building stronger communities.Her presence was a testament to the recognition of the Mobile Library program's achievements.Director of the Queen Anne's County Library, Janet Salazar was also present to share her thoughts and experiences with the crowd. She expressed her gratitude to the community for their continued support and highlighted the dedication of the library staff who have made the Mobile Library a resounding success.Library staff, children, and families, as well as community partners The Judy Center at Sudlersville and the Queen Anne's County Family Center, all attended the event, enjoying refreshments and giveaways. As the celebration marked one year of the Mobile Library's operation, it also provided an opportunity for attendees to explore the various services and resources the library offers, all within the convenience of the mobile unit.To stay updated on the Mobile Library's schedule and locations, please visit the Queen Anne's County Library website at www.qaclibrary.com/mobile library.The Queen Anne's County Library is committed to fostering a lifelong love of reading, learning, and community engagement.Through its various initiatives, including the Mobile Library, the library serves as a vital resource for residents, promoting education and literacy throughout the county.

title: Girl Scouts Care for Furry Friends
author: Tamara Forte; Special To The Kent County News Star Democrat
content:
Girl Scouts care for furry friends

 November 20, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tamara Forte; Special To The Kent County News Star Democrat | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - Excitement filled the Animal Care Shelter for Kent County in Chestertown on Nov. 11, as Claire Anderson-Schultz, Amelia Beach, Clara Gerber and Ayesha Tapia brought in lots of handmade supplies and needed items to the shelter. These four sixth graders earned their Bronze Award for Girl Scouts by setting their sights on helping the cats and dogs at the shelter.To earn their Bronze Awards, the girls from Troop 899 in Centreville had to complete 20 hours of service in a service project. Sharing a love for animals, it was easy to decide that the project would help animals in need. Claire's mom shared that Claire has been visiting animal shelters for years with her grandfather to spend time cuddling the animals after school.This past summer, the girls toured the facility to learn about what the shelter did and what it needed. From June to September, the girls worked independently and as a team to meet these needs. After reaching out and doing research, the girls learned the ACSKC had recently moved into a new building and had many needs.These needs included: a new cat tree, cat and dog toys, pet food and treats, new storage benches, and cleaning items. The girls explained the shelter had to throw out a beautiful, carpeted cat tree due to a sickness that had hit the shelter. The girls quickly began their mission to make a cat tree that was easy to clean and maintain.During these 20 hours or more of time, the girls strategized in meetings (in person and on Zoom) on how to meet these needs and then worked together to create and build the items needed. The cat tree was thoughtfully made, and with a little help from their parents, the girls found a plan that would use easy-to-clean PVC pipes. After making sure the pipes fit, they glued them together and painted them gold. The girls also made Velcro patches of fabric from reused clothing. "These fabric patches were made from my grandpa's old jackets and now they can be velcroed off and on for easy washing" explained Amelia.Shelter worker, Paige Tucker, said they currently have 109 dogs and cats at the animal shelter. Right now, there are 32 animals in need of homes. Allison Otadan, Shelter Media Coordinator, shared the shelter is "so grateful for the efforts of the girls" for the new cat trees and other pet items. She is excited for the new benches, as the current benches are all scratched up. At this shelter, there are special rooms for the animals to freely roam, but that also causes some of the items to get worn down and scratched. In addition to the cat tree and wooden benches, the girls sewed catnip toys, hand tied snuffle mats (where pet treats can be hidden and found), and collected lots of donations from their whole troop, grades kindergarten through fifth grade.If you would also like to help the shelter, they are currently in need of kitten food, cat food, dog food, and cat/dog treats. There is a complete Wish List on their website that includes the specific brands needed at https://acskc.org/ 
 
 Caption: TAMARA FORTE
 
The girls get to play with the cats that need homes at the shelter.
