title: Rotary Event Encourages Students to Explore Local Jobs, Careers
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Rotary event encourages students to explore local jobs, careers

 March 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 469
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Local Rotary Clubs welcomed high school students for a day of opportunities and exploration with the third annual Career Day at Chesapeake College on March 15.Understanding that not all students will go to college or join the military, the Centreville Rotary Club and the Rotary Club of Kent Island once again sponsored a career day at Chesapeake College hosting students from Queen Anne's County High, Kent Island High and Wye River Upper School to discover potential careers.
Event organizer Doug Storck of the Centreville Rotary Club welcomed the opportunity to partner with Chesapeake College and highlight the surrounding businesses that students may not have ever considered for employment opportunities. The day is always well received by students and organizations alike, he said.
Career coaches work with students throughout the year to identify those who would most benefit from the program, he said.
Storck was grateful for the collaboration and thanked the high school administration for leading the way for their students to be on the track to greatness.
"They are here because they care about the success of their students," he said.
Throughout the day of career discovery, students received one on one individual learning opportunities from professionals through mock interviews and financial guidance workshops.
Chesapeake College also presented information on what vocational classes can do for career growth and continual development.
A career fair with 30 local businesses welcomed students to discover hiring opportunities and highlighted skills through a multitude of interests available to them right in their own backyard.
Founder of local IT company Corsica Technologies, guest speaker Dale Walls shared what perseverance can mean for your own story of success.
Walls recounted his own rocky childhood after which he found structure and direction in the United States Marine Corps before going on to found Corsica Technologies.
Since stepping down as CEO, Walls has continued his impressive resume, running marathons, coaching youth football and raising a family.
Encouraging students to take charge of their lives, Walls noted it was perfectly okay not to know what you wanted to do with your life as a high schooler, as long as you were moving forward trying to identify the kind of person you wanted to be.
To do that, he reiterated the importance of setting goals with clarity, having courage and leading the way for future self-success.
"You are the one who is going to get you there," he said.
The day of career exploration is very important to the Rotary Club mindset of "Service Above Self," according to Kent Island chapter President Candi Cook.
The job fair helps students explore the local area for career opportunities in one convenient place and helps eliminate the misconception that students need to leave the area to find quality jobs.
"There are plenty of opportunities for successful post-high school careers that don't require a college degree and taking on tons of debt," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland Teachers Learn from Success in Literacy Labs
author: Matt Hubbard mhubbard@chespub.com
content:
Maryland teachers learn from success in literacy labs

 March 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Hubbard mhubbard@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 505
 Words 

 Read News Document

 After schools in Cecil County were identified as a top performer in student literacy growth, educators from across Maryland gathered there for a Literacy Learning Lab.The effort was hosted by Cecil County Public Schools.
The lab comes in the wake of the Maryland Department of Education identifying CCPS as third in the state for student growth on state reading and writing assessments.
The two-day Literacy Learning Lab took place at the Cecil County School of Technology where educators from a number of Maryland's 24 school districts learned about CCPS's methodologies for identifying and addressing students with additional literacy learning needs in grades four through eight.
According to school officials, these methodologies have led CCPS to not only create a system which helps all students, but they also yield results that show consistent improvement in student literacy performance — identified by the state — year over year.
"What we do is not different from the rest of the state, it is where Maryland State Department of Education wants us to be and CCPS is closer to the ideal so we are viewed as a model," said Rhonda Asplen, CCPS's Instructional Coordinator for Secondary English Language Arts Literacy.
The system CCPS uses to identify student needs is Bookworms — a program that provides teachers with resources to implement reading and writing courses.
Bookworms is used in conjunction with assessments to enable CCPS educators to accurately assess students and make data driven decisions when placing students into one of the three tiers of CCPS's multi-tier support system.
One tier is for students proficient in reading and writing skills. The second tier is for students who need additional support and the last tier is for students who struggle the most with meeting grade level literacy requirements.
CCPS works in collaboration with the Professional Development Center for Educators at the University of Delaware where officials continue to develop the multi-tier system to ensure CCPS continues to make data informed decisions when matching students with literacy learning resources.
"We want to continue the the work we are acknowledged for because our kids deserve it," said CCPS's Instructional Coordinator for Elementary English Language Arts, Sherry Eichinger-Wilson.
The work of both Eichinger-Wilson and Asplen have allowed CCPS to lead the state for meeting the requirements of the 2019 Ready to Read Act, the science-based program, Science of Reading, and the College and Career Readiness portion of Blueprint for Maryland's Future — a statewide funding initiative that aims to increase education quality and funding in Maryland.
"The focus is to make sure that what we offer in our program is aligned to the Science of Reading," Eichinger-Wilson said. "We have a vertical alignment from grades K-12 and we are continuing to evaluate the parts of our program to ensure that they are aligned and that we are meeting the needs of all of our students."
Cecil and Washington County are the only two counties in the state to be deemed as Literacy Learning Lab models for leveraging student support aligned with the Science of Reading to improve literacy outcomes for students in fourth through eighth grade.

title: Maryland’s Teacher Shortage: Will the Blueprint’s Plan for Better Pay, Training Do Enough?
author: Aidan Hughes and Daranee Balachandar Capital News Service
content:
Maryland’s teacher shortage: Will the Blueprint’s plan for better pay, training do enough?

 March 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AIDAN HUGHES and DARANEE BALACHANDAR Capital News Service | Section: Business 
 
 1505
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fifth-grade teacher Melissa Carpenter works a 10-hour day on average during the week, and her job sometimes requires her to put in hours on weekends, too."I feel like teaching is one of those jobs where we go to work to do more work — to do work after work," said Carpenter, who teaches at William B. Wade Elementary School in Waldorf, in Charles County.
Carpenter's long hours are far from unique among Maryland's educators, as the state and nation grapple with a teacher shortage.
The U.S. Department of Education keeps a Teacher Shortage Areas database — and it found that for the current school year, Maryland was short of teachers in 28 subjects, which the state defines as "areas of certification." That's up from 17 five years earlier.
Some teacher certification areas — such as English as a second language, health science and special education — are short on teachers from pre-K through the 12th grade.
The Blueprint for Maryland's Future — a landmark state law reforming public education — aims to fix that problem by "elevating the stature of the teaching profession" through higher pay, better training and stronger recruitment efforts.
However, experts and educators have mixed views about whether that will successfully address the root causes of the shortage.
"Money is a huge help, but it's not everything," said Simon Birenbaum, director of grading, assessment and scheduling at Baltimore City Public Schools. "Human capital is the biggest issue, and money can help with that problem, but recruiting, training and retaining high-quality teachers and staff has to be the primary focus. No amount of money can compensate for a lack of highly-skilled educators."
Documenting the shortageMaryland's teacher woes follow national trends. The National Center for Education Statistics reported 86% of U.S. K-12 public schools faced challenges in hiring teachers for the current school year.
Amid the shortage, the Blueprint calls for hiring an unspecified number of additional teachers to ease the workload of classroom veterans.
"You hear a lot about the teacher shortage — and how are we going to implement all these Blueprint programs, which require additional staffing, when we have a teacher shortage?" asked Addie Kaufman, executive director of the Maryland Association of Secondary School Principals.
Shortages stem, in part, from the fact that teachers are leaving the profession. In Prince George's County, 1,126 teachers resigned between July 2022 and July 2023 — up from 989 the previous year, The Washington Post reported. Meanwhile, 625 resigned in Montgomery County Public Schools, up from 576 a year earlier.
Dorchester County experienced the highest attrition rate in Maryland during the 2021-22 school year at 18%, according to a Department of Education report.
"I used to never have people just quit in the middle of the year," said Dorchester County Superintendent Dave Bromwell, who recently retired. "The pandemic told some people, you know what? If you're not happy, move on."
All those factors end up impacting teachers like Carpenter. She said her grade level saw an influx of students, with around 30 students in her own fifth grade class this year.
"Our class sizes are growing, and we don't have the support in place to help some of our struggling learners," she said.
'teaching isn't approved'Schools are suffering from a long-term decline in the number of people interested in becoming teachers.
That decline has been ongoing since the mid-'70s, "but it gets worse and worse and worse, year over year," said Mike Hansen, an education policy expert at the Brookings Institution.
According to the State Department of Education, 9,134 people were enrolled in teacher preparation programs in the state in 2012. That number plummeted by about half by 2017, but rose to 6,037 by 2020.
Why is teaching becoming less appealing as a career? Zid Mancenido, a lecturer at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, has been studying that issue.
"One of the major findings of my research has been that people are taught over time that teaching isn't a great career," he said in a 2022 interview on the school's website. "There are all these tiny interactions they have over their lifetime that give them this feeling that teaching isn't approved, that they should be aspiring to other careers that might be more prestigious or well-paid."
Amid the shortage, many schools hire less-credentialed "conditional" teachers — those who have not yet received their professional certifications. Maryland's issuance of conditional certificates more than doubled between 2018 to 2022, a state Department of Education report said.
In Charles County, where Carpenter works, 12.4% of all teachers held conditional certificates by 2021 — a rate only surpassed by Baltimore City (13.4%) and Prince George's County (14.3%).
Carpenter said experienced teachers are leaned on to help the conditional hires.
"Which would be fine if you had one or two teachers who needed that support. But we have a massive amount of teachers who are conditional right now," she said.
The Blueprint's pay bumpIn order to address the teacher shortage, the Blueprint provides a number of measures that lawmakers hope will encourage people to become teachers and ensure that existing ones don't leave for more lucrative out-of-state positions — or exit the profession altogether.
A key Blueprint initiative increases teacher pay to a minimum of $60,000 by 2026. In some counties, that means a nearly $15,000 pay bump for new teachers.
David Larner, chief human resource and professional development officer at the Howard County Public School System, said the pay raise will attract teachers from other states and build up Maryland's teacher workforce.
"If our salaries are higher than salaries in surrounding states … then candidates are more likely to come," Larner explained.
However, Hansen, of the Brookings Institution, expressed skepticism about the likely impact of the measure on the state's teacher shortage.
Hansen argued that rather than a universal rise in minimum salary levels, money should be targeted where it's needed the most — attracting teacher talent in high-need schools and specialized fields like STEM subjects and special education. He also highlighted research that suggests salary is just one of many factors that can lead to teacher attrition.
"I think we need to be paying teachers more — I don't think paying a $60,000 minimum wage is the way to do it," he said.
Boosting careers and diversityThe Blueprint also aims to improve teacher quality by encouraging educators to obtain additional training.
The plan provides for a salary increase of $10,000 for teachers who become National Board Certified, an advanced teaching credential that fewer than 6% of Maryland teachers held at the start of 2023, according to the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards. Teachers in high-need areas may see their annual salaries increase by up to $17,000 by becoming certified.
"We want to professionalize the career of teaching, and I think that is absolutely what we should be doing," said Stephanie Novak Pappas, principal of the Holabird Academy, an elementary and middle school in Baltimore.
However, Hansen questioned the Blueprint's emphasis on National Board certification.
"We don't have a lot of evidence that actually getting your NBC makes you a better teacher," Hansen said.
The Blueprint also calls on school districts to create a diverse workforce. The Accountability and Implementation Board — which oversees the Blueprint — will evaluate those efforts.
A diverse workforce has significant benefits, according to David Blazar, an education policy expert at the University of Maryland.
Blazar said that increasing the share of Black teachers has "exceptionally large impacts on students' short and long term outcomes," he said. "I'd say some of the largest impacts I've seen across all of the educational intervention literature."
But maximizing the benefits of a more diverse workforce will be complicated, Blazar said. Even if the state's teacher workforce came to match the demographics of its students, there would likely still be "clustering of Black teachers within certain districts, and within certain schools within districts," he said.
Hansen echoed those concerns, and said that teachers nationwide remain even more racially segregated than students. Rather than aiming to make the teachers within individual districts reflect the exact racial demographics as their students, he suggested that policymakers should "maximize exposure and access to a diverse set of teachers for every student" across different regions.
A work in progressBeyond the Blueprint, the General Assembly last year passed the Maryland Educator Shortage Reduction Act, which requires the state to set recruitment goals for teacher education programs, creates an alternative teacher prep program for early childhood educators and establishes a $20,000 yearly stipend for eligible student teachers.
Gov. Wes Moore, who proposed the legislation, said upon signing it that it is intended to place "world class teachers in every classroom."
Carpenter, the Charles County teacher, said future changes may be necessary, too.
"We will have new students next year, and they will [have] different needs. So we need to make sure that we are constantly evolving," she said.
Meanwhile, Sparkle Jefferson, an assistant principal at Flintstone Elementary School in Prince George's County, stressed that reinforcing the teacher workforce is key to the Blueprint's overall success.
"It lands in the hands of our educators, and if we don't have educators who are highly qualified or able to do the work, then the Blueprint work would never get accomplished," she said.
Local News Network Director Jerry Zremski contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Foundation of HOPE Leading Girls to Success
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Foundation of HOPE leading girls to success

 March 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 606
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Wednesday evening, Keasha Haythe, founder of the Foundation of HOPE, an after-school program for middle school girls on the Eastern Shore, led the program hosted at Easton Middle School's Library.Haythe introduced this week's guest speaker, John Englehart, assistant manager of human resources for Easton Utilities, to the cohort of girls.
During Englehart's presentation, Haythe stood in the back wearing a pink shirt and gray blazer. She smiled at the enjoyment that filled the room. Girls discussed and practiced the best ways to market themselves to achieve their career and education goals.
Haythe, an economic development veteran and certified economic developer, founded the Foundation of Helping Others Prosper and Excel. Its mission is to help young girls and women lead productive lives in their communities by providing cultural, social, spiritual and educational development.
The program serves sixth-grade girls attending middle school. This after-school program covers low self-esteem, bullying, social media, workforce development, economic and community development, financial literacy and more.
"We prepare them to be independent and self-sufficient as well as exposing them to opportunities, thought-provoking conversations and activities," Haythe said.
Haythe began the Foundation of HOPE over eight years ago. She said this program has been a community effort since the very beginning.
During the program's early days, Giuffrida's Pizza donated weekly food for the girls to snack on. From there, more and more businesses have assisted in the nutrition of the girls to make sure they are well prepared to learn.
Haythe said the success of this program would not have been possible without the generous support of volunteers, business partners, board members and donors.
During the pandemic, Haythe and her daughter worked together to create a curriculum for the program. The curriculum, divided into 16 weeks, covered healthy lifestyles, economic development, entrepreneurship and potential futures with education.
This week, representatives from Easton Utilities led a presentation by showing a clip from Englehart's favorite movie, "The Pursuit of Happiness." Through the film, Englehart showed the girls how to properly prepare themselves for the working world.
He said it was an honor to be invited to speak at the event and support such a commendable foundation. As a human resources professional, he is committed to fostering the growth and development of the next generation by equipping them with the skills and knowledge needed to pursue their goals.
"I hope it will inspire them to not only envision their future dream jobs but also understand the steps needed to achieve and excel in them," Englehart said. "Moments like these reaffirm my passion for HR and the pivotal role it plays in shaping the workforce of tomorrow."
His presentation included helping the girls create a career map to reach their goals, developing and practicing an elevator pitch for potential employers, and learning the best ways to write a resume by becoming "resume detectives" on practice resumes.
When Englehart finished his presentation, he passed out Easton Utilities swag bags before passing along a final message and gift.
He gave each girl his business card and told them that before they started applying for their first job, he would help them develop a resume and do practice interviews to prepare them for the workforce.
All the girls crowded around him as Haythe took a photo — big smiles on everyone's face. Haythe thanked Englehart for his time before cleaning the library with the assistance of the cohort of girls.
"This program allows me to use my passion for empowering women and girls through economic development strategies," Haythe said. "This after-school program is an alternative narrative from what they hear from peers and social media. They are setting career goals, and the Foundation of HOPE is here to help them achieve those goals." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Board of Education Member Donna DiGiacomo Resigns
author: Tom McCall
content:
Board of Education Member Donna DiGiacomo resigns

 March 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: News 
 
 547
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — After three years and four months in office, Caroline County Board of Education member Donna DiGiacomo has resigned, citing concerns following a back-and-forth between DiGiacomo and Superintendent Derek Simmons at the board's March 5 meeting.She emailed her resignation to the Maryland Superintendent of Education Monday.
"My problem on the board is I care about the students and I care about teachers," she said in an interview Monday afternoon. "I got a lot of pressure to make it look like we all agreed. But the thing that got me that I finally said I cannot in any way, shape or form be associated with was at the March 5 meeting."
"The superintendent called some employees minions. I was like 'did you just say minions? Mindless people who just do what you say?'" she said.
The exchange between Simmons and DiGiacomo, which can be viewed in the recorded meeting on the board's website, resulted from a conversation in which the superintendent discussed the district's upcoming switch from Apple laptops to Google Chrome ones.
He talks about how many people it took to get the computers ready for summer.
"For getting the devices ready for summer, we don't quite need quite the large numbers of minions, as the devices come in more ready to go out the door. So it helps us on that end as well," he said in the meeting.
DiGiacomo asks, "Minions?... I guess just the word kind of offends me… 'Minions' offends me. It did offend me."
Simmons said, "I didn't mean to offend you. I was thinking Minion movies."
Members of the board laughed.
She said, "A minion is a person that does what they, without thinking. That is all. It is derogatory."
Simmons responded, "Wasn't meant to be offensive, Mrs. DiGiacomo."
She said, "I don't think anyone would be appreciative of that," before the board returned to their initial discussion.
Simmons did not directly respond to a request for comment about the exchange, though the school district did issue a press release following DiGiacomo's resignation.
DiGiacomo's term was supposed to end Nov. 30. She came to the position after 20 years as a high school English teacher.
"The main statement I am trying to make by resigning eight months early is I do not want anyone to think that I condone what is going on," she said.
"... I am not trying to start trouble. I just want people to know that I really did try my best," she said. "But I can't be a part of something that doesn't respect the employees. Calling people minions is not respectful. I don't want people to think I quit. It is a moral thing for me."
"I think the people who voted for me have the right to know why I made that decision," she said.
The Board of Education's statement on the resignation thanks DiGiacomo for her time on the board.
In it, Board President Richard Barton stated, "On behalf of the Caroline County Board of Education, we thank Mrs. DiGiacomo for the time she spent on the board and appreciate her service to the staff and students of Caroline County Public Schools."
The board also said, "regarding the vacancy this resignation creates, the board will discuss options as they pertain to Maryland law with the board attorney at their next meeting."
The next meeting is on April 2 at 6 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dorchester County Awards Teacher of the Year to Katelyn Robinson
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Dorchester County awards Teacher of the Year to Katelyn Robinson

 March 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 350
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EAST NEW MARKET — On Tuesday evening, Katelyn Robinson, Maple Elementary School teacher, screamed with pure joy as she was named Teacher of the Year by Dorchester County Public Schools administrators.Around her, peers, friends and family stood and cheered in celebration of her accomplishment.
Robinson's second-grade teacher, Barbara Mills, provided kind words through a prerecorded video.
"I knew then that Katelyn was just a bright ray of sunshine," Mills said. "She understood what we were trying to do in class was to make it a place that we wanted to come to every day, where we can learn and everybody can be themselves … I can't think of anybody that would be more deserving than you."
Along with naming a recipient for Teacher of the Year, Dorchester County Public Schools named Jordan Lewis, a teacher at Choptank Elementary School, and Haley Wright, a teacher at Maple Elementary School, winners of the First Class Teacher of the Year award, which recognizes teachers in their first year of teaching.
This was the first time in awards history that two finalists were awarded First Class Teacher of the Year.
Lewis was described as sweet, caring and helpful by her students and former teacher. Wright was described as an excellent, talented and helpful teacher by her students.
The evening was filled with excitement as members of the education community dressed up, ate a decadent dinner and were recognized for their work throughout the year.
Plenty of tears were shed as finalists for the Teacher of the Year and First-Class Teacher of the Year Awards were honored with acknowledgements from their students, mentors and former teachers that had inspired them.
Gavin Parker, principal of Choptank Elementary School, said he enjoyed the time he got to spend at the event.
"It's nice to recognize all the hard work that happens in the buildings," Parker said. "We go through a lot. We overcome a lot of challenges. But it's always nice to take some time in the spring to make sure we recognize not only the veteran teachers but the new teachers as well. And all the hard work that they do throughout the year." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: WKHS Celebrates 50 Years of Student Public Radio
author: Lisa J. Gotto Special to the Kent County News
content:
WKHS celebrates 50 years of student public radio

 March 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Kent County News | Section: News 
 
 1312
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WORTON — It's just a normal early morning at 90.5 WKHS when we arrive to the radio station at Kent County High School. As the school's first of four instructional periods commences, so does the first student disc jockey take her place at the microphone in the facility's live on-air studio.Over the next few hours, she'll not only intro and recap songs from an extensive, vetted playlist, but she'll talk to the station's loyal listeners about what's going on at school, in the county and the greater world. The delivery is smooth and polished, and left to the reliability of just one's own ears, you'd never know that this DJ isn't even 18 years old yet.
Today, senior Emma Morris is joined by senior Averie Hitzges, and the subject of conversation for a bit is a reminder that it is the last day of the station's spring fundraising drive. As is the case with any enterprise of this nature, donations are not only welcomed, but they're vital.
To date, those donations have been coming in from loyal listeners and community partners for 50 years — an amazing feat, especially when you consider that the young people who are populating the air waves with their voices did not grow up listening to traditional radio at all.
So in a social culture where it's more likely you're going to listen to a podcast downloaded to your phone during drive-time than a local radio station, how does this eight-studio, 17,500-watt local station remain relevant and a vital part of the high school's Career and Technical Education program?
An essential part of that success can be attributed to the current station manager, Chris Singleton. At the helm since 2008, Singleton was quick to point out that he is just one of a long line of integral station managers WKHS has had the good fortune to work with since that first day in 1974 when they went on-air with their format of educational and public affairs-type programming, as well as a wide-ranging playlist that began mid-morning on the March 28.
Appropriately enough, that first tune played was Elton John's signature hit, "Rocket Man," relayed Singleton, who obviously understands the importance of a mission and knowing when it's time to come back down to Earth.
With every school year, he said, he does contend with a student body that might not understand the connection and importance of continuing the legacy of the radio station at the school.
"It's like having a kid attend culinary school, when they've never even tasted food," he analogized.
Obviously, his plan for getting kids invested is working, as when the bell rings the senior DJs are replaced with equally fresh-faced junior class DJs — and the next portion of the school-day broadcast continues.
Senior Lizzy Watkins, 18, is just one of the students who became invested in the program for the 2023-2024 school year. She was at the station that morning conducting a bunch of tasks; everything from providing the morning's weather forecast to working on an on-going project that flexes her creative muscles.
Watkins aspires to a career in graphic design and gets to try her hand, and brain, at projects geared to such things as part of her role at the station.
"So for me, because I'm going into graphic design and marketing, being here allows me to start to feel what it is that graphic designers do when they're being handed something from a customer who asks, 'Hey, can you do this?'"
Watkins said the process of being able to create and talk through the collaborative process is giving her valuable real-life experience and has helped build her self-confidence.
For junior, Jonah Elburn, 16, it's the sense of professionalism that he feels when enters the station each day.
"This is something that I love more than anything. It feels, and everyone says it, not like you're in high school, but you're in a working environment," Elburn said. "There's a professionalism that at least the vast majority of people that step through these doors have, the way everything has grown [here] as a business. This is not just another high school class. This is a business."
Soon after, the "business-of-broadcasting" tour took us down a hall where the stacks of LPs and 45s used to be kept for easy access to the then two-studio station. Things have changed quite a bit since then, but not until 2018 did the station have its most comprehensive infrastructure upgrade, Singleton said.
The $160,000 station remodel included the addition of six new studios, including an enlarged, on-air studio, a dedicated newsroom, production studios and various equipment upgrades.
Singleton said they were finally able to address the problem of flimsy, particle-board type walls replacing them with structures that were more acoustically sound, and they were able to incorporate an adjacent classroom into their footprint by taking down a wall. This classroom now houses the station's carefully curated collection of nostalgic radio receivers, audio consoles and other equipment from days gone by that provide a visual history of radio broadcasting.
On hand, and actually pitching in for every upgrade, was Singleton and another essential member of the staff, Ken Collins. Collins thoroughly enjoys his part-time role in sales and fundraising for the station, and shares many of Singleton's memories of what it took to get the station to the point where it could be celebrating its 50th year in student public radio.
Collins' role, said Singleton, was part of a larger initiative dating back to 2013, when Kent County Schools welcomed a new administrator, Dr. Karen Couch. It was at that time, said Singleton, that he was most concerned about the future of the broadcasting program at the high school. There had already been substantial talk about whether or not the station would remain a viable part of the curriculum.
Singleton was certainly hoping that a new administration didn't signal the demise of one of the school's oldest programs. The advent of new technologies and ways of thinking could easily have derailed the plans he already had for what was needed next to keep it going.
Fortunately, after much in-depth conversation with the superintendent, Singleton learned that he could count on her to support his efforts to keep the program going. Couch, who retires this year, would champion the program again by allowing the station to hire for the part-time fundraising position that Collins would eventually fill.
"This would not have happened if we didn't have superintendent-level support," Singleton said. "So, we're hopeful that the incoming superintendent could be just as passionate and just as enthusiastic. I think, hopefully coming off of this 50th anniversary wave and with all the positive community dynamics, the new superintendent will pick up on that and go, 'Yeah, this is something we probably need to keep going.' And until they give me a reason not to, we'll just keep on going."
The next big thing, said Singleton, is the biggest thing of all. Literally. The station's tower, actually the oldest piece of infrastructure being erected in 1973, now needs to be replaced. This is Singleton's newest mission.
"I would much rather be able to replace that proactively, than the alternative of just having it come down on its own."
And so, the station's story is still being written and the program continues to inspire the students who reach out to embrace it.
"For whom we are and what we have, I am pretty happy for where we are," said Singleton.
An official station birthday celebration will be held on Saturday, May 4, from 1 to 5 p.m. at Red Acres Farm in Worton. The event called Tune Fest will feature live music from five area bands: Sombarkin', Justin Singleton, Phillip Dutton & the Alligators, The Good Stuff and The Blake Thompson Band. Festival goers also will enjoy a menu of offerings from local food trucks and connecting with many of the station's staff members, past and present. Tickets are $25 per person. For more information, visit wkhsradio.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a high school radio station that is part of the school's Career and Technical Education program, highlighting student learning, curriculum support, and school administration involvement, making Education the most fitting category.

Emma Morris — Student, Kent County High School
Averie Hitzges — Student, Kent County High School
Lizzy Watkins — Student, Kent County High School
Jonah Elburn — Student, Kent County High School
Ken Collins — Sales and Fundraising, WKHS

title: Students Embrace History Once Again in Regional Competition
author: Eric Sylvia Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Students embrace history once again in regional competition

 March 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ERIC SYLVIA Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 578
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Nearly 200 local middle and high school students participated in the annual regional history day event held once again at Chesapeake College.Organized by Queen Anne's County Public Schools teacher Thomas Hayman, the March 23 event welcomed 30 area teachers and a troupe of volunteers who hosted six schools. Schools participating in this year's event represented Caroline, Cecil, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties. This year's theme was Turning Points in History.
Projects entered this year covered a wide range of topics, as students used a lot of creativity to make their cases.
Topics covered included pop-culture history, topics related to women's rights and the Great Depression, as well as improvement in technology and even the advent of fast-food and its impact on history.
The students work hard to get to this level of the competition by first competing at the local level within their home school. The next step is this regional event, with the winners invited to participate in the Maryland statewide competition.
At each level, judges provide feedback the students can use to improve their project for the next competition.
Hayman says the event started as an after-school program he became involved in when he first began his teaching career. As the number of students grew, and the national event began to take shape, local programs also grew.
Eastern Shore counties previously had individual county-level events, but they decided to form a coalition in 2017 in order to be more competitive at the state level.
The plan worked — Hayman reports in the five years the Upper Shore Regional event has been held, two area students have gone on to compete in the national event.
The regional event sends the top two from each category, from each county to the state event. The state only sends the top two in each category to the national event.
The event is offered in conjunction with National History Day and Maryland Humanities, and it is intended to help foster a love of history in the students who participate. Students submit projects in five categories: Paper (Individual), Website, Performance, Documentary and Exhibit.
They can submit content as either individuals or in groups of up to five students. There are now three divisions — a youth division for students in the fifth grade, the Junior Division for students of grades six to eight and the Senior Division for students grades nine to 12.
The regional event is funded by Maryland Humanities, which is also responsible for hosting the state event. Hayman said Chesapeake College also played a vital role, donating the space for the exhibits, presentations and performances free of charge — a location providing a more central location than previous venues. Food trucks rounded out the day's festivities for the students.
These students make a choice to put in extra hours to work on their projects outside of their normal school work, Hayman said. Many of the students who participate, come back multiple years to compete, each year improving their research and presentation skills. The amount of effort and dedication these projects require rivals similar science contests.
While not all participants went home with an award, the judges handed out over 50 awards to the students, including: Sports History Award, Heritage Award, Natural History Award, Military History Award, Contemporary World History Award, African American History Award, Colonial History Award, Equality in History Award, Medical History Award, and the Chesapeake Bay/Maritime Award. First, second and third place finishes as well as Best in Region awards were also given in each category. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a regional history competition organized for middle and high school students, highlighting school involvement, teachers, and student learning—clearly an education‐focused event.

title: DCPS Enters Agreement to Increase Professional Development for Administration
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
DCPS enters agreement to increase professional development for adminstration

 April 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 327
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Board of Education approved a purchasing agreement at a board meeting March 25 that will bring coaching and professional development support for district administrators.Specifically, the agreement states that Creative Leadership Solutions will hold a kick-off event in the summer and offer seven on-site professional learning sessions and eight on-site coaching days, according to meeting documents.
Dorchester County Public Schools will use Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief III funding to pay the nearly $138,000 for three years of the organization's services.
At the board meeting, Interim Superintendent Jymil Thompson said the DCPS executive team expects all its principals to become "great instructional leaders," but not enough professional development has been provided to those leaders.
Thompson said Creative Leadership Solutions will provide instructional leadership and help the district improve its tier one instruction over a three-year period. In education, tier one instruction is instruction given to the entire classroom.
"Right now we see the deficit across the district as it relates to tier one instruction," Thompson said. "And this is the way that we think we're going to improve our tier one instruction, by providing professional development to our leadership."
Thompson said the district has to put its money where its mouth is.
"We're trying to shift our mindset to put instruction first," he said. "And we believe that this is the way to do it: By training our staff and training our leadership to be instructional leaders."
Thompson said Creative Leadership Solutions will cater their services to what the district needs.
At a Cambridge City Council meeting later that day, Thompson gave a presentation to the council on the overall picture of the school system where he talked about the need for improving tier one instruction. He spoke about the importance of having a school calendar that allows the district to provide time for professional development.
"We can't expect teachers to be good at their craft if we're not continuously training them to be better at their craft," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a school board's agreement to fund professional development for district administrators, which directly relates to education policy and administration.

key_people: Jymil Thompson — Interim Superintendent, Dorchester County Public Schools

title: Raskin Speech at University of Maryland Disrupted by Protesters
author: Yesenia Montenegro Capital News Service
content:
Raskin speech at University of Maryland disrupted by protesters

 April 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Yesenia Montenegro Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 518
 Words 

 Read News Document

 COLLEGE PARK — Maryland Rep. Jamie Raskin's planned lecture on democracy Thursday at the University of Maryland instead turned into a lively discussion on the Israel-Hamas conflict.Raskin was invited to give the Irving and Renee Milchberg Endowed Lecture and his intended subject was "Democracy, Autocracy and the Threat to Reason in the 21st Century."
"Progress in history requires not just reasoning, which is certainly necessary, but it's not sufficient, because it also requires the addition of the pro-social emotions, as the psychologists call it, of solidarity, empathy, love and the political virtues of justice and equality and freedom," Raskin said at the start of his speech.
His remarks were interrupted just a few minutes later by pro-Palestinian protesters shouting that Raskin is was "complicit in genocide." In response, Raskin said that he wished the protesters had engaged in a conversation with him, rather than "heckling."
Raskin emphasized that he has taken a strong position on returning the hostages held by Hamas, has advocated a military ceasefire, and has championed a two-state solution. As he attempted to continue his lecture, protesters continued interrupting and shouting. Various protesters questioned Raskin's actions since the Hamas-led attack on Israel on Oct. 7.
"We need a new peace movement too, if you are the representatives of it," Raskin said. "Because you're not engaging in real dialogue with people and you're not convincing anybody."
Protesters supporting Israel and those backing Palestine from both sides continued heckling and arguing with each other, making it impossible for Raskin to continue. He then abandoned the speech and said he was open to taking questions from the audience, leading to more discourse among protesters.
"It's very tough to solve problems in the Middle East here at the University of Maryland in the physics department," Raskin said.
Darryll Pines, the president of the university, later stepped in and terminated the lecture early.
"He came here to speak about where our democracy is going in our country," Pines told Capital News Service. "What you saw play out actually was democracy and free speech and academic freedom. From our perspective as a university, there are the difficult conversations that we should be having."
Pines added that he wished, however, that the protesters had been more civil. He also praised Raskin's patience and empathy when responding to the protesters' comments and questions.
"I wanted to make a plea for constitutional patriotism in defense of democracy and freedom around the world," Raskin told CNS about his original speech. "Their sentiments were perfectly consistent with a lot of what I had to say."
"I'm not really opposed to heckling," the congressman added. "But it seems like heckling today is all about drowning out the speaker, and that's totally antithetical to the spirit of free expression."
Howard Milchberg, University of Maryland professor of physics and electrical and computer engineering, along with his wife Rena Milchberg and their three children, started the lecture in 2019. It celebrates the memory of Howard Milchberg's late parents, who survived the Holocaust.
"It didn't go as planned, but it maybe turned out better than normal," Howard Milchberg told CNS. "It was an actual exercise of democracy rather than a story about democracy." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a university lecture and campus protest, making it primarily about an educational institution and academic discourse.

Darryll Pines — President, University of Maryland
Howard Milchberg — Professor of Physics and Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Maryland

title: Megan Borga is Teacher of the Year
author: Staff Writer
content:
Megan Borga is teacher of the year

 April 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 169
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fifth grade teacher at Kennard Elementary School, Megan Borga was recently named the 2024 Queen Anne's County Public Schools' Teacher of the Year."Megan Borga exemplifies every characteristic of a master teacher," Superintendent Dr. Patricia Saelens shared. "She builds student voice and autonomy. Her impact on students is immeasurable. We are beyond excited for her to represent QACPS as the 2024 Teacher of the Year."
Borga was surprised to be named during the annual awards gala held in March. "I am so honored and humbled to be chosen as the 2024 QACPS Teacher of the Year," she said. "Thank you to my family, friends, coworkers, principal, and so many QACPS staff members who have supported me on this journey. Thank you to the selection committee for bestowing me with this honor and the TOY committee for the hard work they put into this program."
Borga said she looks forward to representing the exceptional teachers of Queen Anne's County over the next year alongside the other teachers of the year in Maryland.

title: Talibah Chikwendu Appointed to Dorchester Board of Education
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Talibah Chikwendu appointed to Dorchester Board of Education

 April 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 293
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Cambridge — Talibah Chikwendu has been appointed by the Dorchester County Council to fill the open District 2 Dorchester County Board of Education seat.A graduate of Dorchester County Public Schools, Chikwendu said she has been involved with DCPS in some capacity her entire life. She became a school librarian 10 years ago and has served as a high school teacher for the past five years. She said she applied for the vacant seat because she saw it as an opportunity to continue to serve the school system.
"It is important, with a lot of the things that are coming up for Dorchester County Public Schools, that District 2 has a voice in making those decisions," she said. "Because, by and large, most of the school children in the county are in this district."
In a press release, the County Council said it believes the board will benefit from Chikwendu's institutional knowledge from working in the district.
Chikwendu was appointed to fill the rest of Theresa Stafford's term, which ends in 2026. Stafford, who was elected to the Board of Education in 2022, passed away in mid-December after battling cancer for several years.
Chikwendu said her first order of business as a board member is to figure out exactly where the district is right now.
"I mean at this point in the year, we are in the middle of budget season, we are about to end the school year," she said. "At this point, it's a function of acclimating myself to just what is happening and where I'm needed."
Chikwendu said she wants to be of service to the community. She said she doesn't do things without a reason and knows how to be transparent.
"I'm hoping I can use those things to bring value to my community," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the appointment of a new member to the Dorchester County Board of Education, focusing on school governance and educational issues, making Education the most relevant category.

key_people: Talibah Chikwendu — Member, Dorchester County Board of Education
Theresa Stafford — Former Member, Dorchester County Board of Education

title: Country School Students Experience Solar Eclipse
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Country School students experience solar eclipse

 April 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Eclipse 
 
 316
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Monday, teachers at the Country School gathered their students outside to witness a partial glimpse of a total solar eclipse.The total solar eclipse, a rare celestial event moving across the United States, will be the last visible over the continental U.S. for another 20 years. Though the state of Maryland wasn't on the path of totality, the moon blocked out nearly 90 percent of the sun at about 3:20 p.m. Monday over the Country School.
Teachers prepared for the eclipse by teaching students about eclipse viewing safety and the science behind an eclipse.
A solar eclipse occurs when the moon passes between Earth and the sun, thereby obscuring the view of the sun from a small part of Earth, totally or partially.
Jean Waller Brune, acting head of school at The Country School, said preparing for the solar eclipse was wonderful.
"It's amazing to be here and help our students understand what a solar eclipse is and how to look at it safely," Brune said. "They've all been little scientists out here, and to do it together in community as a school is just a thrill."
In science classrooms, students labeled on worksheets the eclipse process while watching a NASA live stream of the celestial event.
As the eclipse neared, students sat outside eagerly watching the sun through their brightly decorated eclipse masks made from colored paper plates and certified eclipse glasses.
When the eclipse finally reached a moment of near totality, teachers and students alike watched in excitement as the sky darkened and the moon slowly covered the sun.
Ann Hansen, pre-k teacher's assistant, said it meant a lot to her to share this moment with her students.
"They will hopefully remember this for a long time," Hansen said. "It makes me so happy that we can do something like this at our school. Big events like this are just so important. It means a lot to all of us." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'I am speechless:' TCPS awards teacher, support staff of the year
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
'I am speechless:' TCPS awards teacher, support staff of the year

 April 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — When Rosario Steele stepped up to the podium at the Easton Elks Lodge after being awarded Talbot County Public Schools Support Staff of the Year, she said she was speechless."It has been an honor to work at the high school for the past six years," she later said to the crowd. "I love my students."
At the Talbot Stars celebration Thursday evening, Steele, an instructional assistant for English as a second language students at Easton High School, and Jeremy Hillyard, a Spanish and English as a second language math teacher at EHS, were presented the district's 2024-2025 Support Staff of the Year and Teacher of the Year honors, respectively.
Standing at the podium, Hillyard thanked everyone that supports him. He said he sees his students and coworkers as his family.
"I told my whole table, I said, 'I live down here. I don't have family down here. I don't have any children. And my students are my family, and my coworkers and my friends are my family,'" he said.
Hillyard has taught at EHS since 2010. He is currently working to create a mentorship program for Hispanic students to support their success.
EHS Principal Sherry Spurry said Hillyard "branched out from the foreign language department" this year to teach algebra after recognizing a need for support.
"This is just one example of Mr. Hillyard's willingness to support student success regardless of the extra responsibilities or work it entails for him," Spurry said.
Steele has worked at EHS since 2018. EHS School Manager Toni Hall said Steele works "extremely hard" to provide support to students in math through translating, tutoring and making sure students understand the concepts. Hall said one of the greatest challenges English as a second language teachers face is having new students enter the program throughout the year.
"Ms. Steele is invaluable in helping these students prepare to move into algebra, a critical step in their educational journey," Hall said. "She always greets new students with a smile, making them feel welcome and comfortable, and helping them learn an unfamiliar concept."
Regina Coleman, school security officer at Easton Middle School, and Chanae Neal, an instructional assistant for special education at Easton Elementary School, were also finalists for the Support Staff of the Year title.
Lutisia Blessing, a pre-K teacher at White Marsh Elementary School, and Marissa Carter, a third-grade math teacher at St. Michaels Elementary School, were the finalists for the Teacher of the Year title.
Hillyard congratulated his fellow finalists in his speech.
"I emailed them last weekend. I said, 'I wish there could be three teachers of the year instead of one,'" he said. "It's such an honor to stand in the middle of two other amazing educators, and I'm so glad I work with you." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Chesapeake College Shapes Eastern Shore's Future
author: Clifford P. Coppersmith
content:
Chesapeake College shapes Eastern Shore's future

 April 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CLIFFORD P. COPPERSMITH | Section: Columns 
 
 750
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The new Chesapeake College brand, launched this academic year, highlights our role in preparing our students for "what's next." Our students choose their own goals — whether that is transfer to a bachelor's degree program or entry into a career — but our job is to help them acquire the relevant skills, knowledge and experiences to be successful.This role is at the heart of what our faculty, staff, and administrators do each day. We love to see our students succeed and move on to what's next in their lives. These individual successes echo throughout our community on the Eastern Shore, bolstering a vibrant economic cycle that benefits everyone in our service area.
Our efforts yield tangible results in our community. When we empower individuals with the skills they need to succeed, we are not only transforming lives but also strengthening our local economy. A skilled workforce attracts businesses, drives innovation, and fosters economic growth. Chesapeake College is proud to be a catalyst for positive change in our community, creating pathways to prosperity for all.
Our collaborative endeavors with partners in K-12 education, four-year institutions, local businesses, and economic leaders are crucial. This year we hosted nearly 150 of these partners at our Program Advisory Committee mixer — our largest to date. Together, we create curricula that resonate with real-world demands, ensuring both our credit and noncredit programs offer engaging and pertinent learning experiences. This collaboration is vital as we align our educational offerings with the needs of the workforce and the expectations of our community.
The influence of Chesapeake College graduates is unmistakable across various sectors. Once again, our nursing program boasted a 100% pass rate on the National Council of Licensure Examination for Registered Nurses. As a result of partnership with our public schools, local educators are taking classes to become certified teachers, and others are earning a childcare development associate certificate, helping to fill critical gaps for early childhood education. From health care to education, construction trades to computer science, our alumni are integral to the local workforce.
We recognize that not every great career requires the traditional college path. Careers in the skilled trades can be lucrative and rewarding for students, developing a broad variety of talents as well as skills in problem-solving, customer service, and communication.
This year, responding to the needs of local employers, Chesapeake expanded our trades offerings and launched a new advanced manufacturing program. We now have students learning the latest skills with hands-on experience using 3D printers, CNC machines, and robotics, preparing them for the high-tech jobs of tomorrow. Additionally, we continue to expand existing offerings in construction, HVAC, welding and marine services.
Our enrollment is up 9.5% this year, continuing the growth we celebrated last year. This increase is a testament to the relevance and appeal of our programs — as well as to the impact of Maryland Blueprint for Education legislation, which expands opportunities for dual enrolled high school students. It prompts us to consider sustainable strategies for addressing the accompanying challenges, including funding and tuition adjustments, to ensure that our growth remains inclusive.
We continue doing our work as effectively and efficiently as possible, stewarding the critical resources provided by our state, our five support counties, and our students. As we all know, resources are tight and the state of Maryland faces challenges in funding higher education. We appreciate the support we receive from all of our funding authorities and will continue to be responsible stewards as we make every effort to serve our students and our regional community to the best of our ability.
As we look to the future, it's essential to recognize the challenges ahead. Access to education remains a pressing issue, with many individuals facing barriers such as financial constraints, lack of transportation, or childcare responsibilities. Addressing these challenges requires a collective effort from policymakers, community leaders, and educational institutions like Chesapeake College. We must work together to ensure that everyone has equal access to the opportunities afforded by education.
At Chesapeake College, we are dedicated to fostering the skills that will drive the future, preparing our students to face tomorrow's challenges with confidence and competence. Together, we are setting the stage for a thriving, prosperous future on the Eastern Shore.
As we continue to cultivate optimism through our actions and initiatives, I invite you to share in the vision of a promising future here at Chesapeake College — a treasure of the Eastern Shore, steadfast in its mission to empower individuals and enrich our community.
Clifford P. Coppersmith is the president of Chesapeake College. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Chesapeake College's programs, student outcomes, and its role in preparing a skilled workforce, which aligns primarily with the Education topic.

title: Beyond Words Brings Creative and Innovative Opportunities to the Shore
author: Tamara Forte Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Beyond Words brings creative and innovative opportunities to the Shore

 April 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 887
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — As a special education teacher and a parent to a dyslexic child, Lindsey Parte has lived through the struggles and tears of traditional education and understands firsthand the challenges that affect all types of learners.Parte has focused her 18-year teaching career on teaching struggling learners how to read. Working with students in kindergarten through high school, she is a structured literacy dyslexia specialist and certified in Orton Gillingham. Parte's mission is to increase educational resources for not only her local community — the children of the Eastern Shore — but for all children no matter where they live.
This is where Beyond Words Tutoring was born.
Beyond Words Tutoring is a new educational business, located at The Edge Area on 325 Log Canoe Circle in Stevensville. It offers four innovative services: a hybrid homeschooling program, virtual dyslexia tutoring, academic summer camps, and non-attorney special education advocate services.
This licensed, part-time hybrid homeschooling program is creative and flexible and welcomes students ages 6 to 11.
Parte explains the program "supports families who want to homeschool, but cannot commit to it full-time. It's the opportunity to do school and life with other families. To teach them in creative and innovative ways. It's child-led learning."
The program is three days a week Monday, Tuesday and Thursday from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. and will operate from Sept. 9 to May 15, 2025. The program allows for longer holiday breaks and does not follow the typical school calendar. Currently, there are 11 available spots with a small "class" size to allow for small group 1:1 attention.
Beyond Words Hybrid Homeschooling Program is a microschool that is open to all learners, not just dyslexic learners. This educational alternative aims at reducing student wait time, enriching past a set of grade-level expectations, going beyond a fixed curriculum and meeting the individual's needs.
A microschool is a non-traditional educational setting where students are learning side-by-side with learners of various ages and abilities. Think of it like a one room schoolhouse, Parte explains.
Microschools have become increasingly popular as families are desiring more personalized and engaging learning for their children. The students enrolled at Beyond Words Hybrid Homeschool Program are considered homeschooled students which allows parents to have more involvement in their child's education. This also means that parents are the ones responsible to meet the compulsory attendance laws under COMAR.
The focus of the homeschool group is math and reading. Parte said a lot of families who want to homeschool do not want to focus on being the only one teaching their child to read. She said, "for many reasons families do not want to focus on teaching reading. It may not be in their wheelhouse, or they don't feel comfortable. So, for me to take (the reading and math) off (the parents') plate" helps in many ways.
Besides math and reading, the hybrid homeschool program also includes: nature, STEAM/Science Maker Space activities, arts and crafts, and kindness activities. Since the classroom location backs right up to Terrapin Nature Park, weekly activities may include nature sketching, hiking, going on adventures, forest bathing (meditative walks), community service projects and compassion circles.
Parte said she is "huge into the mental health aspect and teaching the kids self-regulation and growth mindset." And stresses that she "is building a community where the kids feel safe and comfortable. It's building a family. It is teaching them to be okay with who they are and teaching them to look out for each other and others in our community."
In order to gain a hybrid homeschooling program spot for the 2024-25 school year, there is a screening process to ensure it is a good fit for the family and the teacher. There is a curiosity form online for those interested.
Virtual dyslexia tutoring is another offered resource. Currently these tutoring sessions utilize Orton Gillingham, are one-on-on and are individualized. Ages 6 through high school are welcome. Parte is currently tutoring middle school students as far as California, as there is a need for her specialized training everywhere.
Tutoring openings occur later at night, 8 p.m. or 9 p.m. as needed. For the 2024-25 school year, there will be nine openings for the virtual tutoring spots.
Another resource at Beyond Words is the academic summer camp, which prevents summer slide, or educational regression, over the summer in an atmosphere that also encourages meeting like-minded friends.
Camp activities include math, reading, writing, STEM and more. Last year, Parte said she drove her son, Lincoln, three hours to be a part of a similar dyslexic school camp. After driving that far, Parte is excited to bring this resource closer to all those on the Eastern Shore. The camp runs from July 29 to Aug. 16 from 8:30 a.m. to 3 p.m.
Students can participate in one or more of the three-week camp programs.
The last available service at Beyond Words Tutoring is non-attorney special education advocate services. These consulting and advocacy services empower parents to be effective advocates for their children in the Individualized Education Program process. This includes understanding the IEP documents as well as ensuring all your child's academic and behavior needs and goals are met.
Currently, Beyond Words Tutoring is still looking for donations of comfortable seating (like bean bags and foam seats), rugs, tables, chairs, art and crafts supplies, paper, markers, old legos, building blocks and other school supplies.
For more information visit www.beyondwordstutoring.com or email lindseyparte@beyondwordstutoring.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: School Board Looks at Changing Name of School Bearing Name of Revolutionary War General, Former Governor Who Owned Slaves
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
School board looks at changing name of school bearing name of Revolutionary War general, former governor who owned slaves

 April 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 382
 Words 

 Read News Document

 General Smallwood Middle School in southern Maryland may soon be no more.The Charles County Board of Education reviewed the process to change the name of the school and the price tag associated with it at their April 16 meeting because concerns had been raised over Gen. William Smallwood being a slave owner.
Jack Tuttle, a content specialist for the school system, elaborated on Smallwood's history from his findings in the Maryland state archives.
Smallwood was born in 1732 and grew up in Charles County, and his family had already been wealthy plantation owners before his birth, Tuttle's presentation said.
In 1761, Smallwood became a Charles County delegate to the assembly and served in the seat for 11 years prior to the Revolutionary War.
He joined Charles County's committee of correspondence in 1774, which was a political organization against the British that was dedicated to spreading information, Tuttle's presentation said.
In 1776, Smallwood joined the Revolutionary War effort as a colonel, then eventually brigadier general of the First Maryland Regiment. He was promoted to major general based on campaigns throughout the East Coast.
By 1790, Smallwood owned 4,350 acres in Charles County and had 56 enslaved people working on his plantation. He served as Maryland's governor from 1785 to 1788 before he died in 1792, Tuttle said.
Charles public school system will survey the community to garner perspective from students, staff, families, the Smallwood school feeder community, elected officials and advocacy groups on changing the school's name, Superintendent Maria Navarro said.
Navarro proposed that all outreach would take place throughout May and early June and the results of the survey would be presented at a June board of education meeting.
The cost of changing the school's name could span anywhere from $64,500 to $124,500, with most of the variance coming from the type of sign the school chooses, according to Tuttle and Navarro's presentation. A traditional sign would cost about $10,000, while an LED digital sign would cost upward of $70,000.
Other potential costs include $35,000 for exterior school lettering, $3,000 for school graphic window film, $10,000 for school plaques, $1,000 for school banners and $5,500 for athletic uniforms.
Navarro reminded board members of Board Policy 7230, which states that a vote to rename the school cannot be held until at least three intervening school board meetings after notification to the school's community. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Chesapeake Multicultural After-School Program Lets Students Learn Through Taste
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Chesapeake Multicultural After-School Program Lets Students Learn Through Taste

 April 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 541
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Thursday evening, over a dozen fourth and fifth graders walked through Bonheur Ice Cream and Pie in downtown Easton and learned from local chefs of the profession of devoting themselves to sweets.These students are part of the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center After-school Program, a program designed to enrich Hispanic elementary school students of Talbot County.
During the program, students focus on science, technology, engineering and mathematics; reading skills; and food supplement nutrition education to ensure they are educated and well prepared for lessons inside and outside of the classroom.
Estela-Vianney Ramirez, assistant director of the after-school program, said she has been working with the program for over a decade, and it is a beautiful experience to help expand the world for these students.
"It's very rewarding to teach the class," Ramirez said. "Those memories really stick in their, the students', minds and enable them to actually give out to the community, too, because some of our volunteers in our after-school program were our students who went through the program 10 years ago."
Ramirez notes that she sees her former students working in offices and throughout the Eastern Shore, and she is happy to be a part of their development.
During the tour of Bonheur, Chef Tyler Heim brought the students to the kitchen and explained the process of making ice cream and the work that goes into every pint. One by one, students were moved throughout the kitchen and shown the behind-the-scenes of sweet treats and rich desserts.
Julia Foxwell, director of community engagement for Bluepoint Hospitality, said it was a delight for the chefs to share their passion for sweets with the students.
"We have been working with the Chesapeake Multicultural Center for some time on how best to support their initiatives while also providing enriching experiences to their students," Foxwell said. "Bringing the girls and boys in to learn kitchen basics — from prep to final product — exposes them to new concepts, flavors and perhaps a future passion of their own. Chefs (Harley) Peet and Heim loved hosting the kids in the kitchen and even got a few ideas for new flavors."
Victoria Gomez Lozano, Hispanic outreach coordinator for Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, said this program is important in reaching out to community members who may not know about the center's services.
"We started this program to give the underserved children of this community the opportunity to have extracurricular activities and to be exposed to a lot of things that they may not have the opportunity to," Gomez Lozano said. "It's also a good way to contact their parents and the families in the community as well so they can open up to us and so we can give them our services."
At the end of the tour, every student was given a scoop of ice cream and a choice of toppings to create their own flavor.
Each student enjoyed the ice cream while laughing with friends.
Student Yerelin Fuentes said she has been in the after-school program for a few years now and loves the chance to learn new things and spend time with her friends outside of class. But what she loves most, she said, is the ability to learn to be a good person.
"They show us how to be a hero," Fuentes said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
