title: Easton High Teacher Named Finalist for Maryland Teacher of the Year
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton High teacher named finalist for Maryland Teacher of the Year

 September 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 671
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Every day in the classroom, Jeremy Hillyard keeps a simple, two-word phrase in mind: "Yes, and."He learned the phrase from his involvement in Improv Easton, a local comedy group. It's meant to encourage improvisers to listen to their partners and appreciate their ideas.
"I hear what you're saying, I'm going to honor it, and I'm going to grow from it," Hillyard says.
As a Spanish and English as a second language math teacher at Easton High School, Hillyard embraces the "Yes, and" philosophy with his students. It's a core message he has delivered to teachers across Talbot County and the state since he was named Talbot County Public Schools' 2024-25 Teacher of the Year in April.
"That philosophy has really carried over with me into the classroom," Hillyard said. "Having my students know that I have a genuine interest in them as human beings and that I will do what I need to do to support them."
On Wednesday, Hillyard was named one of seven finalists for Maryland Teacher of the Year by the state's Board of Education. A selection panel nailed down finalists from 24 district teachers of the year through a rigorous application and evaluation process.
Hillyard was shocked when he heard the news of his selection as a finalist from colleagues who texted him congratulations.
"I'm like, 'What are they talking about?'" he recalled. "I checked my email and it said I was a state finalist, and I was like, 'Holy cow, I'm a state finalist?'"
Hillyard and the other finalists will attend a reception in Baltimore on Oct. 4 where the Maryland Teacher of the Year will be announced.
"It's very, very humbling, and I'm very grateful to know that my efforts to go above and beyond are being recognized," Hillyard said.
STEPPING UPHillyard has taught at Easton High School since 2010. His original background is in the foreign language department. Last year, the school was in need of a teacher for its English for speakers of other languages, or ESOL, math course.
Having a certification to teach math, he stepped in and took on the workload without any hesitation.
"To me, the best teacher is when they see an educational need that they can help with, they do it," Hillyard said. "They jump in there and do it."
By using his skill sets in math and Spanish, he's been able to embrace the challenge of teaching children at a wide variety of progress levels in their English abilities. Depending on their backgrounds, some may come in on track in math, but unable to complete operations in English.
Hillyard lays the groundwork by starting with basic math in English and then moving to more advanced arithmetic as the full-year course continues.
"They each come with a set of their own challenges and strengths and weaknesses," Hillyard said. "That kind of challenge pushes me to want to figure out a way to overcome those or address those."
LOOKING AHEADHillyard and the other 23 district teachers recognized this cycle will have opportunities to explore the state and collaborate throughout the upcoming months. Hillyard's excited for that journey, which includes stops at Deep Creek Lake in Garrett County and the statehouse in Annapolis.
With the school year beginning, he said he's also excited to advance initiatives with colleagues at Easton High.
Recently, the morning announcements have been presented in both English and Spanish, with the help of Hillyard's Advanced Placement Spanish class. He's hoping small improvements will make the growing number of Spanish-speaking students feel more welcomed at Easton High.
"I'm very excited in my school to be working with some colleagues at making our entire school a more equitable environment for our Spanish-speaking community or multilingual community," Hillyard said.
No matter the background of a student, the district teacher of the year aims to play a supporting role in the student's academic journey.
"The students, at the end of the day, they're the authors," Hillyard says.
"That positive relationship and them knowing that my classroom is a safe, supportive place and they can learn and be themselves without being judged or criticized, is truly the secret ingredient."

title: Rotary Club Members Learn About All4Love
author: Phil Reed, Rotary Club of Cambridge
content:
Rotary club members learn about All4Love

 September 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PHIL REED Rotary Club of Cambridge | Section: News 
 
 288
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Lucas Thorpe, co-founder and executive director of All4Love, spoke to members of the Rotary Club of Cambridge about the organization and the work it is doing with the youth of Dorchester County.He said 10 years ago he and Khail Johnson formed a brotherly love based on their combined interest in youth. Beginning with mentoring a group of middle and high school students, the number of interested boys continued to grow. With a need evident, they asked each other "where do we go from here?" and "All4Love" was formed.
With a mission statement "we are dedicated to improving the lives of adolescents and young adults in the Cambridge community by providing transformative and holistically developed opportunities, uniquely fit for our community.", they worked with the schools and other advisors to create programs to help. They felt, "with the tumultuous times Cambridge has faced politically, economically and socially there is a need to change the narrative and bring hope back."
Thorpe said every day is a new day filled with opportunities to make the next day better. The organization has created a number of programs to help achieve its goals, including a high school mentoring program including guidance, an elementary to middle school flag football league, an elementary breakfast club and an after-school music program they continue to increase the number of youth they are serving.
Thorpe was born and raised in Dorchester County, graduating form North Dorchester High School. After graduating, he attended Chesapeake College and the University of Maryland Eastern Shore.
Thorpe oversees the development and operations of the organization. He said, "believing in the power of consistent and collaborative efforts creates lasting change."
For more information about the Rotary Club of Cambridge visit Cambridgemdrotary.org. For more information about All4Love contact Lucas@all4love.us.

title: For Dorchester Superintendent, It's All About Teaching and Learning
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
For Dorchester superintendent, it's all about teaching and learning

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 746
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — When Dorchester County Public Schools Superintendent Jymil Thompson stepped into a third grade classroom at Sandy Hill Elementary during one of the first weeks of the school year, he saw sheer energy."They might have been doing a social emotional learning lesson," Thompson recalled. "And the kids were so involved. They were standing up in their chairs. And the teacher was so energetic."
Everyone was engaged. And for the student that didn't want to get involved, the teacher had him help her with the lesson on the computer so that he was still participating.
Neither the third grade teacher nor the school's principal knew Thompson would be stopping by Sandy Hill Elementary that day.
"And so you know it wasn't a dog and pony show," he said.
For Thompson, who visits the school system's buildings and classrooms every week, the reason for these visits isn't to catch principals and teachers doing the wrong thing. It's to create a comfortable atmosphere of teaching and learning and to offer guidance when needed.
"I used to be a principal, I used to be assistant principal and teacher," Thompson said. "So I want to make sure that they are comfortable with me and know I'm here to help better them and get them supports to be better."
Since becoming superintendent in June, Thompson has made known his hope of bringing the district's ranking up from 23rd to 15th in the state. In an effort to do this in four years, the district has identified different steps to making that happen.
This year, the district is focusing on instructional leadership, taking a top-down approach in an effort to improve student success. Thompson considers instructional leadership — or leadership that focuses on teaching and learning — as his top priority this school year.
"Outside of the teacher, administration has the most impact on student achievement, without a doubt," he said, adding that because principals oversee the entire school, and not just one classroom, they have the most impact on student achievement.
Jodi Colman, assistant superintendent of academics and student services, said that Dorchester County is usually toward the bottom when it comes to rankings among the other school districts in the state.
"And at this point in time, the only way we're going to change that rating and our students are going to start performing at higher academic levels is (if we) focus on instructional leadership within the school system," she said.
In March, the Dorchester County Board of Education approved a purchasing agreement to bring coaching and professional development support for district administrators.
Thompson, the then-interim superintendent, said at the March 25 board meeting that the district executive team expects all its principals to become "great instructional leaders," but not enough professional development has been provided to those leaders.
On Sept. 16, Thompson said this professional development support includes leadership meetings twice per month that focus on how administrators should give feedback to teachers on how to improve in the classroom.
"Making sure that (administrators are) continually developing (teachers') skills to deliver the best instruction to the kids," he said.
In order to jump from 23rd in the state to 15th in four years, Thompson said the district will need to be consistent with developing instructional leadership and follow through on it.
"Making sure that I'm having meetings with the principals, having conversations on how they're progressing on their goals," he said. "And if they're not progressing, how can we shift and go in a little different direction to ensure that they're meeting their goals?"
Thompson thinks one of the biggest challenges the district faces this year will be getting people comfortable with change and holding them accountable to those changes. He said that often, people automatically think accountability is negative, but when you don't hold people accountable, you end up doing them a disservice.
"We don't want to fire anybody," he said. "We want people to do what they were hired to do. And we want to be able to provide the supports when people are struggling at their craft, and then help them improve their craft. When we talk about accountability, that's what we mean."
Colman said that change can be uncomfortable. She said she hopes that by the end of the year, people in the district will find a comfort in being uncomfortable.
"We're only going to make this move if we all know that we've got the same target and (know) that we're all going to have to push ourselves to probably go and do things that we're not normally used to doing," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Dorchester County school superintendent, instructional leadership, and efforts to improve student achievement, which are core education issues. It also mentions the school board's actions, giving a secondary relevance to local government.

title: Talbot School Board Sees Test Scores, Improvement Initiatives
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot school board sees test scores, improvement initiatives

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 836
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — State test scores released last month show a slight increase in math and English proficiency levels at both the district and state levels.Talbot County's Board of Education discussed that trend and others during a work session on Monday, taking a first deep dive into the test results from 2023-2024's Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program.
In English, 47.3% of Talbot County Public Schools students tested proficient, a jump of 2.8% from 44.5% in 2022-2023. In math, 18.3% of students were proficient, up 1.1% from 17.2% the year prior. The district slots in 14th and 18th, respectively, in those categories among the state's 24 districts.
ENGLISH TRENDS"One of the things that the board is always interested in is how does Talbot County Public Schools compare to other districts in the state," said Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership, while presenting the English results. "And I wish that I could give you better news and say that we have flip-flopped the map, but if you compare this year's results to last year across the state, you will see very little change. There is not a single district in the state who is leapfrogging in improvements on this map."
Einhorn and Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi emphasized that the district internally tracks student learning levels. This is done at benchmarks throughout the year.
"I can assure this board that more than 47% of our students are mastering grade level standards," Einhorn said of the English proficiency rate. "It's just that they are not showing it across the state on this particular assessment."
Some positives for the English rates included third grade proficiency and the growth for certain cohorts and subgroups. Third grade English proficiency saw a significant jump from the 2022-2023 school year.
Einhorn pointed out that in 2023, sixth grade students were 40.1% proficient. That same group of students came in at 43.8% proficient on the seventh grade test. "For that cohort of students, it's growth," Einhorn said.
Einhorn said all student groups saw growth in English rates, though Black students had the smallest increase.
"We are reaching every student in some sense, in some capacity," Board President Emily Jackson said of the subgroups. "Maybe not as well as we could, but we're getting there, we are making growth, and that's what I want to see."
MATH TRENDSIn math, the district has many initiatives to increase proficiency. Einhorn said the number of elementary math coaches has increased from three to six, along with an addition of one middle school math coach.
The district is implementing an adaptive testing program called Measures of Academic Progress for kindergarten through eighth grade to track student growth.
In 2023-2024's state test scores, TCPS students showed increases across the board.
"We see slight increases for each one of our student groups," Einhorn said. "We have less of an increase for our Hispanic and Latino students. And we still continue to have fewer than 5% of our Black students and our multilingual learners proficient in mathematics."
For proficiency levels below 5%, the state does not indicate exact percentages. Of the 24 districts, the Talbot district is one of three below the 5% mark in math proficiency among Black students, and one of nine districts below the 5% mark in math proficiency among multilingual students.
Einhorn and Jackson each thanked the Talbot County Council for its commitment in funding education, particularly the math coaches in elementary schools.
"When you see movement like we did in third grade," Jackson said, "I think that we are making really intentional, really important, really good funding decisions that have a big impact on learning."
EXPERT REVIEWSAs required by the state's education initiative, Blueprint for Maryland's Future, experts vetted by the Maryland Department of Education will be reviewing school districts across the state. Einhorn said state reviewers will be visiting three elementary schools in Talbot County this year.
Those schools will be Chapel District Elementary, St. Michaels Elementary and White Marsh Elementary. They were chosen for separate reasons. Einhorn stated: Chapel for reviewers to look at literacy instruction, St. Michaels to review practices for multilingual learners and White Marsh due to success in state testing.
"They had significant growth in their math achievement across all grades in this last MCAP assessment," Einhorn said of White Marsh Elementary. "So they want to know what White Marsh is doing well."
Jackson asked how the district can take lessons learned from these three schools to its largest elementary school, Easton Elementary.
"Can you speak to how we plan to address that?" Jackson asked. "How do you take what you've learned at a very small, very specific population and duplicate it or replicate it at a school like Easton Elementary?"
"One of the things that we do even though it's a larger school, we have committed the same types of resources but just on a larger scale," Einhorn said. "So while our smaller elementaries might have one math coach, we see multiple math coaches to be able to service the number of classrooms that we have at Easton Elementary."
Einhorn said other schools in the district will have state reviews in the next year or two. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Constitution Alliance Hosts Liberty and Freedom Event in Easton for 3rd Year
author: Kenia Itzep Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Constitution Alliance hosts Liberty and Freedom event in Easton for 3rd year

 September 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KENIA ITZEP Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 451
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Mid-Shore Constitution Alliance hosted its third annual celebration of Constitution Day and Citizenship Week with the event "Our Journey to Liberty and Freedom" on Tuesday, Sept. 17, at the Academy Art Museum in Easton.The gathering featured powerful performances by renowned actors Darius Wallace, as Frederick Douglass, and Kurt Smith, as Thomas Jefferson. The two actors captivated the audience with a conversation between these historic figures and the attendees, offering a unique perspective on liberty, freedom and the Constitution.
Smith highlighted the importance of reading and learning history as a "manual for mankind to be better." With humor and deep knowledge of Jefferson's life, he stressed that "when you allow destruction of your neighbor's rights you allow destruction of your own."
Wallace detailed the flaws within the early years of America, pointing to how slavery oppressed millions of human lives for generations despite the country's claim to be a land of freedom. He emphasized the importance of remembering the injustices of the past to improve the future.
The free event drew a large crowd, eager to celebrate and reflect on the significance of the U.S. Constitution. State Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) delivered a welcome address, setting the stage for the day's festivities, which also included the Sons of the American Revolution in period costumes, a color guard and a town crier who announced the signing of the Constitution. Students from Saints Peter and Paul High School and North Dorchester High School were in attendance.
The event also honored new U.S. citizens in Talbot County, recognizing their achievement in earning citizenship credentials. Attendees enjoyed free Constitution giveaways and sweet treats afterward.
Although the event was well-attended, organizer Julie Quick said that the Constitution Allegiance aims to reach even more schools and individuals in the future. She said, "the Constitution is so important for everybody," adding that it goes beyond being a political document. She said it serves as "the foundation of who we are," encouraging individuals to "think beyond ourselves."
In addition to the public celebration, the Constitution Alliance is committed to engaging local youth. On the following day, students from St. Michaels Middle High School participated in a special event where they watched a reenactment and interacted directly with the actors, fostering a deeper understanding of the nation's founding principles.
The event was hosted by the Constitution Alliance; The Institute for Religion, Politics and Culture at Washington College; and Operation Frederick Douglass on the Hill and was supported through local sponsors.
Beyond this event, the Constitution Alliance remains focused on increasing Constitutional literacy among students of all ages. Through educational programming and its annual $1,000 higher education scholarships, the alliance seeks to inspire a new generation of citizens committed to upholding constitutional values. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: St. Michaels Reading Specialist Receives Fulbright Award
author: Staff Report
content:
St. Michaels reading specialist receives Fulbright award

 September 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 412
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Kelly Coutts, a reading specialist at St. Michaels Elementary School, received a Fulbright Teacher Exchange award for the 2024-2025 cycle from the U.S. Department of State and the Fulbright Foreign Scholarship Board.The Talbot County Board of Education recognized Coutts at Wednesday's monthly meeting with a certificate of achievement.
"We acknowledge your hard work and outstanding dedication to Talbot County students and applaud your accomplishments," TCPS Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said.
Coutts is one of more than 800 U.S. citizens who will teach, study or conduct research abroad for the 2024-2025 academic year through the Fulbright Program. Program participants engage in cutting-edge research and expand their professional networks, often continuing research collaborations started abroad and laying the groundwork for forging future partnerships between institutions.
Coutts will find out which country she will be traveling to later this school year. Once abroad, she will participate in research that will be published in a publication on global education.
"I'm very excited," Coutts said at Wednesday's meeting. "There's been 80 teachers from the U.S. who were chosen for this. There's 23 elementary teachers. For the next 10 weeks, I will be participating in an online course."
Upon returning from their abroad trips, Fulbright recipients share their stories and often become active supporters of international exchange, inviting foreign scholars to campus and encouraging colleagues and students to go abroad.
As Fulbright alumni, their careers are enriched by joining a network of thousands of esteemed scholars, many of whom are leaders in their fields. Notable Fulbright alumni include 62 Nobel Prize laureates, 89 Pulitzer Prize recipients, 78 MacArthur Fellows and 41 who have served as a head of state or government.
Since 1946, the Fulbright Program has provided more than 400,000 participants from over 160 countries — chosen for their academic merit and leadership potential — with the opportunity to exchange ideas and contribute to finding solutions to challenges facing different communities.
The Fulbright Program is the U.S. government's flagship international educational exchange program. The program is funded through an annual appropriation made by the U.S. Congress to the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs. Participating governments, host institutions, corporations and foundations around the world also provide direct and indirect support to the program.
More than 800 U.S. Fulbrighters — teachers, artists and professionals from all backgrounds — teach, study or conduct research overseas through the Fulbright Program annually. Approximately 400 master teachers and administrators participate in the Fulbright Teacher Exchanges each year.
For more information about the Fulbright Program, visit https://fulbrightprogram.org. 

 © Copyright 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dorchester MCAP Data Shows Some Progress, Some Areas of Concern
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester MCAP data shows some progress, some areas of concern

 September 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 483
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Public Schools' Spring 2024 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program successes — along with district concerns — were shared during a Board of Education meeting on Thursday.Although the district ranks in the state's bottom four for MCAP English and math proficiency rates, it did see year-to-year increases.
In English, the district rose 1.4% to 33.7% proficiency, ranking 22nd in the state out of 24 districts. In math, the district rose 1% to 12.3% proficiency, ranking 21st in the state.
During the meetingThursday, Jodi Colman, the district's assistant superintendent of academics and student services, showed proficiency rates and rankings in the state broken down by grade level.
Colman said there were eight grade levels where the district's state ranking in math increased and six grade levels where the district's state ranking in English increased.
In fifth grade science, where 14.4% of students were considered proficient on the 2024 MCAP assessment, the ranking went up to 20th in the state for 2024 compared to 22nd the previous year.
Colman said that at a statewide assistant superintendent meeting recently, Dorchester County was mentioned for its growth in third grade math, sixth grade math and middle school algebra.
"I thought that was nice to be highlighted across the state as seeing a district that is actually moving some of their scores," she said after mentioning that math scores across the state were pretty stagnant in the 2024 MCAP compared to the previous year.
Colman also brought up concerns regarding district MCAP scores.
According to the data Colman shared, 30.6% of 10th graders scored proficient on the English assessment last school year, ranking last in the state.
Colman said the district is looking at its support pathway classes, which it hopes will affect the 10th grade data "more significantly."
Colman also brought up elementary English scores. She said that as students go up in grade, English proficiency levels decrease.
Colman said there have been discussions about whether the district should resume using its instructional program for elementary English or adopt a new one. The district's language arts supervisor is researching this.
Moving forward, the district is getting feedback from the state on a new comprehensive literacy plan, Colman said.
"We are also looking at, across the board, our tier one instruction for any content level," she said. "Making sure that we're really using that instructional planning model, that we're thinking through strategically with our students and that do we have good, formative assessment data to use in order to change teaching within our classrooms. And I think we have a lot of work to do in that area."
Colman said that although the MCAP scores aren't "exactly where we want them," there is hope in the county about increasing the scores going forward.
"So I'm excited about that," she said.
After Colman's presentation, Superintendent Jymil Thompson said although the score increases might not be "monumental," they show progress.
"If we continue that progress over the years, it will add up," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dorchester Schools to Create Strategic Plan for Coming Years
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester schools to create strategic plan for coming years

 September 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 338
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Cambridge — During the first Dorchester County Board of Education meeting of the school year, the board heard about an initiative to create a strategic plan for the school years ahead.Dorchester County Public Schools is developing this plan with Integrated Impact Group, a consulting firm out of Pennsylvania.
During the meeting on Sept. 19, consultant Connie Casson walked the board through the firm's process. She said the purpose of the plan is to guide the work of the district from 2025 through 2028.
"This is kind of a long run for a strategic planning process," she said. "So we want to be really inclusive. We want to be very engaging and come up with something that feels just a little bit scary but very doable for DCPS."
Casson said the questions they want to answer in developing this plan include how to best prepare students, how to recruit and retain the best teachers and staff, how to provide students with opportunities to explore careers in local industries, and how to do best with the resources available.
To create the plan, Casson said September and October will be spent reviewing district data and understanding where the district is right now.
"This will include student surveys, parent surveys and staff surveys," she said.
In the coming months, through June, time will be spent researching and exploring what other districts are doing, prioritizing strengths and new initiatives, making plans and turning those plans into budgets, communicating district priorities to local partners, and starting to plan for next school year and beyond.
Casson said Integrated Impact Group will give monthly updates to the board. She said they have set up an email account, planning@dcpsmd.org, that people can reach out to.
The district and Integrated Impact Group will be holding three community meetings for residents to share their ideas and priorities for the school years ahead. These meetings will be held Oct. 14 at Hurlock United Methodist Church, Oct. 15 at St. Luke Methodist Church and Oct. 16 at South Dorchester School. All three meetings will begin at 6 p.m.

title: Multicultural Resource Center Awards Scholarships to 14 Students
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Multicultural Resource Center awards scholarships to 14 students

 September 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 386
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Over a dozen eager students from the Eastern Shore, many of whom are first-generation college students, have been awarded funds to pursue their academic goals.The Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center's annual scholarship has awarded over $35,000 to 14 students for the upcoming fall term.
The Center has provided various resources and programs to assist students throughout their academic careers. From elementary after school programs to financial aid education, the organization has made it possible for families from the area's growing immigrant communities to achieve different levels of education.
According to Victoria Gomez Lozano, the scholarship was established about four years ago and has slowly gained more funds to extend its assistance.
Gomez Lozano said there is no set criteria for an applicant to be awarded this scholarship, but it is designed for students who may not have a family history of attending higher education institutions.
"The two main things is first college generation and the need of the financial because sometimes some of the applicants are not eligible for all the scholarships, including FAFSA," Gomez Lozano said.
According to Gomez Lozano, the funds provided by this scholarship have been used for a variety of aspects of academia including the purchase of laptops, books and dorm fees.
Morgan Lewis, an awardee of the scholarship program, said it is her overall goal to continue her education toward a masters and possible doctorate in psychology. Lewis said she is thankful for the scholarship because without the additional funds, she would have needed to take out loans for her undergraduate degree.
"With the support of Chesapeake Multicultural Center, I have been able to further my academic career at two different locations in order to get my undergraduate degree in psychology with the hopes to be able to help others who may not be so lucky and have those financial struggles or any number of other struggles," Lewis said.
Gomez Lozano said she is proud that the center has provided opportunities for so many students and encourages everyone, regardless of academic background, to apply for the scholarship.
"I think it's important because a lot of students don't know that they can have the opportunity to go to college," Gomez Lozano said. "… So I just think it's very important, because the way they know that they can take advantage of the opportunity to make their dreams come true."

title: Washington College Electric Boat Team Visits Radcliffe Creek School
author: Staff Writer
content:
Washington College Electric Boat Team visits Radcliffe Creek School

 September 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 421
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Radcliffe Creek School students were treated to a special presentation by the Washington College Electric Boat Team Sept. 20. Team members shared their inspiring story, detailing the design failures they overcame in the process of building their electric boats, which eventually led to the team's success, winning first place in multiple races against other teams from universities with large engineering programs.Electric Boat Team President Douglas Hewes, a member of RCS' Class of 2018, spoke, along with WC students Mac Sansbury, Tiyaba Jamil, and Team Advisor Brian Palmer, about the strategies they used to design their boats each year and remain competitive against teams like Princeton University.
By thoughtfully building better batteries, stronger electric motors, more efficient solar technology, and hydrodynamic hull designs, they were able to start bringing home top place awards. Palmer noted, "Our students are taking away technical insights that are valuable of course, but perhaps more important is the practice they are getting at recognizing problems to solve, learning how to design solutions, and not getting dissuaded when things don't always turn out as they hoped. It's a great opportunity for them to build technical capabilities as well as perseverance and grit that is needed to see complex projects through to fruition."
Palmer excitedly shared the news about the team's most recent success–breaking the Guinness World Record for the greatest distance by an electric boat on a single charge without solar Sept. 2. WC team broke the previous world record by 21 miles. Hewes remarked, "When we were building the trimaran, we didn't even think about beating a world record or even thought we could…Then, we did the calculations and then we realized, hey, we might actually be able to beat the record."
The students had the opportunity to watch video footage of the record-breaking success and see the winning boat in person, as well as to ask questions about the boat's design and the team's plans for the future. "We are grateful to the Washington College Electric Boat Team for sharing their story about how they overcame failure to find success. It's important for our students to hear that it's okay to try hard and come up short; in all good design thinking, failure is just part of the learning process. It was apparent from the number of hands in the air and the thoughtful student questions that this remarkable story had a real impact on our young learners," said Head of School Peter Thayer.
To learn more about the Electric Boat Team at Washington College, visit WACElectricBoat.com

title: Two Student Representatives Appointed to Talbot Board of Education
author: Staff Report
content:
Two student representatives appointed to Talbot Board of Education

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 325
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Two student representatives were appointed to the Talbot County Board of Education earlier this month.Gabriella Streaker, a senior at Easton High School, and Brynn Lizewski, a senior at St. Michaels Middle High School, were sworn in as student board members at the board's monthly meeting on Sept. 18. They will serve on the board for the 2024-2025 school year.
Streaker is president of the Easton National Honor Society, class treasurer and a member of both the soccer and swim teams. She plans to attend college for health sciences and go to medical school to become a pediatrician or surgeon.
"I am extremely honored and excited to serve as student member of the board, not only to fulfill a position with a high level of leadership but more importantly to represent my peers, teachers, staff, parents and the community," Streaker said in a press release.
Lizewski is president of the Student Government Association and a member of both the tennis and field hockey teams. She plans to study political science and women's studies after high school and then attend law school.
"I am very excited for this new position and cannot wait to have a real insight on local politics," Lizewski said in a press release. "Our small community matters so much, and I'm excited to see the backbone of our local education system."
Board of Education members and Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi welcomed the student board members and encouraged them to provide their feedback and opinions as the school year moves along.
"Welcome to our board," Board Vice President Candace Henry said at the Sept. 18 meeting. "We love to hear feedback from the schools, and so we welcome all of your feedback."
"We are excited to have these student leaders represent their schools this year," Pepukayi said in a press release. "The board values their input and feedback about important issues in our district and enjoys hearing their monthly reports from their respective school communities."

title: Washington College Electric Boat Team Visits Radcliffe Creek School
author: Staff Writer
content:
Washington College Electric Boat Team visits Radcliffe Creek School

 October 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 413
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Radcliffe Creek School students were treated to a special presentation by the Washington College Electric Boat Team Sept. 20. Team members shared their inspiring story, detailing the design failures they overcame in the process of building their electric boats, which eventually led to the team's success, winning first place in multiple races against other teams from universities with large engineering programs.Electric Boat Team President Douglas Hewes, a member of Radcliffe's Class of 2018, spoke, along with Washington College students Mac Sansbury, Tiyaba Jamil, and team adviser Brian Palmer, about the strategies they used to design their boats each year and remain competitive against teams like Princeton University.
By thoughtfully building better batteries, stronger electric motors, more efficient solar technology, and hydrodynamic hull designs, they were able to start bringing home top place awards. Palmer noted, "Our students are taking away technical insights that are valuable of course, but perhaps more important is the practice they are getting at recognizing problems to solve, learning how to design solutions, and not getting dissuaded when things don't always turn out as they hoped. It's a great opportunity for them to build technical capabilities as well as perseverance and grit that is needed to see complex projects through to fruition."
Palmer excitedly shared the news about the team's most recent success — breaking the Guinness World Record for the greatest distance by an electric boat on a single charge without solar Sept. 2. The Washington team broke the previous world record by 21 miles.
Hewes remarked, "When we were building the trimaran, we didn't even think about beating a world record or even thought we could. … Then, we did the calculations and then we realized, hey, we might actually be able to beat the record."
The students had the opportunity to watch video footage of the record-breaking success and see the winning boat in person, as well as to ask questions about the boat's design and the team's plans for the future.
"We are grateful to the Washington College Electric Boat Team for sharing their story about how they overcame failure to find success. It's important for our students to hear that it's OK to try hard and come up short; in all good design thinking, failure is just part of the learning process. It was apparent from the number of hands in the air and the thoughtful student questions that this remarkable story had a real impact on our young learners," Head of School Peter Thayer said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Four Years After Her Murder, Madison Sparrow's Legacy Lives On
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Four years after her murder, Madison Sparrow's legacy lives on

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 735
 Words 

 Read News Document

 From a young age, Madison Sparrow always wanted to be a teacher."She definitely knew what she wanted to be and never swayed," her mother, Heather Sparrow Murphy, said. "And kids loved her. She was a tutor and a babysitter and she helped me run my Girl Scout troop for her younger sister."
Madison never got the chance to realize her dream of following in the footsteps of several family members and becoming a teacher. The 17-year-old Newark Charter School junior was murdered by her ex-boyfriend and another friend in Delaware four years ago this month.
Her dream lives on, however, through five Newark Charter students who have received scholarships in Madison's name to pursue a career in education.
"I call them my girls," Murphy said, describing the close bond she has with the scholarship recipients. "They're like my kids. They all keep in contact with me."
The first recipient, Kristen White, is nearly done with her degree and recently started her student-teaching assignment.
"She said to me, 'Miss Heather, as hard as it is...I remember I'm doing this for Madison,'" Murphy said. "And that gets me."
Murphy raises money for the scholarship through the annual Love Wins 5K. Now in its fourth year, the race drew more than 200 people to Glasgow Park on Saturday.
"I definitely cry every year," Murphy said. "It's really emotional, but it also means so much to me and helps me continue to go on and keep her memory alive. You can't even put words on that. I mean, that's what I live for."
The Madison Sparrow Scholarship is awarded each year to a Newark Charter senior pursuing a career in education, and the recipients can reapply for funding each year. Last year, Murphy was able to give a scholarship to two deserving seniors.
Madison was killed Oct. 2, 2020, after her supposed friend Annika Stalczynski lured her into the woods behind Maclary Elementary School, where Madison's ex-boyfriend Noah Sharp fatally struck her with a baseball bat. They then dumped her body near Interstate 95.
Both Sharp and Stalczynski were convicted of first-degree murder in 2022 and are serving lengthy prison sentences.
Murphy is involved with the nonprofit Victims' Voices Heard and recently participated in the organization's victim-offender dialog program, which allowed her to sit down with Stalczynski and talk about the murder and how losing her daughter affected her.
"It was a beautiful experience," Murphy said. "I'm sure it's not for every victim, but as Madison's mom, because I knew these children so well, it was something that I needed from the beginning."
Both Murphy and Stalczynski spent five months meeting separately with a mediator and then spent four hours speaking with each other. As hard as it was to face her daughter's murderer, Murphy felt she had to get answers from Stalczynski.
"She was with my daughter when she was murdered, so there's only that truth, there's only those answers," Murphy said. "And she was very honest with me. Because I was here when Madison was brought into the world, I needed to know how Madison left it, and she was able to give me all the answers."
The meeting helped Murphy process her grief.
"I'll never have closure, but it definitely closed the chapter on the things I needed to know," she said. "I said everything I needed to say and I received everything I needed to learn."
Murphy already forgave Sharp and Stalczynski — both of whom she knew well before Madison's murder — during her victim impact statement during their sentencing.
"Forgiveness is something, I truly believe, that we do for ourselves not something that I do for the people that murdered my daughter," she said. "It's also just the way that Madison lived her life, and that's the whole message of 'love wins.'"
Murphy continues to hear stories about Madison when she sees her daughter's friends and former teachers.
"The community outpouring and love just shows me how much people love my daughter and how much she impacted our community," she said. "It continues every year with this race, and it's a beautiful way for me to see that and be surrounded and for us all to be together."
Madison, Murphy said, "was an amazing soul."
"She just loved children, and they loved her back," she said. "She was a gentle soul, she loved her friends, she was so loyal to everyone, just an amazing daughter."
To donate to the Madison Sparrow Scholarship Fund, visit runsignup.com/Race/DE/Newark/LoveWins5KDE. Murphy is also looking for sponsors for next year's race. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a scholarship established in memory of a murder victim to support students pursuing teaching careers, highlighting educational aspirations and community support rather than the crime itself.

title: How Maryland Schools Are Cracking Down on Cell Phones This Fall
author: Madison Korman Capital News Service
content:
How Maryland schools are cracking down on cell phones this fall

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MADISON KORMAN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 387
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Classrooms across Maryland are a bit more quiet this fall, with students under new rules to keep their phones off and out of sight.At least a third of Maryland public schools have tightened up the rules this fall, according to a Capital News Service survey conducted this month.
Meanwhile, public schools in and around Baltimore are cracking down on phones during instruction — and, in some cases, even on the bus.
In Caroline County, on the eastern shore of Maryland, public schools have a new pilot program in two middle schools. It requires students to place their phones in locked pouches. The pouches stay with the students but remain locked until the end of the school day.
"Today's youth battle constant distraction caused by cell phone alerts and messaging that interrupt their ability to focus," Supt. Derek L. Simmons said in a recent notice to students and parents. He said this "creates a negative impact on school culture and learning."
Elsewhere, administrators are getting creative about persuading students to go along with the plan.
In St. Mary's County, Supt. Scott Smith recently released a video describing the district's new plan to limit the distractions caused by cell phones.
In the video, he comically stops midway through his presentation of the new rules to take out his phone and text, showing students how difficult it can be to have a conversation when they are disengaged and on their phones.
"Hold on, just wait a second, I'm just going to text him real fast," Smith said in the video, pretending to send a message.
"That's really rude isn't it?" he then pointed out. "We're supposed to be having a conversation, and I'm interrupting myself and I'm getting on my phone and I'm texting."
"I'm not really here right?" Smith said. "I'm kind of distracted."
Since the start of the school year, in St. Mary's County, they have confiscated around 30 cell phones per day, Smith told the school board in a recent meeting. That's out of 10,000 students, he said at the meeting.
"We have had many conversations about the joy of being in a classroom without the distraction of cell phones," Smith said, adding that he and his staff "continue to work with our secondary students about the joy and some of the challenges of cellular devices and how we can maximize our joy and fun in life." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot Board of Education Candidates Speak at Town Hall Forum
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot Board of Education candidates speak at town hall forum

 October 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 820
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Candidates for the Talbot County Board of Education fielded questions during an open forum Wednesday evening at the Avalon Theatre.The town hall, hosted by The Talbot Spy and the Avalon Foundation, centered on many issues facing Talbot County Public Schools, including standardized test scores, student engagement and teacher retention.
Three of seven seats on the board are up for grabs in next month's election. Incumbent Candace Henry and Ann O'Connor are squaring off for the District 2 seat. In District 5, incumbent Anna Howie and Karla Wieland-Cherry are running.
The District 6 seat, currently held by Mary Wheeler, is a race between Kerry Gunshenan and Cynthia Jurrius.
Henry, O'Connor, Howie and Jurrius attended Wednesday's town hall, answering moderator and audience questions. Wieland-Cherry and Gunshenan did not attend.
TEST SCORESScores released in August showed slight improvements in math and English proficiency rates in the district. The four candidates, though, were adamant that test scores must improve.
In English, 47.3% of Talbot County Public Schools students tested proficient, a jump of 2.8% from 44.5% in 2022-2023. In math, 18.3% of students were proficient, up 1.1% from 17.2% the year prior. The district slots in 14th and 18th, respectively, in those categories among the state's 24 districts.
"Our scores are not what we want," Henry said. She added that an increase in math coaches in the elementary schools and other forms of benchmark testing are current district initiatives.
"Standardized testing is a snapshot in a period of time," Henry said. "(Superintendent Sharon) Pepukayi has worked with her team to really be intentional about gathering data from students on a more consistent basis."
In recent months, county residents have received flyers in the mail questioning the test scores, along with district spending and, most recently, a health education framework bill proposed at the state level.
"These flyers that came out are pretty alarming," O'Connor said. "And I don't look at them as a negative on teachers. Teachers don't want these scores. The system is broken."
O'Connor, who is backed by Talbot County's chapter of Moms for Liberty, a nationwide conservative political organization, said a lack of "meaningful homework" is a "deficiency." She advocated for summer reading and said the district should look at what nearby private schools are doing in order to raise TCPS test scores.
Jurrius, who along with Henry and Howie is endorsed by the Talbot County Education Association labor union, addressed the most recent mailer sent to residents. That mailer stated, in part, that "radical politicians are more worried about forcing harmful gender ideology" on students, referencing a state Senate bill from 2023 that did not pass.
Jurrius stated she does not believe educators are indoctrinating students.
"This destructive polarization isn't helpful," Jurrius said. "And whoever is behind it, (I) would love to see them contribute in a positive way. I think if we all work together, we can do some amazing things to increase our schools' test scores."
STUDENT ENGAGEMENTAcross the state, many districts are exploring ways to reduce cell phone use and other distractions in schools. TCPS has plans to roll out a pilot program for cell phone pouches sometime after Thanksgiving.
Howie, an assistant principal at Federalsburg Elementary School in Caroline County, said Caroline County's current pilot of those same cell phone pouches has been a success.
"You can see engagement going through the roof," Howie said.
She emphasized that technology should be an addition to student learning and not the sole focus. "A computer isn't a replacement, right. A computer should be a tool," she said.
O'Connor said the same of computers. She said cell phones do not belong in schools and added she hopes to see an increased focus on books.
"Going back to the basics," O'Connor said. "Are we reading books? Are books coming home? … I don't see them as much."
Jurrius advocated for "restorative practices" in student discipline to hold students accountable for actions. She said suspensions aren't always the solution.
"Students right now are different," Jurrius said. "They have different challenges in their lives, their social media, their mental health issues."
TEACHER RETENTIONCandidates discussed the need for effective recruitment and retention of teachers and staff amid shortages in the district, along with strategies to rectify those shortcomings.
Howie emphasized the importance of retaining teachers and staff. She said looking at intent forms earlier will help the district and board understand why teachers leave.
"Being very intentional in having those conversations early … instead of getting that intent form at the end of the year and just start tallying up," Howie said.
Henry added that the district should especially consider the feedback from teachers and staff that decide to stay. She hopes to see specific attention dedicated toward the district's "Grow Your Own Teachers" scholarship program.
"We should be growing teachers from our communities that can come back and teach in our communities," Henry said.
Residents in Districts 2, 5 and 6 will see the respective school board candidates on the ballot on Election Day, which is Nov. 5. The three candidates elected will serve four-year terms. 

 (c) Copyright 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Focus Remains Clear
author: Staff Writer
content:
Focus remains clear

 October 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 258
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recently, there have been reports suggesting that my candidacy for the Talbot County Board of Education is endorsed by Mom's For Liberty. I want to clarify that this is not true. I have not received endorsements from Mom's For Liberty or any other group.I have attended meetings hosted by the local M4L Chapter to better understand their perspectives and issues. This is one of my guiding principles — to attend meetings in the community to gather information so I can make my own decisions. At the last meeting, our superintendent, assistant superintendents and director of communications for TCPS were present as guest speakers, highlighting the ongoing dialogue between our school system and the community.
People may incorrectly label me according to their perspectives, based on where I go, what groups I frequent, and in what activities I'm involved, but my focus remains clear: I am committed to the children of this county, our dedicated teachers and the importance of parental involvement. Collaboration among the three groups is essential to elevate our schools; it's a three legged stool — if one leg falters, the entire system is compromised.
If elected to the school board, I will prioritize listening to all voices to make informed decisions. My platform is based on the ABC's of education: Advancing Academics, Boosting Accountability and Cultivating Character. These principles will guide my decision making and efforts to improve our schools.
Together, let's strive for excellence and overcome mediocrity in our educational system. It would be an honor and privilege to serve as your school board member.
ANN O'CONNOR
Easton

title: Candidates Have Varying Views
author: Staff Writer
content:
Candidates have varying views

 October 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 364
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 2024 election season will see voters from several towns in Talbot County choose their representatives for the Talbot County School Board.There are six candidates and, while neither political party is formally endorsing them, they do have varying views concerning the education of our children.
Three are conservative and three are progressive. The conservative candidates are: Ann O'Connor (District 2), Karla Wieland-Cherry (District 5), and Kerry Gunshenan (District 6). The progressive candidates are: Cynthia Jurrius ( District 6), Anna Howie (District 5) and Candace Henry (District 2).
As a public service, the local chapter of a parent support group called Moms for Liberty hosted a debate for the school board candidates on Sept. 23 at the Easton firehouse. All six candidates were invited; four appeared, including Cynthia Jurrius and the three conservatives Ann O'Connor, Karla Wieland-Cherry and Kerry Gunshenan. The event was a success and helpful for parents and grandparents in deciding for whom they will vote to sit on the local school board. Another school board candidates' debate was held on Wednesday, Oct. 2, at 6 p.m. at the Avalon Theater and all six candidates were invited to speak.
While Moms for Liberty, according to several public statements made by the chapter Chair Jan Greenhawk, does not endorse any of the candidates, the Moms have been accused in a local periodical of "inserting their partisan candidates into a non-partisan position." Such an accusation is surprising in light of the fact that another school board candidates' debate was held at the Academy Art Museum, sponsored by the Talbot County Democratic Forum.
Sadly, only three of the candidates were invited to speak. And guess which three. Yes, the three more progressive candidates, who happen to be Democrats. The other three candidates, the three conservative candidates, were not invited at all. And yet Moms for Liberty, which has not endorsed a single candidate, is accused of partisanship? Why are liberals so afraid to hear the opinions of conservatives, especially as regards our children's education? Is it that conservatives put children's well-being ahead of the latest fads of social-engineering and psychological manipulation? Is it because conservatives want to truly educate the children rather than indoctrinating them with left-wing philosophies?
MARY-EILEEN RUSSELL
Claiborne 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Karla Wieland-Cherry
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Karla Wieland-Cherry

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Karla Wieland-Cherry, 55, is a resident of Trappe and is running for the District 5 seat on the Board of Education.She is a registered nurse and an associate real estate broker. She volunteers with many local organizations. Wieland-Cherry said she grew up in a home that kept up with and often interacted with politics, both local and national. She is married and has two children.
Why are you running for office?
I am running for the Talbot County Board of Education to work to improve our local school system for students, parents and our community.
Goals I hope to achieve will be to improve test scores by enticing more qualified teachers to teach in Talbot County and retaining current teachers; raising education benchmark standards; increase use of CTE programs; improve student discipline rules; improve school safety measures; improve open communication transparency between schools, teachers, administration and parents and the community.
What are your priorities if elected?
After speaking with teachers in different grades at local schools, the constant concern I hear is the lack of student discipline and their safety as teachers. Teachers can't teach and students can't learn… and test scores can't improve… and teachers won't want to come teach in a county… if they are in an environment where everyone feels unsafe.
Teachers have a distrust of the current board and feel that they don't listen to them and take their concerns seriously. I want to rebuild that trust by listening to teacher concerns and addressing those in a more supportive manner to make necessary changes.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces and how do you think the board needs to address it?
Lack of teachers and staff seems to be the biggest issue. As I mentioned already in the prior questions, my priority will be to listen to teachers and rebuild the trust that is currently missing with the present board.
I will also work to improve communication between schools, teachers, parents and the community and work to create a more secure learning environment for everyone.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
Everyone should take their own initiative to investigate local school data from reliable resources. These postcards are one way of bringing awareness to the community and open communication channels amongst parents, teachers, administration and the board to ask questions about their authenticity.
In speaking with many parents of all grade levels of students, I consistently hear that there is no open communication, especially with the current board.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint For Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
Teachers I've spoken with are frustrated and don't know Blueprint well, and what they do know is vague with no clear guidelines to how it's implemented. Funding Blueprint is based on inequities of and poverty levels of students for priority funding. Blueprint prioritizes equity learning.
We need to recognize every student's individuality and work to strengthen those individual skills for college/career readiness. We need to stop looking at certain groups as "minorities" and overlooking their skills as worthy individuals capable of learning instead of trying to make everyone "equal" to someone else. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Anna Howie
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Anna Howie

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Anna Howie 
 
 511
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Anna Howie, 49, is a resident of Easton and the current District 5 member of the Talbot County Board of Education. She was appointed to the post by Gov. Wes Moore in October, 2023.Howie is the assistant principal at Federalsburg Elementary School. She is married and has three children.
Why are you running for office?
I am running for the District 5 seat of the Talbot County Board of Education to represent students, families and other stakeholders. We are making gains in our school district, and I want to continue to ensure that our students and teachers have access to high quality instructional materials that will have an impact on student achievement and success.
What are your priorities if elected?
My priorities align with the goals set by the members of the Board of Education and the superintendent, Dr. (Shraron) Pepukayi. My two main areas of focus are increasing student achievement in the areas of mathematics and reading, and recruiting and retaining quality teachers.
Having teachers that provide outstanding instruction to our students will ensure that our students will be academically successful.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces, and how do you think the board needs to address it?
The most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools face right now is providing exceptional education opportunities for all students while being fiscally responsible.
Currently, the curriculum coordinating committee has brought high quality resources to the board for approval in the areas of reading and mathematics. These resources are paid for through educational grants. Utilizing grants is a responsible way of ensuring that we are providing our students with high quality instructional materials while being fiscally responsible.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
The postcards that have been mailed out focused on student test scores as well as other concerns. In terms of student test scores, we have purchased new high quality instructional materials. Our 2024 data reflects growth in all subgroups as well as certain subject areas and grades.
Student test scores are not just a concern for our district but across the State. Through the Governance and Accountability pillar of the Blueprint, expert review teams will be visiting schools across the state to review literacy and mathematics instruction in our classrooms and provide quality feedback for improvement.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint For Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
I believe that the pillars of the Blueprint reflect the areas that all Maryland Schools want to address. Those pillars address early childhood education, high quality and diverse teachers, college and career readiness, more resources for students to be successful, and governance and accountability.
The Blueprint identifies and prioritizes the needs that we see in our district and across the state. In order for our students to be college and career ready by 10th grade, we need to start addressing their needs in pre-Kindergarten and ensure that they are receiving the resources they need to be successful in every grade. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cynthia Marrah Jurrius
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Cynthia Marrah Jurris, 65, lives in Easton. She practices mediation law and is a director of conflict resolution programs. She is married and has three sons, all of whom graduated from Talbot County Public Schools.She is running for the District 6 seat on the Board of Education.
Why are you running for office?
Our public schools play a pivotal role in shaping our community's future, and we need board members who can help move (Talbot County Public Schools) forward to excellence. With a background in mediation and youth, school, family and community conflict resolution, I listen to all perspectives and value the richness in diversity of opinion.
I am a collaborative problem solver, skilled at helping people work together to solve complex community challenges. I want to ensure that our board continues to function effectively, advancing schools where every student can thrive. We have many strengths on which to build; together, we can solve any challenge.
What are your priorities if elected?
My priorities are interrelated: fostering academic excellence, supporting educators and creating a thriving school environment. I am committed to advancing student mastery of essential skills, improving academic proficiency and preparing students for college and careers.
Ensuring we recruit, retain and support outstanding teachers is key to this vision. Equally important is providing a positive, safe, effective and inclusive school climate where all learners can succeed and promoting strong family and student engagement to build a collaborative, supportive community around our schools. Together, these priorities create the foundation for a bright future for our students.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces and how do you think the board needs to address it?
Advancing academic proficiency is a priority. Supporting a positive, safe, effective and inclusive learning environment is fundamental for student success, as well as teacher retention. Finding innovative ways to engage families, including non-English speakers, and students will support all aspects of student success.
The current board and superintendent are making progress toward addressing these issues despite many challenges, such as the COVID-19 learning gap. Through additional instructional support, expanding use of innovative community partnerships, strategic use of technology, targeted allocation of resources and engaging all sectors of our community, we can accelerate progress in these areas.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
I would like to see the sender of the mailers come forward for productive and honest dialogue. While improving academic proficiency is essential, the harmful attacks on our teachers, fueled by misleading and inflammatory rhetoric, seem aimed at undermining our public schools and inciting fear.
I would welcome an open, honest conversation about what this group seeks to accomplish, with accurate, relevant information. Let's work together to lift our Talbot County Public Schools to be the vibrant foundation of our community, where education is valued, everyone can belong and our teachers receive the support they need and deserve.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint for Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
The creation of the Blueprint was the result of a comprehensive effort with input from many stakeholders. The five pillars are: Early Childhood Education; High Quality and Diverse Teachers and Leaders; College and Career Readiness; More Resources for Student Success; and Governance and Accountability.
The TCPS team has a detailed plan for managing the Blueprint and provides regular reports on progress for public view. There are many areas of the Blueprint that are positive, however, the most challenging aspects are mandates without sufficient funding. I support continued efforts to address the funding formula as it has been applied to Talbot County. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a candidate's platform and priorities for the Talbot County Board of Education, discussing school policies, academic excellence, and student safety, which aligns most closely with the Education topic.

title: Ann O'Connor
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Ann O'Connor

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Ann Oconnor 
 
 589
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Ann O'Connor, 55, is a resident of Easton. She is running for the District 2 seat on the Talbot County Board of Education.She is a former teacher and has six children.
Why are you running for office?
I am running for the school board because I am deeply passionate about children's education. As a former teacher and mother of six, I have dedicated my career to helping children reach their highest potential.
Having witnessed my six children go through (Talbot County Public School), I have observed a decline in academic rigor, expectations and accountability, both in behavior and academics. This experience drives my desire to make meaningful changes on the school board. The fact that our students are scoring 18% proficient in math and 55% in reading indicates a pressing need for new perspectives on our educational strategies.
What are your priorities if elected?
My priorities are the ABCs of education: advancing academics, boosting accountability and cultivating character. The focus is on the whole child. We cannot advance academics without discipline.
When students develop self-discipline, good character naturally emerges. This requires daily practice and consistent reinforcement of rules and clear expectations for all students across all buildings. Disruptive behavior must be addressed promptly and effectively.
Regarding academic accountability: A 95% graduation rate when less than ¼ of our students are proficient in math skills, and less than ½ are reading on grade level is inconsistent — something is broken here and we need to fix it.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces and how do you think the board needs to address it?
The most important issue is the steady decline of academic rigor. We need to make sure we continue to implement early intervention in elementary schools to support those who need that extra push. It's essential to send home books and ensure that our children have access to/and are accountable for reading materials throughout elementary, middle and high school.
We should place greater emphasis on traditional learning — using pencils and paper, cursive writing, fostering reading and critical thinking skills, while reducing reliance on computers. We need to offer pathways for middle school students interested in college or the workforce, including advanced/honors classes.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
The postcards received in the mail are snapshots of where our schools stand. No one wants these scores, they are abysmal. It's a wake up call to attack the problem and change the way we have been doing education here in Talbot County.
We need to put our focus on reading, writing and math. Our students are distracted. Let's eliminate anything that detracts from our mission as educators and focus on what truly matters — educating the child. Let's get back to basics with my ABCs of education.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint For Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
Simply changing a name doesn't lead to improvement. Over the last two decades, this initiative has gone through four name changes. Although there are many wonderful proposals in the Blueprint, I don't believe that top-down programs created by education experts would make our local schools better.
The Blueprint is a blanket principle mandated for all 24 counties in Maryland. The counties have no say in how it is implemented. It removes the schools from the control of locally elected school boards and puts control in the hands of unelected officials. I believe we want control over our local schools. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
