title: Candace Henry
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Candace Henry

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Candace Henry 
 
 571
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Candace Henry, 43, currently serves as the Talbot County Board of Education member for District 2 and is running for reelection. She lives in Easton with her family of four.Henry is the director of the Disability Resource Center at Salisbury University.
Why are you running for office?
I am running for reelection to the Board of Education to ensure that every student, regardless of ability, background or language, has equal access to quality education. My focus on accessibility, equity and belonging stems from a commitment to create inclusive learning environments where all students feel valued and supported.
I believe in breaking down barriers to success, advocating for diverse voices and fostering a sense of community in our schools. By addressing the unique needs of all learners, I aim to promote educational outcomes that empower every student to reach their full potential.
What are your priorities if elected?
My priorities are consistent with TCPS' current philosophy of "transforming and performing." I want the public to know that the Board of Education operates as a collective and is not driven by individual agendas.
I am committed to the collective goals to prioritize narrowing and closing the opportunity and achievement gaps, eliminating barriers to education, recruiting and retaining high-quality educators, enhancing special education services, continuous improvement in reading and math proficiency, enhancing our summer school offerings, and early access to college preparatory, dual enrollment, and CTE programs.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces and how do you think the board needs to address it?
The most important issue facing (Talbot County Public Schools) is the opportunity gap, which directly affects reading and math proficiency for all students. To address this, the board must continue to prioritize equitable distribution of resources, ensuring that schools serving higher-need populations have access to targeted interventions.
Simultaneously, recruiting and retaining high-quality educators is vital, as teachers are the foundation of student success. By investing in professional development and creating supportive environments for educators, we can close the opportunity gap and improve outcomes and opportunities for all students.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
The postcards critical of Talbot County's education system are deeply troubling because they disparage the hard work of our educators. Much of the content includes outdated and inaccurate information, which undermines trust in our schools and the dedicated professionals working to support our students.
These types of messages are circulated with the intent to create division rather than foster productive dialogue. To address these concerns, we must continue to engage the community in open discussion, lead with facts — highlighting the progress being made and the work that still needs to be done, all while celebrating the efforts of our educators.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint For Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
The Blueprint for Maryland's Future presents significant benefits by prioritizing equity, early childhood education and career readiness, which can help close the opportunity gap and enhance student success. It also aims to improve educator salaries and professional development, which are crucial for recruiting and retaining high-quality teachers.
My concern is ensuring that the funding remains sustainable and that implementation is equitable, especially for rural areas like Talbot County. It's essential that all schools receive the resources needed to meet these ambitious goals, with careful oversight to ensure progress and accountability across the state. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Kerry Gunshenan
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Kerry Gunshenan

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Kerry Gunshenan 
 
 442
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Kerry Gunshenan is a regional sales director for Evoke Pharma. She lives in Easton and has served as chairman of the Talbot County Public Schools Advisory Council representing St. Michaels Elementary School and St. Michales Middle and Hight School. She has also served as president of the Advisory Board for St. Michaels YMCA.She has been married for 22 years and has five children ranging from 14 to 20 years old. She is running for the District 6 seat on the Board of Education.
Why are you running for office?
I'm running for office because I have seen a decline in education since my oldest child started in (Talbot County Public Schools). I believe all our children deserve better. No one is going to care more or be more passionate about solving issues that face our schools today than a mother with four children in the system. I care deeply about our schools, I pay attention, and I love our community. I'm a mom who wants to prioritize education and improve outcomes.
What are your priorities if elected?
My top priority is to ensure all students are college or career ready by the time they graduate. I want to see all students obtain critical thinking and problem-solving skills. Additionally, it's important for students to have personal responsibility, financial literacy, strong communication, and respect for themselves and others. With the combination of these skills, our children will have a bright future.
What is the most important issue that Talbot County Public Schools faces and how do you think the board needs to address it?
Candidate choose not to answer.
Talbot County residents have been receiving postcards in the mail criticizing education in the county. What are your thoughts on the postcards and how should these concerns be addressed?
The recent postcards have highlighted the decline in student performance on standardized tests. I believe this is not about placing blame but about transparency.
It brings the issue to the attention of Talbot County residents, which positions us better to solve the problem. Once we realize where we are today, we can determine where we want to go and how to get there. If everyone can unite around a common goal of increasing test scores in reading and math, we can more quickly work together to solve this issue.
What are your thoughts on the Blueprint For Maryland's Future? What concerns or benefits do you see?
The Blueprint for Maryland's future mandates so many requirements that it's difficult for our local school system to continue programs they feel are successful. Having the authority to make decisions at the local level will allow citizens of Talbot County to address the needs of our community schools more effectively.

title: Easton Middle to Pilot Cell Phone Pouches in December
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton Middle to pilot cell phone pouches in December

 October 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 585
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County Public Schools is following the lead of other school districts across the nation and on the Mid-Shore in implementing student cell phone restrictions.Beginning Dec. 2, Easton Middle School will act as the pilot for the district, implementing a cell phone pouch system in which students must lock their phones in pouches during the school day.
Helga Einhorn, TCPS assistant superintendent for school leadership and student success, outlined the pilot plan to Talbot Board of Education members during a Monday work session.
"It should not be a battle in the classroom that our teachers have to engage in to monitor cell phone use, because that takes (away) their time and their expertise in instructing our students," Einhorn said. " … Cell phones seem to be one of the things that is the most problematic to enforce in our schools."
Einhorn noted the work of administrators and staff to research the impacts of cell phone use during school, as well as surveys collected to gauge parent and staff opinions on cell phone usage.
She said surveys conducted by the district showed 94% of parents/guardians and 96% of staff said there should be restrictions on cell phone use during the school day. 90% of parents/guardians and 95% of staff said students should not be allowed to have their phones "visible and usable" during class instruction.
Talbot County is engaging with the company Yondr, also used by the neighboring Caroline and Dorchester county districts, to provide the pouches.
The pouches will be assigned to each student at Easton Middle. Upon entering the school, students will place their phones in the pouches and use a Yondr magnet to lock the pouch. During dismissal, students will use the same magnetic device to unlock the pouches and retrieve their phones.
Einhorn said the district has talked to Yondr representatives about ensuring there are enough magnets in case of an emergency.
"They've been able to share with us some best practices, which include how many magnets you would need per student in the building to be able to effectively and efficiently get students out at the end of the day," Einhorn said.
Like Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said prior to his district's rollout, Einhorn emphasized that cell phones can be a distraction during emergencies.
"We've had conversations and heard from national experts that during a real school emergency, it is actually greater safety risk for 800 students to be pulling out their phones and making phone calls instead of listening to the directions that will help keep them safe," she told board members.
Debbie Gardner, director of communications for Talbot County Public Schools, said each pouch costs about $27. In all, 975 pouches were purchased for a total just below $27,000, "paid for from the local FY24 materials of instruction budget," Gardner said.
Board Vice President Candace Henry asked how long it will take students to put their phones in pouches and retrieve them at the beginning and end of each day. Einhorn and Pepukayi said they expect it will take some time at first but that the process should become simple and streamlined over time.
Easton Middle families will receive more details from the district about the pouch program later this week, and a presentation will be given to students on Friday.
Board Member Deborah Bridges inquired if the pilot program may extend to other schools in the district this year if it is deemed successful.
"I do think we will need to see at least this year what our data is telling us about the impact," Einhorn said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot Board of Ed Approves Funding for Capital Projects, Discusses Turf Field Status
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed approves funding for capital projects, discusses turf field status

 October 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 700
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Following a lengthy discussion last month on the conditions of athletic fields in the district, the Talbot Board of Education moved forward Wednesday in deciding how to allocate available funds toward capital projects, including field improvements.Talbot County Public Schools has $1.5 million in fiscal year 2025 funding from the county meant to put toward capital projects, leaving the decision up to board members on which projects receive that money.
In past meetings, a list of potential projects — which total to $3.36 million — was set to vie for that $1.5 million. Those included Easton High School stadium lights, an Easton Elementary basketball court, a St. Michaels Elementary playground replacement, Easton High auditorium light replacements and an artificial turf field at the high school.
Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones told the board that the first three projects have been funded with grants. On Wednesday, Jones presented a modified list of potential capital projects. The auditorium lights and artificial turf field remained on that list.
Three projects were new to that list on Wednesday: HVAC unit replacements at Easton High for $1,100,000, LED lights at St. Michaels Middle High School for $566,000, and field improvements across the district for $200,000, the latter of which stemmed from concerns raised at a Sept. 18 board meeting about the safety and upkeep of high school fields in the county.
Board President Emily Jackson expressed concern that new projects would continue to usurp side projects, such as the artificial turf field, which is projected to cost around $1.8 million alone.
"Something's always going to take priority, which is why I'm saying (pull from our) fund balance, because that's what it's for, it's for those side projects that are never going to take priority," Jackson said.
Jackson and other board members recognized that the HVAC improvements and LED lights are necessary. Director of Operations Kevin Shafer said the district proposed HVAC improvements in a capital improvement plan to the state, and that the aging units can make it a couple more years before state funding may come through.
Shafer and Jones added that funds for field improvements could be sought through maintenance budget requests or adjustments. Shafer emphasized in order to increase field quality, his team needs better equipment "to do better maintenance."
The board unanimously approved a motion from Jackson to approve $817,321 for Easton High auditorium lights, $566,000 for LED lights at St. Michaels and the remaining $117,000 for athletic field projects in general. The projects will not begin until capital-enabling legislation is approved by the Talbot County Council.
ARTIFICIAL TURF FIELDMuch of Wednesday's back-and-forth between Shafer, Jones and the board centered on the potential of funding an artificial turf field at Easton High. It's a project that has received much community support, including from field hockey players and families.
Some board members suggested the board consider using extra funds the district has to save toward the $1.8 million projected price tag.
"I think we should begin to lay down our concrete plan if that's the way we're going to go, of how we're going to fund it in the future and what that's going to look like," Board Vice President Candace Henry said.
Shafer said that if a new turf field is agreed upon, he believes it should be placed at the current stadium field. Jackson disagreed, citing previous presentations to the board regarding football injury risks on artificial turf.
"We could look at maybe fencing off a different field to make it a more appropriate and safe field for our athletes to be on," Jackson said.
"I would urge the board to consider whether that would be the most equitable use of funds," Shafer responded, "… to just have a turf field for one sport, if it's going to be field hockey or whatever. I question whether that is a good investment in moving forward."
No official motions regarding funding for the turf project were made Wednesday, though Jackson keyed in on pushing the discussion forward.
"Safety for all of our athletes has to be the No. 1 priority," she said. "Number two, very closely following that, is opportunity for our athletes, and I want to make sure that we are giving the most amount of opportunity to the most amount of kids." 

 © Copyright 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Safe Havens of Knowledge
author: Staff Writer
content:
Safe havens of knowledge

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 304
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Thomas Jefferson believed that an informed citizenry was essential to the success of a democracy and the best defense against tyranny. He often stated that "whenever the people are well informed, they can be trusted with their own government."As a country, I believe we should heed the words of our founding father as we head to the polls in November. Our democracy depends on it.
Earlier this month, librarians, booksellers, educators, authors and readers throughout the country participated in Banned Books Week, the annual event that highlights the value of free and open access to information. In preparation, The American Library Association released preliminary data documenting attempts to censor books and materials in public, school, and academic libraries during the first eight months of 2024.
The findings are alarming: Between January 1 and August 31, 2024, ALA tracked 414 attempts to censor library materials and services. In those cases, 1,128 unique titles were challenged. Especially troubling is the fact that 47% of the books targeted for censorship are titles representing the voices and lived experiences of people of color and people who identify as LGBTQ+.
These attempts to silence diverse voices in our community are deliberate, coordinated and dangerous. Public and school libraries should be safe havens of knowledge and information, offering access to a variety of viewpoints and empowering readers to be informed citizens.
This Saturday, Oct. 19, has been designated the Freedom to Read Day of Action by Unite Against Book Bans, an organization dedicated to protecting the First Amendment rights of all Americans (uniteagainstbookbans.org). Concerned citizens can join in the fight against censorship by learning about book bans, reading a banned book or participating in the activities on the website. Above all, we can take the pledge to stand with readers across the U.S. in support of the Freedom to Read and vote.
MARY PELLICANO
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Thoughts on Smart Phone Restrictions in Schools
author: David Reel
content:
Thoughts on smart phone restrictions in schools

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 981
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A recent Pew Research Center survey reports that 95% of teenagers in America have a smart phone or have access to one. It also reports that 45% of teenagers say they are online nearly all the time.Many have suggested this has resulted in a measurable and serious negative impact on the learning environment in middle and high school classrooms. Others have suggested this has resulted in a serious negative impact on standardized student achievement test scores.
As a result, countless school districts in America have put or will be putting new or more restrictions on student smart phones during the school day. Two-thirds of schools in Maryland have already. Talbot County is joining them. Beginning Dec. 2, Easton Middle School will will require students to lock their phones in secure pouches during the school day.
These restrictions have significant public support. Surveys conducted by the Talbot County school district reported 94% of parents/guardians and 96% of staff said there should be restrictions on cell phone use during the school day. 90% of parents/guardians and 95% of staff said students should not be allowed to have their phones "visible and usable" during class instruction.
While I understand and respect these opinions, I suggest restrictions in schools are not addressing more deeply seated roots of the problem.
In his most recent book, "The Anxious Generation How the Great Rewiring of Childhood is Causing an Epidemic of Mental Illness" social psychologist Jonathan Stephen Haidt does a deep dive on a measurable surge in anxiety, depression and suicidal thoughts among American youth.
I understand and respect these decisions. At the same time, I suggest they are not addressing more deeply seated roots of the problem.
In his most recent book, "The Anxious Generation How the Great Rewiring of Childhood is Causing an Epidemic of Mental Illness" social psychologist Jonathan Stephen Haidt does a deep dive on a measurable surge in anxiety, depression, and suicidality among American youth.
In his book Haidt references research showing a measure of anxiety for individuals between ages of 8 to 25 has increased 139% between 2010 and 2020.The measure for depression during the same period, often the result of an inability to resolve interpersonal conflicts or relationship difficulties, has increased 106%.
Haidt suggests three reasons why.
The first is the decline of the what Haidt calls play-based childhood. He maintains children need lots of free play time to prepare them for success as an adult. Out of fears for their safety, many American parents and guardians have reduced children's access to unsupervised free play. The loss of free play and the rise of continual (some may say "smothering") adult supervision has deprived children of what they needed most to overcome the normal fears and anxieties of childhood: the chance to explore, test and expand their limits, build close friendships through shared adventure and learn how to judge risks for themselves.
The second is what Haidt calls rise of the phone-based childhood, which began in the late 2000s and accelerated in the early 2010s. Haidt notes this was precisely the period during which adolescents traded in their flip phones for smartphones. These smartphones were loaded with social media platforms supported by the new high-speed internet and unlimited data plans that has drastically reshaped the social media landscape for adolescents.
The third is what Heidt calls an over reliance on technology that has all but eliminated unstructured face to face interactions from the lives of children and adolescents.
Heidt concludes the negative impact of all three reasons was made worse by many well-intentioned parents, including himself. He writes: "We did not fully understand what was happening in children's virtual worlds and did not grasp that tech companies had designed their online products to be addictive."
As a result, Haidt asserts that all these trends combined, have robbed entire generations of opportunities to develop the resilience, coping skills and independence needed to navigate everyday stressors, and in turn, created unprecedented levels of anxiety at a societal level.
He says these generations have not learned from valuable opportunities to engage in and learn from manageable risks, typical setbacks, failures and healthy social challenges.
What can be done going forward?
Haidt offers the following proactive suggestions for parents and guardians of children in elementary, middle and high schools.
Instead of a giving younger students a smartphone as their first phone, give them a basic phone.
Do not give them a smartphone until high school. Delay the opening of accounts on nearly all social media platforms until the beginning of high school, at least.
Will his suggestions be popular with students? Not likely, especially given the immense power of peer pressure that characterizes life for students in schools at all levels.
One school in Maryland recently surveyed seniors on a new more restrictive smart phone policy to limit the overuse of smart phones during the school day. The questions and answers were: "Do you know overuse of cell phones is harmful? Yes. Do you want to give it up? No."
Are Haidt's suggestions still necessary since efforts are underway when an increasing number of schools are adopting on new or more restrictive rules on smart phone access? Yes.
Despite best intentions and best efforts, schools alone cannot address this problem. One Maryland school district superintendent has observed with thinly disguised frustration — "Students are in school for just 20% of their week. We can't control the other 80% of the time that we don't have them."
Those with some control over most of the other 80% of student's time outside of school are parents and guardians.
Going forward, parents and guardians need to fully embrace two concepts. Success for them is not based on winning a popularity contest with those whom they are entrusted with their care and upbringing. Success for them is measured in part by a willingness to make sometimes unpopular, but necessary decisions on reasonable limits for a young person's own good.
In preparing all our young people for success, they, and our society deserve nothing less.

title: Dorchester Ends Alternative Education Contract in Middle, Elementary Schools
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester ends alternative education contract in middle, elementary schools

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 448
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Cambridge — Four months since the Dorchester County Board of Education voted to terminate its more than three-year contract with an alternative education program for high schoolers, the board has decided to terminate its one-year contract with an alternative education program for elementary and middle school students.At a Board of Education meeting Thursday, the board unanimously voted to terminate its contract with Transforming Lives for convenience. The service provided alternative education for up to 48 Dorchester County Public Schools elementary and middle school students at one time.
Board members did not comment on the decision to terminate the contract at the meeting.
Review of the contract was not originally on Thursday's meeting agenda. The board voted to add it to the agenda after board member Chris Wheedleton made a motion to do so. Later in the meeting, Wheedleton made a motion to terminate the contract for convenience, which the board unanimously voted in favor of.
Wheedleton did not immediately respond for comment on the decision.
According to the contract, either party can terminate it for any or no reason with 60-days advance written notice.
The program, called Positive Change Academy-Dorchester, began this past summer and was set to end June 30, 2025. It is housed at The Judy Center at Sandy Hill Elementary School and at the New Directions Learning Academy. It cost the district $79,000 per month.
The board approved the contract at a special Board of Education meeting in July. At that meeting, district Superintendent Jymil Thompson said the district looked at this program as one stop in a student's education journey. He said it would be a place where students could remedy behavior and improve academics before going back into a "regular educational setting."
The district did not immediately respond for comment on the board's decision.
This is not the first time the board has terminated an alternative education contract in the past year.
In June, the Board of Education voted to terminate its more than three-year contract with Vision Quest, an alternative education program for district high schoolers that had been met with criticism from residents since the contract was approved in September 2023. The district had been paying Vision Quest $93,363 per month for services, which would have added up to over $3.3 million over three years.
The decision to terminate the Vision Quest contract was one of the reasons former Dorchester County Board of Education Vice President Susan Morgan resigned in June. She was the sole vote in favor of keeping the contract. In an interview with the Star Democrat in June, Morgan said the district needed an alternative program for the fall that would benefit the students as much as she witnessed first-hand with the success of Vision Quest. 

 Copyright 2024

title: Group Promotes Extremist Agenda
author: Staff Writer
content:
Group promotes extremist agenda

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 402
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As a former teacher in Talbot County, I find the local school board races concerning. Ironically, hate groups in America like to name themselves after our most deeply held values, while acting against those values. Moms for Liberty (M4L) is one such group.Moms For Liberty has an active chapter here in Talbot County. Nationally, M4L was included as an extremist group by the Southern Poverty Law Center, in its annual report because it advances an anti-student inclusion agenda.
The M4L definition of liberty is that we have the freedom to believe as they do. Our citizens need to know the extremist agenda of M4L evidenced below. Voters need to know that voting for their candidates will turn over the Board of Education majority to M4L.
According to USA Today, the group, which identifies itself as a "parental rights organization," is known for calls to ban books in schools. Founded in Florida, three members have been named to the Department of Education workgroup that oversees school libraries. One cannot help but wonder how influential they were in developing the new standards that require students be taught that being enslaved was beneficial to Black Americans because it helped them acquire new skills.
I encourage you to speak with local Black citizens to hear their views on this.
It is critical in this election year that Talbot County voters reject the three candidates supported by the local Moms for Liberty chapter. I have seen the posts claiming that M4L supports, but doesn't endorse these candidates.
Either these candidates did no homework into M4L or they know their agenda and concur. In my opinion, either option disqualifies Ann O'Connor, Karla Wieland-Cherry and Kerry Gunshenan. Candidates who can't be bothered to understand the agenda of the groups that support them are potential pawns in the hands of extremists. Candidates who agree with M4L would engulf our system in culture wars that do nothing to advance the education of our children.
If you live in a district with a school board race this election, one of these three names will appear: Candace Henry, Anna Howie or Cynthia Marrah Jurrius. I respectfully ask you to vote for one of them.
I can promise you that the educators in this county truly want what is best for our children, and they are the ones qualified to make decisions about their education.
Moms for Liberty's hateful rhetoric and anti-inclusive agenda does not belong anywhere in our schools.
TARA LEESON
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 6 Candidates Vie for 3 Seats on Talbot Board of Education
author: Staff Writer
content:
6 candidates vie for 3 seats on Talbot Board of Education

 October 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 143
 Words

 The Talbot County's Board of Education has three position on the ballot in this year general election. Voters will select Board of Education members for Districts 2, 5 and 6.There are currently six candidates running with a variety of experience and goals for Talbot County Public Schools. The positions are elected on a non-partisan basis.
Each position will serve a four-year term beginning Dec. 1, and ending Dec. 1, 2028. Early voting for the 2024 general election begins Thursday, Oct. 24, and runs through Thursday, Oct. 31, from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. at the Easton Fire House Bingo Hall.
Election Day will be Nov. 5, and voters can cast their ballots at their assigned polling place, which can be found at talbotcountymd.org.

title: Should Maryland Schools Ban Cellphones?
author: Sasha Allen and Audrey Keefe Capital News Service
content:
Should Maryland schools ban cellphones?

 October 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sasha Allen and Audrey Keefe Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1407
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "FOCUS NOW! PHONES LATER," blares the newest school cellphone policy out of Washington County.This "clear message" debuted on the county's website in August, kicking off the 2024 school year with stricter limitations on personal electronic devices.
That message is one that resonates with Maryland's school board candidates. Of the 74 candidates who responded to the Local News Network's campaign questionnaire, 64 favored strict restrictions on cellphones in schools, and only 10 expressed reservations about limiting cellphone use or touted their positive aspects.
Board candidates cited a number of reasons — ranging from disciplinary issues to cyberbullying to phone addiction — for ordering students to put their phones out of sight.
Some candidates offered nuanced proposals for limiting cellphone use — but support for greater restrictions spans the state, from large counties to small.

title: Maryland School Board Candidates Push for Officers, Mental Health Services
author: Emily R. Condon and Max Schaeffer Capital News Service
content:
Maryland school board candidates push for officers, mental health services

 October 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Emily R. Condon and Max Schaeffer Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1315
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In Montgomery County, school board candidate Brenda M. Diaz worries that "knife-wielding vandals" have easy access to schools because the district removed the police officers that are on hand in the rest of Maryland's public school districts to try to keep the peace.Across the state on the Eastern Shore, school board candidate Karla Wieland-Cherry of Talbot County told the Local News Network in a candidate survey that teachers feel threatened by some of their students.
And in Howard County, school board candidate Andrea Chamblee — whose husband, John McNamara, was shot to death in the 2018 mass shooting at the Capital Gazette in Annapolis — said the threat of a school shooting is just one of the stressors looming over the county's children.
"Bullying, mental health struggles, technology addiction, unreliable transportation, larger class sizes, fewer fine art enrichment opportunities, portable classrooms, overcrowding, poorly maintained buildings, food insecurity, poor indoor air quality and bigotry are all eroding the well-being of our students and staff," Chamblee said. "Students who aren't well, can't learn well. In order to focus on academics, we must take on these safety challenges and provide students and staff with a stable learning environment."
Concern about school safety in Maryland spans the state — which is why candidates in Maryland's school district races are stressing the issue. Of the 74 candidates who replied to a Local News Network questionnaire, 48 said they were not entirely satisfied with school safety in their district. Many called for adding more law enforcement officers as well as mental health counselors to their local schools.
Diaz advocates returning school resource officers to Montgomery County schools — but statistics, and the comments of school board candidates statewide, make clear that school safety and student behavior aren't easily controlled just by in-school cops.
School safety at a glanceThe school safety problem is a national one. Violent incidents increased 49% in the nation's schools the 2023-2024 school year, according to the Educator's School Safety Network.
Maryland has not yet released its 2023-2024 statistics, but in the 2022-2023 school year, the number of anonymously reported bullying or cyberbullying incidents rose over the prior year from 91 to 107 , according to the Maryland Center for School Safety. The number of assaults and threats to cause harm increased from 83 to 98. And the number of general school safety complaints shot up from 62 to 104.
The school safety center also tracks critical life threatening incidents, which are defined as incidents that cause death or serious injury, or acts of mass violence under law. These incidents for the past three school years totaled 17, 18 and 18.
Among those incidents are the following:
On Oct. 27, 2023, at a Baltimore City high school, a student worked in tandem with both of his parents to assault and shoot three other students.In April 2024, Montgomery County Police arrested a high school senior who had written a 129-page manifesto on his plans for a school shooting.In January 2024, a high school student was arrested after threatening mass violence and arson at the school, the Somerset County Sheriff's Office said. The student had previously been caught with a gun at school, according to a county press release.
School board candidate Matthew Warren Lankford, whose son was in the school at the time of that last incident, said that student is now back in school. "This student needs special attention and should never be allowed back in the school as a normal student again," Lankford said.
School resource officers
School resource officers, the official name for trained officers in schools under Maryland's 2019 Safe to Learn Act, are posted in some schools in every Maryland jurisdiction except Montgomery County. And many school board candidates expressed support for hiring more school resource officers.
"I am satisfied with the safety for the big, catastrophic-type events," said Jaime Brennan, a Frederick County school board candidate. "But I am not satisfied with the daily acts of violence…that occur. I think that expanding the school resource officer program so that we have a designated SRO in each middle and high school would help."
The Maryland Center for School Safety is responsible for training school resource officers in the state and reports each year on their coverage in schools. The overall number of schools with a full-time officer on hand increased from 273 in 2021-2022 to 288 in the 2022-2023 school year.
In Calvert County, another candidate who is running for reelection, Antoine White, said he meets regularly with his board's safety liaison and local sheriff's department. White voted to increase the number of school resource officers in his district.
But another candidate in Calvert County, Paul Harrison, said he is not content with the lack of armed officers in six schools and pledged to try to fill those gaps.
In contrast, Montgomery County ended its school resource officer program in 2021 amid concerns that students of color were being disproportionately disciplined. The district now has a community engagement officer program, in which officers patrol near schools and enter schools as needed.
A PTA president running for the school board in the county, Rita Montoya, said the officers allowed in schools must be properly vetted.
"Providing opportunities for healthy and positive engagement between students and officers is another necessary step," Montoya said.
More school districts opt for a constant, visible law enforcement presence. Worcester County Board of Education member Jon M. Andes touted his district as the first in the state to have school resource officers.
"We need to continue work with our law enforcement partners, enhance our summer safe schools retreat, and strengthen our proactive approach to preventing problems," said Andes, who is running for reelection.
Conversely, Gerry LaFemina worries about the use of officers in schools in Allegany County, where he is running for the school board.
"I loathe the idea of making our schools seem like they're under attack because that provides an atmosphere ripe for distraction," he said. "I also worry about the use of police in the schools, which can often lead to escalation of problems rather than mediated solutions."
Other than LaFemina, none of the 74 candidates who replied to a Local News Network survey questioned or opposed assigning police officers to schools.
More counselors?Many candidates made clear, though, that school resource officers can't solve the school safety problem alone. Twenty-five candidates mentioned increased mental health or counseling intervention as an important step in their survey response.
"Schools should prioritize not only physical safety but also students' social and emotional well-being," said Tiffini Andorful, a Prince George's County school board candidate. "This could include increasing the number of support staff and providing access to resources and training to effectively handle conflicts. I also think there should be a greater emphasis on emergency preparedness and increased advocacy for gun control at higher levels."
Many also emphasized the importance of building a healthy school atmosphere beginning when students are young.
"We really need to focus on social-emotional learning and fostering a culture of acceptance of others from the youngest grades and up," said Erica McFarland, an Anne Arundel County candidate.
McFarland said she feels that this type of focus can help to prevent bullying, a common reason for students to feel unsafe at school.
Meg Ricks, a candidate in Howard County, said increased counseling services would likely stem other problems, too.
"We must start while students are young to give them tools for dealing with conflict and seeking help when needed," she said in her survey response. "I would like to see more counselors in our schools so that we can provide students with productive solutions to the challenges they are facing."
At the same time, 13 candidates statewide said that the secret to solving the school safety puzzle lies not just in school resource officers and mental health services, but in old-fashioned school discipline.
"We need to re-address school discipline measures and take improved steps to reduce the threats and in some cases, violence," Wieland-Cherry of Talbot County said. "Teaching and learning cannot take place in an environment (where) one feels unsafe." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Is Maryland’s ‘Blueprint’ the Path to Better Schools?
author: Marwa Barakat and Colin McNamara Capital News Service
content:
Is Maryland’s ‘Blueprint’ the path to better schools?

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Marwa Barakat and Colin McNamara Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1365
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A 10-year, $30 billion plan out of Annapolis, the Blueprint for Maryland's Future aims to dramatically improve the state's public schools by boosting teacher salaries, expanding pre-kindergarten and rewriting the curriculum — and school board candidates say the state's schools need that improvement."The Blueprint is Maryland's surest path to creating beyond great schools," said Phelton Moss, a school board candidate from Prince George's County.
But to hear other Maryland school board candidates tell it, the Blueprint is a budget-buster.
"The Blueprint sounds great on paper; however, funding it is a great challenge for every county in Maryland," St. Mary's County school board candidate Elena Brewer said.
That debate echoes across Maryland as voters in 20 of the state's 24 school districts prepare to go to the polls. The Local News Network at the University of Maryland sent a questionnaire to all 109 candidates, asking them, among other things, to name the state's top education issue.
Forty-two of the candidates who responded to the questionnaire expressed concerns about the costs and the mandates stemming from the Blueprint. In a school board election where there are no races in Baltimore City or County, a Prince George's County candidate, Zakyia Goins-McCants, summed up the views of a number of candidates from suburban and rural districts.
"The Blueprint for Maryland's Future is transformative legislation that reflects our state's commitment to equitable education," she said. "However, it was passed without a full funding plan, and the financial implications are significant."
'A transformational investment'Passed by the General Assembly in 2021 over the veto of then-Gov. Larry Hogan, a Republican, the Blueprint is built on five pillars. Under the Blueprint, school districts are mandated to:
Combat the teacher shortage by increasing the minimum teacher salary to $60,000 by July 2026 and build new "career ladders" for educators.Expand pre-kindergarten so that it's available free to low- and moderate-income families and available to all.Adjust the curriculum to ensure students are college- and career-ready by the end of 10th grade.Implement a "ninth-grade tracker" system to assess how the Blueprint is working for each student as part of a statewide accountability plan.Boost funding to match the state's lofty new goals.
Hearing all of that, many of the state's school board candidates said the Blueprint is a great but complex and pricey plan.
Tierney Davis, a board candidate from Cecil County, called the Blueprint "a transformational idea" but noted there are serious issues in implementing the plan. Veronica Lowe from Frederick County called it "a transformative investment in our education system" but expressed concerns about funding the effort.
Michael Shisler from Calvert County said the plan is a chance to "improve our common good."
"If we continue to see education as a cost, rather than as an investment, then folks will just wait for this latest reform to fade away," Shisler said. "The Blueprint is an opportunity to level the playing field for all kids in Maryland."
Several candidates said that the playing field needs leveling.
"The most important issue facing Anne Arundel County Public Schools is the existence of persistent gaps in opportunity and achievement between different subgroups of students," said Joanna Bache Tobin of Anne Arundel County.
Meanwhile, Julie Kaplan of Howard County said schools must improve to make sure every student leaves school prepared for college or a career.
"We must address the learning gaps created by the COVID-19 pandemic," she said.
A number of candidates cited stagnant or declining test scores in their school districts and beyond.
"Statewide, our student proficiency rates in math and English are suffering," said Laura McKenzie of Kent County.
But schools will improve if the Blueprint is implemented properly, its supporters said.
"The Blueprint offers us an opportunity to invest in our schools and ensure an excellent education for every student," said Meg Ricks, a candidate for the school board in Howard County.
'Unfunded'Support for the Blueprint was by no means uniform among the state's school board candidates, however. Many echoed the thoughts of Andre Gao, another Howard County school board candidate.
"The Blueprint for Maryland's Future sounds promising on paper with its goals, but the funding presents a significant problem," Gao said. "Without adequate financial support, implementing the Blueprint will be challenging."
The Blueprint lacks financial support at both the state and the district level.
The General Assembly approved the Blueprint without determining how it would be paid for, and as a result, the state is projected to run long-term deficits that largely track its increased education costs. A state Department of Legislative Services fiscal briefing released in January said that the deficit will appear in fiscal 2025 and hit nearly $2.93 billion in fiscal 2029 — a year when the Blueprint is set to cost the state $4 billion.
Rachel Hise, the executive director of the Blueprint's Accountability and Implementation Board, said she is hopeful the Maryland General Assembly will fully fund the Blueprint and is willing to make changes if necessary.
When asked whether state taxes will be raised to support the Blueprint, Hise said, "That is a decision for the governor and General Assembly."
Against that backdrop, Gov. Wes Moore — a longtime proponent of the Blueprint — has acknowledged that the plan may have to be altered.
"While I believe in making sure that we have a world-class education system, we've got to be able to work together to create an actual plan to be able to implement it because right now there are real challenges in being able to get that done and get it done in a way that the locals, and the state and every other partner who's involved sees that taking place," Moore told Fox45 News in Baltimore in July. "So, there have to be adjustments."
Meanwhile, school district candidates said the Blueprint is already putting pressure on local school budgets, given that school costs in Maryland are shared by the state and its 24 districts.
"While the Blueprint was touted as significantly increasing education funding, the reality is that the funding is not distributed equitably, and rural counties have been left out, by and large," said Cathy Allen, a school board candidate in St. Mary's County. "We did not receive increased funding from the state to cover mandates within the Blueprint."
'So many requirements'School board candidates said they worry not only about the Blueprint's costs, but also about the expensive edicts the plan imposes on local school districts. In some cases, they said, those mandates are already leading to unintended consequences.
Jon M. Andes, a candidate in Worcester County, said he fully supports the Blueprint's five pillars.
"However, without additional state funding, we will not be able to implement the Blueprint plan without making significant budget cuts to reallocate funds," Andes said. "As an example, to reach the $60,000 minimum (teacher) salary, we will need to significantly increase class size and reduce materials of instruction."
Such things are already happening in Howard County, Gao said.
"In our school district, we have not received sufficient funding from the state and county to fully implement the Blueprint," he said. "This has contributed to budget shortfalls, leading to staff cuts, program reductions and increased class sizes. Many teachers have already expressed concerns about the negative impact of staff shortages and increased class sizes."
Such issues stem from the fact that the Blueprint mandates that funding be redirected in a number of ways. For one thing, by mandating higher teacher salaries and a host of other changes, some school districts may be forced to cut other popular programs.
"The Blueprint for Maryland's Future mandates so many requirements that it's difficult for our local school system to continue programs it feels are successful," said Kerry Gunshenan, a school board candidate in Talbot County.
In addition, the Blueprint mandates that districts direct more funding to schools with larger numbers of high-need students, such as those that are performing poorly or where students are learning to speak English.
Mike Lukas, a board member who is running for re-election in Charles County, praised that change.
"Your ZIP code or household income should not define the quality of your education," he said.
Tom Woods, who is running for re-election to the board in Garrett County, neatly summed up the thoughts of many of the school board members across the state.
"The ideas and solutions presented by the Blueprint come with an awful lot of obstacles," Woods said.
Local News Network director Jerry Zremski contributed to this report. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Author Empowering Young Voices
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Author empowering young voices

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 496
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Author and educator Jessieca Montgomery is making significant strides in the realm of children's literature with her innovative series of coloring and activity books focused on public speaking for kids in grades kindergarten through 5.A news release said that "by combining creativity with essential communication skills, the Charles County resident is helping young learners build confidence and express themselves effectively."
As an educator with years of experience in teaching public speaking and communication skills, she recognized a gap in engaging resources tailored specifically for young learners, which led her to create a series that not only teaches essential skills, but also makes learning enjoyable and accessible.
The series consists of several titles, each designed to engage children in a fun, interactive way while introducing them to the fundamentals of public speaking.
Key titles include:
"Speak and Shine: A Coloring Adventure in Public Speaking" — This introductory book invites kids to explore the world of public speaking through colorful illustrations and interactive coloring activities. Each section provides simple lessons on key concepts such as voice projection, body language, and audience engagement, all while allowing children to express their creativity through art.
"Confidence in Every Word: Activity Book for Young Speakers" — In this activity book, Montgomery incorporates engaging puzzles, games, and scenarios that encourage kids to practice their speaking skills. Activities range from creating short speeches to role-playing different speaking situations, empowering children to build confidence and develop effective communication strategies.
"The Little Speaker's Toolkit: Coloring and Crafting Your Speech" — This book combines creative expression with practical speech preparation. Children are guided through the process of developing their own speeches, with templates for brainstorming ideas and spaces to illustrate their thoughts. By emphasizing storytelling and personal experiences, kids understand the importance of connecting with their audience.
Montgomery's books, which reflects her commitment to inclusivity and representation, feature diverse characters and relatable scenarios, allowing children from various backgrounds to see themselves in the material. This approach not only fosters engagement, but also helps to build a sense of belonging and confidence in young readers.
Public speaking is a vital skill that lays the foundation for effective communication, critical thinking, and self-confidence. Montgomery's series highlights the significance of these skills from a young age, equipping children with the tools they need to articulate their thoughts, advocate for themselves, and participate actively in discussions. By making public speaking approachable and fun, she encourages children to embrace their voices.
Montgomery's series of coloring and activity books on public speaking is a remarkable contribution to children's literature and education. Through her engaging and creative approach, she is nurturing a new generation of confident communicators who are ready to express their unique perspectives.
By inspiring kids to find their voices and share their stories, Montgomery is not only shaping their futures but also empowering them to shine in all areas of their lives. Her work is a testament to the to the transformative power of education and the importance of fostering communication skills in every child.
For more information, go to www.speakezforkids.com.

title: Parties Should Stay Out of School Elections
author: David Reel
content:
Parties should stay out of school elections

 October 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: David Reel | Section: Columns 
 
 767
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The official voter guide and sample ballot of the Talbot County Board of Elections for Talbot County voters includes the following introduction on upcoming Board of Education elections:Non-Partisan Contest
Candidates in this contest may or may not be affiliated with any political party.
This election cycle, at least four Maryland political party organizations will be involved in local Board of Education elections at significantly different levels.
One is the Maryland Democratic Party. Recently Maryland Matters reported "The Maryland Democratic Party will spend 'tens of thousands of dollars' targeting at least eighteen school board candidates that they maintain are looking to bring a 'hateful' and 'right-wing agenda' to schools." The article noted the Maryland Democratic Party has never before been involved in nonpartisan races for local boards of education.
The article also noted the Maryland Democratic Party plan includes hiring workers to canvass, knock on doors and urge voters not to elect 26 school board candidates whom the Maryland Democratic Party says support rewriting history, discriminating against kids and book bans. The Maryland Democratic Party will also provide resources to local Democratic central committees for helping candidates who support "Democratic and inclusive values."
Nowhere currently on the Maryland Democratic Party website is a definition of "Democratic values," nor a mention of supporting candidates who back efforts to improve student achievement scores and ensure safe classroom learning environments.
Maryland Democratic Party leaders say this unprecedented initiative is needed to fight "extremist" agendas favored by certain candidates in 11 Maryland counties — Anne Arundel, Calvert, Carroll, Frederick, Howard, Montgomery, St. Mary's and Talbot. The party also plans to warn against eight other candidates in Allegany, Cecil and Washington counties.
In Anne Arundel County, the Maryland Democratic Party has identified three candidates as "extreme" candidates who not only support book bans but are also against those in the LGBTQ community. In a post on "X," the Maryland Democratic Party has referred to the three candidates as the "Anne Arundel Hate Slate."
The Maryland Democratic Party is not the first or only political organization to target candidates in school board elections. At least three Republican County Central Committees have either done it or are doing it, albeit on a much smaller scale than the Maryland Democratic Party.
In this election cycle, the Talbot County Republican Central Committee has paid for a vote early for the school board mailer promoting a school board candidate candidate. The Cecil County Republican Committee endorsed three school Republican board candidates in 2022. The Calvert County Republican Central Committee endorsed Republican school board candidates in at least two election cycles — 2022 and 2024.
Going forward, it is impossible to predict if, how or how much, state, and local political party organizations may be involved in local board of education elections and what their campaign messages may be.
Some may suggest state and local political party organizations have a right to endorse and support local school board candidates.
They do have that right. The larger question is if they will exercise that right in the correct way.
The correct way is embracing the principle of civil discourse even with those who hold widely differing opinions. In other words — agree to disagree without being disagreeable.
Incorrect ways include referring to certain school board candidates as the "Anne Arundel Hate Slate" and targeting at least 18 school board candidates who are characterized as looking to bring a "hateful" and "right-wing agenda" to school boards.
Our society is already dealing with deeply held and seemingly irreconcilable differences on a wide range of public policy issues based largely on vitriolic and divisive messaging from political party organizations. Their continued involvement in local school board elections is almost guaranteed to generate even more divisiveness.
Voter access to information to make informed voting decisions is not an issue.
Voters already have numerous opportunities to research and evaluate every school board candidate's background, experience and views on what they consider to be the most critical issues of the day, as well as their positions, or lack of positions, on those issues.
These opportunities include but are not limited to information posted on candidate websites, candidate campaign literature, candidate meet and greets and candidate forums where all candidates are invited to speak and answer questions from attendees. Voters can use all these opportunities to draw their own conclusions on which candidates have views on education matters that resonate best with their views.
Voters do not need any political organizations to make those conclusions for them. Let the voters and the voters alone decide.
Accordingly, with regard to all future local school board elections, no state and no local political party organizations need to be or should be involved in any way in those elections. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses political party involvement in local school board elections, focusing on the governance of K–12 education, making Education the most relevant category.

title: Experience, Transparency Needed
author: Staff Writer
content:
Experience, transparency needed

 October 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 387
 Words 

 Read News Document

 With so much attention on the presidential election, it's easy to forget the importance of local, down-ballot races. But decisions with direct impacts on our lives are made at the town and county level, and these elections deserve our thoughtful consideration. The upcoming Talbot County school board election is a prime example.I live in District 2, whose northern edge extends to Port Street, includes the southern part of Easton's historic district, neighborhoods around Idlewild Park and Easton High, much of the east side of Route 50, including Mulberry Station and south to Dutchman's Lane. The choice for us is between Candace Henry and Ann O'Connor.
Initially undecided, I tuned into the candidate forum. It was clear that both candidates are well-liked in the community, but it was also clear that Ms. Henry is vastly more knowledgeable about the state of our schools and the actions the school board is taking to improve them. Quite simply, she is the more qualified candidate.
For example, when Ms. O'Connor suggested asking departing teachers their reason for leaving, Ms. Henry pointed out that exit interviews are conducted and used to improve teacher retention. This pattern repeated itself several times, with Ms. Henry having specific answers where Ms. O'Connor did not. Ms. Henry also shared that teachers are already involved in curriculum development, something Ms. O'Connor suggested as a new idea.
But the flyers have made the decision crystal clear. You know what I'm talking about. Our mailboxes have been inundated with them. All contain cherry-picked data about test scores and spending with zero context. Lately these flyers have taken a turn toward incredible as they discuss "required reading" in third grade. Incredible meaning not credible.
The information in these mailers is designed to shock the recipient and the secretive nature of their funding raises red flags. A brief online search about the sponsor "Pay Attention America" leads only to a short-term office space in Wilmington, Delaware. Then last week a Republican friend showed me a flyer she had just received, authorized and paid for by the 1776 Project, a radical far-right group. They were endorsing Ms. O'Connor by name (as well as Karla Wieland-Cherry and Kerry Gunshenan, candidates for school board in Districts 5 and 6, respectively).
I'm voting for Candace Henry. We need experience and transparency on the school board, not hidden agendas.
ALISON SANFORD
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: An Open Letter on Recent Education Mailers
author: Sharon Pepukayi and Emily Jackson Talbot County Public Schools
content:
An open letter on recent education mailers

 October 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SHARON PEPUKAYI and EMILY JACKSON Talbot County Public Schools | Section: Columns 
 
 534
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Dear Talbot County Community,We would like to address the recent mailers that have been distributed to homes throughout our community. This campaign unfairly targets our schools, students, and dedicated Talbot County Public Schools educators.
Our team does face challenges like many school districts, and we face them directly and with transparency. While we do not want to give life to these messages you are receiving, we want to make sure our community knows the truth.
We are working to improve our performance on state assessments. With support from the Talbot County Council, we have made significant investments, including acquiring new rigorous standards-based curricula and hiring and retaining qualified teachers and administrators. Additionally, we have made math one of our priorities and are putting concentrated efforts into the teaching and learning of this curricular area. We also know that student success is measured by many indicators in addition to state assessment scores.
While we know we have work to do, there is growth we can celebrate. The 23-24 Maryland Comprehensive Assessment results showed modest improvement across all Maryland districts. In Talbot County, our overall margin of progress was slightly greater than what the state achieved. In English/Language Arts, out of the 24 school districts, Talbot County Public Schools had the greatest increase in students being proficient. These results inform our continued work on the initiatives put in place to provide our educators with the resources needed to ensure student success.
We adhere to the Health Education Standards set forth by the Maryland Department of Education. Maryland state law requires that parents/guardians be notified about topics covered in the Family Life unit. They have the option of having their student excused if they are uncomfortable with this content being taught to their students by TCPS educators.
Our Talbot County students graduate from our high schools and continue to excel in college, career and life. This is a result of their hard work, the commitment of the TCPS team, the leadership of the Board of Education and the support of the County Council and our many community partners.
Our support staff, teachers and administrators are dedicated professionals who deserve our trust and support. By collaborating openly and constructively, we can ensure that our school system remains a beacon of opportunity and excellence for every child, regardless of their background.
We invite the community to our established public forums scheduled each month through our regular Board of Education meetings. These meetings are open to all citizens, and we encourage everyone to attend and participate in these sessions. Only through collaboration and communication do we truly provide the best opportunities for our students.
We are honored to serve as Talbot County's superintendent of schools and president of the Board of Education, and we are very proud of our students and staff. We believe in and will continue to advocate for TCPS students, families and educators. We are TCPS, and we are committed to transforming and performing together.
If you have questions or concerns, please email us at info@talbotschools.org. We are here for you and all of the children of Talbot County. Thank you for your continued support.
Sharon Pepukayi is the superintendent of Talbot County Public Schools. Emily Jackson is president of the Talbot County Board of Education. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Students Learn to Build and Sell in CBMM's Rising Tide After-School Program
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Students learn to build and sell in CBMM's Rising Tide After-School program

 October 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — The holiday season has come early at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, and boys and girls of a variety of ages are working diligently to craft wooden Christmas trees, stockings, snowmen and marine life to sell as ornaments.As schools across the nation are closing vocational skill programs, the museum's Rising Tide After-School program is filling the gap by providing middle school students the opportunity to learn marketing and vocational skills under the supervision of dedicated volunteers.
This program lasts seven weeks and caters to students in grades six through nine. The students learn project design and development, team collaboration tool management and workshop safety.
Alyssa Zajan, the student and public programs manager, said the students choose the projects they work on for the duration of the program.
"This year, they got in the holiday spirit, so they've been making ornaments," Zajan said. "They've been hand cutting them, using hand saws, as well as some of our saws and our power saws, and decorating them. And they're going to market them to the community."
The ornaments will be included in the museum's store. Students will be choosing price points and learning marketing skills.
All proceeds for the ornaments will go back into the program to help it continue.
According to Jill Ferris, Rising Tide's vice president of education and interpretation, the program began in 2017 as a boat building program and has evolved to better serve the core mission of providing middle school students in Talbot County a fun and safe environment where they can access skills education.
Ferris said schools in the area have not been in the position to provide the vocation training they had in the past. The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum sought to provide that kind of experience for students to be able to work with mentors and educators and learn different skills.
"How do we connect students and help them develop skills to be the future leaders and pursue pathways that they are interested in, and so the idea of taking an entrepreneurial pathway was one that we just thought was really fun and would be really resonant for the kids," Ferris said.
The program runs on a quarterly basis, with the next session opening in January 2025. Ferris said accessibility is a core value of the program, and participants are offered partial to full scholarships as well as transportation for students who live outside of St. Michaels.
Harper Black, a student in the program, said she has enjoyed being in the program and is happy with the work she has been able to accomplish.
"It's really cool to work with things you haven't experienced yet," Black said. "Because you don't have the materials at home. So it's cool to come here and do it." 

 © Copyright 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: School Mailing Accusations Are False
author: Staff Writer
content:
School mailing accusations are false

 November 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 391
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Talbot county residents have recently been receiving U.S. Postal Service mailings questioning the quality of teaching in our county's public schools. Among its many criticisms, the glossy mailings falsely decry the low English and math proficiency and attribute these low scores to time wasted "forcing harmful gender ideology" on students.Here are some facts: 39% of students in Talbot County are classified as "economically disadvantaged" (data gathered by US News and World Report), and 40% are members of a minority. Fully 14% of students study English as a second language. Talbot County Public Schools is one of only eight districts out of the 24 in Maryland that earned star ratings of three or higher for all schools. (reportcard.msde.maryland.gov)
In 2023 Talbot County Schools boasted an attendance rate of 91.5% and a high school graduation rate of 95%. Schools also showed year over year improvement in academic achievement. These are numbers to be proud of, not scorned.
So where are these accusations and false claims coming from? They are originating from a group identifying itself as "Pay Attention America Inc." with a postal address listed as 1000 N. West St, Suite 1200, Wilmington, Delaware. In its mailings, it cites the "Daily Citizen" whose director of communications claims: "God has declared certain things 'good' and certain things 'bad.' He's given us clear principles to use in considering current events. And He's spoken clearly on the subjects of life, marriage, law and government. We cannot remain morally neutral in our reporting."
Are we all to believe that God has spoken directly to the Daily Citizen and told it what is good and what is bad and facts are irrelevant? The mailings scream "radical politicians are pushing extreme radical agendas" and "radical indoctrination" of children is taking place in the schools.
Unfortunately, our public schools make an easy target for out of state organizations with a defined political agenda. It is sad that their misrepresentations and slurs seek to divide our community instead of seeking solutions in a positive, fact-based approach. We believe it is important, more now than ever, to make decisions based on facts, not gobbledygook.
Ultimately, we question why a Delaware religious organization finds it necessary to alarm us when all Talbot citizens have to do is simply talk to our teachers and our school administrators about our concerns.
That is how local control works.
JIM WILKINS
MARTHA HAMLYN
JIM RICHARDSON
Claiborne 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses false mailings criticizing the quality of teaching in Talbot County public schools, providing school performance data and addressing education policy issues, making Education the most appropriate category.

title: Relationships Key to Positive Change
author: Staff Writer
content:
Relationships key to positive change

 November 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 241
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I am writing in wholehearted support of Candace Henry for Talbot County School Board, District 2.At the recent candidate forum hosted by the Talbot Spy, I was impressed with the level of preparation by Ms. Henry, as well as the depth of understanding that she reflected regarding the current issues facing school staff, students and families.
While Ms. O'Connor is unquestionably a compassionate parent and well respected member of the community, these qualities are insufficient to address the complex challenges facing public schools today.
Candace Henry has demonstrated throughout her tenure on the school board that relationships with students, teachers, parents and staff are the key to positive change. Ms. Henry has an in-depth knowledge of the Talbot County community and all of its diversity, as well as an informed understanding of state level issues and initiatives.
She has actually read the Maryland Blueprint for Education and has the ability to conceptualize the strengths and challenges of its implementation. She uses data to develop a solid plan for ensuring that resources and supports are targeted to students who need them most, that all students have access to challenging academics and that all voices are heard and understood.
I urge District 2 voters to choose their candidate wisely. Like her opponent, Candace Henry is also a compassionate parent and well respected member of the community, but is without a doubt the standout choice based on her experience, knowledge and resounding endorsement from the TCEA.
EMILY MOODY
Easton

title: Your Vote Matters
author: Staff Writer
content:
Your vote matters

 November 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 384
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Talbot County non-parents: Your vote counts just as much as those of county parents on Election Day. I urge you to learn about your school board candidates and what they stand for.I'm not a mother, but I feel strongly about voting for the best candidate for my school board district (District 2). That candidate is Candace Henry.
As the product of public schools from Grades 5-12 myself, I want someone on the board who is interested in creating a diverse, inviting and equitable atmosphere for all children in every classroom.
As a librarian by training, I feel strongly about access to information and books for all. Parents who want to have a say in their children's reading material should have that, but that desire should not interfere with anyone else's access to information. The transparency and opportunity already exist for those who want to examine and/or opt out of certain materials.
As a county resident, I am invested in the futures of its students. The best future for them, and for the rest of us, is for students to have equal access to high-quality educational materials and opportunities for success. As our future citizens and leaders, they should be learning empathy.
Candace Henry is the incumbent District 2 candidate. She brings decades of experience in education to the board. As a TCPS graduate and mother of current county public school students, she is dedicated to the success of the school system and every student therein.
While the race for school board is non-partisan, the opposition candidate is backed by Moms for Liberty. This group focuses on policing access to materials that promote diversity, minorities and marginalized groups. They seek to remove protections for LGBTQ+ students when they are at their most vulnerable. They seek to divide, restrict and exclude.
Candace Henry is running on a platform of excellence, equity and inclusivity for all students in Talbot County. If you are in District 2, please vote to reelect Candace Henry to the school board. Anna Howie and Cynthia Jurrius are the other two candidates to support in their respective districts. They are also running against Moms for Liberty-supported candidates.
Your vote matters. Please be ready to make selections for every position up for a vote on the ballot. Be sure to vote for the candidate who best represents your values.
MISSY CORLEY
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
