title: 'Rare Birds': Apprentices Learn the Boat Building Ropes at CBMM
author: Staff Writer
content:
'Rare birds': Apprentices learn the boat building ropes at CBMM

 December 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 595
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum's Shipyard announced the graduation of Seip Family Foundation Shipwright Apprentices Kaeo Clarke and Carstan Gage from its state-accredited program.Both have joined the full-time staff at CBMM as shipwrights.
"Kaeo and Carstan embody the spirit of this program," Vessel Conservation Manager Sam Hilgartner said. "It's both earthy and dreamy. It's monotonous, tedious, and humbling, but also stimulating, uplifting, and gratifying. Kaeo and Carstan have moved through everything that it is, and they've come out of the other end of it in good working order, perfectly capable, and with plenty of enthusiasm to keep on going."
Clarke is a native of Annapolis. His father runs the Oak Harbor Marina in Pasadena, Maryland and he was working there in 2021, learning the basics of maintenance and rigging on modern metal and fiberglass vessels, when he applied for the apprenticeship in CBMM's Shipyard to learn the trade of wooden boat building.
"In my interview, I said that I'm much better at moving boats than building them," Clarke said. "I still don't consider myself an expert at woodworking or boat building, but I can tell you that I know a whole lot more now than I did when I got here."
He's also worked on the Maryland Dove build and the refit of Chesapeake Bay buyboat Winnie Estelle.
"It's an honor to be part of Dove's story," Clarke said. "There are a couple portions of that boat I can point at and say, 'Yeah, I did that.'"
Gage is from Oregon and made the cross-country move to CBMM in August 2022 with a design degree and experience working as a carpenter but little familiarity with boats.
"I would say the community is a big part of why I was able to succeed here," Gage said. "All of the people here are very helpful, and they've created an atmosphere where it's OK to take your time and really learn.
Gage has spent most of his time at CBMM focused on helping to maintain its floating fleet. One of the highlights was getting the historic skipjack Rosie Parks fit for sailing for the first time in several years, which included replacing sections of the sheer clamp, side planking, and deck boards, CBMM said in an announcement.
Gage sailed on Rosie Parks this fall to the skipjack race in Cambridge and Sultana Downrigging Festival.
"After all that, I feel confident in saying Rosie is probably the best-looking skipjack on the Bay right now," Gage said. "I had a big part in that, so that's a good feeling."
The pair logged the requisite 4,000 hours of hands-on experience, plus additional skill development training, under the direction of CBMM's staff.
After words from program supporter and CBMM Board Emeritus Tom Seip, Hilgartner, and Shipwright Educator Steve Garrand, the offered his congratulations to the new graduates of a program that is unique in its scope and ambition, not just across the state but nationally.
"This is truly a standalone program," said Maryland Department of Labor's Director of Apprenticeship & Training Chris MacLarion. "This is the only registered one that I can find on the books anywhere in the country left that's doing this through the state or federal government, that's registering apprentices, training them, and graduating them to not only not lose the knowledge and the skills but to carry it down to the next generation."
That impressed Clarke.
"That was really cool to hear," Clarke said. "I didn't know we were such rare birds in this program, but I'm happy to have been one."
CBMM's Shipwright Apprentice Program will add two more Shipwright Apprentices in the new year. Interested candidates can learn more at cbmm.org/Careers. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot Board of Ed Votes in Jackson as President, Dodson as Vice President
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot Board of Ed votes in Jackson as president, Dodson as vice president

 December 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 176
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Board of Education nominated and elected its president and vice president during Wednesday's meeting.Emily Jackson was reelected as president following a nomination from the nominating committee. No other nominations were made for the position, and the board unanimously voted to approve Jackson.
The District 4 representative is in the middle of her second stint as a board member. Jackson has been on the Board of Education since 2018.
Amy Dodson will be the board's new vice president, also nominated by the committee. She assumes the role of previous Vice President Candace Henry.
All board members voted to approve Dodson as the vice president. Dodson, who represents District 3, has been serving on the board since 2022.
At the end of Wednesday's meeting, Jackson said she's looking forward to the next year in her leadership role on the board.
"I am happy to serve in this position," Jackson said. "I enjoy it, and it's a proud role for me to do. … I'm excited to serve with you Amy. We're going to have a good year."

title: Talbot Leaders Optimistic About Improvements at Easton Middle, Across TCPS
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot leaders optimistic about improvements at Easton Middle, across TCPS

 December 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 697
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — During its monthly meeting, the Talbot County Board of Education was provided with a detailed look into the Maryland School Report Card results, including where improvements may be needed.Released by the Maryland Department of Education earlier this month, the report card awards schools points based on performance in four categories: academic achievement, academic progress, English language arts proficiency progress, and school quality and student success.
St. Michaels Elementary School rose from three stars in 2023 to four stars this year, while White Marsh Elementary School — which remained steady at four stars — produced significant gains in test scores and percentile ranks.
Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, focused her presentation on Easton Middle School, which was the district's only school to have a year-to-year drop in its star rating.
She explained what caused the school's rating to drop from three stars to two stars and pinpointed improvements that weren't reflected in the report card.
"Given the number of factors that make up this star rating and the complexity of the formulas, I wanted to share with you a deeper dive into what impacted the decrease in stars for Easton Middle School so we all have a better understanding of what's happening," Einhorn said.
Einhorn noted that there were small increases in academic achievement and academic progress at Easton Middle. "It was not notable in the MSDE reporting because they truncate the values for their calculations," she said.
The state report did show an increase in points scored for English proficiency. That and the small gains in the other categories show the school's progress, Einhorn says.
"The steps that (Principal Kelly Murdoch) and her school are putting in place at Easton Middle are having an impact in improving outcomes for students," Einhorn said, "even though it doesn't show up in that calculation for the star rating."
Easton Middle's score for school quality and student success dropped from 19.5 points in 2023 to 17.1 points in 2024, which largely caused the star rating drop. Einhorn said that mostly stemmed from the rate of chronically absent students, the "largest single measure that impacts the star rating of a school."
A common misconception is that only unexcused absences count toward considering a student chronically absent. That is not the case, Einhorn said, emphasizing that both excused and unexcused absences count in the tracking for whether a student is chronically absent or not according to the state.
"(Do) we have some investigation going on into what is causing that so it's not carried over into the high school?" Board Member Karla Wieland-Cherry asked.
Einhorn said the district has "several checkpoints" in place and is working with teachers, social workers and administrators to reduce chronic absenteeism.
Board Vice President Amy Dodson expressed optimism about the work being done to improve student achievement at Easton Middle.
"I've spoken to some parents of students at Easton Middle, and they give glowing reports of what they're doing over there," Dodson said. "And some of our neighboring counties did not fare so well with the star system. So keep up the work, there's still plenty of work to do."
"I see every day the work that Easton Middle School is doing, so to have this be the measure of your work is really hard," responded Einhorn. "I appreciate your recognition of what's happening there and the effort they're putting in."
Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the district is constantly assessing school performance and data internally in order to "(celebrate) the growth that we're seeing at Easton Middle School and all of our schools."
"We take our own internal approach, and we just don't wait for the stars to come out every one time a year, or the (Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program test scores) to come out one time a year," Pepukayi said.
Einhorn said while she didn't want to "suggest that we should be happy with a two-star rating," she hoped the detailed breakdown provided context around how Easton Middle is improving.
"I know that with time (and) support from this board that Easton Middle School will continue to see gains in their school improvement efforts," Einhorn said. "I'm really proud of their innovation and persistence in looking at ways to improve outcomes for the students they serve." 

 © Copyright 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot Board of Ed Voices Mixed Opinions Over 2025-26 Calendar Draft
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot Board of Ed voices mixed opinions over 2025-26 calendar draft

 December 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A draft version of a calendar for the 2025-2026 school year drew varying opinions from Talbot County Board of Education members on Wednesday evening.The calendar committee, which plans the district's upcoming calendars, put together the draft that was shown Wednesday. It included two days off in the second week of March 2026 for students and a five-day spring break for students from April 2 to April 6, 2026.
"The thinking of the committee was to put some days off in March, and then to do the April holiday," Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, said. "Dividing the break would also minimize the impact on our students who rely on the support of our schools for their meal support."
Board President Emily Jackson, who serves on the calendar committee, expressed confusion with the draft calendar that Einhorn presented.
"It was a surprisingly contentious group, with a huge set of ideas that ran the gamut," Jackson said of the committee. "So what I am seeing presented today, to me, does not accurately reflect what I took away from the discussions that were had."
Jackson said she was expecting multiple draft calendars, not just one. She added that past surveys have indicated there are strong opinions on extending spring break and having "time for teachers in their classrooms without students."
"Personally, I come back to wanting to give our community what they're asking for," Jackson said. "So I'm looking for a calendar that has an actual spring break on it."
Board Member Deborah Bridges said she liked the two days off in March.
"I think the March break is wonderful from a mental health standpoint, because March is long, dreary," Bridges said. "And everybody — kids, parents and teachers — need a little break, and I think that's a really good thing to do."
Board Member Dyshekia Strawberry raised concerns that the shorter spring break could increase chronic absenteeism in April. Vice President Amy Dodson said while the draft calendar "looks good," an off day in March could possibly be moved to extend spring break.
Jackson also brought up the possibility of staggered starts for students in "transition" grades that are starting at new schools. Einhorn said that she is waiting on direction from the state to understand how other districts do staggered starts while still complying with 180-day requirements.
Feedback from Wednesday's meeting will be taken back to the calendar committee and discussed before a draft calendar is presented for second reader at the board's January meeting.
Einhorn said it'd be possible for the committee to look at keeping the two off days in March, as well as extending spring break, by moving the last day of school back.
Jackson vouched for "consistent breaks" in order to accommodate student needs surrounding mental health, travel needs, college tours and more.
"There are ways to put this together that do make sense and don't look like this," the board president said.
"I think we have to put everything out on the table because we have constraints," Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said. "We can't have it both ways.
"And while I know we want extra days off, I hear loud and clear from parents (about) child care. But we also want to balance, because I also hear from staff, more planning time. We just have to find out, what is that balance?" 

 Copyright 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Lockerman Middle School Celebrates New STEM Center
author: Konner Metz kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Lockerman Middle School celebrates new STEM Center

 December 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 469
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Lockerman Middle School's new science, technology, engineering and mathematics center was celebrated on Tuesday for providing students with unique opportunities and STEM-related resources.The STEM Center held a ribbon-cutting Tuesday afternoon with partners from the University of Maryland Medical System. A $500,000 grant was given to the Cal Ripken, Sr. Foundation, which is funding STEM centers at 10 different schools in Maryland, including Lockerman.
Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said the foundation's contribution is bringing unique experiences to Lockerman students.
"There's no way that this level of resource and these tools would be able to get in the hands of our middle school kids if it wasn't for your partnership and Ripken Foundation's work," Simmons said.
On Tuesday, students showed off the new tools and gadgets that were funded by the grant, such as a 3D printer, coding robots and electronic kits. In the school cafeteria, two students flew drones.
Sixth grader Gracie Spiering showed off her knowledge of how to make backpack security alarms or model cars using littleBits Electronic kits. She knew how to order the kit's pieces and wires, and learned how the coding worked.
"It's been so much fun to have in class," Spiering said. "Everybody's been so ready to come into that class."
Meanwhile, many students have been utilizing the 3D printers to make ornaments for the holidays. Seventh grader Madison Watson said it's been a smooth learning process thanks to the help of her teachers.
"It's pretty fun to have them just at any time we really want them to be here," Watson said.
Lockerman Middle School Principal Jeannine Necessary said students love learning how to use the new materials. Staff members were trained and encouraged to integrate the STEM tools into everyday learning, the principal said.
During the ribbon-cutting, University of Maryland Shore Regional Health President and CEO Ken Kozel said the healthcare system appreciates students involved in STEM because the students are "highly motivated and educated."
"We're here to promote STEM because it's such an important part of the healthcare system," Kozel said. "We're local, we're small, we're a community hospital system, but we need our community to help support our workforce needs."
With a handful of students excited to show off the new technology on Tuesday, Simmons reflected on how much the grant means to the Denton middle school, given the district's financial challenges.
"About 60 to 65 percent of our students qualify for free and reduced meals, which puts a little bit different lens on the opportunities that our kids have to access things," Simmons said. "It also puts a lens on the opportunity the school system has funding-wise to be able to provide those avenues.
"We are thrilled that we were selected by you guys, in partnership with the Ripken Foundation, to be able to provide opportunity and access that we could've never funded for our students." 

 Copyright 2024

title: Beloved Bus Driver 'Mrs. Dea' Brings Holiday Cheer to Young Passengers
author: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com
content:
Beloved bus driver 'Mrs. Dea' brings holiday cheer to young passengers

 December 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lilly Howard lhoward@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1200
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CECIL COUNTY — Nedean Crawford, more commonly known as Mrs. Dea, is much more than a bus driver to the students she drives to and from school each day, where she makes a lasting impression on their lives through her caring nature and holiday cheer."When they're on my bus, they're my kids," Mrs. Dea said. "It's like you're a teacher, you're a nurse, you're a psychiatrist, you know, you're a mother, you're a counselor, you're all of those things, just not a school bus driver."
Over her 28 years driving with Marshall Bus Company, during which she has averaged around 61 students per semester, Mrs. Dea has made an impact on many lives as a positive female role model.
She greets each and every student entering and leaving the bus each morning and afternoon, and spends extra time getting to know them.
"A little bit of 'hello,' or a little hug or something like that, really makes that child's day," Mrs. Dea said. "And if I see it on their face, that they're not right, we get to the school a little bit early and I say, 'Come on, come and talk to Mrs. Dea. What's going on? Tell me your story.'"
Her route includes Elk Neck Elementary, North East High School and their Twilight program for students who need extra help.
Many of the middle school students who grew up riding her bus look forward to reuniting with her in high school.
"My oldest is now a big sixth grader and says 'I miss Mrs. Dea' because her new bus driver, even though he's nice and all, is just not the same," one parent, Todd Hudson, said.
The feeling is mutual.
"It's the kids that keep coming me back," Mrs. Dea said. "Once they go into middle school for three years, six to eight. I don't see them, but I get them back in ninth grade, and it's such a joy to see how much they've grown since…it's just amazing. I'm 61 years old, and it's just, oh, it really gets to you…on my elementary run, my kids just love me, hug me every day, and it makes my day. And that's what has me coming back day after day after day."
According to Mrs. Dea, retirement is not a decision that's up to her.
"I can't retire, because I get them back in high school and the parents say that you can't retire until my child graduates," Mrs. Dea said.
All four of Ashley Culley-Meekin's children have experienced riding with Mrs. Dea.
"My son, who's in kindergarten this year, calls her the magic school bus driver," Culley-Meekins said, adding that Mrs. Dea cares about the children and is always decorating her school bus and dressing up for each and every holiday.
The interior roof of Mrs. Dea's bus 77 is currently embellished in battery powered string lights with festive colors for the holidays. She hung garland with ornaments above the windows and along the side of the bus as well.
Mrs. Dea started this tradition five years ago when she found out some of her students didn't have a Christmas tree at home.
"So I decorated the bus like it was a Christmas tree so that they could feel and see what a Christmas tree would be like, other than, you know, really not having the green branches, but just giving them an idea with the lights and the garland. And it clicked, so I continued to do it every year," Mrs. Dea said.
When those students came home telling their parents about the Christmas decorations in the bus, their mom had to see for herself, and peeked inside in awe when picking her kids up from the bus stop one day.
In addition to the lights, Mrs. Dea puts on the radio and the students sing along when holiday favorites come on the airwaves, like "Rudolph." Mrs. Dea always makes the students on the bus feel special.
"If they have a bad day at school and they get on Mrs. Dea's bus, they're always happier when they get home…even the little things, like she'll give them Halloween goodie bags and Christmas goodie bags, just to brighten their day," one parent with four children who have ridden on bus 77, Heidi Smith said.
But more than the jolly songs and goodie bags, Mrs. Dea watches out for every child that comes through her bus doors.
"The most important thing besides all that, is her caring for not only my kids, but a bus full…She treats them like they're her own [children]. She's always aware of her bus at all times," Culley-Meekins said.
Smith's son RJ is diabetic and Mrs. Dea carries Smarties candy and bags of chips in case his blood sugar drops on the bus. This happened recently, and when RJ's glucose monitor beeped indicating low blood sugar, Mrs. Dea safely pulled over to ensure his levels evened out before she dropped him off.
"I feel safe with all of my kids on there. But like, RJ, being diabetic, I don't know that I would trust another bus driver," Smith said, adding that Mrs. Dea always checks in with RJ to ensure his blood sugar levels are steady, and carries snacks just in case.
She is attentive to every child on the bus.
"There have been times where she has stopped the bus in front of my house for my kids to get off the bus, and she's quickly closed the doors because a car has ran through the bus," Culley-Meekins said.
Mrs. Dea mentioned that some of her biggest challenges come from outside of her magical bus, with crazy drivers, road conditions, and bad weather causing problems.
Last year during a series of storms, a tree fell across Elk Neck Road, blocking Mrs. Dea's route and leaving the bus full of kids stranded, according to Hudson, a parent of students on this bus at the time who was called to move the tree.
"Mrs. Dea was playing games, keeping the kids occupied…They were stranded for quite a while. So she was tap dancing, doing everything she could to keep the kids entertained, under control, and happy and not scared," Hudson said, adding that she even sent his children home with baked goods the following day as a thank you for clearing the road.
Mrs. Dea is always doing her best to make the children on her bus happy.
Bus driving is an often overlooked career choice and drivers sometimes face the stigma that they are uneducated, but Mrs. Dea emphasized that she could and has pursued other careers, but does this because she loves the kids.
"I don't have to drive a school bus. I choose to drive a school bus," Mrs. Dea said.
Before bus driving, Mrs. Dea graduated in the top third of her class at Glasgow High School in Delaware, went to college, and became a certified dental assistant until she had to have rotator cuff surgery five times and was unable to continue this work.
"I would never go back to the dental field, even if my arm got better…I really enjoy driving the bus. The kids are fantastic," Mrs. Dea said. "There's a lot of times as bus drivers, we get overwhelmed, and sometimes you don't feel appreciated. But I do have a good run…I wouldn't give this run up for anything." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Miles River Yacht Club's Annual Angel Tree event brings holiday joy
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Miles River Yacht Club's Annual Angel Tree event brings holiday joy

 December 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Christmas 
 
 543
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — The Miles River Yacht Club's annual Angel Tree event is bringing holiday cheer to the Eastern Shore.Through this time-honored tradition, members of the yacht club come together to celebrate and provide local children with presents and other essentials for the holidays.
This collaboration is in conjunction with the Head Start of Shore Up, a program focusing on children's social and educational development, and the event has recently roped the Benedictine School in an effort to grow the number of children who benefit from the Angel Tree program.
Nick Simpson, commodore at the Miles River Yacht Club, said this year they are providing gifts to over 30 local children. Simpson said this event has showcased the most generous characteristics of their members and the volunteer opportunities that the club promotes for all its members.
"Our mission statement has a lot about boating and doing things on the water, but part of the mission statement is also to give back to support the local community," Simpson said. "The club donates a lot throughout the year. This is just kind of the culmination of it."
Simpson said outside of this Angel Tree event, the club provides meals to those in need during Thanksgiving and members donate school supplies through the Community Center in St. Michaels for children. But the Angel Tree is by far the most anticipated event by members.
According to Simpson, Head Start of Shore Up identifies children in need, then they work to get a list of toys that they want as well as clothing sizes for the children.
Then a tree at the yacht club is decorated with cardboard or construction paper ornaments, and each ornament has two or three toys, as well as clothing items and sizes, requested by the children. Club members select an ornament, purchase the listed items, and return them to the club to be distributed to the children.
Simpson said members will often race to obtain these ornaments.
Jackie Tate, a volunteer at Head Start of St. Michaels, said the children picked for the Angel Tree range from ages 2 to 4. Tate said the program has been going on for well over a decade and she has loved the joy brought to families.
"That's why I continue to do it, because you never know what the parents are going through because they don't tell you and if I can help a family that's in need, do this for them. My heart is satisfied," she said.
Tate said parents will often not know when their child is picked to be part of the Angel Tree, and she recalls a time about 10 years ago when she called a mother and told her that her child had been picked for the program and she needed to come down and pick up the gifts bought for her.
When the mother came to the classroom, she was overwhelmed with gratitude and began to cry.
"(The mother) said, 'Miss Tate, I thank you so much because I didn't know what I was going to do for Christmas for my child, because I've been laid off from my job.' And that touched my heart to know that we could, just as a yacht club, help these children and these families, because you don't know what they're going through," Tate said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Classical Charter School Looks to Open in Queen Anne's
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Classical charter school looks to open in Queen Anne's

 December 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 414
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The first classical public charter school in Queen Anne's County hopes to open in the fall of 2026.Queen Anne's Classical Charter School (QACCS) is a proposed tuition-free pre-K through eighth grade school to provide an alternative educational approach and complement the work of other public schools to over four hundred students.
The drive for QACCS was formed by local parents, educators, business, and community leaders to provide an educational alternative within the public school system to ensure Queen Anne County students are reaching grade level proficiencies, according to co-founder Audrey Scott, of Queenstown.
Disillusioned with national grade level proficiencies in which a concerning percentage of students in any grade were not meeting grade level expectations, QACCS was founded through the support of local parents, grandparents, and community leaders, seeking to provide alternatives, Scott said.
"If you're aware of what's going on with the education system, you've got to take action," she said.
Researching where students were more likely to perform at grade level and above led Scott to identify classic charter schools of Frederick and Anne Arundel counties with proven track records of proficiency.
"Classical charter schools are rapidly gaining national attention for higher student performance and cultivating character and critical thinking," Scott said.
Scott is a former teacher who said the proposed charter school will provide parents educational "alternatives and enhancements," while still being part of Queen Anne's County Public Schools.
The classical charter school curriculum will include a focus on phonics, Western civilization, cursive, as well as Spanish offered in addition to Latin as part of language arts, she said.
With a board made up entirely of parents, charter schools offer more hands-on opportunities for "tremendous parental involvement," which can make a significant difference in performance, Scott said.
Queen Anne's County Commissioners have been supportive of the initiative and presented a $20,000 grant for an application consultant, she said. This application is due in March, she said.
Students will be selected for enrollment via lottery, with all county students eligible to attend, she said.
Options for school facilities are still being explored with the hopes to mirror Frederick County and Anne Arundel counties' business park locations, Scott said.
"It would be a real feather in the cap of Queen Anne's County to have the first one on the Eastern Shore," Scott said.
A public meeting about QACCS welcomes the community to learn more Jan. 25, 2025 at 10 a.m. at Kent Island Fire Department, 1610 Main Street in Chester.
More information including a petition of support can be found at QueenAnnesCCS.com and its Facebook page. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: State Eyes New Way to Count Students in Need
author: Jack Bowman Capital News Service
content:
State eyes new way to count students in need

 December 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JACK BOWMAN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 376
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland is set to examine its current method of evaluating poverty in schools throughout the next year, potentially opening a pathway to boost funding for schools with students in need.A new study is meant to address the undercounting of poverty in Maryland public schools, according to Maryland Comptroller Brooke Lierman. The Board of Public Works approved funding for the study at its Dec. 4 meeting.
"This issue is exacerbated for undocumented students or citizen children of undocumented parents," Lierman said at that meeting.
The current method of tabulating poverty "really penalizes" schools with large numbers of immigrant students, Lierman said.
The state currently uses proxy measures, such as eligibility for national programs like Medicaid and SNAP, to calculate aid for public schools, according to the proposal for funds from the Department of General Services.
According to the Governor's Office for Children, an accurate count of students in poverty is important to ensure that they get adequate resources. The office also told CNS that the "Blueprint for Maryland's Future created several new school funding streams that rely on counts of low-income students."
Schools currently rely on applications for the free and reduced meals program and enrollment in social programs like Medicaid as methods of calculating student poverty. According to the Governor's Office for Children, "not all low income families participate in these programs."
The office also said that "districts that provide free school meals to all students under the federal community eligibility program do not collect that data."
In the case of immigrant families, some may not qualify or, as the office told CNS, may be hesitant to enroll and reveal their citizenship status.
Other data the state might rely upon is out of date. According to Lierman, the Maryland State Department of Education recently proposed using data from 2013 to calculate school poverty in Baltimore City. Lierman said that many public schools have been shuttered in the city since that data was collected.
"As a Baltimore City Public School mom," Lierman said, "I've got a lot of strong feelings about this."
The board approved the DGS request for $48,000 monthly for "modeling, analysis and providing a presentation on findings."
According to the Office for Children, a recommendation based on the results of the study will be made to the Maryland General Assembly by Dec. 1, 2025. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland Stories: This Reading Club Is Going to the Dogs
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland stories: This reading club is going to the dogs

 December 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 628
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Those who might get nervous reading in front of a group might be better suited reading for those with four legs, a shell, big floppy ears or a tail.That's just one of the ideas behind Southern Maryland-based Pets on Wheels, which recently stopped at the Leonardtown Library.
"It improves confidence, reading skills and literacy," said Southern Maryland Pets on Wheels Coordinator Sharon Stapf. "Pets don't care if you get a word wrong. They're non-judgmental."
Stapf said the program can even benefit adults learning a second language.
"It gives the kids confidence when maybe they wouldn't want to read to a big group, but they'll read to a really cute dog," Brittany Haun of Leonardtown said as she watched her daughter, Charlotte, pet a large brown dog. "I think it's great and if they had more of these events, I would recommend people coming to them."
"My son loves dogs and all kinds of animals," Cassondra West of Mechanicsville said. "It just seems like a calming effect.
But reading is not the only benefit of the program, which Stapf said started out of Johns Hopkins to see if pets could help homebound patients feel less lonely.
"Whether it's children or adults, animals are the one thing that people miss, whether it be in the military or in existed living and maybe they've outlived their pets," Stapf said. "It is a family member and they miss that contact. They may not remember what they had for lunch, but they can tell me the name of every animal that came through that facility for the entire week before I visit."
Joshua Crosley of Mechanicsville can relate. The Panera Bread manager lost his beloved 11-year-old Corgi "Izzy" in a tragic accident in 2022.
"We had a baby [several months ago], so it's not a good time to find a new family member, but when given the opportunity, trust me I'll take an animal," said Crosley, who now has a young son. "This gives me an opportunity, at least a little bit, to come down for this and get some solace. [My daughter Elliot] misses Izzy as well and she'd love to have a dog, so this is kind of a shared experience."
Stapf also relayed a story about an individual at Naval Air Station Patuxent River who was "standoffish toward dogs, but when he found out we had a giant tortoise he came alive. His home was Hawaii and he had a pet tortoise."
She also told how an individual at Charlotte Hall Veterans Home had trouble getting words out, but following a visit with a dog it was discovered that if he had two hands on the animal it connected something that allowed him to speak.
"It sparked something," Stapf said. "It was phenomenal. It gave me chills all the way down to my toes."
Tracey Quade of Drayden recalled an incident at Chopticon High School in which a girl dressed all in black reached over and hugged the dog Loki Sandstorm for a good 15 minutes, all the while crying.
"Then she stood up, wiped her tears and walked away and never said a word to me," Quade said. "And [Loki] looked at me and honest to God I think he smiled. That kid needed something and he gave it to her."
Volunteers wanting to work with the organization must have pets that meet several qualifications — the "canine good citizenship test," Stapf calls it — in which they must be good around other animals, able to be touched "nose to toes," and not be disturbed by loud noises, staring or wheelchairs.
"I wanted to serve the community and I love dogs," Quade, who is retired from the federal government, said. "Personally I see the benefits for myself, for the dog and for the community."
For more information on Pets On Wheels, go to www.petsonwheels.org.

title: Chesapeake College Works to Become Hispanic-Serving Institution
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Chesapeake College works to become Hispanic-Serving Institution

 January 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado valvarado@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 950
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Zulema Delacruz Martinez, a 2024 graduate of Chesapeake College, was described by the school's faculty as an achievement.During her time at Chesapeake College, she was a founder of the Hispanic/Latino Student Union, the chair of the annual Unity Fest and a mentor for area high school students with TRiO's Upward Bound summer program.
"She's the type of person that (Chesapeake College) would love to see her success repeated in many more," said Lorelly Solano, director at the Chesapeake College Cambridge Center.
Delacruz Martinez credited support programs like TRiO, a federal student services program, for her own college success. She said having TRiO provided her opportunities for academic success and to better understand financial resources for education. It is programs such as TRiO that motivated her to lead in the creation of the Hispanic/Latino Student Union.
"In my mind, when I founded (Hispanic/Latino Student Union), it's more like, 'How can I help others? What kind of resources can I create, or kind of resources can become available, so that way the students coming after me, who come from similar backgrounds, they don't have to worry as much, and they can focus more on being students, focus on being essentially teenagers and young adults enjoying college life and creating connections?'" Delacruz Martinez said.
The student union hosts community nights to assist Latino community members who are having trouble filling out the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, commonly called FAFSA.
This form assists current and prospective college students to determine their eligibility for student financial aid. The Hispanic/Latino Student Union has been leading Chesapeake College's Latino student recruitment by hosting events catered to potential students.
Delacruz Martinez said that more than 90% of attendees of FAFSA Nights applied to Chesapeake College. She assisted families from all age groups, including grandparents with limited knowledge of the internet.
Chesapeake College, a public two-year regional community college in Wye Mills, is going through changes to address the growing Hispanic population.
According to Marcie Alvarado Molloy, director of public information at Chesapeake College, over the last decade the Hispanic population at the school has increased by more than 64% and is expected to continue to grow.
The college has made an effort to translate all pamphlets and documents for Spanish speaking families and students. Additionally, the school is trying to increase the number of Spanish-speaking staff, especially in key offices like financial aid. The college has made efforts to collaborate with family liaisons from Talbot County Public Schools and has attended various community events to increase the school's presence and visibility.
Clifford Coppersmith, president of Chesapeake College, said the college is on its way to becoming a Hispanic-Serving Institution. A Hispanic-Serving Institution is defined by the U.S. Department of Education as an eligible institution with an undergraduate enrollment that is at least 25% Hispanic.
According to the Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities, in 2023 there were about 600 Hispanic-Serving Institutions in the United States. The U.S. Department of Education offers Hispanic-Serving Institutions 64 grants through the Developing Hispanic-Serving Institution program, and in 2023 the Biden-Harris Administration announced it would award more than $40 million to support Hispanic/Latino students.
Coppersmith said more and more Hispanic students are transferring from Chesapeake College to four-year colleges every year.
"So with our Hispanic population, up until probably fairly recently, the predominant interest has been short-term non-credit, but more and more we are seeing Hispanic students getting into transfer education," Coppersmith said. "They intend to go in and get bachelor's degrees."
GENERATIONAL ACHIEVEMENTSolano said she appreciates the collaboration Chesapeake College does with schools and nonprofits to help accomplish the academic dreams of the Hispanic community.
"When our society is so polarized, and you also hear a lot of negative rhetoric about immigrants, I think it is so important for for these kids and for their families to actually demonstrate to themselves and to others that that they actually can achieve their dreams, that they can show this very dignified side of of their dreams, because, quite frankly, this is about generational achievement," Solano said.
College degrees have generational impacts on families. According to the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis' Center for Household Financial Stability, families with at least two generations of college graduates have median income and wealth that are higher than those of families where fewer generations have college degrees. Hispanic families across the county have been enrolling their children in record numbers over the past two decades, according to the Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities.
In 2023, Chesapeake College welcomed its class with Hispanic students making up the largest minority student demographic at more than 43% of the college's more than 1,395 minority students.
During this year's graduation Delacruz Martinez was awarded the John T. Harrison Award. This award is given each year to a student who has demonstrated the highest academic performance, leadership and overall contributions to the college and the community.
Milton Nagel, vice chair of the Chesapeake College Board of Trustees, presented the award to Delacruz Martinez and gave her praise for her commitment to Hispanic and Latino students within the region who are interested in college but may be intimidated by the academic process.
Delacruz Martinez, said she is happy to see schools throughout the Eastern Shore adapting to the growing Latino population through different programs and the efforts to hire diverse faculty and staff. According to Delacruz Martinez, these efforts are not going unnoticed.
"Hispanic Latino students are resilient. We are very, very, very hardworking," Delacruz Martinez said. "We will put in the effort if given the chance. But this issue is that sometimes we aren't given that chance. We have to focus on other difficult situations we are placed in, within our own homes, within their own communities. So invest in us, and we will certainly put in the effort." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Foundation of HOPE Moves Toward Goals in the New Year
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Foundation of HOPE moves toward goals in the new year

 January 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 532
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Over the last year, Foundation of HOPE, an Easton-based nonprofit, has worked to empower women and girls in the Eastern Shore. In order to celebrate the foundation's accomplishments and to share the upcoming year's goals, the foundation held a gala/luncheon for its supporters on Dec. 14.During the foundation's annual fundraiser event, over a 100 people gathered together to participate in a silent auction and honor scholarship recipients, their experiences and their accomplishments.
Keasha Haythe, founder of Foundation of HOPE, said the fundraiser provides the opportunity for donors and supporters of the organization to see the progress made so far through presentations and speakers, including past students and scholarship recipients.
"It was really good to have people in the room to hear about where we've been, where we're going, what our goals and our priorities are to expand the program to not only have more girls participate, but also to serve the community," Haythe said.
Haythe said speakers for the event included 2024 scholarship recipients Kaleigh Hammond and Michaela Gibson. Gibson, a student at John Hopkins, and Hammond, a student at Chesapeake College, shared their experiences with the program and how the foundation helped them achieve their goals.
Haythe said they were a part of the second cohort of the program, which offers after-school classes to sixth-grade girls.
Haythe said the Foundation of HOPE program was established in 2018 with the goal to teach middle school girls how to be viable contributors to the future workforce. The program covers topics including addressing low self-esteem, bullying, social media, workforce development, and economic and community development.
Haythe said over the years the program has grown to cater to more girls in the community. According to Haythe, the program hopes to grow to include 30 students. Additionally, they hope to start pre construction work for a foundation headquarters around quarter two of 2025.
According to Haythe, the foundation received $150,000 from the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development in December. The foundation has launched the capital campaign to the public.
Haythe said supporters can make donations to the foundation in many ways, but she encourages the public to show their appreciation for women or girls in their lives by honoring them with a Rose of Hope. A Rose of Hope is a donation made in someone else's honor to help support the foundation's Economic Development and Empowerment program. Names of those honored are shared on the foundation's website and listed at the Annual Gala Program.
Haythe said she is proud of the opportunity to help girls in the program. She shared that Gibson wanted to study marine biology in sixth grade and now she is studying at John Hopkins. For Haythe, continuing to foster that growth and belief in young girls is what she enjoys.
"I think looking over the last year, I've been most proud of how the girls who have completed the program have blossomed into young women," Haythe said. "How they are following their dreams. I mean, these dreams that they had in sixth grade, they're manifesting for them… these young ladies are truly understanding who they are, and they're developing in the program, and after completing the program, into nice young women that are going after their dreams." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Schools to remain closed Friday

title: Biden Hall: UD Planning Social Sciences Building Named After U.S. President
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Biden Hall: UD planning social sciences building named after U.S. president

 January 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 363
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As researchers begin to move into the University of Delaware's new interdisciplinary science lab, Building X, the university is already planning for its next major construction project: an interdisciplinary social sciences building named after UD's most famous alumnus."Advancing signature programs as an interdisciplinary nexus for the social sciences, Biden Hall will be a new forum for learning and civic debate at the University of Delaware, educating and engaging our country's future leaders as the permanent home for our Joseph R. Biden, Jr. School of Public Policy & Administration and Biden Institute," UD spokesman Christopher Vito said.
The Biden Institute was created after Biden left the vice presidency in 2017, and it is currently located in the old Blue and Gold Club on Kent Way. Chaired by the president's sister, Valerie Biden Owens, the Biden Institute hosts events, brings prominent speakers to campus and focuses on developing domestic public policy.
UD's highly ranked School of Public Policy & Administration, which was renamed for Biden in 2018, offers undergraduate and graduate programs in leadership, public administration, public policy, public health, disaster management and related fields. It is currently headquartered in Graham Hall on Academy Street.
Vito said the Biden Hall project is still in the early stages, and more details will be made public as the process moves forward.
"This modern facility will harness the latest technology to cultivate academic growth, interdisciplinary research collaborations, dialogue, and civil discourse, all of which are crucial to a flourishing democracy in the 21st century," he added.
The new building will be located on the main campus in Newark, but the specific location has yet to be determined.
"We are fundraising and planning with intent to enter design and programmatic planning in the 2025 calendar year," Vito said.
Former Gov. John Carney included $20 million in state funding for Biden Hall in his recommended capital budget, which he released just one day before resigning to be sworn in as mayor of Wilmington. The budget will be debated and voted on by the state legislature in June.
"We're very excited, because this is yet another opportunity for productive state investment through the University of Delaware, which will ultimately benefit the entire community," UD President Dennis Assanis said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Phone Pouches Improving Student Focus, Discipline in Caroline, District Says
author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Phone pouches improving student focus, discipline in Caroline, district says

 January 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 624
 Words 

 Read News Document

 An experimental pilot program aimed at keeping students off their phones saw some success in its first semester being implemented at Caroline County Public Schools.Cellphone pouches created by the company Yondr were tested in both Caroline County middle schools last semester.
"We've been pleased with the outcome, Superintendent Derek Simmons said. "You see attentiveness much higher in classrooms, kids learning how to talk to each other, even in the cafeteria. It's been really cool to see at the middle schools."
The students carry locked pouches during the entire school day, with their phones inside but not accessible.
Each student has their own pouch, which travels with them daily from home to school. Phone are locked into the pouches at the beginning of the school day and unlocked at the end using a magnetic device. If a student leaves the pouch at home, they put their phone in the school office for the day.
Every classroom in Caroline County comes equipped with a wired phone for use in case of an emergency, and teachers have been given a special pair of scissors to cut through cellphone pouches if needed.
For students with health needs, the schools offer special services allowing students to check their phones for medical purposes only.
There have been talks within the county of expanding cellphone pouches to ninth graders in coming years, but that determination has not yet been made, district officials said.
In determining whether the pouch program will be expected, the district still has to weigh the pros and cons, officials said. They hope that by the end of the school year they will have a solid understanding of the program's successes and shortcomings.
SUCCESSES
The pouches have done a good job at keeping students off their phones during the school day, district officials said. But beyond that, the middle schools where the pouches have been implemented have seen some other benefits from the program.
The cellphone pouches help prevent cyber bullying in the school during the school day, they said. Students have needed less disciplinary intervention since the pouches were rolled out.
"We've seen about a 21% reduction in discipline incidents," Simmons said.
Simmons also said teachers report that taking cellphones out of the picture has allowed them to better focus on instructing students.
"We ask a lot of our teachers, most of our class sizes average 20 to 20 plus students, so if you're asking them to improve reading or improve mathematics on top of being able to see if they're on cellphones it's a lot," Simmons said. "With the pouches they don't have to be the cellphone police."
Although schools don't yet have test scores back for last semester, the superintendent said pass rates have gone up with the cellphone pouches.
DIFFICULTIES
Reception of the cellphone pouches has not been entierly positive among students and parents in the district, Simmons said.
Students have tried to tamper with or break into their pouches during the school day on multiple occasions.
"They're not indestructible, they're not the end all be all, but they are a great preventative tool to put in place," Simmons said. "They're easy to tell if somebody's tampered with one, It's also easy to tell if a kid has their phone or has a phone out because they don't want their pouch or pouches to look empty."
Some parents do not like the idea of the phone pouches because they prefer to have a direct line of communication with their child, Simmons said.
Students have not yet been polled on their feelings about the pouches, but the districts plans to weigh student attitudes toward the program in any future decisions made.
"I think overall, we're seeing a positive impact on the academics, on the social skills piece. If we asked kids if they'd rather have access to their devices, I'm sure they would," Simmons said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a school district's pilot program to improve student focus and discipline by using locked phone pouches, which directly relates to educational policies and classroom management.

title: Talbot Board of Ed Sees Initial Budget Proposal
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed sees initial budget proposal

 January 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 720
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot Board of Education had its first look at the district's proposed budget for fiscal year 2026 Monday.During a board work session Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones presented the draft budget, which totals $85.8 million in unrestricted dollars — an $8.6 million increase from fiscal year 2025, Jones noted.
Jones provided the year-to-year budget changes by looking at 12 different categories of expenditures. The areas in which increases were highest are fixed charges ($2.23 million increase), instructional salaries ($1.7 million increase) and other instructional costs ($1.47 million increase).
Jones added that while $9 million to $10 million in grants are expected next year, anticipated grant funding is more than $5 million less than last fiscal year. That drop in grant funding precipitated a portion of the rise in the requested unrestricted budget.
In Annapolis, it still remains to be seen how Maryland's expected $2.7 billion deficit is tackled and if legislative decisions will impact funding for The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's education improvement and funding initiative.
Talbot school leaders say budgeting will be a fluid process in the coming months as they keep an eye on state legislation and the Accountability & Implementation Board, an entity that ensures the state and county governments are correctly implementing Blueprint.
"There's one area where I did do a little bit of hedging our bets, on the conservative side," Jones said of the proposed budget. "I don't think we'll know any of that until April or May. But as certain pieces of legislation gather steam and seem to gather support and seem likely, then I think we will work behind the scenes to figure out how we will address this if this comes to fruition."
In creating the draft budget, Jones and Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi emphasized that the district considered its top priorities: academic equity in math, an engaging environment for students and staff, recruitment and retention levels, and meeting Blueprint objectives.
Monday's discussion included a breakdown of 33 proposed additional positions for the next fiscal year. The proposed budget includes a $3.6 million jump in salaries and wages.
"This list is whittled down, if you can believe it, from a longer list of wants and desires," Jones said. "And it was very much informed by school administration. This is what they felt they needed in their buildings."
ADDITIONAL POSITIONSJones outlined the 33 additional positions that are in the requested budget. Six of those positions are for English for Speakers of Other Languages teachers, assistants or coaches.
She cited the district's need to serve its multilingual population, along with the state funding for multilingual learning, for adding the positions.
"Our (Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program) data … demonstrates that we do consistently underserve our multilingual students," Jones said. "And so, we just need to provide more resources there."
Board of Education President Emily Jackson asked if those English for Speakers of Other Languages positions will be difficult to fill.
"Because I know we've had problems — specifically with ESOL in the past — finding people who are qualified and had a desire to do that," Jackson said. "And that's a quarter of the positions we're looking for."
Zulieka Jarmon-Horsey, assistant superintendent of administrative services, systems and strategies, said it's a challenge both in Talbot County and statewide. She said recruitment and retention are key aspects.
"We have to definitely start promoting earlier and just doing the best that we can," Jarmon-Horsey said. "And doing things that are unconventional, like our on-site career fair that's going to be happening here this week."
Other requested positions in the budget include: an art teacher at Easton Middle, a high school math coach, a middle school reading coach, four special education positions at Easton Elementary and a special education teacher at Easton Middle.
One athletic trainer to serve Easton High School and St. Michaels Middle High School was also on the proposed list.
"I'm happy to see that at the top of the list," Jackson said of the athletic trainer role. "I would be in favor of two … making sure that we have coverage for all of our athletic events. I know sports parents, they have eyes on that."
The draft budget will be discussed again at Wednesday's monthly Board of Education meeting before the board hosts its joint meeting with the Talbot County Council on Jan. 22. On Feb. 10, the board will host a public hearing on the budget.

title: Talbot Board of Ed Adds Makeup Day for Snow; Approves 2025-26 Calendar
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed adds makeup day for snow; approves 2025-26 calendar

 January 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 580
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — During Wednesday's meeting, the Talbot County Board of Education added a day onto the end of this year's school calendar following last week's snowstorm.Talbot County Public Schools was closed Monday through Friday last week due to snow that blanketed the Mid-Shore. However, the 2024-2025 school calendar only had four inclement weather days built in, meaning an additional day was needed to comply with the state's 180-day requirement.
Helga Einhorn, assistant superintendent of school leadership and student success, recommended that a day be added in June, moving the last day of school for students to Friday, June 13.
The last day for teachers would be Monday, June 16. Einhorn said that historically, most teachers complete mandated training that affords them with not having to come in on the last day.
The board unanimously passed the adjusted calendar for this year.
2025-26 CALENDAROn Wednesday, the board also chose the district's calendar for the 2025-2026 school year.
At last month's meeting, Einhorn presented a draft calendar with two days off in March and a five-day spring break, which was the recommendation of the calendar committee. Board President Emily Jackson, however, expressed frustration there weren't multiple options posed.
This month, Einhorn returned with three draft calendars. The first was similar to what the board saw in December, with a four-day weekend in March and the shorter spring break. The second draft removed the off days in March and had an eight-day spring break.
A third draft included both the March break and an eight-day spring break, pushing the last student day back to June 10, 2026.
All three drafts included the typical days off in November for Easton's Waterfowl Festival, as well as a winter break from Dec. 20, 2025, to Jan. 4, 2026.
"There is no calendar that we're going to create that is best for every single person," Jackson said.
Jackson said it's clear — based on previous polling and community input — that most families favor the extended spring break. Board Vice President Amy Dodson suggested the board move forward with the second or third calendars.
Board member Karla Wieland-Cherry said she preferred the first calendar with the shorter spring break.
"You're losing a lot of school time for eight days off for students," Wieland-Cherry said. "You're losing a lot of momentum. And plus you're concerned with providing day care. Not all employers are going to allow that. That's quite a long time to take off of work and find day care and so forth."
She added that not all families are looking for a longer spring break.
"My only concern is that if 59% of our students are at the poverty level, we're really talking about more of a smaller group who are really going to financially be able to afford an Easter holiday," Wieland-Cherry said. "… You really could possibly potentially be causing more hardship for something that's more an elitist type thing, quite honestly."
Jackson said while she agrees with Wieland-Cherry's point, she has "to go with what the community is saying."
"We have asked again and again, and the majority of the respondents to any time we've asked this have said they like that spring break," Jackson said.
Following board discussion, Jackson motioned for approval of the third calendar featuring two off days in March and five days for spring break. Her motion included an amendment to the calendar that the March days off serve as two of four inclement weather days for the district.
By a 6-1 vote, with only Wieland-Cherry voting against, the board approved the 2025-2026 school year calendar.

title: Educators Need to Return to Basics
author: Staff Writer
content:
Educators need to return to basics

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 381
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I was glad to hear that Gov. Moore had decided to postpone implementing the experimental Blueprint for Maryland in our schools, due to the $2.7 billion deficit accrued by the state of Maryland.The Blueprint has been described as follows:
"It has taken the focus of schools off teaching students the academic and content knowledge they need to be successful adults in our society and made them 'one stop shopping' for services like medical, dental, nutritional, social engineering and mental health. It has promoted the implementation of 'restorative discipline' which has created a generation of students who are out of control and violent since there are no consequences for bad behavior. It has drained our schools of teachers as they flee to other states where working conditions are better even if the salaries are lower. These are just some of the negative impacts." (Easton Gazette, Dec. 20, 2024)
How disappointed was I to read in The Star Democrat (Jan. 15, 2025) that the Talbot Board of Education wishes to implement the Blueprint anyway, especially equity in math, with an $8.6 million increase to the school budget. With nearly 60% of Talbot County students (grades 3-8) showing a lack of proficiency in basic English language skills, while mathematics proficiency for Talbot County students stands at a dismal 17.2%, the last thing we need is for our children to be guinea pigs in yet another social experiment.
What is equity in math? According to Edutopia: "Math teachers can use short activities based on student goals related to equity in order to make classes feel more inclusive and accessible." The key words are "feel" "inclusive" and "accessible."
I was a sixth grader once, a sixth grader who hated math class. We had a strict teacher, of whom most of us were afraid. But we all learned to multiply and divide, in spite of the negative feelings, unlike, it appears, many of today's children who are not even being encouraged to memorize their times tables.
Those negative feelings can give way to feelings of confidence and assurance when a subject has been mastered. I beg our educators to return to basics and stop making our children the latest casualties of yet another half-baked, ill-conceived progressive scheme for remaking society according to the designs of Karl Marx or Saul Alinsky.
MARY-EILEEN RUSSELL
Claiborne

title: Local School Districts Affected by PowerSchool Data Breach
author: Konner Metz
content:
Local school districts affected by PowerSchool data breach

 January 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 344
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Schools in Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot counties were impacted by a data breach in late December affecting PowerSchool, a company that provides student information systems to schools across the country.Districts in each county notified families of the data breach earlier this month, shortly after PowerSchool informed districts that for some individuals, personal information such as names, dates of birth, medical information and social security numbers were obtained by hackers.
Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi wrote in a statement to families earlier this month that PowerSchool notified the district on Jan. 7. PowerSchool, according to its website, became aware of the incident on Dec. 28.
"They have confirmed that this includes information belonging to some of our families and educators," Pepukayi wrote. "Through discussions with PowerSchool, the company acknowledged that there was no action that TCPS could have taken to prevent the breach."
Dorchester County Public Schools sent out a similar message to the community on Jan. 14.
"PowerSchool said the incident is contained and the company has enhanced its security protocols," DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson wrote. "We were assured that there is no current and ongoing threat to our students' and educators' data."
"PowerSchool has also made a commitment to conduct a thorough notification process to all impacted individuals," wrote Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons. "We intend to hold PowerSchool to these commitments."
A PowerSchool spokesperson said in a statement that upon learning of the breach, the company "immediately engaged (its) cybersecurity response protocols and mobilized a cross-functional response team, including senior leadership and third-party cybersecurity experts."
According to its website, PowerSchool is working with a credit reporting agency to provide credit monitoring services to those impacted by the breach.
"PowerSchool will be offering two years of complimentary identity protection services for all students and educators whose information was involved and will also be offering two years of complimentary credit monitoring services for all adult students and educators whose information was involved," the website reads. "We are doing this regardless of whether an individual's Social Security Number was exfiltrated."
For more information, visit PowerSchool's incident page at powerschool.com/security/sis-incident/. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dorchester BOE Recognizes Student Contest Winners
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester BOE recognizes student contest winners

 January 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 336
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The audience of the Dorchester County Board of Education meeting on Thursday looked a little younger than usual.As the meeting kicked off, three of the winners of the Superintendent's Holiday Card Contest for 2024 sat patiently in the crowd, waiting to be recognized for their achievement.
The contest, which is held every year, gives students across the district a chance to sharpen their colored pencils and show off their artistic talents. Four winners are chosen: one early elementary student, one elementary student, one middle schooler and one high schooler.
This school year, the winners were:
Vienna Elementary second grader Adalynn Haugh.Hurlock Elementary third grader Kali Johnson.North Dorchester Middle eighth grader Elisabeth Claggett.North Dorchester High 10th grader Adrien Sinkeldam.
Theresa Connors, the district's supervisor of English language learners, library media and fine arts, said the DCPS' central office staff loves getting to see the submissions and vote on their favorite every year. She said that each year the number of submissions gets larger.
"Even though they're supposed to screen them at the schools before they send them and choose their best, they send me more and more every year because it's hard for them to make a decision on what to send," she said. "So it's very competitive."
As Connors read the names of each winner, the students got up from their chairs to accept a certificate and show off their designs, which included snowmen, Christmas trees and snow globes. Their teachers were also at the meeting to show support. Sinkeldam was not able to attend.
At the end of the meeting, Dorchester County Board of Education members and Superintendent Jymil Thompson talked about the students and their designs. Thompson said they did a "fantabulous" job.
"I just made that word up," he said, laughing. "I really, really liked the cards. And everyone we sent the cards to liked the cards. ... They did a great job."
Board President Sheri Hubbard called it a "wonderful time" when students are recognized at board meetings.
"That's one of the best parts of this job," she said.

title: Dorchester County Public Schools Faces Budget Deficit
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester County Public Schools faces budget deficit

 January 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 636
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — As Dorchester County Public Schools prepares to submit its fiscal year 2026 budget to the county, it is also preparing for some tough conversations.With $86 million in expected revenues and $97.5 million in estimated expenses for fiscal year 2026, the district is facing a deficit. Currently, with carryover in funds from previous years, the estimated deficit is at $10.19 million.
"We've just got some difficult decisions to make as a district on how we're going to move forward with the current budget crisis that we're in," DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson said during a Dorchester County Board of Education budget work session Thursday.
Jodi Colman, district assistant superintendent of academics and student services, said the budget increases for fiscal year 2026 make it possible to keep the district's current staff in place.
"This would just be to basically maintain the programs that we have right now," she said about the draft budget. "All of those increases were due to just keeping our staff that we have for the most part."
Thompson said "a whole host of things" has caused the deficit, mentioning fixed costs and unfunded mandates from the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, a plan passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 that aims to improve student outcomes and the quality of education across the state.
Board of Education Member Brandy Dawson Cumberland said that although the board likes a lot of what the Blueprint aims to do, there are "certain unfunded mandates that are going to cut other things."
Thompson said the district is still waiting on exact numbers from the state and county. He said once they have those numbers, it is possible the deficit could be lower than $10.19 million.
"But I don't think that it will be higher than that," he said.
So far, the district has taken a number of actions to reduce the deficit, Thompson said. This includes:
Reducing some positions added with Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief fundingSending emails about non-essential spendingDeciding not to hire for vacated positionsReducing the central office custodian scheduleReducing student support monitorsMerging some job dutiesEliminating the education specialist position
"We did try to make some significant changes," Thompson said. "And there's more that I didn't put up that we have done. But the reality is it's not enough."
The district is looking into more actions that can be taken to reduce the deficit. Some possible actions include revisiting who should have board vehicles, auditing and reducing the number of programs and platforms the district uses, revising overtime policies, sharing resources with the county and reducing staff.
"No one wants this one," Thompson said about reducing staff.
While listing different "cost containment options" Thompson and board members made it clear that the district hasn't made any decisions yet, and is just looking at potential cost-cutting options.
"We are just at the beginning of starting to think about what things we can do to attack that number," Board of Education Vice President Talibah Chikwendu said.
"And that's why we really would like to have public input to know what the public feels are areas we should focus on if possible," Board President Sheri Hubbard said. "Because we want to do what's best for kids, bottom line."
The Dorchester County Board of Education will host another budget work session on Feb. 13. It will also hold one in March. The district's proposed budget must be submitted to the county in June.
Board Member Chris Wheedleton said that if community members are able to do anything, they should talk with their representatives in Annapolis.
"Because we need their help," he said.
Thompson urged that this is the time to work together and not be divided.
"Because at the end of the day, we know that $10 million deficit that we're in, that's going to hurt the kids," he said. "That's going to have a profound impact on how we can provide resources for our students."

title: TCPS Superintendent Addresses Immigration Enforcement Concerns in Letter to Families
author: Konner Metz
content:
TCPS superintendent addresses immigration enforcement concerns in letter to families

 January 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 261
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Addressing recent changes to federal immigration enforcement, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi emphasized schools as "safe places" in a letter to staff and families Thursday."I want to assure you that our schools remain places of safety, inclusion, and respect for all students, staff, and families," Pepukayi wrote. "As a district, our priority is to ensure every student can learn, grow, and succeed without fear. We are committed to providing a welcoming and supportive learning environment for every student regardless of their background or immigration status."
The letter included a list of resources, including services from the American Civil Liberties Union and Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center.
Since President Donald Trump's inauguration last week, executive orders and directives have brought sweeping policy changes to federal immigration enforcement.
A directive last week from the Trump administration reversed a policy that established places such as schools, churches and shelters as "protected areas." That policy discouraged immigration enforcement agents from conducting arrests in those areas.
"Criminals will no longer be able to hide in America's schools and churches to avoid arrest," Department of Homeland Security spokesperson Benjamine Huffman wrote in a Jan. 21 statement.
In her letter, Pepukayi said that school administrators and staff are prepared to support students. She added that the district will keep track of policy changes that may affect the community and "share updates if appropriate."
"The strength of our community lies in our unity and compassion for one another," Pepukayi wrote. "Together, we can ensure that our schools are safe places for all students, staff, and families to feel supported and valued."
