title: Olde School Builders Welcomes Student Apprentice
author: Konner Metz
content:
Olde School Builders welcomes student apprentice

 June 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Business 
 
 307
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Olde School Builders, a local home construction and improvement company, welcomed its first ever apprentice last week.Kimberly Escalante-Garcia, a rising senior at North Caroline High School, signed on as an apprentice on June 16, joining the business that focuses on reconstructing historic buildings in the area.
Olde School Builders and school leaders said Escalante-Garcia joining the team was a display of impressive initiative from the 17-year-old.
Eric Cook, coordinator of career readiness for Caroline County Public Schools, said it was the easiest apprenticeship he's ever connected because Escalante-Garcia was the only one to pursue it after a Junior Achievement Fair attended by hundreds of fellow students.
"That's absolutely a kudos and a show of what kind of student and what kind of future employee Kim is, because it is one of 600 in terms of reaching out afterwards to the business," Cook said.
Olde School Builders President Craig Postlewait said Escalante-Garcia will be involved with all aspects of the company, from helping with construction labor to business operations. He noted that during interviews, she indicated interest in owning her own business one day.
The apprenticeship comes at a time when he says the company is on a mission to get girls and young women involved in the construction and building industry and empower them to go after job opportunities in similar fields.
Olde School Builders has recently partnered with Easton Middle School to run a Girls Who Build club. Postlewait said this past spring, the students who joined were hesitant at first but left feeling more confident and comfortable.
On June 16, Postlewait expressed excitement to welcome Escalante-Garcia on board for the summer and following school year. He said he wants people and young girls to gain that confidence in areas that may, at times, not be considered by most high schoolers.
"We're so happy to have her with us," Postlewait said.

title: Shoe Drive Will Start Greensboro Elementary Students Off on the Right Foot
author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Shoe drive will start Greensboro Elementary students off on the right foot

 July 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 291
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — St. Paul's United Methodist Church is partnering with Greensboro Elementary and the Town of Greensboro to start a shoe drive for Greensboro Elementary students.The Rev. Bonnie Shively, pastor of St. Paul's, came up with the idea as a way to serve the community.
"I've never done any school drive or a shoe drive before," Shively said. "I was talking with a couple other folks, and we were kicking around the idea of maybe doing a backpack drive. So, that led to a conversation of wondering what kind of school supplies the kids need at the beginning of the year."
Shively then contacted Greensboro Elementary to see what supplies would be needed and got the answer of new shoes for students.
"One of the things that was shared is that so many kids start out the school year, the kids don't get new school shoes like a lot of us did when we were growing up. So, that's kind of how it came about and it's a unique idea," Shively said.
The church is accepting new shoes from sizes 7 toddler to size 6 adults. The only shoes that will not be accepting are flip flops.
Shively said the church is excited to do something for the community and hopes the shoe drive will be positive.
"I think it's a really good feeling when we can help out the kids," Shively said. "Certainly, getting the various groups together in the community to come together put this drive together. We're already looking at where this will lead us in regard to what are some other areas that we can partner together for our community."
Residents can drop off new shoes at Greensboro Town Hall from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. on Monday through Friday until Aug. 29.

title: Ed Spec Committee Recommends North Caroline Site for New Lockerman Middle
author: Ahmad Garnett
content:
Ed Spec Committee recommends North Caroline site for new Lockerman Middle

 July 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 467
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Board of Education is one step closer to picking a new location for Lockerman Middle School.At the monthly Board of Education meeting Tuesday, the Lockerman Middle School Ed Specs Committee said that after the feasibility study and community input, the recommended location for the new school is on the same property as North Caroline High School.
Board of Education members decided not to formally vote on a location after receiving almost two hours of information from the Ed Specs Committee. The board decided to push the decision back to the August meeting.
Multiple reasons came forward on why the North Caroline High site was recommended over the Double Hills Road site.
"Some of the highlights that came out throughout the analysis and the surveys was again, the infrastructure. If you're not spending a lot of money on that, the site readiness, the educational alignment, a lot of really exciting ideas came out during the community meeting of ways that you could really have mentorships and things like that with the older and the younger students being on one site," said Robyn Toth, architect for the new school.
Reason included the use for indoor and outdoor activities and the ability to share space for events at North Caroline High.
"There's clear paths for the indoor and outdoor activities," Toth said. "There's no crossing of streets, lots of capabilities there also because you are sharing more spaces… There were some concerns about large events and right now, if they're at Double Hills or if they're at Lockerman now, where do we go for these large events? That don't happen that often and you don't necessarily need to build more space that the state's not going to support. Well, you've got a high school right there that's got a large auditorium. It's got a large gym."
With the North Caroline High location, development prices will be about $500,000 cheaper. The site development for the North Caroline High location will be $10 million, while Double Hills Road would cost $10.5 million.
Although in the community meetings multiple builds were shown, the new middle school, regardless of the location, will be a two-story building with a two-wing design.
According to the Ed Specs Committee Powerpoint, the new anticipated project budget would be $103.82 million with state funding coming in at around $80 million and local funding covering the remainder.
The only concerns brought up about the North Caroline High site were the solar array on the property and the traffic Central Avenue could receive from a new school being added to the location.
To purchase the solar panels on the property, it would cost about $180,000, which doesn't include the cost of relocation.
The Board of Education will take all the information received and make a decision on what location will be picked at its August meeting.

title: Dorchester Schools Prepare for More Cuts
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester schools prepare for more cuts

 July 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 322
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Dorchester County Public Schools are projected to lose over $642,000 in federal funding after the Trump Administration suddenly announced the decision to withhold $6.8 billion in federal education cuts, according to DCPS communications specialist Casey O'Bier.The U.S. Department of Education cut 28 K-12 programs saying "states and localities, not the Federal government, are best suited to determine whether to support the activities authorized under this program or similar activities within their own budgets and without unnecessary administrative burden imposed by the Federal government," or stating the program has not been proven effective, or that cutting funding is to restore fiscal discipline in the states.
In an email to the Star Democrat, O'Bier said those cuts will impact a variety of programs including teacher training, internal and external student experiences, and English Language Learner programs.
"DCPS would need to reallocate existing funds to sustain programs that were originally funded through some of these federal grants or eliminate various programs in a worst-case scenario," O'Bier stated as one of the district's central concerns.
The federal funding cuts to education come at a time when Dorchester County Public Schools are already struggling financially.
In January, DCPS faced a budget deficit of $10.19 million, which they reduced to $5.59 million in March. To further reduce the deficit, DCPS got rid of their after school and summer programs.
The county had to reduce staff sizing, but Superintendent Jymil Thompson said he wants to keep class sizes small and retain teachers at all costs.
The Board of Education has been making concerted efforts to move DCPS from 23rd out of 24 school districts — including Baltimore City — in state education ranking, but the federal funding cuts make those efforts more difficult.
"Moving forward, we will be proactively looking closely at unique ways to reallocate pre-existing funds to support the inclusion of these federally funded programs which are a major asset to Dorchester County Public Schools and the enrichment of its students," O'Bier said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dorchester School Board Adjusts Spending in Wake of Federal Budget Cuts
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester school board adjusts spending in wake of federal budget cuts

 July 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 271
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Board of Education met Thursday for the first time since hearing about massive U.S. Department of Education budget cuts.According to the Maryland Department of Education, the Department of Education informed them that they will not be receiving the $360 million that federal officials had allocated to the state.
Dorchester share of the funding cuts will be about $642,000.
This comes at a time when Dorchester County Public Schools are already struggling financially, having dealt with a $10.19 million deficit in January that forced the county to make hard decisions like cutting afterschool and summer programs.
However, the the board was able to make several approvals with only one program cut during Thursday's meeting.
Board members approved the following:
The board approved a five-year writable contract for grades 6-12, which is critical for writing instruction and assessments tied to state standards. The entire $50,000 cost is covered in this year's budget.Approved a five-year IXL learning contract for grades 3-12, which is budgeted at $23,000 for the current year and future payments must be budgeted in subsequent years.Approved Math Curriculum Consumables, which is paid from this year's textbook budget.Approved the annual contract with the Dorchester County Health Department school nurse contract.Approved the Facilities Master Plan Update which is necessary for capital improvement eligibility.
Board members did not renew or approve Lexia, a widely used computer-based literacy program designed to help students improve their reading skills, because of concerns and issues with its effectiveness like inaccurate data, lack of instructional alignment among teachers and staff, and its high cost.
The board will meet again in August to discuss policies regarding digital devices, AI and dress codes.

title: Moving to the Music
author: Will Bontrager
content:
Moving to the music

 July 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 748
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Ten students in Ashton Mooday's modern band camp in Chestertown received an unexpected thrill to close out their class, Friday, June 27. They got to record in a professional studio, a privilege and honor many musicians do not get the chance to have.The 28-year-old singer/songwriter, teacher and owner of Mooday's Music LLC, teacher said it was beneficial for her students to see the hard work behind the making of music while developing pride in their accomplishments.
Mooday explained that Ken Schweitzer, associate chair of the Department of Music at Washington College, had received a grant to record small independent artists at their studio. Schweitzer, knowing about Mooday's music, asked her to record something. Mooday was honored but did not have any new songs at the time.
However, she did have students which the grant also allows for, Schweitzer pointed out.
After learning three favorite and popular songs: Michael Jackson's "Beat It", "OK Not To Be OK" by Marshmello and Demi Lovato and "Best Day of My Life" by American Authors, students of Mooday's week-long class decided to go with the latter to record.
On 9 a.m. that Friday, students Mason Poulson, Abbie Donophan, Emma Christophel, Whitley Sparks, Micah Christophel, Hannah Sadler, Quinn Greenwell, Asher Sadler, Adah Sadler and Jezzy Greenwell stepped into the studio prepared.
Washington College audio engineer students Stevie Lyles and Mariana Kilman got the equipment set up to record the students choice "Best Day of my Life." Mooday, with assistance from guitar teacher Matt Wirtz and drum set instructor Emily Holden, said the tune was fun for the kids to learn. "It's just catchy with two chords and a simple, fun drum pattern," she said.
The class recorded in parts. Micah Christophel posted up behind the drum set establishing the beat first. Next, Wirtz guided students on guitars and helped lay out the licks (musical phrases). Mooday assisted her kids on the ukuleles as well as vocals. All the while, she insisted they participate as much as possible which they were eager to do.
"All the kids played played a part in the process which was really cool. Every student sang when it came to lay down the vocals track as well."
Mooday said it was also important for them to see the hardworking people in the background behind some of their favorite songs. They were eyewitness to the engineers mixing the track, adding some reverb to their vocals and were amazed at the finished product.
Mooday took joy seeing the kids' confidence grow in the studio.
The entire recording, mixing and production process was efficient. They were in and out in two hours, Mooday said. The engineer students delivered the finished track to her in time to develop a slideshow to be presented to parents and students later that day for a final performance.
That same afternoon at Mooday's Music, the kids performed two songs, the one they had recorded and also "OK Not To Be OK," receiving applause for their hard work and dedication.
Mooday was elated, appreciating the timing of Schweitzer's offer coordinating with her class schedule. "It worked out so nicely," Mooday said. "They are so young and for them to have this opportunity was amazing."
Now in her sixth year teaching, music changed Mooday's life and at an early age she desired sharing that with others.
Mooday followed that passion, using some bleak times in her life to shape her faith and music. She has a B.S. in music education and B.A. in flute performance and Masters degree in music education with a certificate in modern band at Lebanon Valley College.
The intense years of music study allowed her to live out her dream, owning her own music classroom, passing on the lessons music taught her.
"I really enjoy the private lessons setting because it gives me a chance to work individually with a student, meeting their needs and helping them grow to not only play their chosen instrument, but also grow a love for music. I have a passion for working with students with higher needs and challenging myself to find what works best for their learning processes."
And in the future, she will have more space to do that, adding on an extra 2,000 square feet, enabling her team to conduct two summer camps a year, with more room for private lessons, kid classes, and to teach homeschoolers.
Learn more about Mooday's Music LLC by visiting her website, moodaysmusicllc.org, and be sure to check out all of her work, which includes albums, singles and EPs that date all the way back to 2017 on Spotify. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

 July 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester Board of Education met Thursday July 11 for their monthly meeting and discussed the following agenda items:Approved $50,000 for the Houghton Mifflin Harcourt contract for grades 6-12 for five years, which allows instruction, assessment and monitoring of student progress.Approved the IXL contract, a subscription based program that provides personalized learning experiences and allows teachers to share materials for better consistency, for grades 3-12. title: Dorchester County Board of Education Discusses Student Devices
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester County Board of Education discusses student devices

 July 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 205
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Board of Education has decided to revisit its student device usage policy.At Thursday's board meeting, board members voiced a need to create a standard across all Dorchester County campuses.
In October of last year, the board implemented a pilot program at three DCPS middle schools: Maces Lane, North Dorchester and South Dorchester School, where students secured their phones in locked pouches at the beginning of the school day and got them unlocked at the end.
Board members said they learned the pouches are not effective.
"What we did learn is that the kids are crafty young people," DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson said. "They're able to get around a lot of things with the pouches. They got great skill."
With the school year approaching, the board of education wants to make a decision on the policy sooner rather than later. Board members agreed to get rid of the pouches, but they will likely come up with an alternative like locking student's personal devices in lockers or backpacks.
The board made a motion to pass the policy as a first read with the understanding that revisions will be made before the second read and final approval at the next meeting on Aug. 21 at 6 p.m.

title: Washington College Receives $4.5 Million Gift
author: Staff Writer
content:
Washington College receives $4.5 million gift

 July 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 359
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Richard and Tara Wood, both alumni and parents of a recent Washington College graduate, have made a substantial gift to the small liberal arts college on Maryland's Eastern Shore that will fund endowed chairs in leadership and international business, as well as improvements to the College's tennis and sailing initiatives.The $4.5 million multi-year contribution aligns with Washington's strategic priorities and will be divided into several initiatives with $2.5 million allocated to the creation of the Wood Director of Leadership. This role will attract top-tier leadership experts to campus for special programs, oversee leadership program development, and support students in their leadership journeys.
"This new role will allow us to expand our co-curricular offerings and provide dynamic leadership development experiences that will benefit our students greatly," said Washington College President Mike Sosulski. "We are incredibly grateful to the Wood family for their commitment to enhancing the distinctive opportunities we provide our students and for their visionary leadership in supporting the College's historic mission to prepare the next generation of citizen leaders."
The gift from the Woods includes funding for:
$750,000 for the establishment of the Wood Family Chair within the Business Management Department for International Business. The gift is a match extending the capabilities made possible from a $5 million gift from the JHC Foundation, a Warehime family foundation, made in 2024 to support Business Management programmingA $1 million challenge grant to support the construction of an indoor tennis facility$250,000 to support the Washington College Sailing Program.
These initiatives aim to advance the mission of the college and position it for long-term sustainability and growth as well as enhancing the student experience.
"Tara and I are deeply committed to Washington College's enduring mission of cultivating well-rounded citizen leaders," Richard Wood said. "It is our sincere hope that these endowed chairs in leadership and international business, along with the support for athletics, will empower generations of students to develop the knowledge, skills, and character necessary to make meaningful contributions to the ever-evolving world. This investment will not only enhance the academic and co-curricular experiences at Washington, but also ensure its continued success in shaping principled and impactful individuals for many years to come."

title: 'Closing Gaps': TCPS Data Shows Some Literacy, Math Improvements
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Closing gaps': TCPS data shows some literacy, math improvements

 July 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 586
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Test score data from last school year is showing key math and English improvements for some Talbot County students, according to school officials.Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi presented data sets to the Board of Education last week. She's especially pleased with jumps for the district's Black and Hispanic students.
"We are closing gaps and moving the needle on the subgroups," Pepukayi said in an interview.
School data from the Measures of Academic Progress, or MAP, testing program shows 68% of kindergarten students scored in the 50th percentile or above in math in the 2024-2025 school year. That's up from 54% the year prior.
The percent of students, sorted by grade, meeting or exceeding that 50th percentile for the math and ELA tests mostly increased across the board. Dips were seen for third and fifth graders in ELA performance.
And in subgroups, there were many green arrows for Black and Hispanic students. For instance, both Black and Hispanic third graders saw a 31% year-to-year jump in testing at the 50th percentile mark or above in math, and a 21% year-to-year increase for that same mark in ELA.
"I'm really glad to see such improvement in the Latino and Black community. That's huge," said Board Member Deborah Bridges at the July 16 meeting.
Pepukayi attributes the hikes, in part, to improved curriculum and the dedication of Talbot County's teachers.
"I can't pinpoint to say that was it, but I think we're on the right track of students learning skills that are aligned to standards," Pepukayi said. "And we're looking at students being proficient on standards versus just getting a grade."
The tests discussed at last week's board meeting included MAP testing and the Dynamic Indicators of Basic Early Literacy Skill test. Statewide test scores typically are released in August or September.
DIBELS scores weren't drastically different from the year prior. A higher percentage of rising first and third graders tested above the literacy benchmark in 2024-2025 than 2023-2024, but second graders above the benchmark dropped by 5%.
In the MAP testing, the percent of fifth graders meeting the 50th percentile for ELA dropped by 6.6%. That decrease was mirrored by ELA drops for fifth graders in the following subgroups: Hispanic students, students with disabilities, multilingual students and students on free and reduced meals.
Data also shows this year's incoming sixth-grade class performed 4.1% worse in ELA in fifth grade than they did in fourth grade.
"Fifth graders are the kids that didn't get to finish kindergarten because of COVID," noted Board Vice President Amy Dodson.
Pepukayi said the next step is to fix those trends by focusing on the elementary-to-middle transition. She said in an interview that TCPS is vying to fill open reading and math coach positions for the middle schools — roles that have been beneficial at the elementary schools.
"That's what we're working on," Pepukayi said. "I would say that's probably the challenge, of getting our staff and finding the staff to really do the interventions needed in the middle-school levels."
She emphasized that schools are collecting data on a smaller, classroom scale in order to know what's working and what's not.
"While we still have work to do, I think we do have to celebrate the small wins," Pepukayi said.
Board President Emily Jackson thanked Pepukayi and administrators for diving deeper into the year-to-year trends.
"We have been asking for these kind of results for a long time," said Jackson, who's served on the board since 2018. "And the way that you showed up with the full transparent picture of what is happening in our schools, I think is really important."

title: Hip-Hop meets High Street
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Hip-Hop meets High Street

 July 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 764
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When headed down High Street in Chestertown toward the water, you may notice the building near Dixon Drive has gotten a little more colorful.Across the field, the side of 800 High Street is covered in graffiti-style art — checkered patterns, winding vines, sun rays and messages such as "Labor of Love," alongside odes to the former Dixon Valve building and Vita Foods.
These were two former businesses located on the property — historic places with plenty of stories still to tell and a new generation beginning to learn about them.
The art is part of a two-week summer course called the Hip Hop Time Capsule. High school students from Cecil, Queen Anne's and Kent counties, along with Washington College student interns, were taught local history while exercising creativity in a way that merges both.
The project is spearheaded by Washington College's Starr Center for the Study of the American Experience, Chesapeake Heartland: An African American Humanities Project, and the Kohl Gallery, in partnership with Minary's Dream Alliance.
Organizers selected and supervised the students.
For two weeks, they worked with musicians, college professors and museum professionals to research, explore, document and interpret the rich history of African American music in Kent County.
In past years, students composed original tracks using digitized audio clips to build beats. They wrote lyrics or performed spoken word pieces and layered them over music, producing original songs complete with cover art.
Pat Nugent, director of civic engagement at Washington College, has led the innovative class for the past five years.
And innovation is the name of the game. Since an innovation plant is being established at 800 High Street, organizers moved the Hip Hop Time Capsule program into the building — a natural fit, said Darius Johnson, director of the Starr Center's Chesapeake Heartland Project.
"We really wanted the students to feel like they have a stake in what we're doing here," Johnson said. "So having it at the innovation plant just made sense. And the music is a great hook."
"Our student interns have come together to learn a number of skills and trades, to reflect on our community's past and future, and to make their mark on this evolving property at the heart of Chestertown," Nugent said.
"The tables, benches, murals, posters and music they designed and brought into being have enriched the site and will ensure the innovation plant becomes a vibrant crossroads for both campus and community."
Organizers pared down the original pool of 60 students to just under 40. Selected participants received an introduction to hip hop, explored local art, learned about the historic uptown area and studied the histories of Vita Foods and Dixon Valve.
Based on survey responses, students were assigned to one of four tracks: music, murals, metalwork or screen printing, Johnson said.
They spent a two-hour workshop with an instructor from their chosen track. For example, Eastern Shore native Shelton Hawkins oversaw the murals and shared his experience beautifying basketball courts — a skill that has taken him across the globe, including painting the Golden State Warriors court.
In each workshop, students learned about the origins of hip hop, explored how to make their mark and practiced self-expression using modern technologies, Johnson added.
They also had access to 5,600 digitized materials of Black history — including photo albums, home movies, oral histories, interviews and documents dating back as early as the 1700s.
The class began July 14 and concluded Friday, July 25, when close to 100 children from the Horizons of Kent and Queen Anne's program attended a special event, broadening the program's reach and impact.
Participants were also paid for their involvement: high school students received $1,200 each and the 11 college interns received $1,422.
Johnson said the students gained confidence from the experience.
"It has been a really beautiful process," he said. "Students built trust, overcame fears, developed employable skills and analyzed their community with critical eyes."
For those who voiced concerns about the art on the building in historic Chestertown, Johnson offered reassurance.
The artwork is only temporary.
It served as a way for interns to express creativity and passion, engage in community outreach and strengthen local ties.
"We know that the foundation of a successful innovation plant has to be built on relationships and be responsive to community interests," said Sara Clarke-De Reza, chair of the education department at Washington College. "Programs like Hip Hop Time Capsule help us imagine how this space might be best developed to meet the needs of the next generation of makers, innovators and entrepreneurs."
The program encourages students to become both civic leaders and innovative designers.
Follow along with the continuing work of the innovation plant on Instagram: @wc_innovation_plant. Learn more about Chesapeake Heartland at chesapeakeheartland.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot, Kent See Rise in Student Homelessness
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot, Kent see rise in student homelessness

 July 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 674
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — State numbers show youth homelessness on the rise in parts of the Eastern Shore. Local shelters aiding families and single parents are noticing similar trends.Data from the Maryland State Department of Education shows Kent and Talbot counties had the largest year-to-year increase, by percentage, of students experiencing homelessness.
In the 2022-2023 school year, Kent County reported 66 homeless students; in 2023-2024, it took a 55% jump to 102 students. Talbot County's increase rate was 39%; 233 students experienced homelessness in 2022-2023, and 324 students in 2023-2024.
Counts for 2024-2025 haven't yet been released — the most recent data was published in February — but leaders of nonprofit shelters have been seeing the increases in recent months.
"We are definitely seeing an increase in calls for families needing shelter," said Julie Lowe, executive director of Talbot Interfaith Shelter.
Last school year, Easton-based Talbot Interfaith housed 31 children, Lowe said. That's a "steady increase," she noted, though the shelter is limited on how many families it can help due to high demand, requirements for shelter residents and bedroom sizes.
Just three of Maryland's 24 districts saw a year-to-year drop in student homelessness, state data shows. The counts are collected as required by the federal McKinney-Vento Act, which ensures students experiencing homelessness receive an education.
A reason for the increase in Kent County is that school staff are better trained to identify the students defined as homeless under the McKinney-Vento Act, according to Kent County Public Schools spokesperson Dan Divilio.
"Homelessness in Kent County looks different from the common perception of someone living on the street or in a car," Divilio wrote in an email. "Unhoused students often still have a roof over their head at night, but it may belong to an extended family member or a family friend."
Divilio added that in addition to free school meals and the efforts of social workers and counselors, the district maintains partnerships with local organizations that serve families and children in need.
Talbot County Public Schools officials say the pandemic has played a role in the increased count.
"The number of students experiencing homelessness is generally a reflection of the current economic climate in the nation, state, and region," a statement from the district read. "The increase from SY 22-23 to SY 23-24, which is evident in the data for nearly all Maryland School Districts, was largely due to economic challenges faced by many families following the COVID-19 pandemic."
In Talbot, around 7% of students are homeless under the McKinney-Vento report, per state enrollment data. Nearly 6% of Kent County's 1,700-plus students experienced homelessness.
Those marks in other Eastern Shore districts like Dorchester (3.6%), Queen Anne's (2.9%) and Caroline (2.2%) are lower, but the need to help the youth still remains, nonprofit leaders say.
Stefanie Johnson, executive director of the Denton-based shelter His Hope Ministries, has seen an increase in families and single parents seeking assistance, too.
The McKinney-Vento data for Kent County doesn't come as a shock to her. And Divilio, the KCPS spokesperson, noted that the district's count for 2024-2025 is 108 children, including children enrolled K-12 and toddlers in the district's early learning programs.
"Absolutely a lot more calls coming to us from Kent County, so I'm not really surprised by that unfortunately," Johnson said.
Shelters on the Eastern Shore are moving to assist homeless youth, but helping that age range comes with its own unique set of obstacles.
Johnson said a specific challenge in the 13- to 18-year-old range is that her shelter can't take on children without some sort of guardianship or family present.
"With that 18 to 25 (age range), it's a little easier to kind of help them navigate," Johnson said.
Lowe said the Talbot Interfaith Shelter serves many single parents — some of them with two or three kids. The shelter offers life skills and job readiness assistance, as well as a transitional program for people to begin paying partial rent before being able to graduate to full payments.
But with the murky affordability of rentals in the area, Lowe said it's not always easy for families to make that transition.
"Homelessness is a housing problem," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Lockerman High School Celebrates 95th Anniversary
author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Lockerman High School celebrates 95th anniversary

 July 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On Saturday, The Lockerman Schools Association Inc. celebrated the 95th anniversary of Lockerman High School.The celebration Saturday featured a theme of "Capturing our history, preserving our legacy and advancing our future."
Lockerman Schools Association Chairperson Willie Woods called the event "gratifying" as different generations came together to celebrate Lockerman.
"It was very gratifying to see the community continuing to just work together and come together to celebrate the rich history that Lockerman has and the role it has played in the lives of multiple generations of residents of Caroline County," Woods said.
Lockerman School started in 1930, when Isaac Thomas donated land to the Black Parent-Teachers Association for a school. In 1931, the school was named after Joseph H. Lockerman, a Black educator who was born 1862 near Denton.
The school remained Joseph H. Lockerman High School until 1966, when the school closed its doors as a Black high school and became the integrated Riverview Middle School.
The Lockerman name was restored in 1993 at a Lockerman Middle School pre-dedication ceremony, which highlighted the history of Lockerman School.
The president of the Caroline County Board of Education at the time was George W. Fisher. William D. Brown was president of the Concerned Friends of Lockerman, the forerunner of the current Lockerman Schools Association Inc.
The Lockerman Schools Association Inc. was established in 1993 as a nonprofit to engage in educational, literary or charitable activities that benefit students who have ties to any of the Lockerman Schools.
Woods described the process of planning Saturday's event as honoring the past and addressing the present.
"You sort of share the vision, the idea, brainstorm with individuals and then begin to establish It's a working plan," Woods said. "...Then we look at some things we want to recognize and honor. If you look at our theme, capturing our history what other kinds of things are happening or we're experiencing that we can bring to the forefront, so that our members and the community in general are aware and some of those were highlighted during the presentation of awards and certificates."
Members of classes 1935, 1945, 1955 and 1965 came to celebrate class anniversaries.
While some members weren't able to attend, family members or friends accepted plaques and small trophies on their behalf. Caroline County and Board of Education officials attended the anniversary event.
The Lockerman Association also presented 13 scholarships to Caroline County students pursing higher education. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Green Thumbs: Kids, Teens Learn to Grow Plants Nature's Way
author: Will Bontrager
content:
Green thumbs: Kids, teens learn to grow plants nature's way

 August 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 719
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Kids in the summer program in Kent County Parks and Recreation are learning at a young age to grow plants using only natural methods, no pesticides.Former U.S. Rep. Wayne Gilchrest, a longtime area resident, is working with Parks and Recreation on this horticulture program on county-owned land in Turner's Creek.
Almost directly across from the Kent County Museum, at the end of a dirt trail, there is a garden with 12 plots measuring 10 by 20 feet reserved for elementary and middle school students who attend summer camp.
"The kids have their own space to garden. They plant them and grow them," Gilchrest said. "We supervise and give them the tools they need."
Tools like 40-gallon water drums and compost piles of hay, cedar chips, cow manure and food scraps.
They learn these skills, taught by expert growers including Gilchrest, University of Maryland Extension Agent Beth Hill, Maryland SNAP-Ed Nutrition Educator Eric Fitch, members of the University of Maryland Extension Master Gardener Program and several others.
Gilchrest, who has been growing crops the majority of his life, teaches kids their first lesson, pointing to the forest line full of mature trees and vegetation.
"I tell them, 'You see these woods? They don't need fertilizer to help them grow,'" he said.
The key is to copy those same natural conditions in the garden, he said.
At the end of the school year, they met at the grounds. Bonnie's Plants donated tomato, squash, watermelon, pepper and many other plants. Kids chose what they wanted in their garden and planted it in the soil, using the mulch mixture of cedar chips donated from waterman Sam Joiner and cow manure from a nearby farm. Hay was also donated by Hopkins Game Farm.
This mixture sits for a year, decomposing and providing nutrients, phosphorus, calcium, potassium and minerals for the health of the plant. With hay surrounding the plant like a "rug," stamped down properly to keep the weeds away, growing experts show campers how to foster their plant's growth.
The hay also attracts wolf spiders, Gilchrest added, providing a demonstration of how nature polices itself.
He explained wolf spiders are actually beneficial. They are predatory toward insects that like to chew on the vegetables and would otherwise kill the plant.
With predatory bugs, healthy compost and weed control, kids learn how to prepare their gardens for harvest.
"I say to anybody, if they know a little about photosynthesis and the living soil, you can be a farmer," Gilchrest said.
He explains to the kids that photosynthesis, the process that green plants use sunlight to synthesize foods from carbon dioxide and water, is essential to growth.
When the sun hits a green plant, it creates glucose, which is used by the plant for energy and growth.
He said they learn about soil health creating a vital ecosystem for all living things.
In the example of the sunlight hitting the plant, bacteria then eat the glucose, or plant sugar, that the plant produces, and then other things eat the bacteria, and through waste removal, establishes a cycle of growth to nourish everything — plant, animal and human.
These important lessons are being taught to kids who, when out there, are focused.
"The kids are amazing. They take to this stuff like blue to the sky," Gilchrest said, smiling.
And when visitors are there, they know they have something important to impart. For example, Hill helps them identify bugs beneficial to the plants and harmful to them.
"The kids were so excited. Some said 'here comes the bug lady!'" Gilchrest said, chuckling.
Hill pointed out that they have been identifying and talking about insects as they find them, including dogbane beetles, butterflies (tiger swallowtails, zebra swallowtails, monarchs and black swallowtails), damselflies and dragonflies, bees, squash bugs and striped cucumber beetles.
"We have also looked at fungus, weeds, birds, native plants and more. It's been a lot of fun and the kids and counselors are terrific," Hill added.
With Fitch there every Monday and Thursday, Hill's visits and the Master Gardeners as regulars, the campers are in good hands — hands with green thumbs.
"Everyone has been very helpful. This has been a good program of everyone coming together," Gilchrest said.
The program is in its second year with aims to expand, possibly adding a solar-powered well 100 feet deep so they do not have to rely on water drums.
"Hopefully there is much more to come in the near future," Gilchrest said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Board of Ed Selects North Caroline Site for New Lockerman Middle
author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Board of Ed selects North Caroline site for new Lockerman Middle

 August 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 396
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County Board of Education members unanimously voted in favor of the North Caroline High site for the new location for Lockerman Middle School.The approval came at the board's meeting Aug. 5. The site puts the new middle school right next to North Caroline High School, giving the county its second location with a middle school and high school on the same property.
The North Caroline High site will allow 15.52 acres of space for the build of Lockerman Middle. The exact location of the building on the site has not been determined yet.
At the previous Board of Education meeting in July, multiple reasons came forward on why the North Caroline High site was recommended over a Double Hills Road site that was also being considered.
"Some of the highlights that came out throughout the analysis and the surveys was, again, the infrastructure. If you're not spending a lot of money on that, the site readiness, the educational alignment, a lot of really exciting ideas came out during the community meeting of ways that you could really have mentorships and things like that with the older and the younger students being on one site," said Robyn Toth, architect for the new school, in July.
Reason included the ability to share space for events at North Caroline High.
"There's clear paths for the indoor and outdoor activities," Toth said. "There's no crossing of streets, lots of capabilities there also because you are sharing more spaces… There were some concerns about large events and right now, if they're at Double Hills or if they're at Lockerman now, where do we go for these large events? That don't happen that often and you don't necessarily need to build more space that the state's not going to support. Well, you've got a high school right there that's got a large auditorium. ."
Bill Mengel, director of operations for Caroline County Public Schools, said the only concern with the North Caroline High site is the solar array on the property. The county has been in conversation with Tesla to purchase the solar array. No official purchase has been made yet.
To purchase the solar panels on the property, it would cost about $180,000, which doesn't include the cost of relocation.
Board members said the decision on the location was a very early step in a marathon of decisions before the new school will be built.

title: New Learning Center in Southern Maryland Provides Resources for Children with Autism
author: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com
content:
New learning center in southern Maryland provides resources for children with autism

 August 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 392
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A zip-glide, slide and shelves with toys and games welcome children with autism to play with same-aged peers at a new learning center in Waldorf.SPARKS ABA, which uses personalized therapy treatments for children with autism, serves 30 Charles County families at home or at the center, Genevieve Marshall, senior regional director at SPARKS ABA, said.
Having a location in Waldorf offers a space for families who are not always available to stay at home during sessions.
Leah Jones, a behavioral analyst at SPARKS ABA, said, the learning center opened in May for children to have an open space to learn, play games, and work on arts and crafts.
"There's a lot of natural opportunities to learn and grow and spend time with peers," Jones said.
Center-based and applied behavioral analysis-based services offer a different experience for different families, Marshall said.
Every child who comes for care is assigned to a technician for one-to-one support, Marshall said.
They also offer multi-learning instruction where children are matched with a peer or peer group. This could be circle time, like in preschools, or learning in small group interactions like sharing.
"Having that opportunity for social interaction and developing meaningful peer relationships is really important, especially at the preschool level," Marshall said.
During a child's first visit, SPARKS ABA does an initial assessment, which tells them how many hours a week a child needs to visit.
Programs aim to change the trajectory of a child's learning so they can catch up to their peers with the duration of treatment being measured in six-month increments.
"We want to try and get as many learning opportunities in as possible," Marshall said. "The goal that we have is therapy to be part of their everyday life."
Applied behavioral analysis looks at three things, Marshall said.
"Applied" considers problems or skills people have and looks for solutions based on positive teaching opportunities. SPARKS ABA takes guidance from science to inform their practice.
"Behavior" looks at things SPARKS ABA can see and measure. They focus on the individual, which includes looking at social interactions, language and navigating sensory issues.
"Analysis" evaluates data on the child to ensure the goals that were selected are changing.
"We know we're doing a good job when we've worked ourselves out of a job," Marshall said.
SPARKS ABA plans to have a Halloween-themed "Truck-or-Treat" open house on Oct. 25 from noon to 2 p.m.
For more information about the business, visit www.sparksaba.com.

title: Horses Are My Happy Place: Horse Rescue Welcomes Student Readers
author: Marty Madden mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
'Horses are my happy place': Horse rescue welcomes student readers

 August 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 554
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If you love to read and you love horses, there's a local rescue organization working in partnership with Calvert public schools that will give you a chance to combine those passions."I love horses," Morgan Chambers, 9, of Huntingtown said. "Horses are my happy place."
"She would rather spend every waking moment in a barn," Melissa Chambers said of her daughter's unabashed affection for the noble animals.
During an early August afternoon, Morgan, a student at Calvert Elementary, was one of several youngsters who used some summer vacation time at Freedom Hill Horse Rescue in Owings to read a book or two for the enjoyment of several of the facility's 10 retired equines.
Clutching a copy of "Harry the Dirty Dog," the nearly 70-year-old Gene Zion classic, Morgan Chambers prepared to read to Apollo, a 29-year-old quarter horse.
Although Freedom Hill has been almost the exclusive venue for the program (another facility, Traveller's Rest Farm Sanctuary in Hughesville has also hosted reading to horses events), school officials said the strategy could be used for just about any animal.
Marcy Gruver, who currently serves as Calvert County Public Schools' coordinator of Blueprint for Maryland's Future, told Southern Maryland News the local program is called "Read to the Animals." It's a similar initiative as one that was done in Baltimore County.
Calvert's Read to the Animals program is available for kindergarten to fifth-grade students.
"We've almost been fully booked every time" an event is held at the sanctuary, she said.
"The approach fosters reading fluency in a calm, supportive setting while also helping animals become more comfortable with human interaction," Gruver said. "Students also learn the value of service and compassion. Increased community presence at rescue centers can positively impact adoption rates and generate greater awareness and support for these organizations."
According to Gruver, school officials also reached out to local shelters housing dogs, cats and smaller animals, who graciously declined "due to staffing constraints and high intake numbers."
"It shows the students really caring about the animals," Melissa Huffman, supervisor of elementary English language arts, said.
"We're trying to do more outreach within the community," Beth Meader, the secretary of the Freedom Hill Horse Rescue board said. Of the Read to the Animals program, she added, "It's a win-win for the children."
"The kids seem to enjoy it and the horses seem to enjoy it," Lori Harrington, Freedom Hill's board president, said.
In its mission statement, the nonprofit's members affirm their dedication to "rescuing horses from neglect, abuse, abandonment and slaughter. We strive to improve the lives of horses by providing a haven for healing and rehabilitation."
Founded 21 years ago, Freedom Hill Horse Rescue is located on the grounds of historic Hampton Manor.
Reaching out to youth and adult organizations, Harrington said, has become a major focus at Freedom Hill. In addition to public schools, the organization also partners with homeschool groups, Scouts, first responders and veterans organizations.
Freedom hill hosts "about two or three programs a month," Harrington said, adding that no programs are held during cold weather months.
Meader said there is hope the reading initiative might inspire some of the participants to consider volunteering when they are older. A Freedom Hill volunteer must be 13 or older.
Gruver said Meader and the other volunteers at Freedom Hill "have gone above and beyond to prepare the horses for student visits."
For more information on Freedom Hill Horse Rescue, go to www.fhhr.org.

title: How Will Talbot County Schools Regulate AI This Year?
author: Konner Metz
content:
How will Talbot County schools regulate AI this year?

 August 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Headlines 
 
 155
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's already back-to-school time for kids in Talbot County.As parents and families prepare to drop off their kids Monday for the first day of school, district leaders have outlined new guidelines on artificial intelligence use. And they're not just looking at students.
At a Board of Education meeting Monday, Talbot County Director of Teaching and Learning Robin Werner presented the district's AI guidelines for the 2025-26 school year.
She said staff are encouraged to responsibly use AI tools. But teachers shouldn't be using it to fully plan lessons or make classroom decisions, Werner emphasized.
The board held a short discussion on the guidelines, which also lay out safe procedures for students, prohibited uses of AI and a rubric that will be piloted this school year. To learn more, read our story below.
Also in today's newsletter: Cambridge police discuss stats from the second quarter, Denton is getting a girls flag football team, and more.
Thanks for reading.
— Konner Metz

title: Talbot School Officials Discuss AI Guidelines for Students, Teachers
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot school officials discuss AI guidelines for students, teachers

 August 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 659
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County school district leaders aren't only focusing on how to moderate student use of artificial intelligence — they're looking to teachers, too.New guidelines discussed at a Board of Education work session Monday encourage teachers and staff to use AI responsibly. But AI shouldn't be used as a replacement for lesson planning or decision-making, said Robin Werner, the district's director of teaching and learning.
"It should be enhancing our instruction, but human oversight is imperative," Werner said. "We are not using it to replace any positions or staff members, but it is really a guiding tool that can help teachers."
On Monday, Werner presented an AI guidelines document to be observed this school year. While not a formal policy, the document lays out how the district's schools, teachers, staff and students should use AI.
Staff are encouraged to be transparent, and Werner said students should be comfortable asking when they can use AI tools.
AVOIDING THE 'GRAY AREA'
A committee of Talbot County teachers and administrators began researching AI last fall and developed the guidelines this winter. They visited the district's middle and high schools this spring to consult with teachers.
"Our goal is to ensure that AI empowers students and staff while maintaining academic integrity, equity and human oversight," Werner told board members.
Board members on Monday weighed whether to rely solely on the guidelines or consider adopting official policy changes. Policies and administrative regulations must be approved by the board.
Talbot County Public Schools' work to regulate AI comes as Werner said the State Department of Education is lagging behind other states in creating AI rules.
TCPS academic integrity and plagiarism policies are tied to state rules, which hasn't been updated to include new AI provisions, Werner said. Revising Talbot's official policies before any state updates wouldn't be prudent, she said.
"My suggestion would be that we wait until the state updates their code of conduct, and then we could avoid having to update it more than once," Werner said.
But Board President Emily Jackson said that while she understands AI is ever-evolving, a policy could spell out the standards more clearly.
"If we don't have solid policy to lean back on … I find it gets stickier and into that gray area," Jackson said.
Board member Dyshekia Strawberry agreed, and recommended the board adopt an AI policy, even if broad in nature, as the district waits for clearer advice from the state.
"Just to set some safety standards, such as not uploading any confidential information," Strawberry said.
Jackson suggested the policy committee bring back an AI policy or administrative regulation to the board at a future date.
STUDENT RULES
Despite not being an official policy, the guidelines highlight some specific rules that students and teachers should follow.
AI is prohibited when used to plagiarize or bully, Werner said.
Werner said the district will be piloting a rubric scaled from 0-4 this year for students. Teachers, if they wish, can notate certain assignments in one of the following categories:
0, AI cannot be used.1, AI can support ideas and brainstorming. Disclosure statement on how it was used is required.2, AI can assist in editing but not creating new material. Disclosure statement and link to AI chats must be included when work is submitted.3, AI can complete a specific task approved by the teacher. AI chats must be disclosed, and AI-created content must be properly cited.4, AI can be fully used as a "co-pilot" with human oversight. AI chats must be disclosed, and AI-created content must be properly cited.
Werner said staff appreciated the rubric, which was adapted from guidelines in North Carolina.
The district is encouraging that misuse of AI be "teachable moments" instead of automatic jumps to discipline, Werner said. That will give the students a "clear understanding on how AI can be used to enhance their education, not replace it," she said.
This year, members of Talbot's AI committee will be visiting elementary schools. Werner said it's "imperative" to stay on top of the issue and provide the best guidance to the district's youngest learners. 

 © Copyright 2025

title: Backpack Fair Provides Hundreds of Kids with School Supplies
author: Konner Metz
content:
Backpack fair provides hundreds of kids with school supplies

 August 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 385
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Hundreds of backpacks stuffed with school supplies were handed to families Wednesday ahead of the first day of school Monday.For All Seasons hosted its annual School Supplies Giveaway and Resource Fair at Easton Middle School, moved indoors from Idlewild Park due to rain. The turnout, though, remained steady. Kids picked up supplies, played indoor games like cornhole and enjoyed free snow cones.
Carly Palmer, For All Seasons' outreach coordinator, said 800 backpacks were prepared for the event with help from the Talbot County Department of Social Services.
Those that weren't given away Wednesday will be delivered to local schools, Palmer said.
She added that the resource fair helps equip families with a stock of supplies even if they already went school shopping earlier in the summer.
"At the start of the school year, you may have some school supplies," she said. "But they need that care throughout the year as well. This is just to really get them started."
Over 25 community organizations and partners set up tables inside Easton Middle's gymnasium to give out free supplies and resources. The Talbot County Free Library brought more than 400 cartons of colored pencils, while Eastpoint Church provided kids with drawstring bags filled with notebooks, markers and more.
For All Seasons CEO Beth Anne Dorman said the supply giveaway checks one thing off the list that can often make parents stress in the build-up to school. And it makes students more confident walking in on day one, she said.
"The child can walk in knowing that it's one thing that they're prepared for," Dorman said.
In addition to supplies, Dorman said For All Seasons assists children who are experiencing stress due to school starting up. This time of year, the organization sees an uptick in mental health requests from students, Dorman said.
"The transition is difficult, especially for kids who are new to a school or kids who are transitioning into one school or another," she said.
Especially for low-income children, the supply giveaway is a chance to build community, Dorman and Palmer both said.
"Children who don't have maybe what other kids have understand they're not alone," Dorman said.
"Folks identify it as a safe space," she said of the event. "That's the beautiful thing about not only what we're doing with the school supplies, but having all of our partners in the community together."

title: As Students Return, Chapel District Elementary Begins Next Phase of Renovations
author: Konner Metz
content:
As students return, Chapel District Elementary begins next phase of renovations

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 513
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CORDOVA — Renovations at Chapel District Elementary School are well underway as the school prepares to welcome students next week.This summer, construction teams completed the second phase of the project, which includes the school cafeteria and some classrooms. Talbot County Public Schools Director of Operations Kevin Shafer updated the Board of Education on the project at a work session on Monday.
"We did squeeze a lot of work into a very small amount of time, which was a bit risky," Shafer said. "But the team has pulled it together, and things look fairly good."
As crews worked inside and around the building, teacher and staff moved in for the school year earlier this week.
"Staff returned today and it was very smooth according to (Principal Kari) Clow," Shafer said Monday.
The renovation is a multimillion-dollar effort that includes around $27 million in county funding as well as state funds from Maryland's Interagency Commission on School Construction. Construction is led by the Whiting-Turner Contracting Company.
The project is fully renovating the existing building, adding around 16,000 square feet. The Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers site located in the building was redone as part of phase one. Construction is expected to finish in 2026.
Chapel District Elementary is one of five elementary schools in the district. It was built in 1952 and last renovated in 1994.
Shafer acknowledged a few concessions had to be made in order for the school to welcome students back in time. Some hallway flooring hasn't been replaced, but he said it will still be safe in the meantime.
The school's gym won't be ready on the first day, either. It should reopen by the end of September, Shafer said. For now, PE will be held outside or in select classrooms.
Furniture for the first two phases arrived on time, Shafer said. The district had to rework its furniture plan, placing orders this spring before tariffs took effect and drove up prices, Shafer told board members at previous meetings.
Furniture for the third phase was ordered at the same time and is being kept in warehouses by the supplier at no cost to the district, Shafer said.
Drivers passing the elementary school on Cordova Road will likely see significant construction work obstructing the front of the building. That's the third phase of construction, which includes renovations to the administrative offices and some classrooms. A new media center is also being added to the school.
A temporary front office is located at the back of the building where the Critchlow Adkins Children's Center is located, according to a recent school newsletter. Parking will remain limited during construction.
"By the time students come next week, everything should be in good order," Shafer said on Monday.
On Thursday, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi shouted out Chapel District Elementary administrators, teachers and staff.
"They are going to be teaching through the sounds of loud noises, construction, dust," Pepukayi said. "They packed up their rooms at the end of the year. They just unpacked their rooms this year. And they are still managing to assemble classrooms to be ready for our students to walk through the door on Monday."

title: Back to School: Talbot Celebrates Teachers, Staff Ahead of School Year
author: Konner Metz
content:
Back to school: Talbot celebrates teachers, staff ahead of school year

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Speaking before teachers and staff, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi encouraged employees to carry first-day-of-school energy with them throughout the entire year.Hundreds packed the Easton High School auditorium Thursday morning for the annual opening day rally. Pepukayi asked everyone to remember why they got into education — for the students.
"I want us to remember this feeling when we're happy, we have smiling faces, and we see our students," Pepukayi said. "Because we all know what happens, the rollercoaster of education."
"It'll go up and down, it'll ebb and flow," she added. "But remember your why."
Children return to the classroom on Monday for the first day of school. Before teachers get into the full swing, Pepukayi unveiled new district initiatives to staff.
One is what she called a "community bus." Decked out with school logos, it will go around the community providing clothes, food and other needs to families, Pepukayi said.
She updated staff on two other items. The staff health center in Easton is under construction and expected to open sometimes this fall. District officials have had to overcome delayed construction work on the project this spring due to a federal reimbursement snag.
Meanwhile, a new early learning center for kids up to 5 years old is in the works for White Marsh Elementary School in Trappe, Pepukayi said. This spring, Tilghman Elementary School opened its Judy Center, joining Easton and St. Michaels.
Giovanni Wynn, family service coordinator at the St. Michaels site, delivered a speech on the importance of early learning and her excitement for White Marsh Elementary to join the district's other Judy Centers.
Wynn, the 2025-26 Talbot Support Staff of the Year, and Easton High School band director Lauren Rose, the Teacher of the Year, each were presented with new cars from Hertrich Chevy Buick GMC of Easton and General Manager Pat Papineau.
Other awards were presented on Thursday, including the J. Sam Meek Unsung Hero Award. Pepukayi spoke on the impact of the two winners: Kristen Tilghman, former Blueprint implementation coordinator, and Michelle Ringgold, administrative assistant of curriculum.
Tilghman, now assistant principal at Easton High School, spent three years as the district's point person in carrying out The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's expansive education reform package.
"When I first came on board, the Blueprint was alive and kicking, and I had no idea what it was about," Pepukayi said. "... She helped me tremendously in navigating through the Blueprint."
Ringgold has juggled a large budget, supporting field trips and arranging tutors to go to classrooms in her role at the Talbot County Education Center, Pepukayi said.
"When I walk in, no matter what day, no matter what challenge she's been through, there's always a smile on her face," Pepukayi said of Ringgold.

title: Dorchester Schools Restricting Cell Phone Usage
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester schools restricting cell phone usage

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 443
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Dorchester County Board of Education passed its new student policy on the use of electronic equipment, internet safety and portable electronic communication devices at the final board meeting before the school year begins.The new policy is harsher than previous years', banning the use of personal electronic devices during the entire school day. Students' devices must remain off and stored. Consequences will vary case by case, but violations may lead to confiscation and discipline, with severe penalties for recording or sharing inappropriate content.
"I recognized that there probably will be a learning curve for students and parents with this policy," board President Sheri Hubbard said during the Aug. 21 meeting.
Hubbard shared that during her time at the National School Board Convention, she attended a presentation from a high schooler who said not having her phone during lunch has made her class closer because they truly talk to one another now.
"And students, I just wanted to give you that little glimmer of hope, that all is not lost," Hubbard said. "Your life will not end because your cell phone is in the locker."
Peter Singleton, who has been working within Dorchester schools for 53 years, urged the board to vote in favor of the harsher policy. He said he's seen the negative effects of students being on their phone during class or walking down the hallway.
When the board passed the policy, Singleton quietly said, "Thank you, thank you, thank you, God."
Board members did not make this decision hastily. A majority of the members acknowledged the 115 comments they received from the public, wanting commenters to know their responses did not go unread or unheard.
"I want to make it clear, I read every single one of them. And I want that message out there to the public because there were a lot of people who responded with copies of their own research, and I've done a bunch of research as well as we've shared among the board, and I see the different perspectives on it, and I was really pleased to see, number one, that many people responded and two, with very real impact to them," board member Chris Wheedleton said.
The responses showed 38 responders were for the new policy, 59 said yes with some suggestions, and seven people opposed it, Wheedleton said. He said the remaining individuals had questions surrounding some of the policy's language, which Dorchester Assistant Superintendent Michael Collins said the board addressed in this iteration of the policy.
"They need to learn how we converse with each other," Singleton said after the meeting. "That's what life's all about."
The new policy will be in effect for this upcoming school year, which starts Sept. 2.

title: If We Want Reading Success, We Need to Invest
author: Trish Brennan-Gac
content:
If we want reading success, we need to invest

 August 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TRISH BRENNAN-GAC | Section: Columns 
 
 518
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland is about to see how well we are addressing the reading crisis that has plagued our state since 2013 when NAEP test scores began a decadelong decline.Test scores are lagging indicators — by the time they drop, years of missed investments are already behind us. That means that the 2025 MCAP test scores, scheduled for release on Tuesday, are likely to reflect a mix of old decisions and new strategies but will not fully reflect the bold policies now on paper.
The central question is: Has our state done enough to expect dramatic improvement? Unfortunately, our answer is no.
In 2023, the state Board of Education took an important step forward by adopting a reading resolution and recruiting Carey Wright as state superintendent. Wright has worked with urgency to establish the frameworks and infrastructure needed for real change: creating a pre-K–3 Literacy Policy, revising standards, launching a process to update assessments and, most critically, building a statewide coaching model to help teachers transform instruction in line with the science of reading.
But policies without resources do not change outcomes.
Since taking office less than two years ago, Wright has secured:
$40 million over five years from the U.S. Department of Education$6.8 million from the IBIS Group for Science of Reading trainingOver $3 million in private funding for a statewide literacy coaching program
That is nearly $50 million in federal and private funds — a lifeline for Maryland's reading agenda. But these investments are time-limited and unsustainable. We need to sustain this early investment with a permanent dedicated state commitment.
Implementation of the Pre-K Literacy Policy is beginning with clear expectations for how local education agencies should deliver literacy instruction and steps they must take to help struggling children. Teachers now have access to no cost training in the Science of Reading. But coaching is a necessary component to help teachers apply what they have learned so that our children receive the maximum benefits of their reading instruction.
If we want the kind of results Mississippi achieved, we need the kind of investments Mississippi made. When Wright led the Mississippi Department of Education, the legislature passed the Literacy-Based Promotion Act, which dedicated roughly $15 million annually — just 0.2% of the state's budget — to literacy coaching and support. That investment powered Mississippi's dramatic gains.
By contrast, in Maryland, Wright asked the General Assembly to fund a statewide coaching program. The Excellence in Schools Act authorized a school leadership training program that included "a research-based model for coaching school leaders and 25 instructional coaches." Yet the Legislature appropriated zero dollars for implementation.
Meanwhile, the only state program we can identify that directly supports reading — the funds for Targeted Support and Improvement — is expiring.
The message is clear: Maryland cannot coach its way out of this crisis on outside dollars. Federal and philanthropic grants cannot replace state commitment.
If Maryland is serious about a reading comeback, the state must do more than hire the right superintendent. Our legislature must invest real, sustained resources in literacy — just as Mississippi did.
It's time for the Maryland legislature to step up and fund a reading agenda worthy of our children's potential. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot County Students Return to School
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County students return to school

 August 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 414
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Students at the Talbot County's eight public schools returned to classrooms Monday, getting an earlier start compared to other districts that begin after the Labor Day weekend.In St. Michaels, a crossing guard stood on S. Talbot Street, directing drivers toward the St. Michaels Elementary School entrance. Car drop-off was relatively smooth, and all the buses arrived on time.
St. Michaels Elementary Principal Indra Bullock greeted families at the car drop-off starting at 7:30 a.m., while teachers showed kids the way to the front door. Some students walked in with smiles, while others were emotional for the first day.
Dan Schwartz dropped off his two kids, Henry and Eddie. Henry started kindergarten Monday, and Eddie started pre-K at the Critchlow Adkins Children's Center facility within the school building. The boys were excited for the upcoming school year, Schwartz said.
"I think they're just excited to meet new friends and get to know their teachers and the new school," Schwartz said. "Eddie's excited to play, and Henry's just excited to learn."
Schwartz, from Royal Oak, said his kids previously went to daycare in Cambridge. He's looking forward to their start at a new school.
"It's been a bit more of a schlep," he said of the commute to Cambridge. "Now they're just excited to be going to school close to home."
"We're really, really happy to be in this school district," Schwartz added. "We're excited, and have a lot of friends who had their kids in St. Michaels schools and have had a really good experience."
ON THE HORIZON
Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said on Monday that the district's cell phone pouch policy will be implemented in the fall for St. Michaels Middle School students. The policy requires students to lock their phones in pouches during the school day in hopes that academic achievement and student engagement will both rise.
The pouch program was piloted last year at Easton Middle School. "So far, so good," Pepukayi said of Easton Middle's cell phone rules.
St. Michaels Middle will begin to roll out expectations for the cell phone pouch policy before implementation around October, Pepukayi said.
Meanwhile, teachers across the district will have a new policy to adhere to later this year: emergency lanyards. The lanyards will have buttons for staff to request help to their precise location during an emergency.
The superintendent said the lanyards, from the company Centegix, will also be a "slow roll out."
"It's just one more layer, not just for students, but also staff," Pepukayi said earlier this summer.

title: Back to School: What's Ahead for Talbot County Classrooms
author: Staff Writer
content:
Back to school: what's ahead for Talbot County classrooms

 August 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Headlines 
 
 131
 Words 

 Read News Document

 School is back in session.For us at The Star Democrat a new school year brings a fresh opportunity to fine-tune our education coverage.
As students return to classes, our newsroom is having conversations about how we can share information that helps students and their families navigate this year's ideas, programs and challenges.
On Monday, reporter Konner Metz jumped right in, covering the first day of classes in Talbot County. Along with talking to parents, teachers and administrators about their outlooks for the new school year, Konner's highlighted two upcoming programs that deal with cell phone usage and classroom safety.
You can read more about those initiatives in his story below.
