title: Ag Education Day Teaches Students About Careers in Farming
author: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com
content:
Ag Education Day teaches students about careers in farming

 May 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Erik Halberg ehalberg@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 604
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Over a thousand Cecil County middle schoolers journeyed to the Cecil County Fairgrounds in Fair Hill last week to learn about agriculture in and around the county as part of the second annual Ag Education Day."Ag education and literacy are two top priorities of our government and agency," said Maryland Secretary of Agriculture Kevin Atticks, who attended the event on Wednesday. "Everything starts and ends with food."
Held from Tuesday through Thursday, with two of the county's six middle schools attending each day, the event was a joint effort between Cecil County Public Schools, Cecil Soil Conservation District, Horizon Farm Credit, Maryland Agricultural Education Foundation, Department of Natural Resources and University of Maryland Extension.
Throughout the day, students rotated in groups between twelve different stations spaced throughout the fairgrounds. At each station, volunteers talked to students about various aspects of the agricultural field, from animal sciences to land and water safety to farm drones. Organizers said that approximately 80 professionals volunteered their services during the event.
"It's giving these seventh graders insight to all the careers available in agriculture, not just working in a field," Atticks said.
Based on feedback after last year's Ag Education Day, organizers set out to make this year's event even better. Mel Bacon, Cecil County Farm Museum's executive director and an Ag Education Day board member, said that surveys and an essay contest given to students who attended the event last year helped them hone in on what made the event shine.
He also noted that CCPS has been a huge help in pulling the event off and raising funds
"CCPS has been very supportive," Bacon said.
According to CCPS Instructional Coordinator Day Mashongamhende, CCPS incorporated Ag Education Day as part of its curriculum for the 1,042 middle schoolers in the county this year, which allowed them to embed the event in the schedule and organize lessons around it.
"We teach kids fundamentals," Mashongamhende said. "We see how everything connects."
Mashongamhende also noted that CCPS officials took a trip to the Ag Education Day held in Queen Anne's County earlier this year to incorporate ideas from that event into Cecil's own.
One of the major goals of the event, organizers stressed, is to interest students in the ag industry and show them that there are a wide range of career options available within ag.
Following the event, there are options for students whose interest has been piqued.
"Search out a local 4-H club," recommended Paul Rickert with University of Maryland Extension, one of the event's organizers.
Another option is to enroll in the Ag Sciences programs that the Cecil County School of Technology offers once the students reach high school.
Alongside the adult volunteers staffing the event, a number of CCST Ag Sciences students manned stations and worked with the students at Ag Education Day. The CCST students spoke to kids about the programs they are a part of, giving them a preview into things they could be studying in a few short years.
Students from non-ag programs at CCST also came at lunchtime to speak with students about their own programs, according to Rachel Coffey, an Agricultural Sciences teacher at CCST.
CCST juniors Kaitlynne Harrigan and DeAnna Parker were part of the staff at the beekeeping station on Wednesday. The pair plan to do their capstone project on beekeeping together.
They enjoyed sharing their knowledge with the younger students and watching them get engaged with the subject.
"They're learning a bit of everything," said Harrigan. "It's amazing and I get really happy when the kids ask a question."
Harrigan noted that she didn't know much about ag before beginning at CCST, but finds the field fascinating.
"If I could recommend it to others, I would," Harrigan said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Growing Green: Kent Island Community Garden Celebrates Open House
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Growing green: Kent Island Community Garden celebrates open house

 June 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 211
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — The Kent Island Community Garden opened its gates to the public June 14 for its first open house, welcoming about 60 garden enthusiasts to explore the site and its mission of promoting locally grown food and environmental education.Formerly known as the Galilee Community Garden, the new location sits off White Pine Lane in Stevensville, adjacent to the Cross Island Trail and Island Dog Park. The site is fully built and ready for the growing season.
The garden features 18 raised beds for community use, one charity bed for food bank donations, and three specialty education beds planted with native pollinators, flowers, and herbs.
In addition to offering residents a place to grow their own food and contribute fresh produce to local food banks, the garden serves as a hands-on learning space. Through partnerships with the Maryland Department of Agriculture and the University of Maryland Master Gardener Extension Program, it supports educational programs on native plants, beneficial insects, and land management practices that protect the Chesapeake Bay.
"There are life science hands-on opportunities available locally," said organizer John McKnight.
County officials, residents, and Bill Tharpe from the Maryland Department of Agriculture joined the open house to show their support for the project.
More information about the Kent Island Community Garden is available at kicg.online. 

 Copyright 2025 Star Democrat. All rights reserved.

title: Kent County 4-H Fair Celebrates Youth, Farming and Fun
author: Will Bontrager wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent County 4-H Fair celebrates youth, farming and fun

 July 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 721
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TOLCHESTER, Md. — The Kent County 4-H Fair drew crowds July 16-19 with animals, contests, food and fun, showcasing the dedication and spirit of local 4-H youth.The fair officially opened to the public Wednesday evening with a prayer from Pastor Josh Rendulic of Hope Fellowship Church, honoring the late Pastor Bill Carroll of Still Pond United Methodist Church.
The ceremony also introduced the county's 4-H clubs, including Bits and Bridles, Kent Clover Calf, Fuzzy Tales and Shiny Scales, Kent Puppy Pals, and Kent 4-H Triple Shots.
The fair is a time for 4-H members to present the hard work they've invested throughout the year, judged by experts across a variety of categories. Livestock competitions — featuring cows, pigs, goats, rabbits, horses, ducks, dogs and chickens — continued into the weekend.
"It's hard work," said Beth Hill, principal agent associate for 4-H Youth Development in Kent County, "but it's also fun for participants and spectators alike. Our 4-H really shined in their project work and in all the other things we look for: teamwork, cooperation, responsibility, sportsmanship, character — even empathy and joy for others."
The 2025 fair theme was "Blue Jeans and 4-H Dreams." New to the lineup this year was a 4-H alumni showmanship event hosted by Kent County Young Farmers, along with the return of the lawn tractor contest.
Animals were a major highlight. Livestock were shown in the main staging arena, while rabbits and poultry had their own exhibition space. Glossy coats, straight backs, brushed fur — even moody horses — were all on display as handlers aimed to show their animals in peak form.
Thursday afternoon brought out tractor enthusiasts for the lawn tractor obstacle course. Under the direction of instructors Mitch and Drew Debnam, youth demonstrated their ability to maneuver a tractor pulling a two-wheel trailer through a series of challenges. The event even drew a visit from vintage tractor puller and former winner.
"I took off work just to come out and support these young fellas," he said.
On Friday, volunteer Jaime Orndorff hosted the fourth Youth Goose and Duck Call competition, judged by bird outfitter Steve Goss. Plaques for winners were provided by Mark Kwiatkowski of All For A Bird. Orndorff expressed gratitude for the support of her sponsors and contributors.
Inside the exhibit hall, judges evaluated everything from cakes to houseplants, herb arrangements, artwork, photography and even corn stalks. Select baked goods were auctioned off Saturday evening, with proceeds benefiting Kent County 4-H and the Kent Ag Center.
Throughout the week, fairgoers enjoyed police K-9 demonstrations, archery, turkey call contests, a cornhole tournament, fashion shows and a carnival of rides and games. Youth from programs like Horizons of Kent and Queen Anne's, as well as local parks and recreation camps, attended as part of their summer activities.
Each night featured live music from performers including Robert MacFarland, Quinn Arnold, Kevin Kemp and the Del-Mar Band. Wednesday night brought out dancers for a session led by local line dance instructor Minnie Maloney.
Food and refreshments were a big draw, with vendors offering fried treats, funnel cake, kettle corn and ice cream. Each evening also featured a full meal sponsored by local businesses, including crab cakes, barbecue beef and grilled chicken.
One of the most anticipated events came Friday night: the greased pig contest. About 200 people surrounded the fence to watch children — from toddlers to teens — chase and try to catch squirming piglets sponsored by local businesses. The event was emceed by Sherrie Spray, who kept the crowd entertained with lively commentary.
Saturday featured the return of the Power Wheels Demolition Derby for children ages 3 to 5. Toddlers, seated in 12-volt toy cars, delighted the crowd as they popped balloons in a playful smash-up competition.
"As always, we ended with the tug-of-war," Orndorff said. "It really is something for everyone."
Hill said the fair went smoothly overall.
"I will say we have the highest 4-H membership in over a decade, and it's very exciting going forward," she said.
Volunteer coordinator Valerie Mason estimated attendance at over 3,000 — slightly down from last year, likely due to the heat. She noted that gate proceeds support the Kent Ag Center and help reinvest in the fairgrounds.
Competition results will be posted online and published in a future edition of the Kent County News.
Hill thanked the community for their support. "We're grateful to everyone who helped make this fair a wonderful experience." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the Kent County 4-H Fair, highlighting livestock shows, farming contests, and youth agricultural projects, making Agriculture the most fitting category.

key_people: Beth Hill — Principal Agent Associate for 4-H Youth Development, Kent County
Jaime Orndorff — Volunteer, Kent County 4-H Fair
Valerie Mason — Volunteer Coordinator, Kent County 4-H Fair
key_events: Youth Goose and Duck Call competition

"As always, we ended with the tug-of-war," Orndorff said. "It really is something for everyone."
Hill said the fair went smoothly overall.
"I will say we have the highest 4-H membership in over a decade, and it's very exciting going forward," she said.
Volunteer coordinator Valerie Mason estimated attendance at over 3,000 — slightly down from last year, likely due to the heat. She noted that gate proceeds support the Kent Ag Center and help reinvest in the fairgrounds.

title: Hog Heaven: Gracie's Pigs Are Top Tier at Local Fair
author: Will Bontrager
content:
Hog heaven: Gracie's pigs are top tier at local fair

 August 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 354
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Congratulations go out to 18-year-old Constance "Gracie" Troyer for a successful performance at the Kent County Fair last month. Her swine Novalee was awarded grand champion among market hogs.Novalee started out winning first among heavyweights. Then Randy, Troyer's other hog, was awarded first among middleweights. At the final showdown, it was between Novalee, Randy, and Laurel Clarke's lightweight champion hog, Diva.
Judge Kelsey Zepp's decision was Novalee, exclaiming one hog stood out among the others throughout the competition.
Troyer's mother, Stacie was among her daughter's cheering campaign and beamed, "Proud momma here! She has worked so hard."
Troyer exclaimed she always did well in past competitions but was shocked that both Randy and Novalee went home winners.
The mixed breed hogs can hold their snouts up high as the best there is in 2025.
Troyer pointed out the judge looks for a specific musculature among heavy weights and for middle weight Randy, the same kind of structure just slightly leaner. Zepp also looks for how clean they are and basically the potential of a quality market pig.
Having prize-winning hogs requires dedication. For Novalee and Randy, training started around January. Troyer walked them every day to build stamina, washed their coats making sure there were no yellow circles and ensured they had clean water.
Recently they have found a quality feed that works for them too — Sunglow — which provides a balance of carbohydrates, amino acids, innovative ingredients, active nutrient supply, and show micronutrients.
All this prepared before under the bright lights of the fair, the swine were led by their handlers around the ring with pig sticks to encourage their utmost cooperation.
The prize was taken back home to Harmony Acres in Kennedyville, where Novalee and Randy and the Troyer family could get a little rest.
Troyer, a graduate of Queen Anne's County High School, enjoys learning, competing and making friends in 4-H. She has one more year at the fair and will be attending Chesapeake College in the fall pursuing an early childhood teaching degree.
"This was a very cool experience," she remarked.
So what rewards do the grand champion hogs get?
"Just some street-cred around here," Stacie joked. "No...correction on that...some fair-cred." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Seaweed boom? - The global market for seaweed could see significant growth; can the U.S. get in on the aquaculture and ecological wave?
author: Mike Sunnucks; APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Seaweed boom? - The global market for seaweed could see significant growth; can the U.S. get in on the aquaculture and ecological wave?

 September 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks; APG National Enterprise Editor | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 1208
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Is there a future for seaweed farming in the U.S.?Could seaweed farming see a big global aquaculture boom - along with helping clean up ocean waters challenged by climate change and environmental degradations via natural filtering systems?Rafael Cuevas Uribe and Rick Zechman want to find out - and see potential on both fronts.Zechman is associate dean of marine operations and Cuevas Uribe is a fisheries biology professor at California State Polytechnic University, Humboldt (Cal Poly Humboldt).They are leading a new university effort to farm seaweed (bull kelp) off the far northern coast of California.They want to see if the U.S. can boost its overall production of seaweed - which serves as a natural cleaning filter for bodies of saltwater confronted by climate change and in need of environmental remediation.Right now, the U.S. seaweed farming is concentrated in Maine, Hawaii and Alaska, according to the Cal Poly researchers.U.S. kelp and seaweed production is barely a blip in a marketplace dominated by China, Indonesia and other Asian markets in a sector that is projected to grow to $14.3 billion by 2028, according to research firm IMARC Group.The Cal Poly school created a seaweed farm in 2019 leasing space in Humboldt Bay from the local harbor district. It recently harvested a small crop of kelp from that farm.Cuevas Uribe said the school's operation is for research purposes."Our system is purely experimental. A commercial operation would be much larger," he said.Graduate students help work the farm and with research into its production and viability. Its most recent harvest entailed analyzing kelp planted onto various types of ropes "to test growth rates and viability" with the aim of helping "future aquaculture entrepreneurs," according to the school.· MARKETPLACE AND GROWTH POTENTIALSeaweed (or kelp) can be farmed for food and dietary uses - including sushi nori as well as for uses in soups, salads and snacks. It is an especially popular food in Asia, but could see growth as global diets look for alternatives to traditional proteins and face food insecurity challenges spurred by climate change and geopolitical conflicts.Zechman said certain types of seaweed can be used in biotechnology and pharmaceuticals as part of compounds and ingredients. Seaweed has long had herbal and homeopathic uses.Brooklyn-based business research firm IMARC pegs the worldwide commercial seaweed market at $7.5 billion in 2022, according to a new analysis released late last month. The group sees the industry growing to $14.3 billion by 2028 with an 11.64% annual growth rate between 2023 and 2028."The rising demand for seaweed in dietary supplements, owing to its nutritive content, flavor-enhancing, and weight loss properties, is primarily catalyzing the global seaweed market," IMARC writes in its August analysis.That bullish outlook has plenty of company.An Aug. 30 market analysis by Redding, California-based Meticulous Market Research Pvt. Ltd., sees significant growth potential with seaweed-based fertilizers."Recently, there has been a growing interest in seaweed fertilizers for higher crop production and soil quality improvement. Seaweed nutrients boost plant growth, enhance soil fertility, improve crop yield, and boost plant resistance to diseases and pests. This can reduce the need for inorganic fertilizers and pesticides, leading to safer food production," the group writes in its research report.Fertilizer supply chains have also been recently challenged by U.S. and European sanctions against Russia and Belarus - two of the leading fertilizer producers - over the Ukraine war.Another August report by the World Bank sees substantial growth in the seaweed aquaculture space.The international financial institution sees the potential for a $11.8 billion boom in growth in seaweed farming by 2031 with potential gains in using seaweeds/kelps in pet food, animal feed, nutritional supplements, protein alternatives and methane reducing additives."Seaweed farming demonstrates how development, climate and nature work together to generate value and uplift communities. Seaweed farming will be a source of nutrition security as well as an alternative to synthetic fertilizer," said Martien van Nieuwkoop, World Bank's global director for agriculture and food in a statement last month on the growth potentials.· HELPING THE OCEANS, ECOSYSTEMS AND THE PLANETFor Zechman, it's not just about monetary gains and an industry boom. He sees more seaweed cultivation as a way to help clean up ocean waters.He said seaweed in animal feed could reduce methane emissions from cows.The world's 1 billion cows produce an estimated 40% of global methane emissions through manure and 'burping' - a contributor to climate change, according to the Environmental Defense Fund.Seaweed-based animal feed could help reduce cow burps and flatulence.Zechman said kelp beds off the California coast have been decreasing significantly because of a decline in sea stars. The sea stars feed on sea urchins, which feed on kelp and seaweed. More sea urchins mean less seaweed which helps keep ocean waters clean via their natural filtering."The technology that's involved in starting a farm for seaweed can also be used for conservation," he said.· U.S. growth and market potentialSo, what about the U.S. getting in on a potential seaweed boom?Global seaweed aquaculture production has grown to 35 million tons annually.Data from FAO in 2019 showed North American seaweed production at 23,000 tons.Ninety-eight percent of the seaweed harvested globally over the past two decades has occurred in Asia with China (57%) and Indonesia (29%) leading the marketplace, according to a 2022 study by researchers with China's Fujian Agriculture and Forestry University.Other major seaweed cultivating markets include South Korea, the Philippines and Japan. Isolated and food-challenged North Korea has accounted for 1.68% of the world's seaweed farming, according to Fujian researchers' analysis.Currently, U.S production is barely a blip in the global marketplace.The Western Hemisphere has only accounted for 1.36% of global seaweed/kelp farming the past two decades, according to U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization date cited in the Fujian study.Chile has accounted for 88% of the total.That's where the Cal Poly efforts come in, according to Cuevas Uribe and Zechman.They want to see how their farming efforts work out and whether more cultivation can be brought to California, the Pacific coast and other domestic coastlines.Cuevas Uribe said pollution levels and other external factors such as oil drilling and other commercial marine uses could mean the waters are not clean enough for seaweed farming for food production and other commercial uses.But seaweed aquaculture and its natural filtering could help those same bodies of water - including the dead zones and environmentally challenged areas of the Gulf of Mexico and Chesapeake Bay, according to the U.S.National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.Kelp forests can grow along coastal areas in temperate climates, such as the Puget Sound, helping fish and other marine life, according to NOAA.Seaweed is best grown and cultivated on coastlines with inlets and protected bays."It requires fairly calm inland waters," Cuevas Uribe said, pointing to places such as the Atlantic coastline of Maine. "It's got to be sheltered waters." 
 
 Caption: WIKIMEDIA COMMONS/CREATIVE COMMONS/JAKUB HA£UN
 
Seaweed farmers in Myanmar
 
RAIYAN I MUHARRAMAH/WIKIMEDIA COMMONS
 
Asian markets - including China, Indonesia, the Philippines and South Korea - accounts for the vast majority of seaweed and kelp aquaculture with projections of global economic boom for the sector.
 
COURTESY CAL POLY HUMBOLDT
 
Cal Poly students unload a harvest from Humboldt's commercial, open-water seaweed farm.
 
PETER SOUTHWOOD/WIKIMEDIA COMMONS

title: Eastern Shore Resident Advocates for Sustainable Seafood on Capitol Hill
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Eastern Shore resident advocates for sustainable seafood on Capitol Hill

 June 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 466
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON, D.C. — Oyster farmer Imani Black has stepped off the boat and onto Capitol Hill with 21 members of the Coalition for Sustainable Aquaculture to urge lawmakers to support sustainable seafood in American open ocean waters.The coalition is familiar with the suits, high heels and high rotunda ceiling on the Hill after consistently supporting science-based, inclusive off-shore aquaculture bills, according to the Coalition for Sustainable Aquaculture's Website.
Black founded nonprofit Minorities in Aquaculture in 2020. The organization educates underserved communities about the growing opportunities in aquaculture, its benefits and sustainability and sustainability's lasting impact.
Black, an Easton resident, is an Eastern Shore native through and through and works in oyster restoration. "I just think there's so much power in a little oyster," Black said. "And they do so much for us. In the water and out of the water."
Oysters clean the Chesapeake Bay through filter feeding, which helps clarify the water; nutrient cycling, which allows oysters to process nitrogen in a way that removes it from the water; and through habitat creation, where oyster reefs can provide essential habitat for other marine species.
Her waterman heritage and Chesapeake culture heavily inspired Black's involvement in this type of work. She said she is proud of her Eastern Shore heritage and seeks to honor her family's legacy by representing the region.
"I love being on the Eastern Shore so much," Black said. "I mean, I may not like living here sometimes because we don't have a lot of stuff, but I love the essence and I love the culture."
Minorities in Aquaculture's mission focuses on workforce development. Black said that sometimes, the name can be a deterrent, but once people get past the buzz words of diversity, equity and inclusion, they start to understand the importance of this work.
"If we are going to have U.S. seafood competitiveness increasing like this administration wants us to, we're going to need skilled labor to be able to do that," she said. "And so it doesn't really matter if you're Black, white, purple or, whatever, we need you and your skills."
Black and the 21 members of the coalition went to D.C. to advocate for consensus legislation that aims to create federal regulations and guidelines surrounding aquaculture, such as permitting and site regulations, fish health and welfare measures, labor and equity standards, and climate and sustainability standards.
Black said the bill has seen a tremendous amount of support, especially in Maryland and Virginia, but there is excitement and growing interest elsewhere too.
{p class="p1"}"I think that people are getting more curious and want to strengthen their connection and understanding to agriculture and what's going on and things like that," Black said.
Black said if anyone is interested in following along with this new initiative or her other work or wants to get involved, they should visit the website mianpo.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: $500,000 Grant Moves Center Closer to Goal - St. Michaels Community Center Plans Opening Soon
content:
$500,000 grant moves center closer to goal - St. Michaels Community Center plans opening soon

 August 31, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 623
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS - With a grant of $500,000 from The Harry and Jeanette Weinberg Foundation, the largest it has ever received from a private foundation, the St. Michaels Community Center is poised to finish the total renovation of its aged building and provide enhanced services to the most vulnerable in the Bay Hundred area of Talbot County and throughout the Mid-Shore."This grant is truly a difference maker for us," community center Executive Director Patrick Rofe noted. "We are grateful to the Weinberg Foundation for its generosity, and for its commitment to our shared goal of meeting the essential needs of every member of the community, especially the neediest and most vulnerable among us." Rofe said adequate nutrition, a safe environment in which to learn and play, access to training and appropriate educational offerings - all of which are offered at the community center - are the basic building blocks of human dignity."This crucial grant will make a profound difference in SMCC's ability to serve our community," he said."We are just months away from moving back into our building," said Rofe, adding that "with the support of the Weinberg Foundation and our other supporters we will then be able to provide not only our existing programs but expanded services as well." When the St. Michaels Community Center reopens early next year the new facilities - well-equipped classrooms, a technology center and a modern commercial kitchen - will allow for expanded programming in four broad categories:. Community Food Distribution and Culinary/Hospitality Workforce Development.SMCC will expand food distribution from three to five days a week, and, in partnership with Chesapeake College, launch a new program to train muchneeded culinary and hospitality workers. SMCC past Board member Chris Agharabi, CEO of Ava's Hospitality Group with two restaurants in St. Michaels says, "St. Michaels is known for great food and hospitality, which means we depend on outstanding team members at all levels. I'm confident SMCC's new programs will help talented people grow into promising careers that will help our town and industry thrive." & #9642; Education. In addition to core programs such as after-school and summer camps, SMCC will offer additional workforce development programs, programming for adults including book clubs, a speakers' series, and continuing education courses as a satellite campus for Chesapeake College.& #9642; Technology. A fully equipped technology center with Wi-Fiwill both support community center programs and let community members access academic courses, job search resources and support for personal business.& #9642; Arts & Culture/Community Fellowship. A new, large atrium will be a home for concerts, dances, films and other events, bringing both adults and children into the renovated building."St. Michaels Community Center plays a critical role in serving the Eastern Shore," said Earl Millett, managing director at the Weinberg Foundation. "We are pleased to support its efforts to meet people where they are and expand services to provide the space and support the community needs." The donation moves St.Michaels Community Center closer to completing its $4.5 million Capital Campaign.Board Chair Langley Shook notes, "At the outset of the campaign, we knew we would need to succeed on three levels - government support, private donations and foundation grants. I am gratified that thanks to the hard work of our entire team and the generosity of our scores of supporters, we have done just that: We have received $1.75 million from the state of Maryland, the federal government and the town of St. Michaels; more than $1.5 million in donations from individuals; and $750,000in major foundation grants. 
 
 Caption: SUBMITTED
 
St. Michaels Community Center Executive Director Patrick Rofe stands at the front entrance of the center's building now under major renovations. The community center recently received a $500,000 grant from the Harry and Jeanette Weinberg Foundation, representing the largest grant St. Michael's Communty Center has ever received from a private foundation.

title: Get Teens Investing Early
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Get teens investing early

 September 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: A15 | Section: News 
 
 318
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Have teens? Are they always hitting you up for money? The next time they come sweetly beseeching you for cash, place this book, "The Motley Fool Investment Guide for Teens: 8 Steps to Having More Money Than Your Parents Ever Dreamed Of," in their hands.These financially savvy authors, creators of the award-winning site Fool, came up with this hip, funny and right-on book. Unlike their other great reads, though, this one is geared to teens.The Brothers Gardner give teens the wherewithal to make some serious money by the age of 21.There are numerous testimonials by teens who have followed the Fools' advice and have built up impressive portfolios.These are not rich kids dipping into daddy's till, either. For the most part, they are high school kids working part time. The difference between them and their peers who work and never seem to have a dime is that these kids are investing in the stock market.The authors do a great job of getting teens excited about saving money. That alone is worth the price of the book. Starting off by helping them set goals, they explain the glories of compounded interest. Your teen is reminded that by setting goals he can achieve his dreams. No goal is too large or too small; whether it's to retire at age 40, pay for college, buy a car or a cool stereo, this book will convince your teen that he can realize his dreams.Here's an idea: Challenge your teens that if they'll read this book and provide you with an oral report, you'll give them their first $50 of seed money to get them started. (OK, it's a bribe. Let me know if it works.)Bravo to the Motley Fools for making learning about capitalism way cool. Totally.Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living." COPYR IGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: First Country Christmas Market nets $1K for local 4-H, FFA
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
First Country Christmas Market nets $1K for local 4-H, FFA

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 783
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - "Phenomenal" is how one vendor described the firstever Country Christmas Market sponsored by Caroline and Dorchester 4-H Clubs and Caroline County FFA.The day was chilly but sunny, and the main pavilion of the Caroline County 4-H Park south of Denton saw a steady stream of shoppers from 10 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. Saturday, Nov. 25.Outside, Jimmy Watkins' petting zoo welcomed kids and provided rides on Wedgie the Shetland pony, while inside about 30 vendors had set up their wares. Santa, dressed in cowboy duds, listened to requests from believers young and old.Event chairpersons Missy Saathoff of Denton and Taylor McCann of Federalsburg were "pleasantly surprised and impressed" by the turnout."We joke and say this is our first rodeo," Taylor said. "Everything's gone well, vendors seem happy, and so are we." "We've had a really good crowd so far, and hopefully that keeps up throughout the day," Saathoff said at about 2 p.m. "We should have a few hundred dollars to donate between Caroline-Dorchester 4-H, as well as Caroline FFA, so we're happy about that." Each of the three organizations received over $300, Saathoff reported Monday, Nov. 27.A tree decorating showdown garnered donations. "Dorchester County 4-H's tree won the decorating contest (donations) by $6, so it was a close race for the contest," Saathoff said via text message.She estimated about 980 visitors attended the event."These ladies did a wonderful job; I can't say enough about how great they were," said Cambridge photographer Candi Taylor, who sold her wildlife photos converted to canvas on Saturday."I've sold a bunch of them already," she said. "This (market) has been phenomenal. People like to shop local." The market was promoted as a Shop Small Saturday event, where holiday shoppers could buy gifts and decorations from "country and western vendors and other local favorites," according to the event poster.Vendors offered a wide range of merchandise - from boutique clothing and freeze-dried candy to handwrought iron tools and hand-painted wine glasses."I love seeing the smiles," said Mandy Nash of American Corner.She sold homemade gnomes and NFL-themed weighted snowmen made from socks, and she took orders to make more.Nicole Jackson of The Merry Magpie, based in Cambridge, said she and her husband Michael had "been slammed." They moved from Texas in the spring and create personalized, laser-cut ornaments and plaques.Vendors paid a fee to display their wares, while tables were provided for them. Organizers even gave them coffee and donuts.Lunch and dinner were available to purchase from The Farmer's Daughter BBQ. A raffle was offered, and door prizes rewarded shoppers throughout the day. A tree-wrapping service was also available."I would say it's been exceptional," said Navonne Owen, Caroline County 4-H educator with University of Maryland Extension. "I mean, people were coming in before the doors opened at 10 a.m.They've had a steady crowd all day." Longtime Talbot County 4-H leader Linda Brown, who is also the Culinary Arts lead teacher at Easton High School, shopped with her daughter and grandchildren."I think this is a wonderful community activity and a great way for 4-H and FFA to not only explain the program, but all these folks are learning about 4-H and FFA by coming out, so that's important," Brown said."The community needs to know that we exist and we're educating and doing great things for kids," she said. "Too often, the news is about kids that make bad choices, and this is all about (kids) making good choices." "All in all, (it was) a great day, and we can't wait to hold the event next year and continue raising money and awareness for these great organizations," Saathoff said.

title: Haven Harbour Marina Manager Talks Shop and Sails
author: Will Bontrager wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Haven Harbour marina manager talks shop and sails

 March 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 874
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Erik Lostrom, manager of Haven Harbour Marina Resorts in Rock Hall, is trying to keep an important industry afloat here.Boat building, boat repair and marina management.
The recreational marine industry.
He's hoping his new position on the board of directors of the Marine Trade Association of Maryland can help him support the industry that has been in his family for generations.
To do this there has to be new blood.
"We need to develop the younger generation to get them interested in the business," he said.
He acknowledged it's an aging trade and noted that schools should do a better job encouraging the industry. Trades, in his opinion, offer better pay starting out and does not come with enormous debt.
To get younger people enthused, he spends his time talking to the high schools.
He's doing his part to educate at the college level too, teaching a course on Marine Systems two nights a week, where students learn to install, troubleshoot, diagnose and repair marine equipment and systems.
The class consists of some late teens but also boat owners who wish to gain knowledge about the hobby they enjoy.
In the classroom, his students have the benefit of learning from a man coming from a long line of shipbuilders. His grandfather on his mother's side, Elmer Rosenblad was a master shipbuilder during World War II.
His father, Robert F. Lostrom built wooden boats as well.
He carries on that tradition, working in naval architecture and boat building before settling into boat repair.
"It's in my blood I guess. I've built 15 types of wooden boats."
Being born on the Jersey shore was an ideal place to learn those skills. After high school, Lostrom pursued his passion in Kennebunkport, Maine, the location of the infamous Bush compound. In Kennebunkport, at the Landing School Lostrom spent two years of intensive study being instructed on wooden boat building and yacht design.
Graduating in 1989, he found a way to ply his trade, in Philadelphia at the Independence Seaport Museum.
His marine versatility grabbed the attention of Kent County residents, the Johnson family in Quaker Neck. They owned a log canoe that was built in 1890, they wanted restored. After several months, working with a crew, Lostrom completed the job.
He remarked it was so efficient it started winning races.
Over a summer watching the log canoe compete, soaking in the sights and sounds on the Chesapeake Bay, Lostrom said he fell in love with Kent County. He found a job at Higgins Yacht Yard in Saint Michaels around 1995 and has lived on the Eastern Shore ever since.
With forty years experience he's a good candidate to keep our elected officials informed about the issues of the business.
He was nominated to the board the Marine Trade Association of Maryland board in December.
A group that consists of marina owners, boat builders and boat suppliers, they lobby with the state on regulations to support the marinas. Lostrom will be helping in the area of workplace development.
They'll be addressing all the changes in the industry. An industry, he said which is a luxury business.
Lostrom further described it as a "sunset dream industry."
"The people who sail, have a dream view in mind, of having a cocktail and cruising on their boat," he added.
The business may be luxury, but it is also vital to the economy on the Bay.
According to John Stefancik, executive director of Marine Trades Association of Maryland, a nonprofit dedicated to promoting the recreational marine industry, the annual economic impact to Maryland is $4.2 billion. He estimated that in Kent County that could be tens of millions.
With approximately 350 marinas in the state and only 1100 workers, Lostrom sees the challenges ahead.
There is lack of experienced skilled trade labor to service customer vessels in a timely manner.
He said, "The customer base has become more 'turnkey' type users putting more demand on skilled labor to keep vessels operating."
For instance, vacationers might have two weeks to get their yacht in the water. If it's still in the shop for repairs, and the boats are backed up, they might decide to sell it and stop living that specific dream.
A dream doesn't have to be limited to the boat owners either.
It could also be a dream for a lot of young men and women on the Shore, who hunt, fish, boat and love the outdoors.
A career outside of a cubicle.
There is a need for workers, Lostrom said. All marine trades are needed, from mechanics, marine plumbing to administrative work.
With a salary range starting at $40,000 that can go upward to $200,000, it could be a good option.
Lostrom pointed to one local success story, a life long employee of his. Under Lostrom, the employee learned about working with wood, received tips on proper use of tools and was instructed on fiberglass repair, engine mechanics and proper maintenance.
And he's doing it where he loves, working outside around the boating environment. And at Haven Harbour, a business that Stefancik indicated is one of the largest marinas in the state.
Between balancing the responsibilities of his marina, Lostrom will be lobbying across the state, passionate over his newfound responsibilities.
"I want people who read this to know that this is a professional career. A trade that should be treated as such."
In April, Lostrom will be conducting a career fair; the exact date to be determined later.

title: University of Delaware breaks ground on $150M biopharmaceutical manufacturing center
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
University of Delaware breaks ground on $150M biopharmaceutical manufacturing center

 April 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 506
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A new $150 million facility at the University of Delaware will provide a space for testing new biopharmaceutical manufacturing practices as well as train workers in the highly technical skills needed to produce advanced medications.UD, state and federal officials broke ground Monday on the SABRE Center, which stands for Securing American Biomanufacturing Research and Education.
The 70,000-square-foot SABRE Center will be located on the STAR Campus next to the Ammon Pinizzotto Biopharmaceutical Innovation Center.
It's meant to be an extension of the National Institute for Innovation in Manufacturing Biopharmaceuticals (NIIMBL), which is already located on the STAR Campus.
NIIMBL is a UD-led coalition of nearly 200 companies, educational institutions, nonprofits and state governments. The public-private partnership is designed to accelerate innovation in the U.S. biopharmaceutical industry, which produces vaccines, monoclonal antibodies, gene therapies and other medical products derived from biological sources.
NIIMBL Director Kelvin Lee said the SABRE Center will allow researchers to further test and refine innovations developed at NIIMBL.
"This facility would provide a place where we can actually test how those technologies work in a manufacturing environment," Lee said. "And then if we need to modify or make adjustments to make it more suitable, we then have those lessons learned."
Sen. Chris Coons said the COVID-19 pandemic, and the speed at which a vaccine was developed, demonstrated the power of biopharmaceuticals.
"What is going to be possible with this institute, with its next phase, is to speed up the cycle of innovation," Coons said.
That innovation, he said, will give birth to new companies.
"Spinning out from that will be a remarkable next generation of opportunities for Delawareans to work in biotech and in manufacturing, for companies to be launched here and regionally," Coons said.
SABRE will also be a training ground for people looking to develop the skills needed to work in high-tech biopharmaceutical manufacturing.
"This facility provides an opportunity for people to get trained in how you gown up properly, how you move through a facility properly, how you actually operate pieces of equipment," Lee said.
Having a skilled workforce here will help attract new pharmaceutical companies to Delaware. UD officials have previously said that the SABRE Center will bring 3,500 jobs to Delaware over the next decade.
"Places that have very effective training programs typically find a significant amount of capital investment coming down the road, where companies want to build their factories there because they know they can access a talent pool to staff their factories," Lee said.
Sen. Tom Carper said the SABRE Center is an important addition to the STAR Campus, which already boasts 1 million square feet of new development on what used to be the Chrysler assembly plant.
"While we're not going to build tanks here anymore, we're not going to build Chrysler products here anymore, we are going to be building facilities that help provide medicines that will make us a healthier country and a healthier world," Carper said.
So far, the SABRE Center has secured $45 million in investment from the federal government and $30 million from the state.
Lee declined to say when the new facility will open. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Lierman Calls for Better Support of Day Care in Maryland
author: Tom McCall
content:
Lierman calls for better support of day care in Maryland

 May 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 640
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On April 26, Maryland Comptroller Brooke Lierman made a stop to visit the Talbot County Council on her tour of the Eastern Shore. She has been traveling around the state to let different county councils know what the comptroller is up to.Her stops emphasized getting women back into the workplace in Maryland by supporting them with better day care.
The council members asked questions after Lierman's 15-minute update.
"I have three key roles as comptroller. No. 1 is to act as an elected CFO. To see every dollar in and every dollar out of the state. We also pay all the employees and balance all the books with a general accounting of the state. The second responsibility is that we act as, or I am on, a number of financial boards for the state," Lierman said.
She said she was on the Board of Public Works, which approves major contracts and any contract or grant over $200,000. She is on the State Retirement and Pension System Board with $65 billion in assets.
Her third role as comptroller is revenue administrator.
"We just finished tax season, and I will give you a little update," Lierman said. "We have processed about $2.7 billion tax returns. We are ahead of schedule from last year. We have sent out refunds to 1.7 million Maryland households."
Then Lierman got into how the Board of Public Works affects Talbot County.
"We have approved five projects worth almost $1 million since I took office," she said. "For the renovation and expansion of the St. Michaels Library and a 665-foot living shoreline as well."
She touted the modernization of her office.
"Louis Goldstein used to brag that he took the Office of the Comptroller from pencil and paper to the mainframe. We now we are moving from the mainframe to the cloud. … The online portal is called Maryland Tax Connect. We launched it in February," she said.
The number of workers is affecting the state's economic profile.
"We are constrained in our economic growth because we don't have the labor force we need. We have seen a lower labor force participation rate in Maryland since the pandemic. Other states have rebounded, and we have not. We have lost around 181,000 workers since COVID," she said.
One of the key demographics is loss of women in the workforce.
"We lost about 2%, and nationally was about 1%. One of the key reasons that we did see, and that was cited, is the cost of child care," she said.
Earlier in the day, Lierman visited Critchlow Adkins Day Care Children's Center of Easton and found that they have a waiting list of over 100 people for their services.
"If we are talking about the economy and we are not talking about child care, we are missing a big part of the picture. It is a key piece of economic development," she said.
"We are the eighth most costly state for child care in the nation right now. We lost a number of child care spots in the pandemic, and we haven't recovered all of them. We need accessible, and affordable and high quality child care available for families who want to have working parents, who need to get out into the workforce," Lierman said.
The council members had questions for Lierman.
Council member Lynne Mielke asked about affordable housing. Lierman responded with statistics about the population shrinking in Maryland because people are moving away. People are moving from high-cost to low-cost-of-living states.
She said the No. 1 reason for people moving is the cost of housing.
"The support for housing really comes from the Department of Housing and Community Development budget," she said.
"Part of your housing crunch is because you have so many short-term rentals. It used to be long-term rentals. You on the Shore face this," Lierman said.
Lierman invited those who want to learn more about her office and Maryland's economy to go to marylandtaxes.gov.

title: QA Celebrates Minority-Owned Business Program Initiative
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QA celebrates minority-owned business program initiative

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — A collaborative initiative to strengthen minority owned business presented its first inaugural class to the Queen Anne's County Commissioners Sept. 10.Funded through the Rural Maryland Economic Development Fund, which is supported by the Maryland Department of Commerce and Upper Shore Regional Council and administered through Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development, the Minority Entrepreneurship Training Accelerator (META) pilot program provided tailored mentoring, networking opportunities, and strategic resources to help small minority-business owners overcome challenges and achieve sustainable growth.
Presenting certificates of achievements to participants, Rebecca Murphy, founding consultant of Upper Shore Community Development Founder and Chief Strategist noted META was created with the belief that diversity and entrepreneurship strengthens communities and economy.
"It is with great pride and joy that we congratulate the graduates of the inaugural class of the Minority Entrepreneurship Training Accelerator program today at this commissioners meeting. We celebrate not only their accomplishments but also the bright futures that each of them is carving out in our community," she said.
"META is a six month intensive business development and coaching program aimed at providing a cohort of small minority businesses with the resources they need to scale," said Sam Shoge, cofounder and partner of Rivers and Roads Consulting, who served as program facilitator and coach.
The program intends to close the knowledge resource and funding gap between minority-owned and non-minority owned businesses, he said.
Data is applied across all minority businesses including women-owned and veteran-owned, he said, and the importance of the program is noted in the disparities between minority and non-minority owned businesses, he said.
The average revenue of black sole proprietorships versus non-minority sole proprietorships is $22,000 versus $50,000 respectively, according to Shoge.
On average non-minority owned businesses are six times larger than black-owned businesses, he said.
A total of 15 applications from women and minority owned businesses were received in 2023 and five Queen Anne's County businesses were selected to participate in the inaugural program, he said.
Participants included Moniesha Baynard, owner of Three Guys and a Girl Personal Chef and Catering; Diane Moorman-White, owner of DMW Soul Fitness; Timeka Wheeler, owner of Long Live Assisted Living; Deayna Ewell, owner of Onyx Beauty Supply Salon Barbershop; and Ebony Johnson, owner of Tips and Toes Nail Studio.
The six-month program at the Kent Island Library began its first seminar in February 2024 and concluded in August.
META entailed monthly business development seminars including a variety of topics such as market strategy, business planning, sales and customer service, bookkeeping best practices, licensing and regulation as well as personal coaching, Shoge said.
A key aspect of the program was how entrepreneurs can partner and collaborate and support fellow community small businesses, he said.
"Our secretary of commerce Secretary (Micheal) Gill always said that economic development is a team sport and that is very much reflected in this program here," Shoge said.
Officials were very happy with the outcome and success of the program, with many participants reporting increased revenues, Shoge said.
Transitioning from a 36-year veterinary career, participant Moorman-White, credited the program with giving her the push and the confidence to prove to herself she could turn her "side-gig" into a full time career.
"Probably the biggest thing the META program has done for me was it changed my mindset. I am now recognizing the power I possess to achieve my goals both big and small," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Battle Lines Being Drawn for Tax Fights in 2025
author: David Reel
content:
Battle lines being drawn for tax fights in 2025

 April 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 790
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Earlier this month I joined countless Marylanders in filing my federal and state income tax returns.As I did so, the timeless observations of Benjamin Franklin came to mind: "In this world nothing is certain except death and taxes."
After the Maryland General Assembly adjourned, I suggest Ben was only partly right.
I suggest that in Maryland, almost certain are new state taxes, state tax increases, new state fees and state fee increases. The only uncertainties about them are when and how much.
Before the 2024 Maryland General Assembly adjourned for the year, this matter was discussed at length but never fully settled. Some relatively modest tax and fee increases were approved, but none as large as or as far reaching as expected.
None will be approved throughout the balance of this year. The earliest formal discussions on any tax increases can happen is after the General Assembly reconvenes in January 2025.
Battle lines are already being drawn.
Proponents and opponents of tax increases are busy organizing and promoting their positions. Not surprisingly, there are stark and irreconcilable differences between them.
The Maryland Public Policy Institute recently released a statement headlined "Tax increases Are Never Inevitable."
The statement includes the following messages: "Maryland's political leaders would have us believe the state is in a fiscal mess through no fault of their own and that the only solution is massive tax hikes that they've put on hold — for now. This narrative, however, both misrepresents the problem and ignores a real and preferable solution. When pressed, responsible lawmakers admit that the primary cause of the budget chaos at both state and county levels is the Blueprint for Maryland's Future (a.k.a. Kirwan) education plan. The Spending Affordability Committee projected that budget shortfalls will increase substantially over the next five years "due to the need for general funds to support costs related to the Blueprint."
The recommended treatments are to "minimize the enactment of new mandates," increase "efficiency," and "consider revenue options." Sadly, legislators seem focused only on that last tactic — i.e., tax hikes. But the Blueprint is not Holy Writ etched in stone. And tax hikes on hard-working Marylanders are not inevitable. Instead of pretending to have no way out, lawmakers could choose to alter the Blueprint's mandates or eliminate it altogether."
Supporters of Kirwan especially the Democratic super majorities in the General Assembly and the state teachers' union have a much different view.
They support increasing state revenues to a level to ensure Kirwan is fully implemented as it was written when the current version was approved by the General Assembly.
They believe they have public support for that. They may be right.
A recent article in the Baltimore Sun had the following headline: "Majority of Statewide Voters Support Blueprint for Maryland's Future."
The article included the following.
"An overwhelming majority of Marylanders support the state's ambitious Blueprint for Maryland's Future education plan, according to a new poll done for The Baltimore Sun, the University of Baltimore and FOX45. Nearly three quarters of the 1,300 likely general election voters polled across Maryland said they supported the Blueprint. When the poll asked about potential changes to the plan to lessen its financial pressures on local [education] budgets, 55% said they supported making some reduction, such as cutting all-day prekindergarten programs (24%), or teacher pay raises (11%). However, 29% said they would not cut anything.'"
The professional pollster who conducted the survey opined the results indicate "profound, widespread" support among voters for the landmark education plan, tempered by "a willingness to set adjustments.
He further observed, "It's very hard to argue against public education. The intent [of the Blueprint] tracks with the priorities of Maryland voters."
I suggest the results of this survey, like the results of all surveys, only reflect public sentiment at a point in time. How durable those poll results has yet to be seen.
The pollster did acknowledge one huge unresolved issue that cannot be ignored going forward.
He said, "Local school boards will have to balance how to fund their school districts with meeting their Blueprint financial burden, which could force [school board] members to cut local initiatives. Will it force school boards to cut other things? That's where the electoral equation changes."
That is a key observation that leads to to more certainty on discussions and debates on taxes and fees in Maryland.
Between now and January 2025, supporters and opponents of Kirwan will be aggressively engaged in efforts to inform, galvanize and mobilize voters to support their respective positions ranging from maintaining Kirwan as presently written, adopting modifications to Kirwan and the necessity for and scope of revenue sources needed to fully fund implantation of whatever the final form Kirwan turns out to be.
Depending on the outcomes, those efforts may continue well beyond next year.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant who lives in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on upcoming tax increases, budget shortfalls, and fiscal policy debates in Maryland, which are core economic and business issues, with education funding discussed mainly as a driver of the tax debate.

title: Boys and Girls Club, Mace's Lane Community Center Work on Closing Funding Gap
author: Maggie Trovato mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Boys and Girls Club, Mace's Lane Community Center work on closing funding gap

 November 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 568
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — With hopes to begin the third phase of a project to create the Mace's Lane Community Center, the Boys and Girls Clubs of Metropolitan Baltimore and community center are working to close a funding gap.When complete, the community center will host a Boys and Girls Club. The facility will have a gym, tech lab, game room and classrooms. It will also have a museum and cultural center to honor the area's African American history during and following segregation.
"We have a lot of work to do," Jeff Breslin, president and CEO of the Boys and Girls Clubs of Metropolitan Baltimore, said during a Dorchester Chamber of Commerce luncheon on Oct. 29. "We're still fundraising every single day."
With about $8 million raised so far, Breslin said there is a $4.5 million funding gap. He said they feel confident in getting $3 million of that funding and so they are pushing for the final $1.5 million.
Breslin said so far, the building — which is the vacant Mace's Lane High School — has had its roof and windows replaced and its facade updated. He said there have been remediation efforts inside, including asbestos removal.
"But really, we're just about shovel-ready to get the inside done," he said in an interview.
Breslin said the start of the project's third phase, which they hope to begin in early 2025, is dependent on funding.
The Rev. Keith Cornish said raising the remaining funds for the project will ensure "everyone wins."
"Every part of our society will be impacted," he said about the community center.
Cornish is board president of Mace's Lane Community Center, a nonprofit that was formed by the Good Shepherd Association and the Mace's Lane High School Alumni Association. He compared the Boys and Girls Club at Mace's Lane Community Center to fertilizer for the school system.
"When they come alongside and help the school system, everyone benefits," he said.
Breslin said across the country, every dollar invested in the Boys and Girls Clubs returns $10.32 in economic benefits to club members, their families and society. He said in Maryland, every dollar invested in the Boys and Girls Clubs returns $7.64.
Breslin said that since opening the Boys and Girls Club at Leonards Lane in Cambridge in 2021, there has been a 35% decrease in juvenile crime within 0.3 miles of the club. He said that percentage has been controlled for recent juvenile reform laws.
"Ultimately it just means that when kids have somewhere safe and predictable and hopeful to go, we know what it does for the community," Breslin said.
During the lunch, Breslin introduced Leonards Lane Club Manager Gabe Butler and the organization's Manager of Community and Youth Support Kentavius Jones.
Butler said when kids come into the club, they are given dinner and time for homework help and tutoring before going through Boys and Girls Club programming. Programs deal with health and wellness, career and workforce readiness, social emotional wellness, and more. After programming, the children are given time to "just have fun and play," Butler said.
Jones talked about the importance of focussing on social emotional learning. He said COVID-19 had a negative impact on the social emotional wellness of this generation of kids.
"So learning healthy connections, how to relate to people, how to express what you're thinking, what's going on — our kids are struggling with that," he said.
Those who are interested in donating to the Mace's Lane Community Center project can donate at bgcmetrobaltimore.org/donate or maceslanecc.org/. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Alpacas, lunch and learn for Caroline Women in Business
author: Tom McCall
content:
Alpacas, lunch and learn for Caroline Women in Business

 November 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 374
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PRESTON — Zen, mindfulness and alpacas brought over 20 female leaders together on Tuesday.The super soft animals followed the women, who were all armed with green feed buckets, around in a pasture at Outstanding Dreams Alpaca Farm. This was the site of lunch and learn for the Caroline County Women in Business.
It was a fun moment of delight to see and touch these creatures from the Andes.
"Look at them following her. This is hilarious," Tracey Snyder, director of the Caroline County Chamber of Commerce, said.
"We love the alpaca farm. This is the second time the chamber has been here. Women in Business meets quarterly. We're going to eat a sack lunch from the Culinary Center. We are going to do a little sip and shop and we have Michelle Hammond as our guest speaker. She is going to show us how to be a little more zen in our hectic lives," Snyder said.
Owner of Outstanding Dreams Alpaca Farm Phil Liske gave a talk on the animal's behavior.
After the animal interaction, it was time to listen to the keynote speaker, healer Michelle Boulden Hammond.
"We are talking about mindfulness today. It is a peaceful forum and how to handle stress today. Some spiritual message like how to learn about frequencies. Learn about how to get yourself grounded. We will learn stress management techniques," Hammond said.
She said it is even beneficial for the animals and their frequencies. She specializes in sound healing.
"We are going to do a little breath work. I have got my sound bowls. I got my tuning forks and I have my ocean drum. So I will give a little demonstration. I have a brass and I have a crystal bowl," Hammond said.
She also had a comment on the current moment.
"In these times of high stress, there is a lot of hostility. You have got to learn to get grounded and centered. Always reflect the negativity with the goodness," Hammond said.
One participant was Nikendra Bordley, who runs the hair salon Scalp Reveals in Federalsburg. She specializes in dreadlocks.
"I love it. It is a new experience," she said about the event Tuesday. "I have never seen alpacas. I have only known of llamas. I like seeing everybody getting together and the other Chamber members." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Budget, Blueprint, Energy Are Top Issues for Shore Legislators This Session
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Budget, Blueprint, energy are top issues for Shore legislators this session

 January 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: General Assembly 
 
 710
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As Eastern Shore legislators prepare to cross the bridge and return to Annapolis for the first day of the Maryland General Assembly's 2025 legislative session on Wednesday, the state's budget is top of mind."It's just a tough time right now, and we're going to have to be very cautious and very thoughtful of the citizens and the impacts that our citizens are feeling," Del. Jay Jacobs (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said in an interview with the Star Democrat.
The state is facing a predicted $2.7 billion budget deficit in fiscal year 2026. Jacobs said when it comes to the budget process this year, he thinks everything will be on the table. "The devil is in the details," he said.
"We're certainly — on the Shore — fiscal conservatives concerned with any cost increase, any tax increase or any cost toward citizens," Jacobs said.
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said he hopes state Democrats realize that some state goals, such as the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and some climate initiatives, are unrealistic and need to be reexamined.
"So I hope there's some reality checks," he said.
Del. Jefferson Ghrist (R- Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline) said the state has overspent. He said although House leadership seems to be ok with raising taxes to balance the budget, the governor might not be "comfortable" with that.
Ghrist said he expects to see a "clash" in the Democratic Party regarding the budget.
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) sees this legislative session as a "defining" one for Gov. Wes Moore (D).
"He's going to have to balance this out within his own party," Mautz said about Moore. "Because the policies that are in place now that have caused these economic problems largely come from the Democratic Party and Democratic leadership."
BLUEPRINT FOR MARYLAND'S FUTUREThe Blueprint for Maryland's Future is another issue that legislators on the Shore expect to be one of the top issues this legislative session.
The Blueprint — a plan passed by the Maryland General Assembly in 2021 that aims to improve student outcomes and education quality across the state — has garnered some concern across the state due to funding challenges.
Hutchinson said that with a budget shortfall, the state should be "pulling back" on the Blueprint. He said the plan has "been devastating" to counties across the state.
Jacobs said he thinks this legislative session will result in adjustments to the timeline of certain Blueprint goals.
"I don't think that they're going to do away with Blueprint by any means," he said. "I just think that there may be some changes in the timeline of different parts of it."
Mautz said "something has to happen" with the Blueprint. He said he isn't sure if legislators will create bills "to address the damage that's been done" or create bills that put pauses on the plan.
ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTFrom solar energy to electric vehicles, Eastern Shore legislators see energy and environment issues as important heading into this legislative session.
Ghrist called the state's renewable energy goals "virtually impossible to achieve." He said he has concerns about who is controlling where solar energy systems are being placed in the state. He plans to put out "several" bills that address solar energy.
"Our number one industry is agriculture and it's being threatened right now by solar," he said.
Jacobs said he has heard that there have been some "serious conversations" about expanding nuclear energy in the state. He said he hopes state leadership and legislative committees that deal with energy issues will look more into nuclear energy and figure out if it's a direction the state should be going in.
When it comes to electric vehicles, Hutchinson said he doesn't think the state has the capacity for its electric vehicle initiatives.
"There's not enough power stations to be able to charge them," he said. "And based upon what I'm hearing from our local dealers, there's not a market for them and they want to stay with combustible engines."
Hutchinson said he expects a lot of debate this session.
"And again, I hope that we see some reality coming that we can't continue to afford to spend and that we have to make sure we address this $2.7 billion short fall that's going to get worse and worse each year if we don't do anything today," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: State of State Ignores Eastern Shore Realities
author: Johnny Mautz
content:
State of State ignores Eastern Shore realities

 February 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOHNNY MAUTZ | Section: Columns 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Gov. Moore's recent State of the State address painted a rosy picture of Maryland's future, but as your state senator, I need to be straight with you about where we really stand.Maryland currently ranks 43rd in economic outlook and faces a staggering $3 billion deficit that could balloon to $7 billion by 2030. This crisis wasn't created by Gov. Hogan or the Trump administration — it's the predictable result of expensive, unfunded policies and overregulation pushed through by the Democratic supermajority in Annapolis.
The most glaring omission from the governor's hourlong speech? The crushing cost of living hitting Eastern Shore families right now, especially those sky-high utility bills. His solution is to raise taxes on businesses and high earners, but we all know those costs always find their way down to workers, consumers, and our local businesses.
Let's break down what's really happening in Annapolis:
Instead of cutting wasteful programs, the governor wants to raise taxes and increase spending. Maryland already has one of the worst tax burdens in the country. His budget talks about job creation but ignores how businesses keep fleeing to states with lower taxes and fewer regulations.
The governor doubled down on the Blueprint for Maryland's Future — a massive unfunded mandate our counties and state can't afford. His proposed $1.6 billion in savings falls woefully short when we're facing a $4 billion annual shortfall to implement it.
Rather than working to control costs, the state has unleashed almost universal increases for licenses and other fees, accompanied by aggressive property tax assessment increases. Aspirational environmental mandates are being reenforced rather than reexamined, while they continue to drive costs. This includes their enormous impact on agriculture in comparison to the meager and in many instances, unmeasurable benefits. Meanwhile, the economy on the Chesapeake Bay has been strangled by poor management strategies that range across the board from the blue crab fishery to migratory waterfowl.
Here are a couple immediate actions to cut costs: eliminate thousands of funded, vacant positions; repeal costly mandates in the Blueprint that have not been implemented; cut wasteful spending like the Red Line Study and mass transit; and stop the new $2 billion annual payroll tax for paid family leave. Finally, there must be some incentive for agencies to save money rather than exhaust budgets to ensure they are funded in the following year.
Meanwhile, crime is a very real problem in Maryland and while ending recidivism is essential, the lack of attention and urgency over repeat offenders is alarming. The Eastern Shore way has always been practical and commonsense, there are options that support economic growth, environmental and educational improvement, and promote public safety without breaking the bank. That's what we should be supporting — not costly mandates from Annapolis. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
