title: Shore Legislators Worry About Tax Hikes, Energy, Education in the Wake of General Assembly
author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Shore legislators worry about tax hikes, energy, education in the wake of General Assembly

 April 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 802
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Maryland General Assembly session officially ended Monday night. Lawmakers fought through a very tough fiscal year budget, which had some significant impacts for Eastern Shore communities, legislators said.Members of the Eastern Shore delegation stressed budget difficulties loom over state lawmakers, who spent much of this year's session tackling an over $3 billion deficit.
"I think the session was not a good session," Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said. "We've just made Maryland a very expensive, more expensive than it was, and it's going to make us less competitive in the region.
"If you believe that economic competitiveness is in fact a priority, I think that it is, and I think that by raising taxes and fees, both at the state level and then forcing the locals to also increase their fees and taxes is a double whammy."
Maryland lawmakers passed a balanced budget Monday, concluding their spring session after months of grappling with the deficit. The final budget included about $2 billion in cuts and about $1.6 billion in tax hikes.
"I think we left frustrated that we had to raise taxes $1.66 billion and there was no regard to wanting to really seriously cut expenses from the state budget," said Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico).
Eastern Shore Delegation members believe after this year's session, the Shore will see lasting effects both fiscally and in several key industries.
Solar
One of the biggest concerns for the Mid-Shore this budget session has been solar energy.
A renewable energy bill aimed at increasing generation of energy within the state by promoting solar energy production was passed by both chambers of the state legislature.
Some Eastern Shore Delegation members feel provisions added to these bills during legislators' deliberations supersede counties' authority regarding solar permitting and regulation.
"It undermines all the work that the counties have already done to try to facilitate where and how to put solar," Mautz said. "It includes a new assessment for planting solar, which is going to raise energy costs."
Hutchinson echoed this sentiment, saying, "It falls on deaf ears that the Democrats from Montgomery and Prince George's county all think that they know how the quality of life is here on the Eastern Shore."
Utility bills
House Bill 1035 and Senate Bill 937, known collectively as the "Next Generation Energy Act," include plans to reduce energy bills and address shortfalls by modernizing the state's energy infrastructure and incentivizing in-state energy production.
Eastern Shore Delegation members believe this effort to get the cost down lacked the immediacy rate payers need to address bill hikes.
"We have not addressed the number one complaint I received when I arrived in January," Hutchinson said, "rate payers calling to say that their electric bills are astronomical. We put legislation forward to try to lower utility bills, and again, it falls on deaf ears."
Education funding
The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's education improvement and funding initiative through 2032, originally outlined an increase in teacher collaborative time, during which teachers are not in classes and can plan, grade or meet with students individually. But with adjustments made in the state's budget to combat the deficit, funding to implement the change has been postponed.
The Blueprint also sustained several other cuts and freezes that impact county finances. Multiple Mid-Shore county school boards have had to make budget cut decisions and potential layoffs in response.
"So let me take Dorchester County, for example," Hutchinson said. "They pushed down the teachers' pensions. They pushed down the Blueprint. They pushed down other mandates that the state usually paid for, but now it's all the county, they have to pay for (it)."
"The school board is short about $5 million. They just eliminated summer school," he said. "They're looking at having to lay off student support personnel. They say we want to create a world-class education. Yet you look at the results of what's happening in Maryland and say that doesn't make sense."
Potential special sessions
While the 2025 session has ended, Mautz doesn't believe discussion is officially over.
As the federal government continues to shift funding priorities, state legislators may need to reconvene to address any impacts this has on the balanced budget, he said.
"Counties are probably going to have to raise revenue through taxes and different things," Mautz said. "The federal government is probably going to continue to reduce spending. Then there's a high likelihood that we're going to have a special session."
"So we would have to go back to Annapolis again to address any changes that that come from federal spending reductions. Just as the federal government is reducing its spending, the state is doing the same thing to the counties, and so where all this ends, it seems to be, taxpayer, taxpayer, taxpayer.
"Everybody should know it's very hard to predict how this is all going to play out, but I don't think the discussion about the budget is is officially over." 

 Copyright 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Court Rules Digital Ad Tax Violates First Amendment
author: Bryan P. Sears Maryland Matters
content:
Court rules digital ad tax violates First Amendment

 August 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BRYAN P. SEARS Maryland Matters | Section: State News 
 
 461
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A provision in Maryland's digital ad tax is an unconstitutional restriction on free speech, a federal appeals court ruled Friday.The 2021 law — the first of its kind in the nation — imposes taxes on large tech companies for the digital ads they sell within the state. But it prohibits those companies from passing the tax on to consumers as a surcharge, fee or line item on their bills — what a three-judge panel of the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals saw as a ban on telling customers about the new added tax.
In a ruling that invoked American protests against the Colonial-era Stamp Act, Circuit Judge Julius Richardson wrote that, as then, "complaining about taxes remains a grand American political tradition." And the court said Maryland lawmakers went too far by adding language to the tax bill that was intended to shield them from public criticism.
"Perhaps fearing such complaints, Maryland paired its tax with another rule," Richardson wrote for the court. "Companies that make money advertising on the internet must not only pay the tax, but avoid telling their customers how it affects pricing: No line items, no surcharges, no fees.
"If companies pass on the cost of the tax, they must do so in silence — keeping customers in the dark about why prices have gone up and thereby insulating Maryland from political responsibility," he wrote.
The ruling reverses a 2024 decision by U.S. District Judge Lydia Kay Griggsby, who agreed with the plaintiffs — a group of tech firms and business associations — that the law created some First Amendment issues. But she let the law stand because the offending provision had "many constitutional applications."
Friday's circuit court ruling sent the case back to Griggsby with instructions to determine an appropriate remedy for the plaintiffs.
The ruling is a blow to officials who looked to the unique tax to help pay for expensive K-12 education reforms contained in the Blueprint for Maryland's Future. Expenses associated with that law continue to rise and are potentially budget busting — even if the digital ad tax survives the onslaught of legal challenges.
The 2021 law — sponsored by Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) — targets big tech firms including Apple, Meta and Google.
Under the law, companies reporting $100 million of gross global annual revenue are subject to a 2.5% levy. The tax increases in increments of 2.5% to a maximum rate of 10% levied against companies reporting more than $15 billion in gross global revenue.
The state could collect as much as $250 million annually from the digital ad tax, according to a legislative analysis. The funds are earmarked for the education reform program.
Neither Ferguson nor Comptroller Brooke Lierman (D), the defendant in the lawsuit, immediately responded to requests for comment on the ruling Friday.

title: QAC Economic and Tourism Development welcomes Manufacturers Roundtable
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC Economic and Tourism Development welcomes Manufacturers Roundtable

 September 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 362
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Local manufacturing representatives gathered to hear about available resources and opportunities to connect during a Manufacturers Roundtable with the Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development at Chesapeake College Aug 28.Collaboration is the key to economic and workforce success, and QACETD welcomed manufacturers, county officials and regional partners for open dialogue on training initiatives, grant resources, technology adoption, supply chain resilience, and policy support as well as a tour of Chesapeake College's Advanced Manufacturing Program.
Serving as the voice of manufacturers across industries and regions of the state, Maryland Manufacturing Extension Partnership is a nonprofit focused on growing and strengthening Maryland manufacturers.
Maryland MEP Executive Director Mike Kelleher said finding, recruiting and keeping qualified talents is the number one challenge faced by manufacturers.
There is no one-size-fits-all for training and Maryland MEP has a number of programs to support honing qualified talent and helping companies apply and find services and programs, including specific to rural manufactures, he said.
"It is important to improve the skills of the people," Kelleher said.
Providing a glimpse into what manufacturing officials are seeing out in the field, open discussion shared challenges in recruiting and marketing the availability of quality local jobs especially for a younger generation, as well as a lack of affordable housing and transportation.
QACETD Workforce Development Administrator Connie Dean stressed the power of connecting local business with local youth.
The county's Workforce Development supports opportunities for youth on-the-job training and experiences, especially those in technology and trade industries and since the implementation of high school career coaches, workforce development has increased the number of students in "career focused internships," Dean said.
Understanding students can't get interested about an industry they don't know about, this year, the department is moving forward to bring local industries to the students, with more career fairs and field trips to visit manufacturing areas in person, Dean said.
Partnering with QACTV, the department also highlights business and local field opportunities with career awareness videos to present in schools and online at QACTV.com.
Encouraging local industries to get involved with workforce development, "It's important to let people know what the business is," she said.
More information about QAC Economic and Tourism Development can be found at choosequeenannes.com.

title: AI Course Offered for Business Owners, Managers
author: Staff Writer
content:
AI course offered for business owners, managers

 October 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 296
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Eastern Shore business owners are encouraged to participate in a free, first-of-its-kind artificial intelligence online training series for local businesses this fall.The two-part online program takes place Oct. 27–28 from 6 to 8 p.m. via Zoom and marks the first time the economic development departments of Dorchester, Caroline, Talbot and Worcester counties, along with the Mid-Shore Regional Council, have partnered on a training initiative of this kind.
The training will give entrepreneurs and business owners practical tools to integrate AI into marketing, sales, lead generation, fundraising, operations and proposal writing.
Cassandra Vanhooser, director of Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism, recently completed an AI certification course through Johns Hopkins University and says the timing could not be better for local businesses to embrace these new tools.
"This partnership allows us to bring high-level, practical training to entrepreneurs across the Eastern Shore, free of charge," Vanhooser says. "It's an unprecedented opportunity to make sure our local businesses aren't left behind, especially as this technology becomes essential for growth and competitiveness."
Consultant Will Holmes, who facilitates the program, emphasizes that the program's purpose is to demystify AI and empower business owners with practical strategies they can implement immediately.
"AI is no longer a futuristic concept. It's a present-day tool that can dramatically accelerate growth," Holmes says. "By breaking down what can often feel like a complex or intimidating subject, we're helping entrepreneurs gain a clear understanding of how AI can drive results for their businesses."
The AI training series reflects a broader regional commitment to fostering innovation and economic vitality. By combining expertise and resources, the partners are delivering an accessible program that would otherwise be cost-prohibitive for many small and midsized businesses.
Eastern Shore business owners and entrepreneurs are encouraged to register for the free online training sessions. Registration is available at talbotworks.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dorchester Dems hosts climate change forum
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Dorchester Dems hosts climate change forum

 August 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 637
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Electric school buses and creating recycling education programs were discussed at a Dorchester Democratic Party forum as possible solutions to address climate change locally.More than 20 people attended the Aug. 2 event, both via Zoom and in person at the organization's headquarters in Cambridge. The forum included a presentation by Cambridge resident and environmental advocate Susan Olsen, a Q & A and a moderated discussion.Olsen's presentation outlined what climate change is and its affects on the Eastern Shore before diving in to discuss Maryland's Climate Solutions Now Act of 2022."We are doing a great job in Maryland," Olsen said. "The Climate Solutions Now Act of '22 is the most ambitious greenhouse gas reduction program in our country." The act requires the state to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions through setting new goals and developing emissions reduction requirements.Olsen said environmental justice is a large part of the environmental bills being passed.She said the Climate Solutions Now Act uses tax incentives to encourage community solar for low and moderate income Marylanders.Community solar gives utility customers who rent or are unable to purchase solar panels the option to power their homes with solar energy through a subscription, according to the Maryland Office of People's Counsel."It's wonderful," Olsen said. "It really is." Olsen ended her presentation by sharing how residents can be a part of the solution in Dorchester County and on the Eastern Shore.She mentioned tree grants from the state's 5 Million Trees Initiative. The grants can pay for trees that are planted in public areas. Olsen said that folks who are interested in getting involved with planting trees can look into the ShoreRivers Tree Stewards program.Other ways to get involved include joining environmental groups or lobbying for the implementation, compliance and enforcement of the Climate Solutions Now Act.Olsen also talked about her experience trying to get Dorchester County Public Schools on board with electric buses. She said the Environmental Protection Agency has been giving out grants to school districts to trade in their diesel school buses for electric, propane or low-emission buses."Last year, we were a priority district," Olsen said about Dorchester County Public Schools."They would pay the full cost of the buses." However, Olsen said the Dorchester County Board of Education decided against switching to zero-and low-emission buses.Maris Wicker, who attended the forum, said she remembers when the Board was discussing this."I was very disappointed to learn that there was not a move toward electric buses," Wicker said. "I thought it could have been a great learning moment for kids riding school buses." Olsen said that while Dorchester County is no longer a priority district for this grant - meaning the EPA would only fund a percentage of the cost of each bus-it is still possible for the district to get involved with the program.Sarah Gavian, chair of the Dorchester Dems Committee, said she could see a group of advocates coming together for this issue."I think there probably is a lot of momentum around things that could be done to support at least understanding what Dorchester can win and lose from (with electric) school buses," Gavian said. "I think (we could) probably find some advocates in this room to work with Susan on this." Forum attendees also talked about how to improve and increase recycling in the area.During her presentation, Olsen said that recycling correctly can decrease the amount of methane, a greenhouse gas, in landfills.Miriam Zijp said that when it comes to recycling in Dorchester County, the problem is information."People don't know how to recycle," Zijp said. "But they don't get taught." Zijp suggested creating programs to teach children how to recycle."You have to start somewhere," she said. 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Mary Dennard-Turner talks about recycling at a forum on climate change hosted by the Dorchester Dems on Aug. 2 at the organization's headquarters in Cambridge.

title: CCC Corps class graduates at CBEC
author: Doug Bishop; dbishop@kibaytimes.com
content:
CCC Corps class graduates at CBEC

 August 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Doug Bishop; dbishop@kibaytimes.com | Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 643
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GRASONVILLE - More than 30 participants in the Chesapeake Conservation and Climate Corps graduated Tuesday, Aug. 15, in a ceremony held at the Chesapeake Bay Environmental Center in Grasonville.This was the first class since the expansion to include climate change work in the Corps."Maryland has just taken a bold step toward comprehensive bay restoration with the announcement of the Moore-Miller administration's Chesapeake and Atlantic Coastal Bays Improvement Strategy.We are counting on Corps members and alums to play a key role in helping us reach the goals outlined in the Governor's executive order to better protect the Chesapeake Bay, our state, and our planet," said Maryland Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller. "The growth of this program is essential; it not only addresses the urgency required by an escalating climate crisis, but it closely aligns with our administration's commitment to service and to empowering our youth to gain real-world professional skills." The Class of 2022-2023 was made up of students from Allegany, Anne Arundel, Caroline, Howard, Montgomery, Talbot, Washington and Worcestor counties and Baltimore City.They were addressed briefly by seven special guests: Miller, Comptroller Brooke Lierman, Maryland Senate President William Ferguson, Maryland Senator Pamela Beidle, Maryland Energy Administration Director Paul Pinsky, BGE Sr. Vice President Alexander Nunez, and Chesapeake Bay Trust President Dr. Jana Davis. Each speaker touched on the potential each of the graduates have to continue the fight to protect Maryland's environment and the restoration efforts of the Chesapeake Bay.Pinsky told the graduates, "Never doubt what you can do to change things for the better. A group of young people in Wyoming brought action in court to protect the environment there. Those young people are the same ages you are. You do the same thing they did, if the cause arises." Beidle also focused on the power of individuals. Quoting Margaret Mead, she said, "The power and influence of one person has always been the force for change throughout history." The CCCC was created by the Maryland General Assembly in 2010. It is administered by the Chesapeake Bay Trust. The multi-faceted expansion of the program to include more intentional climate work is possible due to the additional $1.5 million per year investment from the State of Maryland.CCCC provides career and leadership training for young people interested in environmental careers.Corps members are matched with non-profit and government host organizations and receive firsthand training on a wide variety of topics on the realms of climate, energy, watershed restoration, agriculture, forestry and education."The goal of our Corps program is to create future generations of environmental stewards who are poised to address climate change and other environmental challenges, either in their personal or professional lives or both," Davis said. "I am so proud of these amazing young people. Their efforts not only serve the environment, but also boost local economies and revitalize often underserved neighborhoods." The 55 selected 2023-24 Chesapeake Conservations and Climate Corps participants will serve this year in Anne Arundel, Charles, Calvert, Garrett, Howard, Kent, Montgomery, Prince George's, Talbot and Worcester counties, and Baltimore City. 
 
 Caption: DOUG BISHOP/BAY TIMES AND RECORD OBSERVER
 
Members of the 2022-2023 Chesapeake Conservation and Climate Corps receive the symbolic golden shovel from previous graduates following their graduation, Tuesday, Aug. 15, at the Chesapeake Bay Environmental Center in Grasonville. From left, standing directly behind the shovel is Comptroller Brooke Lierman, Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller (applauding), and State Senate President William Ferguson. The graduates were charged with continuing the fight to protect the environment and restore the Chesapeake Bay.
 
DOUG BISHOP/BAY TIMES AND RECORD OBSERVER
 
Maryland Energy Administration Director Paul Pinsky, left, addresses graduates of the Chesapeake Conservation and Climate Corps Tuesday, Aug. 15, at the Chesapeake Bay Environmental Center in Grasonville. Seated are Maryland Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller and Maryland Senate President William Ferguson. More than 30 graduates were tasked with helping protect and revive the Chesapeake Bay.

title: Pickering Creek Gets New Interpretive Panels - Life
content:
Pickering Creek Gets New Interpretive Panels - Life

 September 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 792
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Pickering Creek Audubon Center is a 450-acre nature center in Talbot County, which is open to the public daily with no admission for exploring on our trails.The center is a primary provider of outdoor science experiences for school systems on the Eastern Shore.Visitors to the Center on a daily basis use Pickering Creek's Farm to Bay Trail, which is 2.5 miles in length. The Farm to Bay Trail winds its way through cool season grass meadows, warm season grass meadows, brackish wetlands, freshwater wetlands, pine forest, emergent hardwood forest, mature hardwood forest and gives up close views of agriculture on Delmarva on a working farm.While exploring the habitats, about half of the trail borders agriculture fields while the other half borders brackish Pickering Creek.The trail affords a rare opportunity to experience most of the rural, coastal plain's habitats in one place coexisting with agriculture successfully. Interpretive panels along the Farm to Bay Trail tell the story of Delmarva's key ecosystems and species.In the fall of 2022, Pickering Creek received a grant from the Rural Maryland Council to support creation of new messaging and new artwork for nine interpretive panels. People visit places like Pickering Creek Audubon Center to learn, explore, find adventure, relax and exercise.Interpretive panels help give meaning to the visitors experience by telling the story of the land: past, present and future. Interpretive panels help draw connections between habitats, plants, wildlife and people.The panels highlight the key habitats along the Center's Farm to Bay Trail, which include forest, wetland, meadow, agriculture and brackish water creek. Through the panels we tell the story of key habitat features, flora and fauna through both concise written messages and compelling visuals. Panels help the visitor understand the interconnected nature of land and water on Delmarva.The panels replace aging panels that have been weathered by the sun and rain. None of the existing panels were replicated, so each of the nine panels shares a brand new story about the center, its wildlife and habitats. In addition to replacing existing panels, the new panels fill in spots along the trails that have not been previously highlighted.Over the course of the past year, center staff researched, designed, contracted fabrication and installed nine interpretive panels. At the Center's entrance parking area you will now be greeted by a timeline history of the center that explains its donation and evolution over time.New panels along the Farm to Bay Trail highlight songbirds in the woods, no till agriculture, the importance of forested buffers between land and water, fungi of the woods and birds seen on the creek.New panels along the Wetland and Meadow Trails highlight which amphibians you are likely to see and hear, the importance of milkweed in meadow communities, and bluebird boxes and their benefits."Pickering Creek is unique as a nature center in that we are also agricultural landowners. As the Olds Family who donated the center's core property wished we continued to highlight agriculture as part of the landscape on Delmarva while also sharing how conservation practices coexist with great habitat for wildlife," said Center Director Mark Scallion.Pickering Creek is open to the public daily during daylight hours. Check the center website for exact open times as evening daylight gets shorter this fall.There are several viewing platforms and blinds along the way for you to enjoy scenery and wildlife.Benches for resting are spread throughout the trails. The new panels join seven existing panels that have been installed in the last five years in both wetland and meadow habitats.Together they share the story of outdoor habitats and ecosystems and the creatures we share them with on Delmarva. 
 
 Caption: Keep an eye out for mushrooms growing high on trees!
 
Species like this Dryad Saddle (right) or Cracked Cap Polypore (above) can grow dozens of feet off the ground on standing snags.
 
"There is Fungus Among Us" is one of the new interpretive panels.
 
Some species of fungus grow directly in the ground. These species, like this Russula species (above), are seeking nutrients like nitrogen that are already in the soil and therefore don't need to grow on wood.
 
Look around our forests and you'll find some kind of mushroom. Coming in all colors of the rainbow, most mushrooms are easy to see but they are only the fruiting body of the fungus or mycelium. Mycelium, which look like thin roots or strands of hair, help to break down organic material like leaves and wood for food which recycles the nutrients back into the soil for other plants!
 
Check fallen logs for mushrooms. Many mushrooms like the False Turkey Tails (right top) and Bonnet species (right below) can only grow out of dead wood so fallen logs and branches are crucial! 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a nature center, habitats, wildlife, and ecosystem interpretation, which aligns most closely with the Environment topic, while also touching on educational outreach and agricultural context.

title: Head Of Environmental Science Center Retiring
content:
Head Of Environmental Science Center Retiring

 September 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 540
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - After a 40-year career in science and higher education culminating in leading Maryland's university for the environment, University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science (UMCES) President Peter Goodwin retires at the end of September. He has been leading the university's commitment to unbiased scientific research and public service while developing the next generation of environmental scientists since 2017."The University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science is a very special community within a unique institution driven by a common mission driven by truly exceptional researchers and staff," Goodwin said. "It has been the honor of a lifetime to lead UMCES toward its second century of impact in Maryland and around the world."An internationally known expert in ecosystem restoration, he has championed bringing together the best available science around issues of coastal resilience, oyster recovery, ecosystem management, and using large-scale environmental data in decision-making to Maryland. As part of UMCES' longtime role to advise the state on Chesapeake Bay management and restoration programs, he has served an integral role on the Governor's Chesapeake Bay Cabinet, as well as lead science advisor on the Maryland Commission on Climate Change. He has been a consistent leading voice associated with expanding Diversity, Equity and Inclusion initiatives not only within UMCES but throughout the environmental sciences."President Goodwin's leadership of UMCES has been vitally important to the state and to the nation, as the science coming out of his institution guides the approach to our shared environmental and climate challenges," said University System of Maryland Chancellor Jay A. Perman. "President Goodwin's compelling vision for UMCES, his skill in developing the next generation of talented and diverse environmental scientists, his well-earned influence in Annapolis, which advances better policy and practice - all of it will be greatly missed. I thank him for the exceptionally strong foundation he's laid for UMCES' dynamic future."A globally eminent research institution aimed at advancing scientific knowledge of the environment, UMCES has a unique mandate from the state of Maryland to conduct scientific research and provide sound advice to help leaders manage Maryland's natural resources. Since its establishment in 1925, UMCES has played a key role in expanding our understanding of the Chesapeake Bay ecosystem and is known for tracking progress on its restoration.UMCES addresses some of the most pressing environmental challenges facing society nationally and internationally and prepares future scientists to meet the global challenges of the 21st century through the Marine Estuarine and Environmental Sciences (MEES) graduate program, as well as other educational offerings."On behalf of the Board of Visitors, we have greatly enjoyed working with Peter to advance UMCES these years. He has moved this institution forward in so many ways," said outgoing Board of Visitors Chair Charlie Monk. "Thank you for giving us the opportunity to share our ideas and support your vision for this unique institution."Perman has appointed longtime UMCES Vice President Bill Dennison as interim president, effective Sept. 25. He will serve in that capacity until a permanent replacement is named by the Search and Screening Committee appointed by the USM for the UMCES, one of the university system's 12 institutions. 
 
 Caption: AMY PELSINSKY/UNIVERSITY OF MARY LAND CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE
 
University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science President Peter Goodwin retires after 40 years in science and higher education.

title: Lawrence Wetlands Preserve Officially Opens in Chestertown
author: Laura Tayman
content:
Lawrence Wetlands Preserve officially opens in Chestertown

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman | Page: 12 | Section: News 
 
 681
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN - It took the efforts of county, state, and federal governments to make Michael Lawrence's dream of children learning in the outdoors a reality. The Sultana Education Foundation held a ribbon cutting ceremony for its new Lawrence Wetlands Preserve this week.Drew McMullen, President of the Sultana Education Foundation located in Chestertown, said the educational programs provided by the foundation show how the Chesapeake Bay includes wetlands, shoreline, and now the watershed. "We can now show the connection between land and water," he said.Under development since 2017, the Lawrence Wetlands Preserve is an 8.5-acre urban nature center that features a variety of ecosystems including upland forest, swamp, marsh, shrublands, meadows, and a freshwater pond. In addition to its natural elements, the property boasts an accessible trail network, wetland boardwalk, viewing platforms, an activity field, and the 1,200-square-foot Harwood Nature Center.The land was purchased from Washington College in 2017.McMullen told the ribbon-cutting guests that already the foundation has provided over 200,000 students from the Eastern Shore and 15 other counties hands-on lessons, "now that the center is open new programs start next week." Joining the ribbon cutting team were state Senator Stephen Hershey, state Delegate Jay Jacobs, National Park Service Planning and Development Manager Bob Campbell, Chestertown Councilman Albert Nickerson, and Kent County Superintendent of Schools Dr. Karen Couch.Jacobs, a Kent County resident, took a tour of the area before the project began. "I've seen the before and after, and it's remarkable" he said. As for funding they received from the state, Jacobs said, "It speaks to the credibility of the Sultana foundation that they were able to get that kind of funding level - when you get what you want when you want it." "We are grateful to Mr.Lawrence and the individuals, foundations, and government agencies that made the creation of the Preserve possible," commented Sultana Board Chair Robert Hindman. "We're thrilled to have created a resource that will enhance the Foundation's environmental education programs while serving as a green space for the entire community." Several state and federal agencies awarded sizable grants to the project including the Maryland General Assembly, the National Park Service, Chesapeake Bay Gateways Network, the Maryland Heritage Areas Authority, the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development, and the Stories of the Chesapeake Heritage Area.The Lawrence Wetlands Preserve will host environmental literacy programs and professional development opportunities for 3,000 students and teachers annually, with a focus on PreK through fifth grade. The Preserve will often be used in conjunction with activities taking place at other locations on Sultana's Chestertown campus, including its LEED Platinum Holt Education Center, the schooner SULTANA, and canoe and kayak trips based out of Wilmer Park.When not in use for programs, the Preserve will serve as a contact point for the National Park Service's Chesapeake Bay Gateways Network, host programs for the public, and be open for general visitation daily from dusk to dawn.Kent County Superintendent Dr. Karen Couch said McMullen was one of the first people she met when she came to the county. "I found we weren't accessing the foundation like we should. Together we worked diligently to provide students valuable lessons to become good environmental stewards," said Couch.All KCPS students from pre-k through grade eight have had at least one activity with the foundation. Using the Maryland state science standards, plans are for all first grades to visit and study bird adaptations; for all third graders to student pond ecology, and all eighth graders to study soil and water chemistry."This is hands-on learning by doing," said Couch. These lessons will stay with them the rest of their lives." Said Hershey, "It's important that students learn how things work outside of the classroom. A lot of us would have loved to get these opportunities when we were young." 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
State Delegate Jay Jacobs, State Senator Stephen Hershey, Kent County Schools Superintendent Dr. Karen Couch, Kent County Commissioner Albert Nickerson, National Park Service Planning and Development Manager Bob Campbell, and Drew McMullen, president of the Sultana Education Foundation cut the ribbon to open the Lawrence Wetlands Preserve in Chestertown.

title: Officials Tout Bay Education and Funding Bill
author: Shifra Dayak; Capital News Service
content:
Officials tout Bay education and funding bill

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Shifra Dayak; Capital News Service | Page: A4 | Section: News 
 
 603
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - A House panel held a hearing Wednesday on a bill that would boost Chesapeake Bay restoration and environmental education programs.The Chesapeake Bay Science, Education, and Ecosystem Enhancement Act of2023, sponsored by Rep. John Sarbanes, D-Maryland, would reauthorize the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administrations Chesapeake Bay office for the first time since 2006.Congress has appropriated funds to the NOAA office each year, but an official reauthorization would allow the office to more efficiently carry out Chesapeake Bay restoration and monitoring initiatives, Sarbanes told the House Natural Resources Committee's water, wildlife and fisheries subcommittee."In recent decades, the health of the Chesapeake Bay has been negatively affected by nutrient runoff across the watershed, disappearing coastal and marine habitats and many other factors," Sarbanes said. "That makes the passage of the Chesapeake Bay SEEE act all the more important."The bill would also enhance NOAA's interpretive buoy system, which collects data on water quality, weather patterns and more; enhance NOAA's aquaculture programs that aim to support marine habitats and workers in the seafood industry; and finance grants for hands-on environmental education in kindergarten through 12th grade classrooms in the region.This bill, introduced in the summer, "could not come at a more critical time," according to Allison Colden, the Chesapeake Bay Foundation's executive director."There's still much work to be done," Colden said. "To achieve meaningful and lasting restoration we need all of our federal partners at the table."Colden pointed to the NOAA Chesapeake Bay office's positive track record on oyster restoration projects, citing the bill as an avenue to continue such initiatives in the future by ensuring the office has financial stability.NOAA staff are working to restore oysters in 11 tributaries in the Chesapeake Bay watershed, and have completed restoration across more than 1,900 acres, according to a tracker by the Chesapeake Bay Program."The scale of this work is really unprecedented," Carrie Selberg Robinson, the director of NOAA's habitat conservation office, said of the oyster conservation efforts. "We want to continue to build upon our successes that we've had and continue this great work of oyster restoration into the future."Rep. Rob Wittman, R-Virginia, who co-sponsored the bill, also praised its potential impact on furthering oyster restoration projects."Large scale oyster restoration is really Mother Nature's filter in taking a lot of stuff out of the bay that would otherwise take years and years to do," Wittman said.The Chesapeake Bay SEEE Act comes amid other efforts this congressional session to restore the health of the nation's largest estuary.Sarbanes also sponsored a bill that would designate the bay as a national recreation area under the National Park Service. Wittman sponsored a bill that would fund conservation initiatives in the watershed, such as a pilot project to plant riparian buffers.The latest Sarbanes-Wittman bill includes provisions to instill stewardship values into students, allowing for bay restoration to continue in the longterm, witnesses told the subcommittee. If passed, the bill would continue to fund NOAA's Chesapeake Bay-Watershed Education and Training Program, which provides grants for environmental education in the watershed.Witnesses faced slight pushback on the the bill from Rep. Cliff Bentz, R-Ore-gon - the ranking member of the subcommittee - who called for supporters to provide more specific metrics about the benefits of environmental education.Colden said that the Chesapeake Bay Foundation will provide the subcommittee with numbers ahead of further movement on the bill, but added that the positives of teaching children about caring for the bay are evident."We're building the workforce that can continue the work of Chesapeake Bay restoration," Colden said. "It's so incredibly important to make that investment in our next generation of bay stewards." 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: How will dogs, cats, birds, livestock and wild animals react to the total solar eclipse?
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
How will dogs, cats, birds, livestock and wild animals react to the total solar eclipse?

 April 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: Eclipse 
 
 588
 Words 

 Read News Document

 All eyes will be to the sky for Monday's total solar eclipse when the moon will darken the sun bringing with it daytime darkness.But there is also interest in how animals — from family dogs and house cats to birds and other wild creatures — react to the eclipse across the U.S.
Jacob Dykes, a wildlife specialist and assistant professor at the Texas A&M University in Corpus Christi, will be keeping tabs on how animals react to the eclipse.
"Even among members of the same species, there is quite a lot of variation in how animals respond," said Dykes, who studies animal behaviors. "It may be down to the individual. Some animals respond and some don't. Right now, it's a question that nobody seems to have a complete answer to."
The Texas A&M researcher said animals at a zoo in South Carolina showed varying reactions to an eclipse in 2017 — including some that began nighttime preparations, some that looked to the sky and others who displayed signs of anxiety or unusual activities.
"Researchers saw giraffes suddenly start running around their pen," Dykes said. "Some of the male gorillas became more aggressive. These were some of the anxiety behaviors."
"For birds, they would suddenly go to nest and then a few minutes later, when the sun came back out, they would seem to start their day all over again," he said. "There's no telling what's running through these critters' minds when, suddenly midday, the sky goes dark. Their environment is always having an influence, whether through rain, temperature, wind speed, the amount of sunlight or the length of day. Wildlife are deeply in tune with their surroundings."
Researchers from other universities as well as students and teachers from high schools will also be studying animal and wildlife behaviors.
That includes a contingent from North Carolina State University who will be part of a research effort at the Fort Worth Zoo in Texas during the April 8 eclipse.
Adam Hartstone-Rose, a biology professor at North Carolina State, was also at the Riverbanks Zoo and Garden in Columbia, South Carolina in 2017.
He's excited for the 2024 total solar eclipse to see how animals react.
The researchers welcome input from others who see how farm animals, dogs and cats and other wildlife react during the cosmic happening.
"We're interested not only in figuring out which animals react to the eclipse and how, but (to) what extent of totality is necessary to cause a reaction," Hartsone-Rose said.
"We're really excited about getting data from people that might be at farms or cattle ranches," he said. "We're hoping that people will go out into the woods and see what squirrels, deer and birds are doing. And I'm really excited about people just observing their pets in their backyard."
The eclipse will be visible to varying degrees across the U.S. with a path of totality where the moon will completely darken the sun for three to four minutes stretching from Texas and Oklahoma and into Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, upstate New York and New England.
Overcast conditions and stormy weather could impact how visible the eclipse is in parts of the country — including Texas and Ohio.
It will be the biggest eclipse in the U.S. since 1806 and there will not be another similar event until 2044.
Zoos — especially those in or near the totality path of the eclipse — will also be hosting special events for visitors Monday. That includes ones in Indianapolis, Toledo, Ohio, St. Louis and throughout Texas.
The eclipse comes after a 4.8 magnitude earthquake hit Friday in New Jersey near New York City. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Garden Potluck Unites Residents and Students in Environmental Efforts
author: Will Bontrager
content:
Garden Potluck unites residents and students in environmental efforts

 May 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 649
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — As the weather warms up, more people want to get outside and plant their crops and flowers, and do some outdoor activities. For the Washington College Campus Garden Club that's not just a seasonal thing.They, and residents interested in sustainable living practices, gathered together for a monthly potluck dinner April 12 — a Permaculture Potluck, this time held at the community garden on campus.
President of the club, Jo Perkins described permaculture as a, "smash of two words, permanent and agriculture."
She explained, "It's essentially a set of 12 design principles and three fundamental ethics: earth share, people care and fair share. It's a way to design your systems to be good for humans and for the environment simultaneously."
For member, Justinian Dispenza, permaculture is a way to get back to our growing roots.
"Let's get our feet in the dirt. Eat local and help heal. Everyone is capable of fixing where they're at."
The space itself is a good indicator of this lifestyle in practice.
Since its early roots in 2012, when students put in some vegetable beds and trees, the club has grown significantly. The space now has a fenced area with a coop of happy chickens, a renovated pond, a bridge over a little waterfall, a mud pizza oven (primitive earth oven), a beehive, an insect hotel (for pollination purposes) some fruit trees, some buckthorn trees, and some compost piles.
This all lies beyond the painted wall on campus. A surreal area, especially surrounded by brick dorm buildings and cars chugging by.
Perkins said, "It's really impressive how far the space has come."
She pointed to her first project she started, over the fence where a scarecrow in Perkin's clothes is humorously referred to as 'The Scare-Jo," towards the chickens.
There are eight chickens in total, among them Black Jersey Giants, a Leghorn, some Easter Eggers, a Rhode Island Red and a Favorolle.
As nature teaches lessons, Perkins described permaculture at work inside the coop.
She said that chickens eat bugs which have nutrients, then chicken manure fertilizes the fruit trees, then the chickens eat some of the apples that grow, becoming a catalyst for compost and finally humans eat the nutritious eggs.
Everything in nature harmonizes.
Shane Brill the permaculture educator at Washington College called it applied common sense.
He's been introducing these concepts to his classmates and the've been acting on them, which has produced incredible results.
The growing principles and rural way of life is something that Kent County and Eastern Shore residents know about already, so the club hopes to keep good camaraderie with the public.
Based on the laughter and fellowship it's effective.
Dispenza, who takes the lead in the potlucks, said they always start with people introducing themselves and their field of interest.
For example, he said, one could say 'I'm a bee keeper,' and from there, the crowd would learn about another facet of sustainable living.
As it stands, the garden has plenty of green space for people to congregate, and they're building a new addition, a section for poetry, for classroom instruction and planning events.
"There's a lot of potential for things to come in and do a lot of cool things," Perkins commented.
Dispenza and company are always working on more activities for community engagement. They have master gardeners come in, and community events as well as volunteer with the Chestertown Garden Club on various projects.
But they are always looking for more people with knowledge on growing, planting, building, producing, harvesting, foraging, or anything else like that.
Dispenza said if anyone is interested in hosting a permaculture potluck, he encouraged them to reach out. He stressed the importance of going to different places in the county to learn, since no two areas are alike.
"There's a lot of great people in Kent County and Eastern Shore Community that know about sustainability. I'm here to learn," Dispenza said.
The next potluck is May 5, at 6 p.m. at Kentmore Park.
People can check out www.facebook.com/espigrow or email espigrow@gmail.com for more details. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland Conservation Corps Graduates Celebrated
author: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
content:
Maryland Conservation Corps graduates celebrated

 August 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maryland Department of Natural Resources | Section: Life 
 
 316
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Maryland Department of Natural Resources honored 39 members of the 2023-2024 Maryland Conservation Corps during their graduation program at Wye Island Natural Resources Management Area.The Aug. 1 ceremony capped the members' completion of 10 months of job training, conservation work and stewardship with the Maryland Park Service.
"Through the past 10 months, these dedicated young professionals have shared their passion for our natural resources and public lands through hours of plantings, training, projects and public engagement," said Maryland Park Service Director Angela Crenshaw.
"I am thankful for their hard work and hope they've grown both professionally and personally during their time with us," she said. "I am exceedingly proud of our graduates and excited for the many meaningful things they will accomplish in the future. I would also like to thank our wonderful Conservation Corps Team and everyone in the Maryland Park Service who helped support our corps members."
Maryland Conservation Corps members come from across the country, are between the ages of 17 and 25, and complete at least 1,700 hours of service.
This year's corps class improved more than 2,400 acres of parks and public lands; planted more than 9,963 native trees, bay grasses and plants; treated more than 7,902 trees against harmful insects and diseases; and taught environmental education programs to more than 23,750 students, youth and park visitors.
The program offers hands-on, real-world experience in a team-based environment in subjects ranging from aquatic systems to public lands management.
Many alumni of the program have gone on to conservation careers with organizations including the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, the National Aquarium, the United States Geological Survey and others.
The Maryland Conservation Corps, an award-winning AmeriCorps program, has been managed by the Maryland Park Service since 1984. The Park Service is now accepting applications for the next class, which begins in the fall.
More information and applications for the Maryland Conservation Corps can be found on the DNR website. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Horn Point Lab Talks Community at Cambridge City Council Meeting
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Horn Point Lab talks community at Cambridge City Council meeting

 February 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 386
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — In an effort to build a closer relationship between the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science at Horn Point and the city, Horn Point Laboratory Director Michael Sieracki came before the Cambridge City Council Monday.Before delving into the school's existing community engagement and ideas for more engagement opportunities, Sieracki told commissioners about the school's history and its mission.
"We have a unique statutory mandate as a university to conduct a scientific program that informs the improvement and preservation of Maryland's physical environment," he said. "Not many universities have a mission like that."
Sieracki talked about the lab's areas of research, which include oyster restoration, sea level rise and coastal resilience. Currently, the lab is working with the city on a flood mitigation project along the Choptank River.
Getting to community engagement, Sieracki brought up what Horn Point already does to connect with the Cambridge and Dorchester County community. Along with the flood mitigation project, he mentioned the school's weekly Tuesday lab tours, its annual open house in October and the science talks it hosts. He also talked about student internships, K-12 programming and a summer camp the lab hosts called Toadfish Adventures.
In looking at where community engagement could expand, Sieracki brought up ideas of supporting local oyster aquaculture and expanding the number of internships and K-12 student programming available. He also mentioned workforce development.
"And I want to just challenge you to talk with us about new ideas or directions that we could go that would impact our town," he said to the commissioners at the meeting. "I'm a citizen and resident of the City of Cambridge, so I'm interested in what happens here."
After his presentation to the council, Commissioner Shay Lewis-Sisco talked about her experience working with Horn Point as a Dorchester County Public Schools employee. She said the district has a student apprenticing at Horn Point this year and she would love to expand those opportunities.
Commissioner Brett Summers talked about an idea to promote tourism through oysters in a partnership with a variety of players, like Horn Point, ShoreRivers and the Richardson Maritime Museum.
"Perhaps creating some kind of destination where you get to enjoy oysters, learn about what Horn Point's doing and just the history of our area," he said.
Summers said the city could help develop this potential "oyster trail."
"And I'm interested," he said.

title: Charles Humane Society Celebrates 50 Years
author: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com
content:
Charles humane society celebrates 50 years

 September 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 547
 Words 

 Read News Document

 While many things have changed over the last half century, once constant has been the care provided to animals by the Humane Society of Charles County.The nonprofit organization is hosting its Golden Paws Gala on Oct. 10 to celebrate 50 years of taking care of sick, injured and homeless animals.
The event is from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m. at the Waldorf Jaycees at 3090 Crain Highway. Tickets are $75 per person.
Local humane societies are not directly attached to the National Humane Society, making the Humane Society of Charles County 100% reliant on local donations, grants and fundraising, Rayanne Benya, president of the board of directors for the Humane Society of Charles County, said.
In 1975, the humane society did not have a building. Instead, people who found an injured animal had to take them home, Anne Gardiner, founder of the Humane Society of Charles County, said. In 1981, the St. Charles County Association of Realtors gave the humane society the land for a shelter and it opened in 1983.
"It was tough getting started," Gardiner said. "One time I had [animals] in all three bathrooms and we were wondering what we were going to do."
The humane society has three sections: the kennel, which houses animals ranging from dogs and cats to guinea pigs, rabbits, lizards, turtles and snakes; the humane education program, which teaches students about animals and environmental science; and the clinic.
"Fifty years later, we're still here," Benya said. "We're here because we're supported by the residents of the county … and I think that's something to celebrate."
The gala will have a silent auction with dog baskets, Gardiner said. Other baskets will have household items. Wine and alcohol will be raffled, and there will also be gift cards for restaurants and businesses.
Live music will be performed by the "Original" Moonlighters and there will be a lipsologist — a person who "reads" lip prints — and a cash bar. Food is being donated by the Waldorf Jaycees.
"It's just for a great cause," Benya said. "We adopt out anywhere from one to 2,000 animals a year and all those animals need medical care."
Under the shelter's care, the humane society often has about 150 animals, an amount that can go up to 250 animals during the summer, Benya said.
Throughout the year, the shelter has around 200 volunteers who help with adoption events, laundry and being around the animals. They also want to build an animal medical facility for emergencies and a larger surgery wing.
"When [people] come here and they volunteer, they see the connection … between humans and animals," Benya said.
The humane society is holding its annual photo contest until Sept. 27, Benya said. People can send a cute photo of their pet that can be featured in a calendar.
On Sept. 20, they will have an adoption event at the humane society, Benya said.
The nonprofit also has a program called Freedom Friends year round that offers discounts to veterans to adopt animals for animals that have been in the shelter for six months or longer.
"It's important that we receive the funding … so we can continue to be here for the county," Benya said. "If we disappear, that's going to be devastating for the animal population.
For more information about the Oct. 10 gala or to purchase tickets, go to humanesocietycc.org.

title: One Seedling at a Time: Nonprofit Gives Away Native Plants, Empowers Youth
author: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com
content:
One seedling at a time: Nonprofit gives away native plants, empowers youth

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 544
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Esther Bonney turned her grief into growth by starting a nonprofit that aims to spread native plants.Nurture Natives, a youth-led nonprofit organization, empowers young people through native biodiversity, restoration and education.
About a year and a half after losing her older brother to suicide, Bonney, a La Plata resident and founder of Nurture Natives, joined 4-H with the Charles County Pollinator Masters Club to study and dive into being outside with pollinators and native plants.
"I felt pretty lost," Bonney said. "Then 4-H came into my life … and I joined it not knowing that it would be such a beam of support."
After attending the National 4-H Youth Summit on Agriscience, members were encouraged to design a project that would solve an agricultural issue, Bonney said. One of the issues that came up during conversations with farmers in Southern Maryland was invasive plant species.
Nurture Natives was created to address this agricultural issue and the broader environmental issue of invasive species.
These sustainable efforts helped the National 4-H Council select her as one of the 2026 4-H Youth in Action Award winners. Nurture Natives has planted 2.4 million native seeds, distributed 70,000 seedlings and engaged more than 10,000 young people to help protect native plants and pollinators, according to a release from 4-H.
"Pollination is what keeps our world functioning," Bonney said. "Pollination is so key to both our agriculture and our environmental systems."
Jeremy Tidd, owner and founder of Bona Terra, looked for ways to give back to the community and get more engagement about his native plant nursery when he decided to start giving seedlings away for free as part of a grant application, he said. Bona Terra grows 30 native plant species and is working to give away one million seedlings a year.
"There's no shortage of seeds in the world," Tidd said.
Bona Terra became involved with Nurture Native's mission when Bonney called local nurseries to put pamphlets on display racks, Tidd said. Bona Terra invited Nurture Natives to the nursery.
"They saw that I was giving away seedlings and they wanted to volunteer," Tidd said.
Bona Terra and Nurture Natives partnered to decide how to run seedling giveaway events and what training sessions to offer, Tidd said. They had their first training in March.
"Every time the world changes it's because we've taught the next generation," Tidd said. "Young adults … were taught … that we had to do something about it and now it's just accepted, common knowledge."
Nurture Natives is at the intersection of environmental stewardship and youth mental health, Bonney said. The organization is meant to help young people find meaning through environmental action who feel disconnected from nature or who feel powerless when hearing about the biodiversity crises.
"You might notice a lot of people who have a passion for gardening are older," Bonney said. "A discussion that has been pretty consistent … has been how do we bridge this gap?"
Bonney is a freshman at the University of Maryland, College Park and hopes to continue to grow Nurture Natives as a fellow with the university's Do Good Institute, where she will work on expanding the nonprofit's initiatives, she said.
"The coolest thing about the seedlings is it has made people brave," Tidd said. "This is a learning opportunity. Plants are amazing and have so much to teach us." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a nonprofit promoting native plants, pollinator health, and invasive species control, which are core environmental stewardship topics, while also touching on agricultural and youth education aspects.

Jeremy Tidd — Owner and Founder, Bona Terra

title: Anonymous Note About Son's Hygiene Angers Parent
author: Harriette Cole
content:
Anonymous note about son's hygiene angers parent

 August 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Harriette Cole | Page: A18 | Section: Advice 
 
 327
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DEAR HARRIETTE: I have a friend or family member who wrote me an anonymous note telling me that I should teach my 13-year-old son to have better hygiene.I opened my mailbox last week and found it, and I started crying. My family and I live on a farm, and my son loves to spend a lot of time with our pigs, cows and goats. He loves taking care of them every day because they are his pride and joy. As a result of this, he and his clothes often end up having a distinct scent on them from the animals. He tries to get it off of him, but it sticks.I am offended and upset that someone wouldn't have the guts to tell me to my face. Instead, they chose to leave a note without signing their name. I now feel as if I can't trust the people around me anymore, and I feel as if it could've been anyone from my life.How am I supposed to find out who did this and confront them? - My Son's Hygiene DEAR MY SON's HYGIENE: I'm sorry, but I think you are looking at this through the wrong lens. It isn't that the person lacks courage. I believe the message was delivered anonymously so that you can seriously address this situation rather than get in a rage over the messenger.Stop trying to figure out who wrote it. Start getting creative on helping your teen son learn how to take better care of his body and clothing as he continues to love his animals. Ask some of your male farmer friends what they recommend for cleanliness. This is not a new problem for farmers. Somebody should have solutions you can try.Forgive the messenger, and receive the message.Harriette Cole is a life stylist and founder of DREAMLEAPERS, an initiative to help people access and activate their dreams. You can send questions to askharriette@harriettecole.com or c/o Andrews McMeel Syndication, 1130 Walnut St., Kansas City, MO 64106. ©2023 HARRIETTE COLE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: New Book Promotes Physical Activity, Family Fitness
content:
New book promotes physical activity, family fitness

 September 28, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A6 | Section: News

 Words

 Maryland SNAP-Ed, a program of University of Maryland Extension in partnership with Maryland Department of Human Services, has written a new original storybook promoting family physical activity.More than 125,000 free copies of the book will be distributed to low-income sites across the state throughout the summer."The Secret to an Extraordinary Day" follows the story of an ordinary family that takes an unexpected adventure, prompted by a series of mysterious notes. Along the way they discover that being active together is a secret weapon for overcoming the summer blues.SNAP-Ed delivers multi-faceted interventions that support adoption of healthy behaviors by low-income audiences."Physical activity has emerged as a priority for SNAP-Ed, both nationally and in Maryland," Maryland SNAP-Ed Director Lisa Lachenmayr said in a news release. "Among the many lasting effects of the pandemic, sedentary behaviors increased due to increased reliance on technology for school and education. While SNAP-Ed's interest in physical activity is as a tool for obesity and chronic disease prevention, our partners also recognize the power of movement to address critical concerns around social-emotional health." Physical activity is a current focus area for SNAP-Ed, due to well-documented impacts on chronic disease prevention. Supporting youth in developing a lifelong relationship with physical activity also benefits overall well-being.Books are being distributed to partnering schools, early childhood sites, out of school programs, Maryland WIC offices, SNAP Outreach community partners, low-income 4-H youth programs, and summer meals sites, allowing SNAP-Ed to deliver health promotion messages while supporting family literacy and summer learning.For more information or to read the book, go to https://extension.umd.edu/active-fun.

title: Choptank Health Expands School Health Services
content: Choptank Community Health System is expanding its school-based services in Caroline and Talbot County Public Schools with the addition of three new behavioral health providers. Behavioral health therapists Maura Cavalieri and Fiona Kay have joined Choptank Health's Talbot County Public Schools health center team, and behavioral health therapist Reina Ronquillo joins behavioral health provider Lindsay Newcomb in serving the students at Caroline County Public Schools. "Choptank Health recognizes the importance of behavioral health as part of the integrated health services we provide to our patients, and that includes students enrolled in our School-Based Health Centers throughout Maryland's Mid-Shore," said Choptank Health President and CEO Sara Rich. "These three new providers are part of our treating the whole person with medical, dental, and behavioral health services." Behavioral health therapist Maura Cavalieri holds a Master of Science in education from the University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Education and a Bachelor of Arts in psychology with a minor in justice, law, and society from Washington College. She holds a trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy certification, with counseling experience in school and family environments, including the William Meredith School and Family Center at Jefferson in Philadelphia. Cavalieri sees students at Easton Elementary and the St. Michaels campus of schools. Behavioral health therapist Fiona Kay holds a master's of social work from the University of Maryland, Baltimore. She is an experienced school social worker and clinical mental health therapist in local and rural settings. Her experience includes working with Talbot County Public Schools, For All Seasons, Eastern Shore Psychological Services and the Caroline County Department of Social Services. Kay sees students at Easton Middle School, Easton High School and White Marsh Elementary School. Behavioral health therapist Reina Ronquillo received her master's degree in social work from Salisbury University and holds a certificate in advanced trauma treatment Level 1 from the Ferentz Institute. Before joining Choptank Health, Ronquillo worked for Channel Marker in Easton and Denton, Maryland, most recently serving as an adult services director, and working in crisis and youth services. Her community involvement includes serving with the Caroline YMCA Mentor Program, Asian Student Social Workers and the Special Education Citizens Advisory Committee. Ronquillo sees students at Preston Elementary, Federalsburg Elementary and Colonel Richardson Middle and High Schools. Behavioral health provider Lindsay Newcomb joined Choptank Health as the first school-based behavioral health provider in the summer of 2022. She holds a Bachelor of Arts in social work with a minor in psychology from Salisbury University and completed the Advanced Standing Social Work Program at the University of Maryland, Baltimore. Newcomb's experience includes working as a Foster Care Caseworker, Parent Education Coordinator, Addictions Therapist, Mental Health Therapist and Behavioral Health Interventionist. She sees students at Denton Elementary, Goldsboro Elementary, Ridgely Elementary School, Lockerman Middle School, and North Caroline High School.

title: Students Learn to Save a Life - St. Michaels Y Training Session Prepares Students for Emergencies
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Students learn to save a life - St. Michaels Y training session prepares students for emergencies

 October 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 554
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS-Nine middle school students gained lifesaving skills Wednesday afternoon, thanks to a partnership between the St. Michaels Community Center, St. Michaels Youth & Law Enforcement (SMYLE), Talbot County Emergency Services and the Perkins Family YMCA.Talbot County paramedic Rachael Cox led the afterschool CPR and AED training class at the Y, guiding the young students through the steps to take in an emergency.The class was free for all who participated, thanks to a $200 donation from SMYLE, the St. Michaels Police Department's youth program, that covered certification costs for the students. The St. Michaels Community Center assisted in facilitating the program.Cox began her class by showing how to check if a person is responsive, then asked the students what they thought the next step was.The answer? Calling 911 and staying on the line with the dispatcher.The next step, as Cox demonstrated, is checking if the person is breathing. If not, it's time to start chest compressions, she said.Each student practiced chest compressions on practice manikins and learned how to use an AED before moving on to learning how to do CPR on infants.As a community risk reduction paramedic and CPR and AED coordinator for Talbot County, Cox loves teaching. She likes being able to introduce preteens and teenagers to CPR, first aid and AED skills to prepare them for any emergency situation, even if they're alone without adults present."I feel like we call EMS, police, fire and dispatch first responders, but I really don't believe we're first responders because we're not there when the emergency happens-the community is," she said. "And that's why I feel these types of classes are so important."Amethyst Monroe, a Perkins Family YMCA staffer who supervised Wednesday's class, is continuing to coordinate other developing middle school programs. She's planning another CPR and AED session soon.Monroe's aim is to make sure future programs are lowcost and provide the area's youth with more life skills.Anyone who wishes to support future after-school programming at the Perkins Family YMCA can donate to the center's annual campaign or reach out to Tracy Eutsler, the Y's executive director, at teutsler@ymcachesapeake.org.Those who are interested in scheduling CPR and AED classes can contact Rachael Cox at rcox@talbotdes.org.

Community Center to host talk on human-animal bond

 OXFORD - Ahead of this Veterans Day, join the Oxford Community Center for an inspiring evening with Meg Daley Olmert, a world-renowned expert on the neurobiology of the human-animal bond.On Thursday, Nov. 2, at 5:30 p.m., Olmert will speak about the profound therapeutic effects of human-animal relationships.Meg Daley Olmert is an accomplished subject expert, author and lecturer, recognized for her groundbreaking book, "Made for Each Other: The Biology of the Human-Animal Bond," published in 2009.This book traces the evolution of the ancient bond between humans and animals, delving into the emerging neuroscience that underlies this profound interspecies connection.With her expertise in the therapeutic effects of the human-animal bond, Olmert has been a trailblazer in the field, and her two TEDx talks have captivated the hearts and minds of thousands."We're thrilled to host Meg and share her wisdom on the healing power of the human-animal connection," said Liza Ledford, Director of OCC. In addition to her remarkable contributions to the field, Olmert serves as the science advisor and board member of The Comfort Dog Program of Northern Uganda.She was also a co-creator of Warrior Canine Connection's Mission-Based Trauma Recovery Program at the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda.Additionally, she will be featured in the upcoming documentary, "By My Side," which highlights the impact of service dogs on veterans with trauma. title: College Junior Feels Jealous of Friend
author: Harriette Cole
content:
College junior feels jealous of friend

 October 30, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Harriette Cole | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I am a junior in college, and I'm struggling with feelings of jealousy toward my friend. It seems like everything comes so easily to her, and it's hard for me not to compare our paths.Recently, my friend received a $10,000 scholarship for a study abroad program in Japan and landed an internship at one of the top investment banking firms in the United States. She applied to only one internship and only one scholarship, and things fell into place effortlessly. It's as if a fairy comes in every night while she's sleeping and throws magic pixie dust at her to make everything work out. Meanwhile, I feel like I have to fight tooth and nail just to make half as much progress. Every day is a continuous struggle to accomplish the goals that I have. I try hard to be positive, but obstacles pop up constantly. How can I deal with these feelings of envy and move forward with a more upbeat outlook on life? - Jealous DEAR JEALOUS: It is understandable that you would be envious of your friend for what appears to be an easy life. As you also know, it is toxic to dwell on what other people have. No good will come out of that longing. Instead, you must focus on yourself. Do your best to view your life as your perfect challenge. You are gaining resilience as you live through each experience.Claim your small victories.To keep on track, create a vision board. Look through magazines and newspapers for images that reflect the things you want for your life. Cut them out. Brainstorm words and ideas that represent your dreams.Write them down. Next, on a large piece of cardboard or paper, place the images and words together. Make a simple art piece out of this collection of ideas to create your vision board. When thoughts creep in about your friend's success - or anyone else's - wish them well and pivot back to planning your own life. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article addresses emotional well‑being and coping with jealousy, which falls under mental health rather than sports, business, or other categories.
