title: Health department recommends making condoms available at local high school
author: LAURA TAYMAN
content:
Health department recommends making condoms available at local high school

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LAURA TAYMAN | Section: News 
 
 643
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last month, Kent County Board of Education members were provided stark facts about the rise in sexually transmitted diseases (STD) in the community, the state, and the country at its recent monthly meeting.Ashley Minietta, communicable disease and family planning contact for the Kent County Department of Health, made a presentation to the board before the holiday break, saying the solution to reversing the trend is "to provide ground support, monitor trends, and turn data into action."
"While 20% of Marylanders have an STD, almost half of the cases are ages 15-24," Minietta said, citing the 2020 U.S. census map — putting Maryland in the South region of the country, "It's one of the highest rates in the region."
Minietta said the barriers to effectively preventing both STDs and teenage pregnancies in Kent County are lack of education, the cost of birth control, parental resistance to alternatives, lack of public transportation, the geographic barriers of the rural area and lack of health care options.
Teen pregnancy rates are down, Minietta said, because parents have been proactive with putting teenage daughters on birth control. But pills and IUDs do not allow the prevention of STDs that can lead to long-term health consequences.
"Research in 2020 shows only 9% of sexually active high school students used a condom," Minetta said. "That has only increased."
Minetta shared various ways local school systems are providing a condom availability program to meet the needs of their high school students, including those in Queen Anne's, Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot and Wicomico counties, and counties on the western shore.
While some have availability through the school's nurse's office, others provide a "brown bag" approach, where students can pick up a paper bag on an anonymous basis.
Board member Aretha Dorsey said that as a parent she was concerned that a program like that would encourage secrets among parents and their children.
"I feel like parents' rights are being taken away," Dorsey said. "I believe that kids might form a lack of respect for their parents and think they can do things their own way."
Board member Francois Sullivan said Kent County and its rural location is a valid argument for such a program.
"There is a difference between a nurse providing condoms and a cashier."
When asked to share her opinion, student board member Madison Messick said she couldn't even remember her sex education class.
"I think this is really important," she said. "There is a stigma. We can't go to Walgreens because we know the cashier. I know kids that would definitely benefit from this."
Vienna Walker, supervisor of student services for the Board, said she recommended the board adopt a policy where Kent County students can meet with a high school nurse and ask for information and guidance.
Superintendent Karen Couch said she had been asked by parents how students could be opted out of a program if they don't approve. Walker said she would need to check with the state's Department of Education to see how that could be handled.
"Some students have much more open communication with school nurses than their parents," Walker said. "Their office is much less threatening to students who then become comfortable enough to come back if they are not feeling great."
That is Walker's goal. She recommended the board consider approving a program that requires students to visit nurses who can provide education and guidance on condom use.
"Nurses also encourage students to be open and honest with their parents," Walker said.
Messick agreed.
"Students will participate not because kids don't trust their parents," she said. "The program encourages conversations between parents and their children. It's like therapy where they can't tell parents what their child is talking about. This actually helps to form a better relationship between students and parents."
School Board President Joe Goetz said he would like for Walker to get information from other districts on how they manage parent objections.
"I think real life examples would help," Goetz said.

title: Eastern Shore Delegation Hears About Health Care Access Expansion
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Eastern Shore Delegation hears about health care access expansion

 February 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 581
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Expanding access to health care on the Shore was a recurring topic at the Eastern Shore Delegation meeting Friday morning.During the meeting, which was held on Zoom, Mark T. Gladwin from the University System of Maryland spoke about a new program that would bring medical students to the Eastern Shore, and Sara Rich talked about the growth of the Choptank Community Health System.
Gladwin, who is dean of the University of Maryland School of Medicine and vice president for medical affairs at the University of Maryland, Baltimore, talked about the Rural Health Equity and Access Longitudinal elective program.
Once in place, he said the program will have students spend their first two years in Baltimore, coming to the Eastern Shore to do rotations. For students' last two years, they will spend four months of each year learning and training on the Eastern Shore.
This program will address a need for more health care on the Shore, Gladwin said. The five counties in the state with the fewest primary care physicians per capita are all on the Eastern Shore.
"As we all know, there is a pressing need to enhance physician and medical provider services and hospital services for the Eastern Shore," he said.
This new program is a partnership between the University of Maryland, Baltimore, the University of Maryland School of Medicine and the University of Maryland Eastern Shore. Between the three partners, Gladwin said $300,000 has been invested to start the program.
He said a director, assistant director and administrative support staff have been hired. The estimated cost to support and build the program is about $2.2 million per year, Gladwin said.
"We put in a federal grant for the program," he said. "And we think it would be very helpful to get state support for this."
Gladwin said they are mainly seeking scholarship support for the program. He said they would like to be able to give out full scholarships to students in the program who agree to staying on the Eastern Shore to work.
"We think there's a lot of interest (from) our students in rural health care, in health equity," Gladwin said. "And we think this could be a signature program to attract future doctors."
Eastern Shore Delegation Chair Del. Chris Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said he was appreciative of the efforts to get this program going.
"It is surely needed," he said of the program.
Also during the meeting on Friday, Choptank Community Health System CEO Sarah Rich talked about Choptank Community Health's expansions on the Shore.
Currently, the health system has seven health centers and 18 school-based health centers across Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties.
Rich said progress on the construction of its new center in Federalsburg is moving along "very well." The health system broke ground on this project in the early summer of 2023.
This new center will have five wings for medical, dental and behavioral health services. It will house a rural residency program in partnership with the University of Maryland School of Medicine and University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, as well as a dental residency program.
Rich also talked about Choptank Community Health's expansion into Kent County, which includes a health center in Chestertown and a school-based health center in Rock Hall.
Behavioral health in schools is another way the health system has expanded.
"We know that is a huge need," she said. "So we do have therapists now in Caroline and Talbot counties."
Rich said they plan to offer these services to students in Kent County and Queen Anne's County schools next.

title: Board of Education President Undergoes Liver Transplant

Board of Education president undergoes liver transplant

 February 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Board of Education President Mike Diaz is recovering from a liver transplant.At a Board of Education meeting Thursday, Diaz called into the meeting to thank everyone who had reached out with well wishes and prayers.

title: Opioid Deaths Spur Push for Kids to Carry Naloxone
author: Sapna Bansil Capital News Service
content:
Opioid deaths spur push for kids to carry naloxone

 March 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1188
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Jackson Taylor remembers when a peer passed out from an overdose across from his high school. He knows friends who have struggled with addiction. One has been in and out of rehab.Those experiences help explain why the Rockville High School senior now trains his peers on how to administer naloxone, a lifesaving medication that reverses opioid overdoses. They're why he carries naloxone at school and why he wants all districts to let their students do the same.
"It's just like a student having a heart attack," said Taylor, who runs a student task force on drug and opioid issues in Montgomery County. "It might be rare, but on the off chance it happens, you want to be able to save them and help them."
Currently, a disparate and ambiguous set of district-level policies has created confusion on the role students may play in preventing opioid deaths among their peers. But a bill before the Maryland General Assembly aims to provide a clear and uniform set of standards.
The measure, HB 1268, would explicitly authorize students across the state to possess and administer naloxone — also known by its brand name, Narcan — as adolescent opioid deaths surge and teens lobby for urgent solutions.
While the practice is already permitted for students in Montgomery County, others have gotten punished for carrying naloxone in school, according to the bill's sponsor, Del. Joe Vogel (D-Montgomery).
"We know that our student populations are uniquely vulnerable when it comes to (the opioid) issue," Vogel said. "And this (bill) is, to me, a common-sense step to say, 'Hey, you should not be punished for carrying naloxone with you in a school hallway, and you should not be punished for saving a classmate's life if they're overdosing.'"
At a hearing before the House Ways and Means Committee on Wednesday, Taylor, 18, was among those who testified in support of the measure. So, too, did Maryland's Special Secretary of Opioid Response, Emily Keller, an indication that the bill has the backing of Gov. Wes Moore's administration.
"Empowering people and giving them the tools necessary to help is a vital strategy, especially with young people," Keller said in her testimony. "Making naloxone accessible with every Marylander is one of our priorities because we know it's the number one life-saving tool."
The bill responds to an alarming national trend: Between 2018 and 2022, adolescent deaths from opioids quadrupled, according to an analysis by KFF.
The rise in overdoses has coincided with two factors, said Patricia Kapunan, the medical director for Montgomery County Public Schools. One is the use of social media to market pills without a prescription. The other is the rise of fentanyl, a potent synthetic opioid that is being mixed with illegal drugs, often unbeknownst to the user and with deadly effects.
In 2021, fentanyl was involved in nearly four times as many fatal overdoses among young people in Maryland as the next deadliest drug, cocaine, according to the state's Vital Statistics Administration.
"Suddenly, (fentanyl) is showing up everywhere, and suddenly one pill can kill," Kapunan said.
Implementation questionsIn response to the opioid crisis, lawmakers have mandated that school districts take preventive actions. The Start Talking Maryland Act of 2017 required public schools to teach kids about the dangers of opioids and have naloxone available on campuses. It also authorized nurses and other health and school personnel to administer the medication in overdose emergencies.
Most districts have not extended the same permission to students. In Cecil County, students are not necessarily punished for possessing naloxone, according to director of student and school safety John Roush. But "they would be talked to by their school administration about it and informed that we don't have a policy for (them) to carry that in schools," he said.
Roush thinks the bill is a good idea and may help save lives, though he anticipates challenges with implementation and logistics.
"We have over 15,000 kids in our system here," he said. "How do you get Narcan out? How do you get information out? How do you make them educated on the use? How do you make them aware? It seems like there would be a lot of time and details to be worked out in that regard."
While the bill requires schools to educate students about the benefits of naloxone, it does not specifically address one major logistical consideration: training kids on how to dispense the medication.
Available over the counter as a nasal spray, Narcan must be administered by tilting the person's head back and firmly pressing the plunger. Because the medication's effects are temporary and overdose symptoms may return, it is critical that the individual providing Narcan also call 911 and seek medical aid.
To the American Medical Association, the benefits of expanding naloxone access in schools still outweigh the risks. Following a debate on the issue, the group approved a resolution last year encouraging "states, communities and educational settings to remove barriers to students carrying safe and effective overdose reversal medications."
"Narcan saves people quickly, and lack of Narcan kills people quickly," said Kenneth Certa, an AMA delegate from the American Psychiatric Association, which co-sponsored the policy. "When somebody is turning blue and cold, you don't have much time. And to wait until a dose gets from another part of the building can be too late."
'Hugely empowering'In Montgomery County, which saw a 78% spike in youth overdoses from 2021 to 2022, a policy permitting students to carry naloxone took effect on May 1, 2023.
Kapunan, who crafted the measure, said students were never punished for possessing overdose-reversing medications and were already protected under good samaritan laws if they acted in an emergency. But teen advocates nonetheless pressed for a policy change that eliminated ambiguity and codified their right to intervene.
"Those levels of permission were really important to students," Kapunan said. "For me, it was a very small part of the regulation. For them, it was hugely empowering."
Kapunan says the policy does not mean schools are depending on kids to save lives. During the 2022-23 school year, naloxone was dispensed on school grounds in Montgomery County 18 times, almost always by nurses. Since the policy change, there have been no known instances of a student administering naloxone to a peer at school.
But to supporters, the measure remains an important preventive step, permitting those in closest proximity to an overdose to act without fear of repercussion.
"Students know before the teachers do, is the truth," Taylor said. "I'm a lot more likely to know, 'Hey, my friend has a pill in his bag that he's thinking about taking, and it could have a repercussion' than a teacher would know."
Vogel, who is running for the open U.S. congressional seat in Maryland's 6th District, said expanding policies like the one in Montgomery County has become a necessity. Six months ago, he met with student leaders who spoke to the urgency of the opioid crisis and their desire to help address it.
"A lot of them have taken matters into their own hands," Vogel said. "A number of them have stepped up and said, 'We want to get trained on how to administer naloxone, and we want to be able to carry naloxone.' … That's what this bill is in response to." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Choptank Health Updates Commissioners on New Federalsburg Facility
author: Tom McCall
content:
Choptank Health updates commissioners on new Federalsburg facility

 April 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 418
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Sara Rich, CEO and president of Choptank Community Health, met with the Caroline County Commissioners to talk about its annual report and the new Federalsburg Health Center. It will be serving pediatric and behavioral health patients."Last year our Choptank providers and our care teams took care of 32,000 patients throughout our health system," Rich said, "that represents medical, dental and behavioral health service lines."
The Federalsburg facility is replacing the old one and will be 21,000 square feet and have five wings.
"There are two wings for medical, two for dental and two that are for staff," Rich said.
"We are making a lot of progress on the Federalsburg Health Center," she said. "We anticipate it being open for patient care before the end of this year."
The new facility will have a mental health component too.
"Behavioral health will be integrated throughout those medical and dental wings as well," she said.
"I am particularly happy to see it go in Federalsburg," Commissioner Larry Porter said. "Good job. Very, very, very sincerely saying that."
Porter said health care is important to the community and noted the way Choptank Community Health has been incorporated into the community in the schools.
"You touched about every organization," he said. "Thanks for being a very good partner."
The health care organization is celebrating 25 years of serving the school-based population and providing medical, dental and behavioral health in Caroline County Public Schools.
"Our claim to fame is that we are the only county in the state of Maryland that has a school-based health center in every one of our public schools," Rich said. "We are not only offering medical services and dental preventative services, but we have also added nutrition through having a dietician available to meet with our students to provide education and counseling."
She said that they have added behavioral health based therapists in the schools. In the last school year, they have had 8,769 medical visits and 1,135 behavioral health visits.
"So that is about 9,900 visits right here in Caroline County. We have just been approved for a pediatric dental residency. This will start in July. Three pediatric residents will join Choptank Community Health," she said.
She highlighted the mobile health units used to reach a vulnerable population in Caroline County including guests of His Hope Ministries. They have hired a Spanish-speaking nurse practitioner for the Denton office.
"We have hired a dentist for Goldsboro. We have hired a dental hygienist who is also in Goldsboro. We have a dentist that will be joining Federalsburg next month," Rich said. 

 © Copyright 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: For All Seasons is Growing with the Latino Community
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
For All Seasons is growing with the Latino community

 May 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 802
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — For All Seasons, a behavioral health and rape crisis center serving the Eastern Shore, has had what could be described as a long and continuously adapting relationship with serving the local Latino community.Ivy Garcia, director of Latino services at For All Seasons, said it began in 2006 when she was hired as an interpreter for the nonprofit. Garcia said though the work she was doing at the time was important, the more she talked to the local community, the more she realized that this was just a stepping stone.
She moved on to become an advocate, and when word got out that a Latina was advocating for the Latino community, more and more Latino clients began to seek resources.
Garcia's passion shone through her work as she began to advocate for more and more services, including a Spanish language crisis hotline, staff training, educational groups, and the Latino Program at For All Seasons.
"The people started to trust and confide themselves to me," Garcia said. "I started doing education workshops on self-esteem and women empowerment. I also bring in guest speakers like Planned Parenthood and the Department of Health, and we eat food together and discuss topics they may have questions about."
Today, For All Seasons has established a Latino Program to help serve the many needs of the local Latino community. This program provides bilingual education and outreach initiatives for communities throughout the Mid-Shore region.
The services provided range from support groups, case management, advocacy and referrals to local resources. Garcia leads a support group for Latinas on Mondays from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m., where she listens to the needs of women and finds ways to assist their ever-changing needs.
Beth Anne Dorman, president and CEO of For All Seasons, said it's important for people to understand that the Hispanic community in Talbot County is growing. Currently, 15% of the clients For All Seasons serves are Spanish-speaking, and Dorman said they are preparing for those numbers to continue to climb.
Education has been the staple of expanding mental health services for the Latino community. Garcia said that mental health is seen as taboo to many Latinos and carries a stigma of being associated with "crazy." For Garcia, it's essential to explain to clients that mental health should be taken as seriously as physical health.
However, education does not stop with clients. Garcia and Dorman have made a point of educating both community members and staff on culturally relevant information in order to better serve the Latino population.
The entire agency team receives cultural education so that when Spanish-speaking community members come in, all staff can better understand ways to assist and accommodate expected needs.
Alongside the education the staff receives, Dorman said For All Seasons has also created a safe environment where staff can ask questions if they have questions pertaining to cultural differences that may arise.
Garcia said that because many of their Latino clients are undereducated about health, especially mental health, it's important for staff to put in extra work to help assist them and meet them where they are. However, what she keeps at the forefront of her work is admiration for her clients.
Many of her clients are migrants who have left behind friends, parents and children to come to the United States to work to send money back to their loved ones. Still, when they journey to the United States, they will often go through intense trauma and may not know the tools to navigate their new reality.
"It's important to sit down with clients and tell them that though I may not be in your shoes, I see you and admire you for doing that," Garcia said.
"Because to leave your family is not easy, but you are doing it for love and because you didn't have another option," Garcia said. "It's a passion that I have for this community that I don't think I will ever lose in my lifetime."
Dorman said one of the moments that made her feel that the Latino Program was working was two years ago when they hosted a backpack giveaway in the nonprofit's parking lot.
"I'm not joking with you. They were lined up down the street, and we were their safe place to land," Dorman said. "When you think about the trauma that these families have experienced, you think about being in a space where they know nothing, they know no one, and they are coming here for them to show up in the parking lot of For All Seasons during the backpack giveaway, and be able to know that there's a place for them to be served.
"And that they're a part of our community and they are a part of something. To me, that's the moment that I think just really sort of says it all about who we have become for the Latino community and Talbot County." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a behavioral health and rape crisis center expanding mental health services and culturally relevant education for the Latino community, making health the primary focus.

Beth Anne Dorman — President and CEO, For All Seasons

title: The Gift of Sight: Nonprofit Has Provided 15,000 Free Pairs of Eyeglasses to Delaware Students
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
The gift of sight: Nonprofit has provided 15,000 free pairs of eyeglasses to Delaware students

 May 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 546
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Approximately 30 Keene Elementary School students received the gift of sight Thursday when a nonprofit stopped by to deliver free eyeglasses.The excited kids received their new glasses during a brief ceremony in the school library.
"It's amazing to see one of our kiddos put on glasses for the first time and seeing their face light up when they can see," Principal Mariellen Taraboletti said. "It's very heartwarming."
The glasses were courtesy of Vision to Learn, a nonprofit that has been serving Delaware schools since 2014. It started in California and now operates in 15 states.
School nurses perform an initial vision screening on students and, on average, approximately one-third are referred for an eye exam by an optometrist.
Vision to Learn comes to the school and performs eye exams in a specially outfitted van. Kids who need glasses get to pick out their frames, and the nonprofit returns to deliver the glasses about a month later.
Over the past decade, Vision to Learn has performed 20,000 eye exams in Delaware and provided 15,000 pairs of glasses – all free of charge. The effort is funded by donations, as well as billing Medicaid.
At Keene, County Executive Matt Meyer presented Vision to Learn with $100,000 from the county's share of the American Rescue Plan Act, enough to provide glasses to nearly 700 more kids.
Ann Hollister, CEO of Vision to Learn, said it never gets old seeing kids receive their glasses.
"It's a little aha moment. So often kids tell us they didn't know the world looked like this," Hollister said. "It's a special moment when they realize, 'Oh, I can see better.'"
Often, she added, parents don't realize their kids are struggling with their eyesight.
"If a child has a tummy ache, they might go home and tell a parent. But they don't know they can't see," Hollister said. "At a young age, they just think that's what the world looks like."
While school nurses have done vision screening for years, having Vision to Learn come to the school to do eye exams and fit kids for glasses is a huge convenience for parents, Taraboletti said.
"It's not even just the free glasses," she said. "You don't have to take off work to go to the eye doctor, you don't have to then go back and pick up the glasses. People are busy, and it just makes it so much easier."
Being able to see properly helps kids do better in school, Hollister said.
"Studies show that it makes a profound difference in academic outcomes," she said. "It's one of the most impactful interventions you can provide a child. Everything else works better if you can see."
Christina School District Superintendent Dan Shelton concurred.
"A lot of times when we talk about accessibility, we talk about accessibility by access to programs and access to services and access to courses," Shelton said. "But none of that stuff is very helpful if you can't see it."
Keene fourth-grader David Pierre has worn glasses for a few years but was happy to receive a new pair with an updated prescription.
"All my other ones have scratches," Pierre said.
Aiden Onfroy, also a fourth-grader, was happy to have a new pair of glasses.
"The first pair of glasses I got, I still wore them but every couple seconds, I kept on squinting," Onfroy said. "I can see way better." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a nonprofit providing free eye exams and glasses to students, a health service that directly impacts their well‑being and academic performance.

title: Escape the Vape Youth Summit Held at Chesapeake College
author: Eric Sylvia Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Escape the Vape Youth Summit held at Chesapeake College

 May 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ERIC SYLVIA Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Life 
 
 672
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — On a rainy Saturday, approximately 35 students from area schools gathered at Chesapeake College for an event called Escape the Vape, a youth summit.The kids ranged in age from sixth grade to high school and chose to participate in an event designed to empower youth to embrace a vape-free and smoke-free lifestyle. Those attending came from Dorchester, Kent, Talbot and Queen Anne's counties.
The program was spearheaded by Dorine Fasset of Queen Anne's County Department of Health, Prevention Services and her colleague Anna Ashley. In addition to the Department of Health, this event had support from Citizens Against Smoking Tobacco Coalition and Chesapeake College Office of Student Diversity, Equity & Inclusion.
The program is made available through a grant from Kent County Health Department and Maryland Department of Health.
According to the latest available data from the 2021-2022 school year, over one in four high school students within the five-county Mid-Shore region are current tobacco users. This epidemic is largely driven by the use of electronic smoking devices, e-cigs, or vapes, which have been heavily marketed to teens.
The summit featured rap and dance performances aimed at promoting a passion for healthy choices and encouraging young people to reject harmful habits. Special guest Sterlen Barr, CEO of Rapping About Prevention, hoped to inspire attendees with his message of positivity and resilience.
Dr. LaMarr Shields of Baltimore's Cambio Group led the morning session with his son Mosiah by his side. An inspirational speaker, educator, thought-leader, author and artist, Shields creates with purpose in all aspects of his professional and personal life using the common thread of Ubuntu philosophy: a person is a person through other people.
An Open Society Institute Fellow and a former faculty member at Johns Hopkins School of Education, Shields is co-founder and senior director of education and innovation at the Cambio Group. Shields dedicates his life to inspiring adults and youth alike to pursue a higher purpose, achieve sustainable value for long-term success, and cope with adversity in order to create opportunities in their personal, professional and spiritual lives.
Further inspiration was provided through the music and dance of Barr, aka NoPuffDaddy, delivering a high-energy performance using facts, humor, personal experience, teamwork exercises and audience participation. Rapping About Prevention teaches the importance of maintaining a positive, drug-free, safe, healthy and active lifestyle all while having an amazing and memorable experience.
Barr's own journey began in Philly over 30 years ago when he lost his grandmother to lung cancer. He began writing and rapping as a way to work through his grief, and hopes to help prevent other families from feeling the same pain. A lifetime athlete and former boxer, Barr's presentation style is high energy on purpose — and it too draws the students to the message.
Presented to students in middle and high schools across the country, he reaches thousands each year with his work. He says, " Kids don't care about how much you know until they know how much you care."
Shields shared, "We are addicted almost at birth to sugar and salt — it's one of the reasons kids say they vape — because it tastes good." Shields has spent a lifetime understanding the reasons people and especially our kids get hooked on these substances so easily. These summits are one of the ways he says we can combat it — through understanding and providing a message that reaches the kids. Watching the response as he walked his audience through his presentation made it clear the message was hitting the mark.
High school student Wyatt Tolker attending the session with his mom Kerieanne Hinerman, Dorchester County's Tobacco Program Coordinator, was inspired to write verse in response to one of the exercises.
Speaking after the session with Tolker, he relayed the thought process behind his inspiration, "I've always written stuff — I have a notebook full of things I've written. When Dr. Shields asked us to write down our responses, I knew I wanted to present a message that would appeal and speak to the other kids in the room, regardless of their age." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Drug Free QAC Student Ambassadors Present Escape Room
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Drug Free QAC student ambassadors present escape room

 June 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 396
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Emphasizing no one is alone in navigating a drug free life, Queen Anne's Drug Free ambassadors presented their one-of-a-kind drug free escape room at the Centreville YMCA June 1 and 2.Throughout the weekend, the ambassadors welcomed over 100 puzzle enthusiasts ready to put their clue solving and substance facts to the test.
Participants had one hour to decode puzzles using various hidden clues with the goal to learn facts about substances, solve the mystery and ultimately "escape" the room.
"It is an opportunity to have some fun while learning a few facts about the dangers of substances," Opioid Education and Prevention Coordinator Julie Kille said.
With a design resembling a typical teen bedroom with posters and furniture, a focus for the ambassadors was highlighting the escape room's underlying story the resulting puzzle pieces put together.
Maggie Porciello, an 11th grade ambassador of the Gunston School said, "The important takeaway was we wanted it to be something that could happen in real life."
The ambassadors were proud to offer the escape room to the community as a hands-on interactive way to engage with opioid facts as a team.
Participants had as much fun putting their investigative escape skills to the test as they had designing the room, the ambassadors shared.
"Seeing groups work together in different ways to solve clues has been really fun. Learning things never has to be boring," 10th grade ambassador Samuel Mora of Queen Anne's County High said.
After completing the escape room, groups were invited to have a snack and share their experiences.
The QAC Drug Free student ambassadors had utilized the escape room idea to enter a national competition with Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, Kille said. The goal of the competition was to enter an idea of how to share the dangers of pills with their peers, she said.
The students' escape room was selected as one of the top six winners of the competition's 200 entries, earning them $5,000, she said.
Officials with Save the Day Escape Rooms lent expertise and mentorship to help the ambassadors craft the perfect puzzle space, Kille said.
A collaborative effort with the whole community, the ambassadors partnered with local businesses and drug-free organizations to offer the event including: the QAC Drug Free Coalition, Opioid Operational Command Center, Chesapeake YMCA, Save the Day Escape Rooms and the Mattress Store in Annapolis and Chester.
Information about QAC Goes Purple is available at qacgoespurple.org/home.

title: Food Lion Feeds Donates to QAC Backpack Program
author: Staff Writer
content:
Food Lion Feeds donates to QAC Backpack Program

 July 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 230
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Queen Anne's County Backpack Childhood Hunger Program has received $1,900.00 from the Food Lion Feeds Charitable Foundation to help nourish neighbors experiencing hunger.The Feeding the Hungry grant supports community feeding partners by helping neighbors increase their access to nutritious food and providing nutrition education to eliminate health risks for those experiencing food insecurity.
"The Queen Anne's County Backpack Program and the families we serve are extremely grateful for this generous grant from the Food Lion Feeds Charitable Foundation," said Kathy Sells and Vincent Radosta, Backpack Program co-chairpersons.
The QAC Backpack Program relies on the generosity of caring individuals, churches, local organizations and the Queen Anne's County Department of Children and Families, all dedicated to addressing childhood hunger, according to a press release about the donation.
During the 2023/24 school year, the QAC Backpack Program provided over 2,200 weekend meals to 620 children. The Food Lion Feeds Charitable Foundation grant will help the QAC program provide weekend meals for about 410 children attending the QAC Public School summer sessions and provide over 1,600 bags of food and 1,200 snacks during the summer.
"We are also grateful for the 70+ volunteers who assist the Program year-round in providing the needed weekend food to children in the 13 QAC Schools," the program said in a press release.Donations can be sent to Advocates For Youth QAC Backpack Program, 110 Channel Marker Way Suite 101, Grasonville, Maryland 21638

title: Rotary Club Learns About Melanoma from Expert
author: Phil Reed Rotary Club of Cambridge
content:
Rotary club learns about melanoma from expert

 July 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: PHIL REED Rotary Club of Cambridge | Section: News 
 
 214
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Steve Fine, founder and president of the Melanoma Education Foundation, spoke to members of the Rotary Club of Cambridge about his organization and how to detect melanoma and other forms of skin cancer.He said, "a primary activity of the Foundation is educating high school and middle school wellness teachers about melanoma and the resources available to them."
The organization provides free online lessons on things like self-detecting the signs of this disease while it is still curable.
Fine's interest in melanoma began following the death of his 26-year-old son, Dan, in 1998. Shortly after, he founded the nonprofit to educate people about the disease.
Since 2000, he has been devoted full time to the foundation. Prior to the pandemic, over 1,700 schools were using the lessons. As a member of the Rotary Club of Peabody, Massachusetts, in 2022, Fine expanded outreach to U.S. and Canadian Rotary Clubs in the Eastern and Atlantic time zones.
He uses the technology of virtual lessons to reach those who he would not otherwise be able to meet.
Fine received his doctorate in chemistry from Northeastern University, continuing his postdoctoral research at Lehigh University. After serving as assistant professor of organic chemistry at Lafayette College in Pennsylvania, he moved to New England, where worked as technical and manager in high tech chemical companies. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Kent County Stresses Importance of Stroke Detection Methods
author: Will Bontrager
content:
Kent County stresses importance of stroke detection methods

 August 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 474
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — At their regular scheduled meeting, Kent County Commissioners proclaimed that very day, July 23, was to be designate Kent County Stroke Smart.Those presenting before the commission said it's possible to detect a stroke before it can be a lifelong problem.
Medical Director, Primary Stroke Center at University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton Rena Sukhdeo-Singh, Neuroscience Specialist/Stroke Coordinator Nicole Leonard and Regional Director, Emergency Services Tisha Thompson presented.
Their goal is to spread awareness, showing how to detect the early symptoms of a stroke and get patients medical attention in a timely manner.
"Everything about a stroke is time-sensitive," Sukhdeo-Singh exclaimed. "If a patient arrives three to four-and-a-half hours from the symptoms, their chances are better to reverse it."
Commission member John Price read off the proclamation, stating that one out of six people will suffer a stroke. It's a leading cause of longterm disability that affects 80% families.
Price further read that professionals like Sukhdeo-Singh's team, are reaching out to the public and private schools here to spread that awareness as well as to Emergency services and the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Chestertown.
Sukhdeo-Singh showed the commissioners some materials of their organization as well as how to spot stroke symptoms in an easy-to-remember acronym:
B-E-F-A-S-T
"B" stands for balance. Often the first sign of a stroke, followed by "E" for eyes, distorting of vision. Then "F" for facial abnormalities, like freezing or tics. Then there could be tingling or numbness in the arms or legs, which is "A". "S" stands for "speech," which if muddled, confused or slurred, it's then "T", Time to call 911.
The commissioners could relate, sharing experiences of their loved ones.
Price shared his father suffered a stroke at age 65, and although he lived to be 86, he said his recovery was never fully complete.
Commission member Albert Nickerson recalled an incident when his niece insisted somebody check on her grandmother when she didn't show up for her soccer game. Her insistence and instincts were good. When someone checked on her, they discovered her grandmother was in the beginning stages of a stroke.
County Attorney Tom Yeager shared also that his father suffered a stroke, but he was unsure of what it was at the time. He didn't seek help for it until a week later.
"That's why awareness is so important," Yeager said.
Sukhdeo-Singh called it, "Spot a Stroke, Stop a Stroke, and Save a Life".
And using advanced procedures such as improved imaging technology, they can spot where the source of the stroke happens, the clot in the brain, and prescribe clot-busting medication before it's too late.
Or surgery if needed.
"We work closely to reverse strokes or do surgical procedures to remove the clot from the brain," Sukhdeo-Singh said.
Leonard thanked the commissioners for making July 27, Kent County Stroke Smart.
"This will help with the partnership with the County to get education and support our partnerships." 

 (c) Copyright 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Cambridge Rotary Learns About Brainwaves
author: GEORGE REED Rotary Club of Cambridge
content:
Cambridge Rotary learns about brainwaves

 August 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GEORGE REED Rotary Club of Cambridge | Section: News 
 
 272
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Neuroscientist Douglas Fields recently spoke to members of the Rotary Club of Cambridge about the brainwaves and some of the mysterious and controversial research that had been done in the area of study.He told the members, "a reclusive German doctor discovered electromagnetic energy radiating out of the brains of his patients in a mental hospital in the 1920s." Hidden at the time, today, he said, "research on the brainwaves is transforming how neuroscientists believe the brain works."
Linking the mind to computers has helped scientists to see how brainwaves control machines and prosthetic limbs. Controlling the connection between the human brain and the brain of the computer has helped researchers in their studies.
Transmitting information between the two brains has helped expose conscious and unconscious mental activity. Fields explained how cognitive performance can be improved by manipulating brainwaves.
Fields has authored his latest book, "Electric Brain," which discusses the history, current research and future of brainwaves in monitoring and manipulating brain function. As a neuroscientist, he has written over 150 papers on scientific research as well as numerous books and magazine articles.
A fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, he has received the Mensa Foundation Award for outstanding research in intelligence and creativity. Fields joined the National Institutes of Health in 1987, retiring as chief of the Nervous System Development and Plasticity Section in 2023.
A resident of Taylor's Island in Dorchester County, Doug has such hobbies as wine making, guitar building and mountain climbing.
Following his talk with the rotarians, he was inducted into the Rotary Club of Cambridge by past President Amanda Hailey with his sponsor, Pat Neild, by his side. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Caroline Goes Purple 5K Draws a Colorful Crowd
author: Tom McCall
content:
Caroline Goes Purple 5K draws a colorful crowd

 September 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 443
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PRESTON — A kaleidoscope of chalk was thrown into the air at the start of a 5K event to support the Caroline Goes Purple Saturday. Around 40 people started at the James Wright Memorial Park and either ran or walked the course.Catherine Bowrey is the chair of the Caroline Goes Purple Color Run.
"I am glad to see everyone out here having a good time. We have to get aware of the drug epidemic, which is a big thing. The stigma is terrible. So this way they can come out and get aware of what is going on in their communities," Bowrey said.
Caroline Goes Purple is organized by the Denton nonprofit Drug Free Caroline, a substance abuse disorder prevention and awareness program. Caroline Goes Purple is a community effort during the month of September to prevent drug use, heighten awareness and reduce the stigma around substance abuse disorder.
Jessica Tuel is the director of behavioral health for the Caroline County Health Department as well as the local addiction authority for Caroline County. She stood in front of a public health table filled with information, stress balls and pens.
"We do a lot of services in the schools both for substance use and mental health. We have full time clinicians in the north county schools and we have the Mobile Treatment Unit," Tuel said.
Her work is data-led.
"The statistics say that the earlier people start using, the longer and higher risk their use is later. Today we are bringing awareness to substance abuse in our county. We have a lot of vendors that are going to give education and services for those who need them. It is important to all these peers here, who are in a state of recovery. That is what all of the Caroline Goes Purple events are for," she said.
As a public health expert she wants both education and anti stigma to get across.
"Stigma is multifaceted. So it is stigma of the community against those who use. It is stigma of those that don't want treatment because they fear they will be judged. It is 'We don't have this problem in Caroline County,'" Tuel said.
The remedy to stigma is education and bringing statistics to the community, she said.
Angel Perez, the former Caroline Goes Purple Chair, was at this year's event as a volunteer.
"This event is important because we can raise awareness about substance abuse prevention and what is going on in our communities. We created this event last year to raise awareness in a fun way. Everybody can enjoy, but also get the information. We want to make them aware of what is going on in our community with substance abuse," Perez said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Queen Anne's Welcomes Secretary of Overdose Response
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's welcomes Secretary of Overdose Response

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 474
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Queen Anne's County welcomed Maryland's Special Secretary of Overdose Response Emily Keller for a tour of county programs and departments dedicated to erasing stigma and taking a stand against substance abuse September 25.Beginning at the Queen Anne's County Department of Health in Centreville, the Alcohol and Drug Abuse Services presented its focus on outreach, education and prevention programs.
Showcasing each journey to recovery was unique, but there were local travelers along the way, department Peer Support services offer one-on-one counseling, referral programs, outreach, and lending an empathic ear, Peer Supervisor Brook Todd said.
Providing resources for the community is a crucial aspect of preventing overdose deaths and just over the summer the department of health distributed 600 kits of Narcan to be available throughout the community, she said.
Over 100 One Boxes were also donated to businesses around the community, these kits contain CPR supplies, Narcan, gloves and everything needed in the event of an overdose.
A central focus of the Department of Health Alcohol and Drug Abuse Prevention Services is erasing the stigma connotated with overdose.
"No place is hidden, it can happen anywhere," Angulo Potts, peer recovery specialist said.
Housing and career opportunities are essential aspects of recovering from the disease of addiction and preventing relapse and the Department of Health requested assistance in streamlining the process to bring a recovery house to the county where there currently is none.
Keller noted the Maryland Office of Overdose Response is currently making it a priority to establish safe quality recovery houses and recommended collaboration with the county government.
More information about the Queen Anne's County Health Department's Alcohol and Drug Abuse Prevention Services can be found at https://www.dontlabelus.org.
At the Queen Anne's County Board of Education building, Keller heard about the activities and programs initiated by the QAC Drug Free Student Ambassadors, leading the way in youth advocacy.
Led by Julie Kille, opioid education and prevention coordinator, the Ambassador program puts students in role model positions to educate their peers on taking a stand against substance abuse and living naturally high.
With QAC Goes Purple, the Ambassadors work diligently with leadership opportunities and creative activities to spread awareness throughout the county with poster contests, collaborative community events and team-building exercises.
The Ambassadors recently won first place in the national Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration competition for their escape room sharing the dangers of pills with peers.
More information about QAC Goes Purple can be found at www.qacgoespurple.org.
Other stops on Keller's visit included the County Chamber of Commerce in Chester and the Opioid Awareness Park in Stevensville.
Throughout her visit Keller reiterated that recovery was possible and Queen Anne's County represented a prominent dedication to addressing overdose awareness for all ages in the community.
"It is great to hear what is going on. It is a hopeful time in Maryland," she said.
More information about Maryland's response to overdose and opioid awareness can be found at: https://stopoverdose.maryland.gov. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: New Rural Health Initiative by University of Maryland Seeks to Fill Medical Gap on Eastern Shore
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
New rural health initiative by University of Maryland seeks to fill medical gap on Eastern Shore

 October 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 526
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Medical student Tahreem Riaz said her interest in rural healthcare was established due to the rural community she grew up in Punjab, Pakistan.Riaz is one of six students who has been chosen for the University of Maryland School of Medicine's new rural health initiative to address the physician shortage on the Eastern Shore.
Rural areas in Maryland have notoriously been medically underserved, according to the federal Health Resource and Services Administration. Students like Riaz are taking initiative to address these disparities and help close the medical disparity through the Rural Health Equity and Access Longitudinal Elective.
The students will be provided didactic and mentoring sessions as well as research and clinical experiences on the Eastern Shore.
Leah Millstein, the program director and associate professor of medicine, said there's a real challenge for the population of the Eastern Shore in finding and accessing exemplary healthcare.
"There's a shortage in primary care doctors as well as specialties, and we often have students who are interested in rural medical care in their futures, but their exposure to it during medical school is limited," Millstein said. "So this program seeks to fill those gaps, to really give the students an in depth exposure to rural health care, and give them the building blocks that allow them to feel like they'll be successful serving as physicians in those communities when they're done with their training."
Riaz said her initial circumstances in Punjab made her realize the importance of one-to-one connection with patients and their medical providers.
"I personally faced the challenges of not discussing quality healthcare due (to a) shortage of physicians," Riaz said. "Individuals of my village have to go to far off places to get necessary healthcare."
The program is designed to train and place incoming medical students in Eastern Shore healthcare practices. About $1.4 million has been secured in state funding and from the University of Maryland, Baltimore; University of Maryland Eastern Shore; the Rural Maryland Council and many donors.
Millstein said three of the six students accepted into the program were awarded full-tuition scholarships with a commitment to working on the Eastern Shore for four years after completing residency training. The long-term goal is to support 10 students interested in rural health in this elective program each year.
Ken Kozel, president and CEO of University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, said this program will help draw new providers to the Eastern Shore.
"Strengthening our provider workforce is a top priority at UM SRH, and programs like R-HEALE will help us attract providers who want to practice in rural communities," Kozel said. "We greatly appreciate our partnership with the School of Medicine toward enhancing access across the Shore."
For Riaz, she is happy for the opportunity to focus on improving rural areas and assisting caring for the people in rural areas.
"With this program, I'll be able to be involved in research projects that are deeply focused on improving population and community health, and also to deeply understand the social, economic or cultural factors that are rooted in the disparities of such communities," she said. "I think this comprehensive training through our field will allow me to deliver more compassionate and patient centered care in the future." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland spent big on youth mental health — but then the budget crisis hit
author: Sasha Allen Capital News Service
content:
Maryland spent big on youth mental health — but then the budget crisis hit

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Sasha Allen Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 1370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The new statewide youth mental health program supported behavioral health services for more than 58,000 students in its first eight months of operations from March through October 2024. Four out of every five of Maryland public schools received aid for mental health services under the state's effort.But as the General Assembly moved to balance Maryland's fiscal 2025 budget last spring, lawmakers cut funding for the state's fledgling youth mental health program from Gov. Wes Moore's recommended $110 million to $40 million.
With the state's fiscal problems deepening, Moore is recommending the state allocate $40 million annually through 2030 to a program he once suggested should get $130 million a year starting in fiscal 2026.
Meagan Pantelis, a clinical social worker at Thrive Behavioral Health, said the proposed cuts would decimate services for students that, in many cases, are just getting off the ground.
"Whenever I found out about that proposed cut, the very first thing that came to mind is that Gov. Moore is wanting to balance a budget on the backs of our children," Pantelis said. "I just find that to be just egregious. I mean, why are our children the population that we are targeting? Why are they not the population that we want to build up and support?"
Moore, however, has stressed the state must act to close a structural $3 billion budget gap driven in part by the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the 10-year, multibillion-dollar education reform plan that created the youth mental health program.
"We only have difficult decisions ahead," Moore said in his State of the State address in early February. "We must close this $3 billion budget gap."
The mental health crisisDuring the 2022-23 school year, over a quarter of Maryland high school students reported their mental health was not good at most or all times, according to a Maryland Department of Health survey.
The percentage was only slightly lower for middle school students, with 22% reporting their mental health was not good at most or all times.
"We all know generally that there's a mental health crisis," said Lorianne Moss, the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission program manager. "So as sort of the preamble to our first call for proposals, we laid out some data."
That data, from the Centers for Disease Control, showed 40% of high school students experience persistent feelings of sadness or hopelessness. Citing such statistics, the consortium urged mental health programs and nonprofits across the state to apply for funds.
Applicants requested a total of $380 million in grants, said Mark Luckner, executive director of the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission, which oversees the consortium. That's more than three times what the consortium had to allocate.
Nevertheless, the state funded mental health service providers in every county.
Preventing youth suicide is one of the consortium's key goals, said Dr. John Campo, director of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. Sixteen of the consortium's 129 grants so far focus on suicide prevention.
Suicide is the second-leading cause of death for people ages 10-14 and third for people ages 15-24, according to the most recent CDC data.
"Suicide kills more young people in that age group than cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, respiratory illnesses, infections of all kinds, meningitis, pneumonia, HIV, COVID — the whole nine yards," Campo said. "Add them all together, suicide kills more people than all those things combined."
In Maryland, the teen suicide rate increased by more than a third from 2014 to 2022. Campo said the state's health care system has been ill-equipped to deal with that increase.
"Mental health crisis isn't a priority in most emergency departments," Campo said.
Campo is one of the co-chairs of the consortium's best practices subcommittee, a group that developed a list of evidence-based mental health practices for grantees to implement.
Each program targets a different facet of the mental health crisis. The responses are also tailored to the varying levels of severity of the mental health conditions different age groups experience.
The consortium found through surveys targeted at both students and parents that 90% of students and families were satisfied with the services.
"A lot of these practices have been tested," Campo said. "If regional organizations adopt them and implement them with fidelity, we really do want to believe that there will be positive outcomes associated with it."
From the city to the ShoreThe youth mental health crisis touches all of Maryland, and so does the state's response — but grants are tailored to the vast differences among Maryland's urban, suburban and rural communities.
In Baltimore City, the 11 grants the consortium issued take into account a stigma surrounding mental health services, said Jennifer Cox, director of the University of Maryland School Mental Health Program, which received a $970,000 grant to run a number of programs.
"We think in Baltimore City, we have to be a little bit more creative than just saying, 'Come get help,' " Cox said. "We know we have good things to offer, we just need to find a good way to offer it."
Working with trusted community organizations such as churches and youth centers, the program has been able to reach people who would otherwise not seek out mental health treatment, Cox said.
Services range from in-school counseling from certified clinicians to parent and caregiver education programs.
Meanwhile, the state's efforts on the largely rural Eastern Shore stress increasing access to treatment in a region that's short of professionals to respond to the youth mental health crisis.
According to the October 2024 report, "Investing in Maryland's Behavioral Health Talent," Maryland is nearly 50% short of the mental health workers it needs.
"There's a resounding message of 'we just need more,'" said Beth Anne Dorman, CEO of For All Seasons, a behavioral health and rape crisis center that received a grant to expand its services in Kent County. "We need more."
Caroline County, where two organizations won grants to expand their mental health services, faces the same situation, said Derek Simmons, the county's superintendent of schools.
"We are a rural county that is less wealthy than a lot of parts of the state," said Simmons, co-chair of the consortium's best practices committee. "So access to behavioral health is near and dear, and a real challenge where I'm at."
An uncertain future
If the General Assembly agrees with the funding levels suggested in the governor's budget, programs that just started last year may have to be eliminated, said Del. Eric Ebersole (D-Baltimore County, Howard).
"That group worked in good faith to bring providers online," said Ebersole, a consortium member. "If the government loses them, can you get them back?"
Dan Martin, senior director of public policy at the Mental Health Association of Maryland, said the proposed cut in planned funding comes at a time when youth mental health care is more important than ever.
"At a time when 18% of high school students and 24% of middle school students have seriously considered suicide in the past year, a reduction of this size in school mental health funding could prove disastrous," Martin said.
If the General Assembly approves Moore's budget proposal, the grants distributed by the program in fiscal years 2025 and 2026 combined will be cut 28% from the total amount distributed the prior two years.
Asked for comment, Moore's office stressed the governor's proposed allocation for fiscal year 2026 and beyond is exactly what the General Assembly approved for 2025.
"Gov. Moore is maintaining the current level of funding for the Maryland Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports," wrote a spokesperson from the governor's office. "The Governor strongly supports behavioral health treatment for Maryland's children, and maintaining current levels of funding during the state's budget crisis reflects that commitment."
The Mental Health Association of Maryland is urging action to try to persuade the General Assembly to restore funding to a higher level. The organization is circulating a fact sheet with information on the consortium, the work it's done and what a permanent cut in funding would do to students and schools.
"Use the above information and write an email to your legislators asking them to restore funding to the Community Supports Partnership Fund," the fact sheet said. "Provide testimony (either written or oral or both) opposing the cut" at General Assembly hearings.
And under the "why is funding needed" section, the Mental Health Association fact sheet reads: "Dramatic worsening of the behavioral health of children and youth over the last decade."

title: Building a Better Future: Ethan's Walk Returns to Raise Money and Support
author: Andrea Grabenstein agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Building a better future: Ethan's Walk returns to raise money and support

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Events 
 
 482
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Every parent knows their child stands apart from the crowd, but parents Jon and Erin Krisman know their son Ethan really is one-in a million.Ethan is currently a pre-kindergarden student who, as a toddler, was diagnosed with Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva, a rare and disabling genetic condition that turns muscles, tendons, and ligaments into bone, progressively restricting movement.
In addition to this extreme loss of mobility, the formation of extra bone results in many other health complications and debilitating chronic pain.
With less than 1,000 cases of Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva diagnosed worldwide, the walk seeks to raise awareness for the incredibly rare condition and showcase love and support.
Because the condition is so rare, Jon Krisman noted the initial diagnosis "was like stepping into a blackhole," and it was difficult to find others locally going through the same challenges.
Being a parent to any child is never a cakewalk but the Krisman family has had a whole other level of what they have to work through, she said.
"By doing this walk we want them to know that even though we can't fully understand what they're going through and we can't provide the support that other people facing this disease can provide, we're still there for them," said Centreville Elementary School pre-kindergarten special education teacher Katie Coursey.
A 5K in honor of Centreville Elementary School preschooler Ethan Krisman, will once again be held April 27 at 10 a.m at Route 18 Park, Centreville April 27 at 10 a.m.
Kimberly Schultes, committee chair and Centreville Elementary preschool teacher said it has been amazing to see the community's rallying support behind her former student.
"It's really neat to see," she said.
Last year's first Ethan's Walk centered around dressing as a superhero in honor of Ethan who is a daily fighter, an inspiration, and a real-life superhero.
After the tremendous success of last year's fundraiser and morale booster, the Ethan's Walk Committee saw the need to continue to raise awareness for the cause, Schultes said.
With the motto, "Building a better future for kids like me," this year's walk centers around Ethan's favorite toy: Legos.
Ethan is a very smart student who loves building and gluing activities and despite being shy at school, he receives great support from his classmates, Schultes said.
Seeing the visual of a group of people all wearing the same shirt in solidarity is very meaningful, she said.
All proceeds help support the mission critical work of the International FOP Association.
This year's walk promises to be bigger than ever with sponsorship opportunities and really showcase care and fellowship for one of Queen Anne's County's very own, Schultes said.
Anyone who registers for the walk by April 6 is guaranteed a t-shirt, and anyone who donates $100 or more by April 6 will have their name/logo printed on the back of the shirt.
More information about donations and registration can be found at ifopa.salsalabs.org/ethans_walk_2025/index.html.
More information about supporting the Krisman family can be found at ifopa.salsalabs.org/teamcurefop/p/inhonorofethankrisman/index.html. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a charity walk to raise awareness and funds for a rare genetic disease affecting a child, highlighting medical challenges and support, which aligns most closely with the Health topic.

Kimberly Schultes — Committee Chair and Preschool Teacher, Centreville Elementary School

title: From Crisis to Change: COVID-19’s Enduring Mark on the Eastern Shore
author: Staff Report
content:
From crisis to change: COVID-19’s enduring mark on the Eastern Shore

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 642
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Five years after the COVID-19 pandemic reached the Eastern Shore, its impact lingers in ways both visible and unseen. The empty streets, masked faces, and social distancing markers have faded, but the profound shifts in health care, worship, business and daily life remain.Emma Zonetti never expected the pandemic to reach her tight-knit community.
"I remember being in church, actually. My husband's mom told me that this was happening," said Zonetti, now a senior clinical nurse with University of Maryland Shore Regional Health. "And I went, 'Oh, it's nothing to worry about. It's just another virus.' And then quickly did we learn that it was way more than that."
Zonetti, who was a clinical coordinator in the telemetry unit at the Shore Medical Center at Easton during the height of the crisis, recalled the stark reality that unfolded as cases surged.
"It certainly impacted us far larger than I could ever anticipate," she said.
Late in January 2020, hospitals began screening for the virus as patients arrived in emergency rooms.
By March, State Superintendent of Schools Dr. Karen Salmon ordered a closure of schools — a temporary order that extended well into 2021, much longer than anyone anticipated.
Beaches and boardwalks closed. And by April, the number of positive cases surged and mask orders ensued.
COMMUNITY BLINDSIDEDThe first confirmed case of COVID-19 on the Eastern Shore was reported in Talbot County on March 16, 2020. Since then, there have been 8,056 confirmed cases in the county and more than 40,000 across the Mid-Shore. The virus claimed the lives of 592 Mid-Shore residents.
For religious communities, the impact was swift and disruptive. Pastor Doug Morley of Greater Impact Church in Greensboro said the closure of worship spaces came at a critical time for his newly merged congregation.
"Building on the momentum of coming together for greater Kingdom impact in 2019 and gearing up for what would potentially be one of our highest attended worship experiences on Easter Sunday (April 12, 2020), we were definitely blindsided by the mandated closure of all religious gatherings," Morley said.
Church leaders scrambled to adapt, turning to Facebook Live for virtual worship and launching a "drive-in" service using a tractor-trailer bed as a stage and an FM transmitter to broadcast services to parked cars.
"It forced us to think outside the four walls of the church," Morley said. "That shift in approach has remained with us."
Even after indoor services resumed, Morley noted, worship attendance has not yet returned to pre-pandemic levels. While some members embraced online services, others simply fell out of the habit.
LASTING LEGACYWhen Maryland lifted its COVID-19 state of emergency on July 1, 2021, many expected a swift return to normalcy. In some ways, that happened — travel resumed, restaurants filled and hugs replaced distanced greetings. But the pandemic left lasting imprints on the Eastern Shore.
Telehealth became commonplace. Remote work grew. Businesses closed, moved or downsized. Schools and universities permanently integrated virtual options. Many delayed retirement. Awareness of mental health surged as loneliness and isolation persisted.
The pandemic reshaped our priorities, forcing people to rethink work, education and social connection. Some changes were temporary, but others — like digital access and hybrid work models — are likely here to stay.
While it has taken a few years to get back to some semblance of normalcy, the impact of COVID-19 upon regular worship attendance is still evident.
"We have not returned to pre-pandemic numbers, and we still have individuals and families who choose to worship online rather than in-person," Morely said. "A few who once attended regularly have gotten out of the habit and find it difficult to return on a consistent basis."
As the Eastern Shore reflects on the past five years, the region has found resilience in adversity. Communities innovated, businesses adapted and individuals discovered new ways to connect. The pandemic may have left its mark, but so, too, did the spirit of perseverance that defines the Shore. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the lasting effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on healthcare, mental health, and public health practices, making Health the most fitting category, with secondary relevance to education and business impacts.
