title: Talbot County Provides First Look at Draft Budget for FY26
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County provides first look at draft budget for FY26

 March 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 474
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County Manager Clay Stamp said one aspect was clear when drafting the county's fiscal year 2026 budget: it needed to remain flat.Speaking with the Talbot County Council at a workshop Tuesday, county employees presented a balanced draft budget coming in at $163.3 million. It comes in slightly below last year's budget of $163.8 million.
The county's total budget has ballooned in recent years. In fiscal year 2023, it was $112 million, and one year later, it rose to $128 million. It took a sharper jump to the $163 million mark last year.
Stamp said the increases were for good cause. "You've made incredible and important investments in public safety and education," he told council members.
But Stamp emphasized that given federal uncertainties, state cost shifts and recurring county costs, it is important to curb that recent upward trend.
"That was a mandate as we put this budget together," Stamp said of the belt-tightening.
Stamp said the draft fiscal year 2026 budget currently proposes no additional job positions. The county's capital improvement plan is also trimmed back, he said. He hopes the county can focus on finishing projects already underway, such as Chapel District Elementary School renovations and a new EMS station in Cordova.
When drafting the budget, Stamp and Finance Director Martha Sparks said they initially came in $6 million over their target. To remedy that, they're proposing delayed payments for postemployment benefits and correctional officers' retirements, respectively — the latter of which is to be expected to be included in fiscal year 2027.
Sparks mentioned that tax hikes proposed at the state level for wealthy individuals may have an impact on Talbot County revenues. Sparks said last time a similar tax increase was levied in 2009, it made a significant dent, partly due to the recession.
"We had an exodus of the wealthy in our county as a result of that," Sparks said. "And it took us approximately 10 years to recover."
Sparks added, however, that the county looks OK for fiscal year 2026 in terms of those tax proposals. She said she's "not sure what that will look like for us moving forward."
As for policy and funding shifts at the federal level, Stamp said "it's reasonable" to expect impacts will trickle down to Talbot County.
"We are cognizant of that," Stamp said. "Radars are up, antennas are up. We're watching closely."
The draft budget shows $55 million in funding for the Talbot Board of Education. Stamp said the county must contribute that mark since it's required by state funding formulas. Any additional education funding is left for the County Council to consider in the coming weeks.
Council members and staff will hold a number of workshops this month and in April before a budget proposal is officially introduced April 15.
Public budget hearings are scheduled for May 6, and the County Council is expected to enact a budget ordinance May 27.

title: Counties Approve Chesapeake College Budget Request, Shift Cost of Tech Center
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Counties approve Chesapeake College budget request, shift cost of tech center

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 526
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — In a joint meeting Thursday, officials across Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties approved a shift in county cost shares for Chesapeake College's new technical building.During the meeting, which was held at the college's main campus in Queen Anne's County, the five counties approved a total $9.02 million budget request made by the college for fiscal year 2026. The school's budget is $1.31 million higher than its fiscal year 2025 budget.
Part of the $9.02 million budget request included a $952,560 request for the design of a new technical building. Chesapeake College Vice President for Administrative Services Karen Smith said the new building will have areas for a variety of programs, including agriculture, electrical, welding and fabrication, construction trades and advanced manufacturing. She said the cost for the design phase could be lower depending on state approval.
Although the five counties approved the request for funding for the design, the decision came with a shift in contributions toward the project.
Dorchester County's share of costs for the design phase will be taken on by Queen Anne's County. This means Queen Anne's County's responsibility for the project will jump from 28.9%, or an estimated $275,290, to 47.8%, or an estimated $455,324.
During the meeting, Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer and Vice President Mike Detmer outlined their council's concerns regarding paying for the project.
Although other counties hope to use the new technical building for career and technical education at the high school level, Dorchester County has a career and technology center it is still paying off, they said.
Through its budget process, Dorchester County has struggled to eliminate an estimated $6.2 million deficit.
Pfeffer said Dorchester County takes in about $45 million in property and income taxes and will have to give Dorchester County Public Schools $26.6 million for fiscal year 2026.
"So we're trying to run the rest of the county on half of that," he said. "So while in conceptual context, we believe in the project, fiscally our citizens and our staff are saying we don't know how we're going to be able to participate."
At the Chesapeake College meeting, Queen Anne's County Commissioner Jack Wilson Jr. shared his county's decision to cover Dorchester County for the project design costs.
"We all know what happens if we let this money go back to the state," Wilson said. "It's going to go somewhere else in this state, and it's not going to be here. We got this far. And Lenny, listen, I feel for you guys. I know what you're going through. But I think we just need to keep it on the rails at least through the design phase and see what the state's going to help with."
According to documents from the meeting, the state will support 75% of project costs, and the counties will support the remaining 25%.
After the counties voted to approve the amended capital budget, Kent County Commission President Ron Fithian said he understands the position Dorchester County is in, mentioning the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and "unfunded mandates" by the state.
"I think we all understand any one of us could be in your same position very easily," Fithian told the Dorchester County Council members. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Straightforward and good listener
author: Staff Writer
content:
Straightforward and good listener

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 195
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I have followed the proceedings of the Easton Town Council closely over the past five years. Don Abbatiello brings an impressive record of decades of public service to the race for president of the Easton Town Council.His 27 years teaching our young men and women is noteworthy by itself, but in addition, he has worked 16 years as part of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department, both in the field and in administrative decisions. That kind of experience explains why he approaches even the toughest issues with an open mind and works hard to find agreement on the best solution for Easton.
In my dealings with him, he has been straightforward and a good listener — qualities that are too rare today. No ideologue, he focuses on the facts and not all the excitement around him. He does his homework and explains his reasoning.
Easton faces some tough challenges over the next few years, including adopting a revised Comprehensive Plan, mitigating the shortage of affordable housing and keeping Easton a vibrant community. Having the right person as council president lead the debates that will resolve those difficult problems is essential. Don Abbatiello is the right person.
Tom Ledvina
Easton

title: 70 Children Attend Flashlight Easter Egg Hunt in Caroline County
author: Ahmad Garnett
content:
70 children attend flashlight Easter egg hunt in Caroline County

 April 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT | Section: News 
 
 336
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Kids enjoyed fun and special prizes at Denton Elementary Thursday for Caroline County Parks and Recreation's flashlight Easter egg hunt.Although the event was postponed from the week prior due to rain, Parks and Recreation program specialist Lynn Davis doesn't think the attendance was affected. Seventy kids aged 3 to 10 participated in the egg hunt, which Caroline County has been hosting the past 10 years.
"We love this. This is what we do it for," Davis said about having kids out for the event.
While traditional Easter egg hunts take place in the daylight, the Caroline County event has an added obstacle for egg hunters — darkness. The annual hunt takes place at dusk, and children use flashlights to help locate eggs on the elementary school's lawn.
Each age group had a special egg to look for. For ages 3 and 4, it was a soccer egg. For ages 5 to 7, it was a camouflage egg, and for ages 8 to 10, it was a football egg.
Each group had a separate time slot to capture the most eggs they could and go after the special egg. When a child found the special egg, they received a special prize, an Easter basket.
The event is fun for the children, but Parks and Recreation employees have fun as well.
"I found different patches of taller grass, leaves, branches and twigs," Parks and Recreations employee Liam Wallace said about hiding the eggs. "I kind of just hid it within those."
"It was just crazy. I wanted to see how happy they were out here, no elbows, no shoving, so safe fun," Halie Readores, another employee, said.
Lynn Zepp, a mother of two, brought her son, Weston, and daughter, Willow, to the egg hunt for their first year of participation.
"It was exciting," Lynn Zepp said. "We just got done with a baseball game, and we rushed over here because we wanted to try out the flashlight egg hunt."
When Weston and Willow were asked if they enjoyed the event, they said they had fun.

title: Dorchester County Makes Its Way Through Grueling Budget Process
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Dorchester County makes its way through grueling budget process

 April 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 694
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Over the past four months, an atmosphere of concern, frustration and, at times, despair has colored budget meetings in Dorchester County.In mid-April, the Dorchester County Council introduced a $91.96 million proposed operating budget for fiscal year 2026 with proposals to increase taxes. The introduction came after months of work by county staff to eliminate an estimated $6.2 million deficit.
At the same time, Dorchester County Public Schools has been working to eliminate a multi-million dollar deficit of its own. At an April budget work session, DCPS Superintendent Jymil Thompson said the district is still $5.59 million in the hole. The district hopes to eliminate the deficit by the Board of Education's May meeting.
To balance and pass these budgets, difficult decisions — like the school district canceling summer school for 2025 and the county increasing 911 fees from $1.50 to $4.25 — have already been made.
"We hate to have to put any of this on the backs of our citizens, but these are state laws that are being passed down as a bandaid for us to pay," County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said in an interview with The Star Democrat. "And unfortunately we're having to pass it down onto our citizens because we have no other revenue to pay these bills."
WHAT MAKES FY26 DIFFERENT
Dorchester County's proposed operating budget is $10 million more than the fiscal year 2025 budget passed last May. County Manager Jerry Jones said the increases are in part due to new education requirements from the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's education plan.
Jones said another reason the county has had to increase spending include cost shifts from the state to the county for things like teacher pensions.
In an effort to lessen budget costs, the county sought a waiver for the maintenance of effort for education, which is a law that requires counties to provide as much funding per pupil as was provided in the previous fiscal year. But with a narrow window between the state passing a budget and the waiver's due date, the county had to ask for an extension, which was denied.
"It's disappointing," Jones said. "But at the end of the day, we've got to keep moving forward."
Thompson said Blueprint requirements, like increasing teacher starting salaries, are part of the reason why the school district's budget — which is separate from the county's — has been difficult to balance this year. He said inflation and recurring program costs have also hindered the process.
"No decision is easy," he said. "But I think we're all trying to make the best decision for our students."
Both Jones and Thompson said they don't see the annual budget process getting easier any time soon. Jones said he doesn't see things getting easier unless change is made at the state level.
"I don't see (the budget) easing up in years to come unless some big changes are considered at the general assembly and future sessions," he said. "We'll see how it plays out."
TAX DIFFERENTIALS
One of the proposed changes to balance the county's budget is to remove the tax differential, or lower property tax rate, for Cambridge and Hurlock. This would mean Cambridge and Hurlock residents would have to pay the full property tax rate.
Cambridge Mayor Lajan Cephas said although the county is trying its best to balance the budget, she believes this measure is unfair to Cambridge residents. She said the tax differential essentially returns money to tax payers for "duplicated" services.
Cephas also said Cambridge is growing, which will increase the tax base and bring in more revenue for the county. She said the county should instead look into raising taxes in unincorporated areas that are "a little bit better off."
Jones said he doesn't know what the final budget will look like, but said the council welcomes input.
"We want people to come forward and contribute to this conversation," he said.
Adoption of Dorchester County's budget is slated for May 20. The county's first public budget hearing will be held May 6.
Thompson said the Dorchester County Board of Education has to pass the budget by the end of June, but he hopes the board will pass the budget in May to give staff time to make necessary preparations. 

 Copyright  2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot County OKs $161 million budget
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County OKs $161 million budget

 May 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 685
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County made good on its promise to deliver a flat, conservative budget for fiscal year 2026. The County Council unanimously passed a $161.1 million spending plan Tuesday.It comes in at nearly $3 million under last year's budget amid what County Manager Clay Stamp calls "uncharted waters."
"The economic landscape out there is a bumpy ride right now," Stamp said. "This year, we knew that we needed to flatten the budget out, we needed to live within our means."
Stamp and other officials have emphasized Talbot County's continued financial commitments toward public safety, whether through capital projects such as an EMS station in Cordova or support for correctional officers.
In a draft version of the budget that only received a few adjustments Tuesday, the council is expected to allocate the following funds for public safety:
$11.5 million for emergency medical services.$10.5 million for the Talbot County Sheriff's Office.$7.6 million for the Department of Corrections.$5.4 million for emergency management.$3.3 million for volunteer fire departments.
Council members thanked Stamp, Finance Director Martha Sparks and Assistant Finance Director Kaitlin Foster-Clark for their work during the budget process.
"This was the most challenging budget that I've ever sat through," council member Keasha Haythe said. "The decisions were very hard on some items."
"It was definitely a heavy lift this year, but everyone bucked down, and we made it happen here," council member Dave Stepp said.
The county's property tax rate will remain largely steady at 79 cents per $100 of assessed value, though residents will see a supplemental tax of just over 1 cent per $100 of value on their tax bills.
EDUCATION FUNDING
That supplement stems from education funding OK'd by the county. While most line items were ironed out through deliberations, workshops and meetings, Tuesday's discussion centered on funding amendments for Talbot County Public Schools.
The budget already included $55 million in education funding as required by The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's initiative to fund and improve education. County Council members were left to consider how much the county would contribute above that mark.
In a 4-1 vote Tuesday, the council approved an additional $600,000 in funding for schools, aimed at filling nine positions, including multilingual and special education roles. Council member Lynn Mielke was the sole no vote.
The approved budget change came after an amendment to fulfill the district's entire $1.1 million request — which had been scaled back from $5.5 million earlier this budget cycle — failed narrowly. Vice President Pete Lesher and Haythe favored the $1.1 million, but President Chuck Callahan, Stepp and Mielke did not.
Lesher argued it is "short-sighted" to not fund the full request. He said it'd be prudent for the county to gradually increase its education funding as even higher Blueprint projections loom in future fiscal years.
"This would be a small step in that direction," Lesher said. "And frankly, it will make next year, an election year, a lot easier for all of us up here."
"I think we should be going farther," he said of the $600,000 mark. "But this goes some distance."
Callahan sponsored the amendment to partially OK the district's request, citing the significant need for teachers. The $500,000 not approved by the council was requested by the district to increase teacher and instructional assistant salaries.
"I would ask that the school board use the money that we give you for (hiring) teachers," Callahan said. "I would like to see that, and not for something else."
Mielke said she was initially on board with Callahan's amendment. But she said she needs "more security" that the district will put the $600,000 toward the nine positions.
"I'm not advised that it necessarily would be," Mielke said. "So for that reason I couldn't support it."
A spokesperson for Talbot County Public Schools said in a statement to The Star Democrat that the district stands behind the $1.1 million request but understands the "challenges faced by council and staff in meeting the funding needs of Talbot County in these uncertain times."
"We are grateful for their support for educators' pensions and for the additional staff needed to serve our students," the statement read.
This story has been updated to include a statement from Talbot County Public Schools. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dorchester County Council to Submit Five Legislative Initiatives
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Dorchester County Council to submit five legislative initiatives

 June 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 379
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Dorchester County Council Members are planning to submit five recommendations for the Maryland Association of County's 2026 legislative initiatives.MACo will select four initiatives based on feedback and suggestions from Maryland's county jurisdictions and Baltimore City to prioritize during the state's General Assembly beginning in January.
MACo's 2025 initiatives focused on local revenue structures, infrastructural funding, the Blueprint for Maryland's Future and clean energy. Dorchester County's recommendations for 2026 do not differ too much.
The Dorchester County Council's five recommendations are:
To consider a pause or suspension of the Blueprint for Maryland's Future education plan to allow counties to catch up financially.To rethink or review existing rules or policies that override local control over solar energy regulations.To improve infrastructure related to transportation and water drainage in Dorchester County.To introduce an initiative regarding safety concerns of solar battery storage and concerns regarding the sufficiency of the decommissioning bond that covers the cost of removing solar infrastructure once it's no longer in use.To continue to reform juvenile justice. This recommendation came after a 15-year-old resident shot and killed another resident in the 900 block of Cornelia Street on June 8.
County Council Vice President Mike Detmer said juvenile justice laws need serious reformation to make Dorchester County a safer place.
"Whether you're below 18 or over 18, you have to get some feedback for your actions," Detmer said. "Your terrible actions aren't in a vacuum; we all live here."
The purpose of MACo's recommended initiatives is to address problems counties are facing with state legislators. County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said the organization collects concerns and information from counties to assist them in navigating the legislative process at the General Assembly.
Detmer said that these initiatives don't always align with Dorchester County due to the county's unique set of problems, and this misalignment has caused some tension with the state. "You know, things are complicated," he said. "I would say the tension really stems from the policies and laws that the state is enacting."
Elected officials from Maryland's 23 counties and Baltimore City can submit legislative proposal initiatives on behalf of the county as an elected body, generally at an open meeting or via a voting process, or not on behalf of the county, but as an individual.
Nominations can be submitted online through June 27 on the MACo website.

title: Caroline Commissioners Weigh Potential Locations for New Lockerman Middle
author: Ahmad Garnett
content:
Caroline commissioners weigh potential locations for new Lockerman Middle

 June 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 666
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — During the Caroline County Commissioners' open comment report Tuesday morning, Commissioners Vice President Larry Porter brought up the discussion on Lockerman Middle School's proposed locations.Porter said he preferred that the new middle school go on the North Caroline High School property, one of two locations being considered during the design processes for the building begin. The other location, near the county sheriff's office on Double Hills Road, presents several challenges, Porter said.
"I think at this point I would like to say that I am in favor of the North Carolina location as opposed to being built in town," Porter said.
Commissioners Frank Bartz agreed with Porter and cited traffic and safety concerns on Route 404.
The commissioners also had discussions about the school's location at their meeting two weeks ago.
At that meeting, County Administrator Kathleen Freeman presented the two location options. Commissioners President Travis Breeding sparked a conversation about how much sway the commissioners have over the school's location.
"How much influence do the commissioners actually have over where the school gets constructed?" Breeding asked two weeks ago. "As part of the funding of this, other than a survey, we haven't really been consulted."
Breeding then explained the issues they would run into with each potential location.
"From what I gather, it seemed like a lot of people really preferred the Double Hills location. But, with Double Hills, we've got to work out a ton of details with the Town of Denton as far as sewer, water allocation for that to work, potentially pump station upgrades," Breeding said.
He then mentioned traffic issues on Route 404 with beach traffic towards the end of the school year and students from northern county towns like Marydale, who would have to take the bus a long distance to the potential Double Hills location.
Porter, said he didn't recall that "the county did not have a lot of input" on the design of new county buildings in the past.
Freeman assured Breeding that the county will be involved with the full feasibility study for both sites to determine which site makes the most sense.
Breeding also brought forward discussion of how much influence the commissioners will have for the design of the school.
"Then also, how much input do we have over the the design?" Breeding asked. "I mean, we don't want a situation where we're building something that's way more expensive than it needs to be or making it as functional as we can and keeping the cost as low as we can."
Bartz raised an issue where if the county has to build a new detention center, a school on the Double Hills Road site would cause a problem. The Caroline County Sheriff's Office is located near that Double Hills Road site, making the location logical for a detention center, he said.
The county is in talks with Queen Anne's County about a new 388-bed regional detention center that would house all Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent county prisoners. After conversations about control and cost of the center, discussions between the three counties have slowed down.
Lockerman name
Porter pointed out conversation that are being had about the Lockerman's name staying at the location of the current building instead of being attached to the new school.
Though the existing building will no longer be used as a school when the new school is built, Porter said he was in favor of keeping the Lockerman name attached to the facility in the interest of honoring its history.
"I think it's going to be important that the history of the school and the name of Lockerman be retained," he said. "I don't know what the future use is going to be for that building, but it's important, I think, from the alumni standpoint, from the community standpoint, that the history be be kept there for whatever use is going to be done in the future."
Breeding suggested drafting a letter of intent to the Caroline County Board of Education stating that it would be the commissioners' intention to retain the name of the building.

title: Caroline County Commissioners/July 8, 2025
author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
content: Denton — At its July 8 meeting, the Caroline County Commissioners took the following actions:Dr. Derek Simmons and CFO Jill Hignutt, Caroline County Board of Education, presenting their adopted fiscal year 2026 budget. Hignutt and Simmons explained multiple numbers within their budget including increasing administrators salaries to become competitive with neighboring counties. The commissioners also discussed Lockerman Middle School and the potential new location. Simmons said the Board of Education will keep a close working relationship with the commissioners throughout the process.Lori Bishop and Charlotte Brown provided an update on the addition to 4-H Park. The addition is almost complete, but the bathrooms failed inspection due to sinks being too tall and toilets being to far from the wall.Daniel Fox discussed Opioid Settlement Fund with the county commissioners. The county received $358,000 in local direct payments and $515,000 in target aid grants for opioid settlement. The county plans to talk with other departments and agencies to see how the fund will properly assist on a one-time basis.The county conducted the second reading and public hearing for an emergency bill on wastewater treatment facilities. The bill will allow for non-accessory wastewater treatment facilities to be permitted by special use exception, provided the facilities hold MDE discharge permits for five years and the proposed application is similar to the previous application. The Planning Commission had a positive recommendation. The commissioners moved the discussion to a third reading at their next meeting.During the county administration report, Kathleen Freeman told the commissioners about a conversation she had with Robbie Gill about a new YMCA in Caroline County. The commissioners are adamant about getting a new YMCA in Caroline County and believe the conversations need to turn into building.

title: Superintendent and Commissioners Discuss Lockerman
author: Ahmad Garnett
content:
Superintendent and commissioners discuss Lockerman

 July 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Caroline 
 
 474
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Commissioners and Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons discussed Lockerman Middle School at the County Commissioners meeting on Tuesday.At the last commissioners meeting, the commissioners discussed their role, responsibilities and preferred location for the new Lockerman Middle School.
The superintendent came to the commissioners meeting to discuss the approval of its fiscal year 2026 budget. After the discussion the commissioners talked about Lockerman Middle School and the next steps.
"I think it'd be good for us to say that we are working together on the Lockerman Middle School construction," Commissioners President Travis Breeding said. "We were asking questions about what role the commissioners officially play in siting and construction, they were just questions that we were asking. It wasn't like the Board of Ed's going to run all over us and make crazy stupid decisions and we're going to be stuck with it. It was just what influence do we have over the process."
Breeding explained the consensus the commissioners have come to on their personal choice for the new school location.
"I think we talked about it, and our consensus is that the most logical place to put it is probably next to North Carolina High School for us," Breeding said. "We understand that there's a whole process that has to be going through, fact finding, the Board of Ed will review that and make their decisions based off of that. But we were just saying that that questioning what influence we actually had over the process."
Simmons clarified they understand the commissioners wanting understanding of their role and told the commissioners how the process will go.
"Board of Education selects the site," Simmons said. "The feasibility study, which was presented to the board on July 1st, indicated North Caroline High School was the better of the two locations. We did review the two sites that we were asked to review that were basically the county-owned, which is cost efficient way to do it.
Simmons said the board received the feasibility study that night and should be making its decision on a site at the August meeting. He added the site selection does not include picking what the design of the building will be.
After looking over potential designs for the new Lockerman Middle School, Breeding suggested having athletic facilities have their own location and not sharing fields.
"One of the major things that stuck out with me was, relocating the athletic facilities around there," Breeding said. "If we can get dedicated facilities so we're not sharing space like we have been doing forever, where lacrosse or soccer is using the outfield of the softball and the baseball field, if we can actually get dedicated space, that would be a priority of mine."
He noted that facilities in surrounding counties should be studied.
"We've got one bite at the apple here, let's get it right," Breeding said.

title: From Crushes to Banning Cell Phones — Maryland Lawmakers Propose New Legislation Covering Range of Issues
author: Hannah Combs hcombs@chespub.com
content:
From crushes to banning cell phones — Maryland lawmakers propose new legislation covering range of issues

February 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com | Section: News

636 Words

Read News Document

ANNAPOLIS – Maryland state senators and delegates have introduced a variety of bills in the 2024 legislative session, addressing issues ranging from state symbols and education mandates to law enforcement policy and budget concerns.State Symbols and Utility Regulations
State Sen. Steve Hershey (R-36) has introduced Senate Bill 562, which would designate the original Maryland Orange Crush as the state cocktail. The bill is co-sponsored by Sens. Johnny Mautz (R-37) and Mary Beth Carozza (R-38).
Hershey also sponsored Senate Bill 561, which, along with House Bill 227 sponsored by Del. Chris Adams (R-37B), would allow electric cooperatives to use unclaimed funds only to assist cooperative members or donate to nonprofit organizations, rather than treating them as abandoned property.
Additionally, Hershey introduced Senate Bill 355, seeking to delay the implementation of the Family and Medical Leave Insurance Program by two years.
Energy and Education Legislation
Del. Jeff Ghrist (R-36) is behind two bills on solar energy regulation: House Bill 739 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 478) and House Bill 742. One bill would prohibit the use of eminent domain for solar siting, while the other would return control over solar development to county governments.
Ghrist also introduced House Bill 736, which seeks to remove the mandate requiring local school systems to offer pre-kindergarten for three-year-olds. Another provision in the bill would increase state funding to help Kent County construct a new middle school.
On law enforcement, Ghrist is supporting a bill — potentially House Bill 122 — that would require the removal of unfounded complaints from police personnel files.
Nursing, Historic Preservation, and Cemetery Protections
Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-37B) has proposed House Bill 602 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 407), directing the State Board of Nursing to negotiate reciprocity agreements with neighboring states for advanced practice nursing licensure. Another measure, House Bill 616 (cross-filed as Senate Bill 421), would extend the statute of limitations for crimes related to cemetery destruction and prohibit damaging cemetery landscaping. The bill is co-sponsored by Del. Sheree Sample-Hughes (D-37A).
Hutchinson is also behind House Bill 760, which would establish a local appeals process for Maryland Historic Trust decisions.
Budget Deficit Shifts to Counties
Gov. Wes Moore's proposed budget shifts some of the state's structural deficit onto county governments. Del. Jeff Ghrist (R-36) criticized the move, stating that counties did not contribute to the deficit but are now being forced to compensate for state overspending.
"For my district, $720,000 will be shifted to Caroline County on top of an additional $1.8 million more that the county will have to add to education under Kirwan mandates," Ghrist stated. He cited similar financial burdens for other Eastern Shore counties, including Cecil, Kent, and Queen Anne's.
"This will stifle economic growth because people will be sending more of their hard-earned money to the government rather than spending it in their local economies," Ghrist added.
Law Enforcement and Traffic Stop Restrictions
A controversial proposal, Senate Bill 292, has drawn strong opposition from law enforcement officials, including Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker. The bill would reclassify certain primary traffic offenses as secondary offenses, preventing law enforcement from stopping drivers solely for those violations.
"These minor traffic violations could actually lead to catching suspects that have committed serious felonies, recovering firearms, and stopping drug-related crimes," Baker said. A hearing on the bill is scheduled before the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee.
Other Bills of Local Interest
House Bill 28, sponsored by Del. Josh Bouchat (R-5), proposes a constitutional amendment requiring all Maryland counties to adopt a charter government structure.
House Bill 278, also from Bouchat, would provide an income tax subtraction modification for enhanced agricultural management equipment to support sustainable farming practices.
House Bill 192, introduced by Del. Nino Mangione (R-42A), aims to curb student cell phone use in schools under the proposed "No Distracted Learning Act."
As these bills move through the legislature, local officials and residents will have the opportunity to voice their support or concerns during committee hearings and public forums.

title: We Have a Government of Checks and Balances
author: Staff Writer
content:
We have a government of checks and balances

 September 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Headlines 
 
 255
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A division of power among the president, Congress and judiciary was celebrated Wednesday during a Constitution Day presentation at the Oxford Community Center.Part-time Oxford resident and U.S. District of Maryland Judge James Breder spoke about judicial independence and the constitutional system of government
"This division of power was a central feature of the framers' plan for a representative and democratic government," he said. "Now, when I refer to the framers, I'm referencing the men, and they were all men, who met and conceived the Constitution and the Bill of Rights."
The framers wanted to prevent the concentration of power and subsequent tyranny they experienced under the British king, as noted by the founders in the Declaration of Independence.
The judge's words, delivered to a full-house at the community center, are important reminders of the foundation that the American government is built upon. The Founding Fathers built a system of checks and balances, a system that some people today would say is eroding.
Saturday students will show off their knowledge of that system at the inaugural U.S. Constitution Scholastic Competition at the Talbot County Free Library. Students from throughout the Mid-Shore have been invited to test their constitutional knowledge at the event.
Speaking of government, at the state level the three Republican delegates representing Maryland's District 36 — Steve Arentz of Queen Anne's County, Jay Jacobs of Kent County and Jeff Ghrist of Caroline County — formally filed for reelection Wednesday.
Election Day is still more than a year away, but the races are already starting to take shape.
— Jim Johnson

title: New Plaques at Harmony Community Park Honor Roger Layton, Sarah Mueller
author: Konner Metz
content:
New plaques at Harmony Community Park honor Roger Layton, Sarah Mueller

 September 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Caroline 
 
 548
 Words 

 Read News Document

 HARMONY — Caroline County honored two respected leaders Saturday by unveiling plaques in their names at the Harmony Community Park.Families and friends of Roger Layton and Sarah Mueller gathered for a joint dedication at the park, which is on Route 16 north of Preston and south of Denton.
A fence for the park's ball field got a new addition: a plaque cementing it as Roger Layton Memorial Field, named after the former Caroline County commissioner and longtime youth softball and baseball coach.
In front of the park's pavilion, a large plaque set on brick dedicated the park to Sarah Mueller, a well-known community volunteer and former Character Counts coach at Preston Elementary School. Character Counts coaches teach trustworthiness, respect and fairness to school-age kids.
Current Caroline County commissioners and other officials attended and spoke to the expansive impacts both Layton and Mueller had on the local community.
Stacy Seward, one many local softball players coached by Layton, recalled fond memories of her former mentor.
"He created lasting memories for so many young athletes," said Seward, the county's grants coordinator. "For example, teaching us how to slide in the playground sand at Denton Elementary School, saying 'If I can get my old body down here, you girls can too.'"
Steward said he was key to creating the county's first ever softball travel team.
"He was the true backbone to girls' softball, not only in Caroline County, but to the entire Eastern Shore," Seward said.
Commission Vice President Larry Porter said Layton, a commissioner of eight years and former investigator for the State's Attorney's Office, always put Caroline County first.
Daughter Jaclyn Crawford said her father's "real gift was his deep commitment to young people."
"In each role, he was known for his competitive spirit, but above all, his determination to make life safer and better for the community," Crawford said.
In addition to Crawford, other family members of Roger Layton who attended Saturday's dedication included: wife Faye Layton, sister Rena Callahan, stepfather Ronald Sard, granddaughter Madison Weston, cousin Rick Davis and more.
After Layton's sign was unveiled, the curtain was removed off of a large plaque dedicated to Mueller. Husband John Mueller then reflected on his wife's knack for helping people.
"If she heard that you needed something, she'd be the one to offer," her husband said. " ... She was always there first."
He recalled not just her volunteer efforts as a character coach for elementary school kids, but also her assistance in collecting dog and cat food for the local Humane Society.
In addition to John Mueller, his four kids and six grandchildren attended Saturday's dedication, as well as Sarah's mom, Jessie Browne.
Around four years ago, the Mueller family donated $20,000 to the county for upkeep and improvements at Harmony Community Park, including to the pavilion, walking trails and playground.
County commissioners thanked the Mueller family for their donation to the park and spoke about Sarah Mueller's lasting legacy.
"Sarah was more than a neighbor," Porter said. "She was a friend, volunteer, mother and a mentor who gave so much of herself to this community, from her time as a Character Counts coach to her years with the Girl Scouts, where she poured her love into children and back.
"By placing her name here at Harmony Park, we make sure her kindness, spirit and her legacy will always be a part of this place."

title: Caroline County Commissioners/ Sept. 23, 2025
author: Ahmad Garnett
content: Denton — At the Sept. 23 Caroline County Commissioners meeting, the following actions were taken:The commissioners presented a proclamation for September as Suicide Prevention month to Melissa Kelly, board member, and Allison Jones, Center for Learning associate director at For All Seasons Inc.Superintendent for Caroline County Public Schools, Derek Simmons, along with Bill Mengel, director of operations, presented the FY27 Capital Improvement Plan to the commissioners. The CIP focuses heavily on Lockerman Middle School's new location. CCPS officials also mention plans for upgrades at two wastewater treatment facilities in FY30 and FY31. A new roof for Denton Elementary School is projected to cost $5 million. This project is not CIP eligible, and the district is awaiting a new priority funding program from the state, expected to be voted on by April 2026.The commissioners held the third reading of a legislative bill creating the Caroline County Compensation Review Commission. This commission will study compensation and allowances for county commissioners and make recommendations. The bill was enacted, going into effect Nov. 8, with the committee reporting back by Dec. 15.The commissioners held the introduction and first reading for a new legislative bill amending the composition of the Caroline County Agricultural Reconciliation Committee, removing specific requirements for members and adding the requirement that all members must be residents and citizens of Caroline County. The public hearing is scheduled for Oct. 7.The commissioners held the introduction and first reading for a new legislative bill that creates an Agricultural Land Preservation Fund to receive compensatory preservation contributions when solar energy generating stations are developed on prime or statewide important agricultural land. The fund's money can only be used for purchasing development rights on agricultural lands in Caroline County, with the written approval of the county commissioners. The public hearing is scheduled for Oct. 7.The commissioners approved the consent agenda.

title: MACo Leaders Meet with Talbot Officials to Discuss 2026 General Assembly
author: Konner Metz
content:
MACo leaders meet with Talbot officials to discuss 2026 General Assembly

 September 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Leaders from the Maryland Association of Counties shared predictions for a calmer legislative session in 2026 during a meeting with the Talbot County Council on Tuesday.Michael Sanderson, MACo's executive director, and Jack Wilson, the association's president and current Queen Anne's County commissioner, met for an annual check-in with Talbot officials.
Sanderson reminded the council members of last year's volatile General Assembly session, during which legislators and Gov. Wes Moore (D) had to reckon with closing a $3 billion gap in the state's fiscal year 2026 budget.
Some savings came through cost shifts placing more burden on county governments, the MACo leaders said. But they added that the upcoming 2026 session, and the fiscal year 2027 budget that goes along with it, likely won't be as dire.
"Relatively calm, probably not a big crisis," Sanderson said of his projection for this year's session, which officially kicks off Jan. 14 in Annapolis.
He said the large budgetary concerns are likely to reappear in 2027 as legislators put together a plan for fiscal year 2028.
"The story from last year is gonna repeat itself, but with a year off," Sanderson predicted.
Specifically, the executive director said Maryland's expansive education funding formula, The Blueprint, will influence the 2027 session. And in the short-term, some counties are already coming to grips with increasing cost shares for education.
"Every county is either in the midst or a year or two away from seeing a year where the increase in school spending required under Blueprint requires all the money or even more money than your county's likely to gain in revenue for that year," Sanderson said. "It's an obvious squeeze at the local level."
Talbot County's fiscal year 2026 budget included $55 million in education funding required by The Blueprint's formulas. On top of that, the council approved an additional $600,000 in funding to fill new positions.
That mark had been scaled back twice from the original ask the Talbot Board of Education made of the council — first requesting $5.5 million in supplementary funds, then $1.1 million.
County Council Vice President Pete Lesher, who supported the district's $1.1 million request earlier this year, said it was "short-sighted" for the county to only fund the district's request partially, given that Blueprint requirements are only set to increase in future years. But other council members opted to hold back on dedicating the full request as the county aimed to even out its spending hikes seen in years prior.
Sanderson said on Tuesday that housing legislation will be at the forefront this winter. Recently, Moore signed an executive order that aims to speed up the permitting and building of affordable housing projects.
"I anticipate that being a big fight," Sanderson said. "Whether it's a big fight in the more rural jurisdictions is yet to be seen."
Council Member Lynn Mielke asked how Easton fits into state plans to tackle the housing issue.
Sanderson said there's an opportunity for MACo to advocate for provisions so a potential housing package doesn't "overwhelm" local jurisdictions. He said the association can help push for certain changes to help counties and towns that lack authority in certain areas, such as the variation of impact fees on developers.
"At the same time, we generally want to keep land use decisions local," he added.

title: Gov. Moore Fights for the Shore
author: Staff Writer
content:
Gov. Moore fights for the Shore

 October 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 336
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I've been a Republican all my life — as the mayor of my town, as a delegate who defeated a Democratic incumbent to serve in Annapolis, and when I voted for Donald Trump in the last presidential election.There's no doubt I'm a Republican, but I'll proudly cross that party line to back Gov. Wes Moore and his mission to build a Maryland that leaves no one behind.
I was born in Salisbury, raised near Crisfield and served the people of Delmar for two decades — I know what it's like to live in a community that feels forgotten by Annapolis. I've worked with a lot of local leaders and several governors, trust me when I tell you, Wes Moore is different.
In two and half years, he's made 51 visits to the Eastern Shore and just last week was the first governor to visit Smith Island since 1999. But he doesn't just come to the Shore; he brings investment with him.
Since taking office he's put $1.9 billion in education funding here; he's made historic investments in rural health care and hospitals opening TidalHealth in Salisbury and breaking ground on the University of Maryland Shore Regional Medical Center; he's put a $10 million investment to improve our waterways up and down the Shore; and he's cut through the red tape to open and expand businesses in places like Caroline County and Dorchester County.
But perhaps most importantly, he's focused two of the state's strongest poverty fighting initiatives in our rural communities. His ENOUGH Act includes funding to Dorchester and Caroline counties to end generational childhood poverty, and Cambridge was named as one of the first Just Communities giving them priority access to funding that will help increase assets, home ownership and home values.
We are seeing momentum across the state and in our own communities that we just can't afford to lose. I've endorsed him, I believe in him, and I'm proud to work alongside him, because I know Gov. Moore fights for the Shore.
CARL L. ANDERTON JR.
Former state delegate
Delmar 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Never plug these into power strip
content:
Never plug these into power strip

 August 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A9 | Section: News 
 
 279
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For safety's sake, never plug the following items into a power strip.HAIRDRESSING APPLIANCES You need 'em hot and ready to go, which makes a power strip on the bathroom counter pretty much a godsend when you have only that one outlet. Here's the problem with that: Hairdryers, curling wands and flat irons are required to produce heat, which means they pull large amounts of amperage to get them good and hot. Plugging them into a power strip is just asking for trouble. These types of hairdressing appliances must be plugged directly into a wall outlet - preferably one with a ground-fault circuit interrupter breaker to avoid danger should those tools accidentally be exposed to water.REFRIGERATOR AND FREEZER.These appliances pull too much current for a power strip because they are continuously cycling on and off.That will quickly overload a power strip. These items need to be plugged directly into a wall outlet dedicated solely to that appliance.TOASTER.Here's the clue: It has exposed wires inside those slots that heat up to become red-hot. It takes a lot of current to fire up those wires, which can easily overload a power strip. So, no, do not plug your toaster into an extension cord or power strip.Ditto for your toaster oven.MICROWAVE.I still think of my microwave oven as a miracle for food preparation, thawing, cooking and reheating in a fraction of the time it takes a conventional oven. However, such incredible activity demands more energy than what a power strip can deliver.SPACE HEATER.Most portable heaters consume 1,500 watts of energy on their high settings. Connect one to a power strip and it becomes potentially hazardous due to allowing them to run for an extended period. 
 
 Caption: MARY HUNT 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article provides safety instructions to prevent electrical hazards, which directly relates to public safety concerns.

title: Fire Group Raising $5 Million for Training Center
content:
Fire group raising $5 million for training center

 August 10, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 667
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Friends of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department are in the midst of a capital campaign for the Emergency Services Training Campus in Easton, seeking to raise $5 million in a two-to three-year timeframe.Located at 9095 Mistletoe Dr., the state-of-the-art training campus will serve the town of Easton, fire departments, emergency service personnel, law enforcement and paramedics in Talbot County for specialized education and certification. Currently, volunteer firefighters on the Mid-Shore have two options for training facilities in Princess Anne in Somerset County or Centreville in Queen Anne's County.Components of the project include a 3,500-square-foot concrete public safety building for first responder training, a 3,600-squarefoot classroom training and storage building and a 1,500-square-foot concrete pad for car fire, extrication and stabilization, and traffic safety training.Training for fire departments will include firefighting skills, rescue, and motor-vehicle fire and extraction. Law enforcement training will include hostage rescue, physical training and testing, traffic training, Homeland Security and K-9 operations. Emergency Medical Services can use classroom facilities for their training."This state-of-the-art training campus will not only support EVFD members for their training but will also help us in recruiting and training new members for the department. The training campus will also enable us to support our partners in law enforcement and emergency services in their training and recruitment needs and to better coordinate our roles in emergencies.We encourage the community to support our fundraising efforts as we embark on this $5 million goal," said fire Capt. Daryl Caldwell.The town of Easton gifted the use of a 2.7 acre property on Mistletoe Drive to the volunteer fire department for a state-of-the-art training center. This facility will serve both the town of Easton and the six local volunteer fire departments in Talbot County, as well as fire departments across the Mid-Shore. Talbot County has 260 active firefighters that respond to thousands of calls. EVFD responded to 896 calls involving 10,000 man hours in 2022 and conducted 1910 hours of training in 2022."It has never been more important than now to train our first responders and emergency personnel who serve Talbot County every day. There currently is no dedicated first responder training campus in Talbot County. The Friends of the EVFD and its volunteers accepted the challenge to raise $5 million for facility construction and operational expenses for the new campus.This campaign is essential toward ensuring cutting-edge training is available for all emergency services personnel," said campaign co-chairman Brett Whitehead."The sheriff's office is very excited to see this project come to fruition. The facility will not only offer training to our dedicated volunteer firefighters but will be able to support training for our deputies and police officers. Our citizens deserve the best-trained law enforcement officers. This training facility will support localized training to better equip our deputies while saving hard-earned taxpayer funds through reduced travel time and associated expenses. The facility will also be available for K-9 training for tracking people as well as drug detection," Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble said."We're very excited about the brand-new state-of-the-art training facility to be used by fire departments, EMTs, and law enforcement around the Mid-Shore. This facility will allow us to train and recruit talented first responders from around the region. The Town is fully committed to helping our first responders safely and effectively serve our community, and this training facility is a crucial resource that will improve many facets of their operations. We are very thankful for the dedication and selfless service of the men and women who volunteer to protect and serve our Town, and thankful that they go above and beyond to ensure our community's safety, Easton Mayor Megan Cook said.For further information or to donate to the Friends of the EVFD Public Safety Capital Campaign for its Emergency Services Training Campus in Easton, contact Brett Whitehead at (302) 236-6249 or by email at whitenj20@gmail.com. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF FRIENDS OF THE EASTON VOLUNTEER FIRE DEPARTMENT
 
An artistic rendering shows the planned Emergency Services Training Campus in Easton.

title: Flashing Red Lights Mean Stop - Drivers Need to Watch, Especially When Buses Stop to Load and Unload Students
content:
Flashing red lights mean stop - Drivers need to watch, especially when buses stop to load and unload students

 August 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 296
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland State Police and the Maryland Center for School Safety remind motorists to stop for school buses as students return to class.Drivers must stop at least 20 feet from a school bus with the stop arm extended and the red lights flashing.Do not pass the bus from any direction until the stop signals are off and the bus is moving again. Motorists in Maryland are not required to stop if the road is separated by a physical median - such as dirt, grass or a barrier.Millions of children ride school buses and are most at risk when they get on or off the bus. There were 1,009 fatal school-transportation-related crashes from 2011 to 2020, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The Maryland Center for School Safety encourages Marylanders and visitors to:▪ Pay attention when driving, especially in school zones and during times of day when school buses are typically on routes.▪ Stop when a bus stops. It is illegal to pass a school bus with its red lights flashing.▪ Prepare to stop when the school bus is flashing its yellow lights and be cautious of students beginning to move toward the bus during these times.▪ Students of all ages are unpredictable.Therefore, prepare for the unexpected and maintain a safe distance from school buses at all times.Violators who are stopped by a police officer face a fine of up to $570 and three points on their driver's licenses.Infractions carry a monetary penalty for each violation.For additional school bus safety tips, visit the Maryland Highway Safety Office. 
 
 Caption: JEFF FAUGHENDER/COURIER JOURNAL
 
School buses packed with students make their way to school in Lexington, Kentucky. Maryland public safety officials remind drivers to pay attention to school buses, especially when they are flashing red lights. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: It's time to confront ongoing youth violence
author: Armstrong Williams
content:
It's time to confront ongoing youth violence

 September 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Armstrong Williams | Page: 7 | Section: News 
 
 689
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If you go to Google and type "heinous crimes up with young people," you'll see over 2 billion results.It's a stark reminder that the alarming trend of young people committing gruesome acts isn't a new phenomenon, but the sheer proliferation and frequency of these acts most certainly is. Our society is grappling with a disconcerting reality - a reality born out of the convergence of various factors.From the messages embedded in our music to the desensitizing violence prevalent in our culture, and even the erosion of moral and ethical values, each contributes to the emergence of a more violent society.It's a society where individuals no longer temper their darkest impulses, and regrettably, it's our youth who often find themselves on the frontline, manifesting behaviors at an unacceptable rate. This is a phenomenon that should deeply trouble us all and lead us to pause in concern for the direction in which our society is headed.These young individuals, driven by a cocktail of influences, often react impulsively or, in the gravest of cases, meticulously plan calculated crimes that result in the loss of innocent lives. We've witnessed stories like that of Mackenzie Shirilla, a name etched into the annals of a society grappling with the aftermath of senseless violence.Shirilla was recently found guilty of the murder of her boyfriend, Dominic Russo, and her friend, Davion Flanagan. Their tragic deaths underscore the gravity of the situation we're facing - a situation where young people are becoming entangled in webs of aggression and desperation. In Shirilla's case, she purposely sped up her car to 100 mph and drove straight into a wall, instantly killing her boyfriend and friend.The breakdown of morality in our society is contributing to this disturbing trend. Traditional values that once served as guiding principles seem to be waning, leaving a moral vacuum in which right and wrong are increasingly ambiguous. The erosion of moral foundations means that young people are less equipped to distinguish between ethical choices and destructive actions.The deterioration of ethics further compounds the issue. Ethical conduct is the cornerstone of a civilized society, fostering a sense of responsibility and accountability. Yet, as we witness these disturbing trends among our youth, it becomes evident that the concept of ethics is losing its grip. The pursuit of personal gain, even at the expense of others, has become alarmingly normalized.As we reflect on these developments, the implications for our future are profoundly concerning. A society that permits the erosion of morality and ethics in its younger generation is sowing the seeds of its own demise. The actions of today's youth foreshadow the trajectory of tomorrow's adults. If we fail to address these concerning trends, we risk a future marked by increased violence, social fragmentation and a dearth of empathy.It's time for us to confront these unsettling truths and take meaningful action. By reemphasizing morality and ethics in our families, communities and institutions, we can recalibrate the moral compass of our youth. This requires an unwavering commitment to fostering values that prioritize human dignity, compassion and respect for one another. Only through concerted efforts to restore these foundational principles can we hope to guide our society toward a more harmonious and promising future.This alarming trend of young people exhibiting violence and aggression should serve as an urgent wake-up call for our educational institutions. We must prioritize emotional education alongside academic excellence. By equipping our youth with the tools to manage their emotions, resolve conflicts constructively and communicate effectively, we can help curb the escalation of anger and violence.It's imperative that our schools become places not only of intellectual growth but also of emotional well-being and character development.The rising wave of heinous acts committed by young people underscores the pressing need for a comprehensive societal response. We must address the erosion of morality and ethics, and we must prioritize emotional education within our education system. This is a challenge that requires the collective effort of families, communities, educators and cultural influencers. By refocusing on our shared values, investing in the emotional well-being of our youth and fostering a renewed sense of empathy, we can shape a society that rejects violence and paves the way for a brighter and more harmonious future.COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on youth violence, criminal acts, and the need for societal response, which aligns most closely with Public Safety, while also mentioning schools and emotional education as secondary aspects.

title: School Bus Crash Sends 11 to Hospital
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
School bus crash sends 11 to hospital

 November 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1A | Section: News 
 
 425
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Eleven patients were transported to the hospital following a crash between a SUV and a Caroline County school bus near the intersection of Matthewstown Road and Three Bridge Branch Road just before 8 a.m.Monday morning.According to a preliminary investigation by Maryland State Police, a Kia Sportage failed to stop at a stop sign at a four-way intersection and crashed into the side of the bus.The school bus rolled over.According to a statement from Caroline County Public Schools, the bus was transporting high school students involved in the Navy Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps program to Easton High School. Nine students and the bus driver were transported to area hospitals. All parents of children on the bus were notified.The juvenile driver of the Kia Sportage, whose identity is being withheld by police at this time, was transported to an area hospital for treatment of injuries.In an email sent to parents Monday morning, Talbot County Public Schools Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi said the driver was an Easton High School student.Police said the cause of the crash is under investigation. Charges may be filed pending the outcome of the investigation.Fog blanketed the area around the time of the crash. Neither Talbot County Public Schools nor Caroline County Public Schools issued a fog delay earlier in the morning.Troopers from the Maryland State Police Easton Barrack, Commercial Vehicle Enforcement Division and crash team responded to the scene to assist.All lanes on Matthewstown Road at Three Bridge Branch Road were closed for several hours during the investigation.Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and Caroline County Sheriff's Office also responded to the scene to assist.

title: Students Evacuated for Bomb Threat at Easton Middle School
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Students evacuated for bomb threat at Easton Middle School

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 280
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Students and staff at Easton Middle School were evacuated Wednesday morning after the school administration received a bomb threat.According to a news release from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office, front desk staff at the middle school received a bomb threat via telephone around 9:25 a.m.Wednesday.The caller said there were numerous explosive devices throughout the building that would detonate at a specified time, police said.Police said all identified calls were made from a New Jersey area code.School officials followed emergency policies and safely evacuated students and staff to St. Marks Methodist Church in Easton.Deputies from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office responded to the school and began investigating. Bomb detecting K-9 teams also responded to the building to complete a scan.Similar threats were made to schools across the state, including schools in Frederick, Carroll, Charles and Wicomico counties, police said.Students and staff were allowed to return to the building when the K-9 scan was completed.Police said there are no identified subjects and investigation is ongoing.Anyone with information is asked to contact the Talbot County Sheriff's Office at 410-822-1020, by email at sheriff@talbotcountymd.gov, on Facebook at Talbot County Sheriff or online at talbotsheriff.org.

title: After-School Activities Canceled, Some Wednesday Delays in Place Due to Strong Storm
author: Natalie Jones
content:
After-school activities canceled, some Wednesday delays in place due to strong storm

 January 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 574
 Words 

 Read News Document

 UPDATE 1:30 p.m. Tuesday: Impending heavy rains, gusty winds and flooding from the powerful storm system moving across the region have prompted local school districts to cancel after-school activities Tuesday, with delays and closures possible Wednesday.Dorchester County Public Schools are operating on a half-day dismissal schedule Tuesday, with all after-school activities canceled. All of the county's schools will be operating on a two-hour delay schedule Wednesday, Jan. 10, for evaluation of overnight flooding and storm damage, according to the school system.
Queen Anne's County Public Schools were also dismissed early Tuesday due to the storm. As of Tuesday afternoon, all of the county's schools are set to run on a 90-minute delayed opening Wednesday, with reevaluation and modifications possible in the morning.
Schools in Talbot and Caroline counties canceled all after-school activities Tuesday. Both districts are monitoring conditions to determine if delays or closures will be necessary Wednesday.
The Caroline County Board of Education meeting will be held as scheduled at 6 p.m. Tuesday.
Gov. Wes Moore enacted a State of Preparedness declaration Tuesday morning, directing the state's department of emergency management to coordinate responses to the storm's impacts.
Rainfall of 1 to 3 inches is possible across the region Tuesday, with the heaviest rain expected Tuesday night before tapering off Wednesday morning, according to the National Weather Service.
The main concern is the potential for coastal flooding in Talbot and Queen Anne's counties, said Mike Lee, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service's Philadelphia/Mount Holly office. Dorchester County is also expected to experience significant flooding.
A coastal flood warning is in effect from 7 p.m. Tuesday to 7 p.m. Wednesday for areas along the lower Chesapeake Bay, including Cambridge, which will see major impact from flooding early Wednesday morning, according to the Weather Service. Water is expected be two to three feet above ground level in some low-lying areas.
A coastal flood warning and a flood watch are in effect for Talbot, Caroline, Queen Anne's and Kent counties from Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday morning.
Moderate coastal flooding is possible Tuesday with the high tide cycle. Water levels are expected to continue rising Tuesday night from strong southerly winds. The rising water levels could lead to potentially significant flooding.
The highest tides will be early Wednesday morning and again in the afternoon.
Widespread roadway flooding is expected across the region's bayside communities and along tidal waterways. Dorchester County could see road closures.
Strong, gusty winds are also expected to build across the region throughout the day Tuesday.
Dorchester County is under a high wind warning from 4 p.m. Tuesday to 4 a.m. Wednesday, with south to southeast winds of 30 to 40 mph with gusts up to 60 mph possible. Fallen trees, downed power lines and widespread power outages are expected.
Talbot, Caroline, Kent and Queen Anne's counties are under a wind advisory from 5 p.m. Tuesday to 3 a.m. Wednesday. Sustained winds of 25 to 35 mph are expected, with gusts up to 55 mph.
The already-saturated ground in the region has also made trees more vulnerable to becoming uprooted with strong winds.
The Talbot County Department of Emergency Services urged residents to make sure loose items are secured ahead of time and reminded residents to not drive through or stand in flooded roadways.
The region will dry out some on Thursday, but a second storm is likely to roll through the region again Friday night into Saturday, the Weather Service said.
This story has been updated to include information on school delays and closures. This story may be updated. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Moore Calls for Accountability, Rehabilitation
author: Kiersten Hacker Capital News Service
content:
Moore calls for accountability, rehabilitation

 January 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KIERSTEN HACKER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 487
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Gov. Wes Moore said he expects "robust debates" about juvenile justice in coming weeks — and that his administration will be an "active participant" trying to balance rehabilitation with cracking down on crime."The hallmark of what I hope to see in any juvenile justice legislation that's going to make it to my desk can be summarized in one word: accountability," the governor said. "I believe in rehabilitation, but I will not tolerate lawlessness."
Moore's comments came Tuesday, a day before the opening of the 2024 Maryland General Assembly, in a press conference devoted to his legislative priorities regarding public safety. He said he plans to press for three measures aimed at promoting victim's compensation, expanding apprenticeships in law enforcement jobs and preventing firearm violence.
But he also mused aloud on the issue of juvenile justice, at a time when state Republican officials are calling for passage of tougher crime policies — and specifically for reversing recent reforms to the youth legal system. House Republican Leader Jason Buckel, R-Allegany, recently vowed to toughen up what he called Maryland's "soft-on-crime policies."
Moore said Tuesday he will demand accountability for young offenders who are repeatedly violating the law, or who use a handgun to threaten the safety of others.
While Moore acknowledged the coming debate over juvenile crime this session, he stressed the importance of supporting communities and the advocates working at the grassroots level to prevent violence.
He said he supports lengthening probation for juveniles found guilty of certain crimes to allow for more time for rehabilitation programs. He also backs moving more crimes related to illegal guns from misdemeanors to felonies.
"It takes a village to raise a child, and it will take a village to build safer communities," Moore said.
The legislative criminal justice proposals Moore announced do not address the treatment of juveniles, but rather focus on other things.
He proposed establishing a firearm prevention center based on recommendations from the Safer States Initiative launched by Vice President Kamala Harris.
The statewide office would work in partnership with the White House, taking an "all of government" approach to effective prevention and intervention policies or programs, according to Rob Wilcox, deputy director of Biden's Office of Gun Violence Prevention. Maryland would be the first state to establish such a center, said Wilcox, who spoke at Moore's press conference.
"It's a critical step to focus investments and drive the strategies that we know will save lives," Wilcox said.
According to Moore, 75% of homicides in Maryland are committed with a gun. He said he considers it not only a public safety issue but a public health issue. He pledged to get illegal guns "off of our streets."
To help wage that fight, Moore hopes to recruit more people into law enforcement and public safety with a bill to promote apprenticeships.
"We need officers who reflect the diversity of our great state," Secretary of Labor Portia Wu said, "and we need them to come from the neighborhoods they serve." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Snow Fall Brings Snow Day on the Eastern Shore
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Snow fall brings snow day on the Eastern Shore

 January 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 347
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Residents woke up to two inches of snow Tuesday morning in Easton.With the snow came a snow day for Talbot County Public Schools students. Weather conditions caused the school system to close for the entire day.
Dorchester County Public Schools also closed for the day due to icy road conditions. Caroline County Public Schools closed for students, but offices opened at 10 a.m. for its 12-month employees.
Easton's Superintendent of Public Works Mike Dickerson said Easton Public Works used 46.92 tons of salt to keep the town's roadways safe. He said the department applied salt to the town's main roads — roads like Washington Street that get you into town — three times.
After receiving a notification from the Talbot County Department of Emergency Services, Easton Public Works began salting roads at 4 p.m. Monday. Dickerson said the last of the department's five trucks finished salting for the third time at 4:44 a.m. on Tuesday.
"We had five trucks out," he said. "And each one of them has an assigned route."
According to the National Weather Service, winter weather advisories for Queen Anne's, Talbot and Caroline counties were issued early Tuesday morning and in effect until 1 p.m. on Tuesday.
The advisories were for mixed precipitation with additional snow of up to an inch and ice accumulation of around one 10th of an inch. The advisories stated that morning commutes could be affected due to slippery road conditions.
Dorchester County received a winter weather advisory from the National Weather Service for freezing rain and additional ice accumulation. The advisory was in effect until 11 a.m. Tuesday morning.
As of noon on Tuesday, according to the National Weather Service, snow and freezing rain were likely in Easton before 1 p.m. with a chance of rain and snow between 1 p.m. and 2 p.m. and a chance of more snow after 2 p.m. Little or no snow accumulation is expected. A tenth of an inch of ice accumulation is possible.
Dickerson said Easton Public Works has its trucks prepared in the event that employees have to go back out to take care of the roads. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
