title: 'In Pursuit of Freedom' Lecture at Kennard on Feb. 25
author: Staff Writer
content:
'In Pursuit of Freedom' lecture at Kennard on Feb. 25

 February 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Life 
 
 199
 Words 

 Read News Document

 St. Paul's Episcopal Church will present a Black History Month lecture at the Kennard African American Heritage Center in Centreville at 4 p.m. on Sunday, Feb. 25. The lecture, entitled "In Pursuit of Freedom" will be given by noted local historian Chris Pupke, a member of Kennard's Advisory Board and St. Paul's Church.The program will focus on the many ways that enslaved people in Queen Anne's County sought and fought for their freedom, including then use of the Underground Railroad, the taking up of arms, and litigation in the courts. There will be a question and answer period after the lecture.
Earlier, on the same day, noted baritone Thomas Beard will be singing two songs associated with the observance of Black History Month at the 10 a.m. service at St. Paul's. Included will be "Come Sunday" by Duke Ellington along with a classical selection.
Beard has performed at the White House and in the Washington National Opera's Young Artist Program, where he was the only African American personally chosen by maestro Placido Domingo to take part in the program. He also sung with many opera companies across the U.S.
St. Paul's Church is located at 301 S. Liberty Street in Centreville. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Unknown History: Black History Month Offers Opportunity to Recognize ‘The People’
author: Niambi Davis Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Unknown history: Black History Month offers opportunity to recognize ‘the people’

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 211
 Words 

 Read News Document

 This month, in community centers, libraries, schools and churches like Bethel AME Church in Centreville, when citizens gather to honor the nation's greatest champions for freedom, justice and equal rights, they also honor the people.In 1915, the historian Dr. Carter G. Woodson founded what is now the Association for the Study of African American Life and History. The following year, he began publishing what is now The Journal of African American History, a publication of history, research and book reviews.
In 1926, Woodson founded "Negro History Week" to honor the history, culture and contributions of African Americans. He chose February to coincide with the birthdays of Frederick Douglass and Abraham Lincoln. In 1976, President Gerald Ford extended the observation to a month, now known as Black History Month.
Woodson believed that history was "made by the people, not simply or primarily by great men."
Local writer, Niambi Davis had the opportunity to contribute to the Black History display at Bethel AME. The subjects, Davis said, "are important and more than just the usual Douglass and Tubman stories; they're the unknown local, national and international folks."
The display is open to the congregation and anyone wishing to attend services. Service begins at 11 a.m. Sunday mornings. The church is located on Washington Road in Centreville. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Lawmakers Propose Task Force to Probe Long-Term Inequities Facing Black Women
author: Torrence Banks Capital News Service
content:
Lawmakers propose task force to probe long-term inequities facing Black women

 February 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TORRENCE BANKS Capital News Service | Section: National 
 
 817
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The persistence of economic, educational and legal disparities in the lives of Black women and girls would be the target of a federal task force recently proposed by a group of House members."Simply acknowledging our country's history of targeted discrimination, harassment and violence against Black women and girls will not correct years of systemic racism and sexism," Rep. Robin Kelly (D-Illinois) said in a statement after the legislation creating the task force was introduced earlier this month.
"We must leverage the full weight of the federal government to seek justice for Black women and girls who deserve an equal opportunity for a full, happy, healthy life," Kelly said.
Kelly is co-chair of the Caucus on Black Women and Girls, along with Reps. Yvette Clarke of New York and Bonnie Watson Coleman of New Jersey, who also sponsored the measure. Reps. Jennifer McClellan (D-Virginia), Valerie Foushee (D-North Carolina) and Brian Fitzpatrick (R-Pennsylvania) also have signed on to the bill, called the "Protect Black Women and Girls Act."
The bill would establish a task force to examine several aspects of the lives of Black women and girls, including education, healthcare, economic development, housing and civil rights. The task force would look at the effectiveness of programs and policies at the state, federal and local levels and make recommendations for changes.
Kelly said that the bill would help governments be more proactive in ensuring that Black women receive equal opportunities.
The task force would be led by the Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Justice. Both would then share information with the United States Commission on Civil Rights (USCCR).
The civil rights commission also would conduct a study and collect data about the social justice, economic and health effects of discrimination and inequities on Black women and girls. The bill was originally introduced in 2021 with 15 co-sponsors. However, Congress took no action on it.
Maryland Del. Jheanelle Wilkins, a Democrat, said the legislation would allow the state's government to look at the results from the research and craft more equitable policies.
"We know that signs point to black women being disproportionately impacted by many things whether it's maternal health — and in Maryland, Black women are four times as likely to die as a result of childbirth," said Wilkins, who also serves as the chair of the state's Legislative Black Caucus.
In 2021, the maternal mortality rate of non-Hispanic Black women was 69.9 births per 100,000 live births, according to the Centers for Disease Control. That was more than two times the rate for non-Hispanic white women.
"We are the caregivers for our community, we're the matriarchs of our home, but also of the Black community," said Kelli Richardson Lawson, founder of the mental health nonprofit organization The SonRise Project, based in Bethesda, Maryland. "So we've always had to take care of everybody else before we take care of ourselves."
Lawson said that the passage of the legislation is crucial because of the socioeconomic challenges that Black women have faced.
Thirty-nine percent of white women earn a bachelor's or associate degree by the age of 29, compared to 21% of Black women, according to the American Association of University Women.
"Based on what I've seen, this bill would help mitigate some of the issues that we see involving Black women and girls in a variety of areas," said Lawson, whose non-profit serves as a safe space for Black parents to discuss issues involving teen mental health.
Black girls also face disadvantages in education. A 2020-2021 school discipline report from the U.S. Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights found that "Black girls were nearly two times more likely to receive one or more in-school suspensions, one or more out-of-school suspensions, and expulsions than White girls."
In addition, Black school-aged girls are four times more likely to be arrested in school than white girls, according to research discussed on Kelly's web page.
John Berkley, coordinator for the National Pan-Hellenic Council in Maryland, Virginia and several other states, said that Maryland has many organizations working to help Black women. Knowing that Congress is backing them up with legislation would be a huge boost, he said.
"Now they could say that It's not only a community effort but also a national policy that we now have some teeth behind," Berkley said. "And maybe with that, that will bring more awareness to what's going on with Black females in our various raised communities."
Berkley said that he plans to travel with his fraternity to Annapolis in a couple of weeks to talk to his legislators to see what they're doing to help Congress move the bill along.
Lawson said the task force could lead to the creation of more programs and organizations like hers, where Black women are free to focus on themselves and have vulnerable conversations.
"Changing the narrative, so that we can take off that cape, we can take a deep breath and exhale, and we can start to focus on ourselves," Lawson said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Local Documentary is 'Going Places'
author: Will Bontrager
content:
Local documentary is 'going places'

 March 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1002
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The trip started out by collecting soil on Cross Street in Chestertown. The location where James Taylor, a 23-year-old Black man, was lynched in 1892.That soil would find its way more than 800 miles south in a powerful message to remember a bleak chapter in history.
That journey was followed in the documentary film "Get on the Bus."
Forty-two Kent County youths and adults made the trek, traveling to Civil Rights era landmarks in Alabama and Georgia, including the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church in Birmingham; the King Center in Atlanta, Edmund Pettus Bridge and the National Voting Rights Museum in Selma and the Equal Justice Initiative's Community Remembrance Project in Montgomery.
Directed by Justinian Dispenza of Andover Media, the film debuted on Valentine's Day at the Decker Theatre in Washington College with almost 200 people in attendance. it was also shown the at Ocean City Film Festival earlier this month.
After its debut, the powerful emotions it invoked resulted in people interested in screening it.
For Dispenza, it's uplifting to see his work yielding these results.
"That's what we're all aiming to do as filmmakers. To make a change in people's lives. It was an incredible experience," he said.
As people left the theatre, Dispenza reflected on the process of creating "Get on the Bus" in slight awe.
Because it did not start out as being a film.
The idea initially came from Program Director of Minary's Dream Alliance Paul Tue III and Co-Chair of the James Taylor Justice Coalition Philip Dutton, to take a trip, educating people about the past, to the roots of the Civil Rights Movement, Alabama.
What started as a field trip where Dispenza was brought on to take pictures became something else.
Dispenza, no stranger to films about social issues, was eager.
Except there were obstacles.
Before they left, he was diagnosed with Lyme's Disease. Forced to take antibiotics on the road, he was told by his doctor to avoid the sun.
"That's kinda tough to do, July in the Deep South," Dispenza said, laughing.
It was five days in that sweltering heat with cameras rolling 24-7, no cloud in sight.
While he and Lead Editor Tanner Presswood filmed, Dispenza used long sleeves like protective gear and a floppy hat to ward off the sun.
Perhaps if he didn't feel a strong sense of purpose, he would have thought of his discomfort more than three times in the trip. But seeing through the lens of time how racism was a way of life for many, which seemed like a different universe to him, busied him in a beneficial way.
They went to sites like the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, where on Sunday, September 15, 1963, at 10:22 a.m., the church became known around the world when a bomb exploded, killing four young girls attending Sunday School.
Eastern Shore girls the age of those victims read that and marveled.
"How can someone hate someone so much that they could hurt them and have no consideration in their heart?" Love Jackson asked.
As they ascended the steps to the upper part of the church they witnessed a reenactment of Reverend Martin Luther King Jr.
Overcome by the strong feelings standing where King stood, Pastor of the Presbyterian Church in Chestertown Joel Tolbert opened up.
"I sit in the pulpit every Sunday. But I tried to stand in that pulpit...it's a hard space," he acknowledged.
The emotions would heighten.
Just down the road there were statues of attack dogs, replicas of what Black people faced in 1963. There was a statue of children against the wall in a firing line and statues of enslaved people in chains, heads down in despair.
Broadcasted at the The National Memorial for Peace and Justice were some of the reasons they were lynched, horrific in their simplicity and ignorance.
One was lynched for not tipping his hat to the police officer.
Another to yield a better return in the sharecropping business.
There was one, where, since a man could not be found, his 2-year-old daughter was lynched in his place.
The group journeyed to Selma. At the Edmund Pettus Bridge, they crossed as others did in 1965, knowing that beatings, dogs and water hoses waited for them on the other side.
Founder of Minary's Dream Alliance, Doncella Wilson, felt that weight. Crossing the same bridge that 600 Civil Rights marchers crossed, she had to stop in the middle and reflect, before walking on., head high.
The camera captured the moment.
Inside the Equal Justice Initiative Museum while delivering the soil as an addition to the Legacy Museum, Dispenza broke down himself.
He sat on the floor and cried, having taken some ownership of the atrocities committed. But through that pain and despair, the tears and sorrow, shone hope.
"People were not afraid to be vulnerable," Dispenza said. "It led to healing."
They were receptive to the filming process too, seeing it as a tool to do good. "It was a tough film but a beautiful film," Dispenza said.
And the results of the film did not leave people in despair.
One resident leaving Decker Theatre told him the film "had given him a peace and hope he's never had before."
Throughout the film there were positive messages to the youth. Wilson told a group of children the activists they have read about and heard were no older than they were. Tue told the youths they don't know how powerful they are.
Dispenza's film echoed with its audience as well. After the debut, it has been featured at the Bill Johnson Film Festival in Indiana.
Tue, who was with them through the entire trip, was amazed at how the footage was compiled altogether.
He told Dispenza, "My God, this is going places!"
With eight or nine screenings already having taken place, he was certainly not wrong.
Dispenza sees this as an urgent message to spread. "This conversation needs to be had as school districts try to suppress Critical Race Theory," he said.
It is a topic debated among educational groups. Dispenza is more than happy to pursue these challenges and encouraged those who have great story ideas to reach out to him at Andover Media.
For more of his projects, visit his Imdb page at imdb.com/name/nm14340956/ as well. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Calvert County Middle Schoolers in Calvert County Face Hate Crime Charges
author: Marty Madden mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Calvert County middle schoolers in Calvert County face hate crime charges

 April 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 344
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to the Calvert County State's Attorney's Office, three 13-year-old students at Plum Point Middle School in Huntingtown have been charged as juveniles with harassment and violations of Maryland's hate crimes statutes. The state's attorney's office released the information Friday afternoon.According to charging documents filed by the Maryland State Police, the students displayed swastikas, made Nazi salutes and directed offensive comments to a classmate because of the classmate's religious beliefs.
The state's attorney's office press release stated the behavior began last December and "continued over several months despite repeated requests to stop."
The matter was reported to the state police, who investigated and filed the charges against the juveniles. The press release does not report the names or genders of the charged students.
The charges will be forwarded to the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services for appropriate action. That entity has the discretion to refer the charges to the Calvert County Circuit Court for a hearing. The state's attorney's office then would be required to prove the allegations beyond a reasonable doubt.
"Calvert County Public Schools is committed to providing students and staff with an environment that is safe, welcoming and free from all forms of discrimination," Susan Johnson, chief academic officer and spokesperson for the school system, said in a statement released Monday. "The civil rights of all individuals will be protected. All complaints are investigated promptly. Upon completion of an investigation, students and school personnel may be subject to disciplinary action or consequences for discriminatory behaviors."
Calvert County State's Attorney Robert Harvey (R) issued a statement last Friday.
"Maryland was founded on the principle of religious toleration," Harvey said in the statement. "It is frankly astonishing that nearly 400 years later some people continue to persecute others based upon their religion. I call upon parents, educators and community and faith leaders to make sure that our children know that religious persecution has no place in our society."
On Tuesday, Commissioner President Earl F. "Buddy" Hance (R) stated, "We will not tolerate hate speech. That's not who we are. I hope they [juveniles] get the counseling that they need." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland Stories: Equity Coalition Launches New Regional Website
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland stories: Equity coalition launches new regional website

 May 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 609
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Southern Maryland has long had a diverse history, and those who are looking to learn more about its rich and extensive background will now be able to do so in one place.The Southern Maryland Equity in History Coalition promoted its new website featuring 31 organizations, oral histories, landmarks and much more that interpret the experiences of Black, Indigenous, and other people of color during a launch event on May 1 at St. Mary's College of Maryland.
"This is a good idea because a lot of people, especially me, didn't have a lot of knowledge about our history," Wayne Blackwell of Callaway said. "That's the way it was with my family. We had a lot of older generations that had a lot of knowledge of what happened and it was never told to the kids, so the kids never knew what was going on."
The event also included exhibits featuring historical and cultural institutions, authors, quilts and poetry.
"They're amazing. They're just so detailed," St. Mary's College North Campus Area Coordinator Meghan Pushee said as she gazed at story quilts. "I love the collage aspect and the multi-media aspect. I'm in awe of them."
Later, speakers took to the stage at the Nancy R. & Norton T. Dodge Performing Arts Center on campus.
"Now, more than ever we must expand this history in your voice, from your memory, from your attics, from your archives," Southern Maryland Equity in History Coalition Hugh Davies said. "Let us commit to doing so to bring this history forward."
The event was dedicated to longtime Calvert County NAACP officer Malcolm Funn, who died in 2022.
"It has been said that before we can travel forward or even truly understand why we're here today, one must understand the past," Piscataway Conoy Tribe Tribal Chairman Francis Gray said. "History is our willingness to connect the past to the present. It provides us with a sense of purpose, of who we are, a sense of being … and it's here that we all have the opportunity to obtain that knowledge. The Piscataway Conoy people are excited to have this opportunity to unearth the narrative of Maryland's history."
St. Mary's College Community Affairs Liaison Kelsey R. Bush read the land acknowledgement and pledge, while Southern Maryland Equity in History Coalition Steering Committee member Janice Walthour read her poem, "Ancestors."
"My mother used to tell my sister and me, 'Actions speak louder than words.' She would also say, 'Beauty is as beauty does,' and today is beautiful," said author, performer, GU272+ descendent and keynote speaker Mélisande Short-Colomb. "More information and more stories about Native American history and African American history will be unveiled. The ancestry and history of all … will be accessible to all. Our ancestors would be proud."
"Since all stories start at the beginning, we have started by working directly with the Piscataway people to see if this was a story they would trust to be told," Southern Maryland National Heritage Area Executive Director Lucille Walker said. "That's why this particular initiative is so critical. Because why are we telling any stories if we're not telling the whole story? If we're not doing it for the next generation then what are we doing?"
The coalition, which is administered by "Big Conversation: Partners in Dismantling Racism and Privilege in Southern Maryland," which was started at Middleham and St. Peter's Episcopal Parish in Lusby, and is supported by public school systems, libraries, museums, colleges and churches.
St. Mary's College President Tuajuanda Jordan said the coalition "is a testament to the realization that we have work to do to create and sustain an inclusive community free of racism and prejudice."
For more information or to see the new website, go to www.equityinhistory.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Ceremony Honors 18 Black Union Soldiers Buried in Unionville Cemetery
author: Tom McCall
content:
Ceremony honors 18 Black Union soldiers buried in Unionville cemetery

 May 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 618
 Words 

 Read News Document

 UNIONVILLE — It was a soulful reckoning with history.Soldiers clad in Union Army uniforms filled their barrels with gunpowder and fired three rounds to mark each of the names.
The loud volleys brought the assembled crowd to a quiet reverence.
John Blackwell …
Ennels Clayton …
Isaac Copper …
John Copper …
Eighteen names. Eighteen volleys of musket fire.
The men fought for the Union. They fought for freedom. Their freedom.
The 18 were Black Union soldiers who fought in the Civil War. They are buried in the cemetery behind St. Stephens AME Church in Unionville, the town named to honor their fight for freedom.
"Hearing the names is the best part," Pamela Roberts Price said. She has relatives in the graveyard.
Around 70 people gathered at St. Stephens on a recent Sunday. There was a contingent of Union-garbed men with rifles, flags and shiny brass buckles.
The sounds of "Amazing Grace" drifted over gravestones that are worn by thousands of rainy days. A solo violin played "Taps."
St. Stephens Pastor Eddie Scott opened the ceremony with a prayer. "Comfort us in knowing that these soldiers that we stand on their shoulders, that we can have life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness."
Harriette Lowery has more than 10 relatives in the cemetery.
"I am related to one of the soldiers, definitely," she said. "Benjamin Demby is my great-great-grandfather. My grandfather's mother was Agnes Demby Green. That was Benjamin's mother."
Like Price, Lowery loves hearing the names.
"Every time I hear the names it gives me such pride," she said. "Thinking about the chaos that is happening in our community or somewhere else, thinking about what they did, what they went through really touches me."
She noted that there were no promises to these soldiers.
"They did it hoping they would be free," Lowery said. "They hoped they would get emancipation."
She noted some of the local Black soldiers traveled as far as Texas, and some of them had to walk from Texas to get home.
"I want the history to be told over and over again because not only do our young people, all races of young people, need to know what they went through," Lowery said. "They sacrificed for us to do better. So don't give up on education and things like that. They need to know what people sacrificed."
Dan Cowgill of Middletown was master of ceremonies for the event. His ancestors were Quakers who donated the land for Unionville where freed slaves settled after the Civil War.
"We are honoring the 18 soldiers from the U.S. colored troops during the Civil War that created the town of Unionville," he said. "It is amazing I still get choked up when I read these words."
The African American history within 10 miles of St. Stephens Church is remarkable. Not all of it is known or even written about. Sandy Johnson is working to change that.
"I am a budding historic preservationist," she said. "It is good to honor those that came before us. It gives us a direction to know where we are going in life. Without the past you really can't move forward."
There were white participants in the crowd whose roots go way back too. Some of their relatives had owned big estates. Some have tilled this land for generations. A few got together to swap stories and show old black and white photographs. You could hear them saying old names too.
The Green Meadows Bluegrass Band finished playing "Amazing Grace," the sounds of the music falling softly on the worn gravestones marked with the names of the Union soldiers — John Blackwell, Ennels Clayton, Isaac Copper, John Copper, Benjamin Demby, Charles Demby, William Doane, William Doran, Horace Gibson, Zachary Glasgow, Joseph Gooby, Joseph H. Johnson, Peter Johnson, Edward Jones, Enolds Money, Frederick Pipes, Henry Roberts and Mathew Roberts. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Nause-Waiwash Aim to Preserve, Uncover History of Native Americans from Dorchester County
author: Konner Metz
content:
Nause-Waiwash aim to preserve, uncover history of Native Americans from Dorchester County

 August 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 567
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Since 1989, the Nause-Waiwash Band of Indians have preserved, honored and passed down the stories of their ancestors, many of whom were Nanticoke people living along the Choptank River.Chief Donna Wolf Mother Abbott is the band's leader. The group preserves the tradition of the indigenous people who fled in the 1700s to the marshes after being converged on by foreign settlers.
Abbott's passion for exploring the county's native history began when she enrolled in the Nause-Waiwash around 20 years ago, though she wasn't always dead set on joining.
"There were probably two, three, maybe four generations that were brought up believing that it was disgraceful to claim your heritage, so they didn't teach it to their children," Abbott said. "And my grandmother was one of those."
Abbott's cousins convinced her to enroll around 10 years before she became the band's second chief in 2014, following the death of former Chief Sewell Winterhawk Fitzhugh.
"They brought up a very good point, and that was, 'If you don't (join), how are we going to preserve the history?'" Abbott recalled her cousins telling her. "'Because it's fading, it's dying quickly. And what are you going to tell your grandchildren?'"
The Nause-Waiwash is made up of around 300 descendants of not just the Nanticoke, but Choptank and Pocomoke people as well. Nause was a Nanticoke village outside of Vienna and Waiwash a Choptank village outside of Cambridge, Abbott said.
It's a "matrilineal society," one where the women hold the power to elect a chief and make important decisions. At meetings, the nonprofit organization plans upcoming events and collaborations with other tribes in the state, along with discussing heritage and history.
Two churches — Hughes African Methodist Episcopal Chapel near Cambridge and Wesley Chapel south of Cambridge in Andrews — are being renovated so the Nause-Waiwash can provide services and have a resource center. The organization is hosting its 32nd annual Native American Festival on Sept. 14 in Vienna.
Such outreach events are meant to educate people on the history of who occupied Dorchester land, but also how Native Americans treated the land and surrounding waters.
UNCOVERING HISTORYDespite living on the Western Shore, Erin Kennedy, a member of the Nause-Waiwash, often combs through records and land deeds in and around Taylor's Island, the community in which she grew up, hoping to piece together her mother's side of the family.
She took inspiration from her uncle, who created a family tree for her father's side of the family.
Online resources, records from the Maryland State Archives and discussions with fellow indigenous descendants on the Eastern Shore have helped Kennedy and other members of the Nause-Waiwash understand their line of ancestors.
Abbott emphasized that she's learning every day as well. She's uncertain if permanent state recognition is in the Nause-Waiwash's future given that it's not quite as large as other tribes. However, recent recognitions such as a historical roadside marker next to the Choptank River have raised the prominence of the dedicated nonprofit's work.
Nearly 10 years in, Abbott is developing a love and commitment to the work of the Nause-Waiwash.
"I have this passion for it, which I never really knew I had until I became involved," Abbott said. "And I do know that a lot of our history is gone. I want to read all these books and see if I can't find some new information out that I don't know. So I'm reading books that I'd never thought I'd ever read before." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Turner Station Residents Try to Heal Community with Prayer and History
author: Joel Lev-Tov jlev-tov@chespub.com
content:
Turner Station residents try to heal community with prayer and history

 August 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JOEL LEV-TOV jlev-tov@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 512
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DUNDALK — First, someone broke a window in Servant Courtney Speed's house in Turner Station, the storied, historically Black neighborhood in Dundalk. The next day, another window was broken. The day after that, someone broke her back door and her back windows. They stole her son's football trophy.It wasn't just Speed. Two other houses on her street had windows and doors broken. That's unusual for the neighborhood established in the late 1800s, Speed says. Until recently, residents all lived in peace, without fear of crime.
So Speed, the unofficial matriarch of Turner Station, decided to get to work.
"I did not feel that spirit from God to get the police," she said in an interview on July 24. "So now we are trying to work with the children of new families that have moved to historic Turner station."
On Saturday, she held an event to educate new residents about the neighborhood's history. It started with a service inside the dimly lit Union Baptist Church.
JaBrea Rodgers presided over much of the service and told about a dozen attendees about her great-grandmother, Henrietta Lacks, whose "immortal cells" helped a Johns Hopkins Hospital researcher study cancer cures.
Lacks moved to Turner Station in 1941 so her husband could work at the nearby Bethlehem Steel plant. She was hospitalized with cervical cancer, and a surgeon removed her cells and sent them to Dr. George Gey, the researcher. He shipped the cells to Philadelphia, Speed said. When the cells returned, they were still living — in fact, they had multiplied.
Her cells still live.
After the service finished, Speed led the small crowd to the headquarters of her movement, Save the Nation of Turner Station, at 411 Main St., where tables, chairs and a vendor selling watermelon pieces and chips awaited them.
Bill Barry, a retired labor studies professor at the Community College of Baltimore County, Dundalk, held a lecture about Turner Station and Bethlehem Steel, which employed many residents during its heyday.
Then Andrew Morton, who worked at Bethlehem Steel in the blast furnace smelting metals, reminisced to the the dozen-strong crowd about his time — the good, the bad and the ugly.
"OSHA didn't come into the plant until 1974," he said. "Every other week, somebody was getting killed or maimed. Three or four of my buddies that went down there with me are not here today. They got killed on the blast furnace."
Along with educating new residents, Speed worked to raise money for the revitalization of the somewhat blighted Turner Station. She's asking 1 billion people to donate $1 to the cause.
In previous years, Barry said, the event had a much larger turnout and included horses, games and kids. Speed said the organizers didn't have time to distribute flyers to the new neighbors, the rainy forecast gave many pause and the horses were unable to come because of the collapsed Key Bridge.
Still, Speed called the event a success.
"Put us down, Lord willing, for next year. If we are gone, the next generation that was here, we have asked them to come on," she said. "So we're going to replicate, repair and repurpose." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Rabbi Hyman Delivers Multicultural Understanding
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Rabbi Hyman delivers multicultural understanding

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: News 
 
 705
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Easton has been and is blessed with an extraordinarily number of exceptionally talented individuals engaged in a wide range of community service endeavors.One of them is Rabbi Peter Hyman DD (Doctor of Divinity) who is retiring in October after serving 18 years as the first full-time rabbi at Easton's Temple B'nai Israel.
Rabbi Hyman has a long history in walking his talk on promoting greater understanding of and respect for individuals with different religious beliefs and different faith journeys.
There is no more enduring symbol of Rabbi Hyman's commitment to respect for other religious beliefs than a Persian rug he bought in Israel 40 years ago. It is now on display in his office. That rug includes 99 names of God in Arabic. Rabbi Hyman views it as a metaphorical bridge connecting people of different faiths.
He once asked the leaders of a mosque if they could help him translate some of the Arabic words on his rug. They did so, amazed that such an inclusive rug was owned and displayed by a rabbi.
For Rabbi Hyman, it was simply his belief that "building relationships not only creates friendships, but they also cement ties."
A partial list of his local efforts to improve the quality of life in our community and beyond, includes serving as a member, program vice president and president of the Talbot Association of Clergy and Laity. He received an Award of Appreciation for Outstanding and Inspiring Interfaith Work in Talbot County for a Temple B'nai Israel February Lecture Series: "Introduction to Islam."
He was a recipient of the NAACP Dorothy Webb Black Community Service Legacy Award and a recipient of a Governor William Donald Schaefer Helping People Award. He was a member of The Frederick Douglass Celebration Committee and delivered the sermon at the Community Interfaith Worship Celebration, which was a part of the "Douglass Returns" statue dedication.
An author and teacher, he served as a presenter and instructor at Chesapeake College's Institute for Adult Learning and collaborated with Bishop Joel Marcus Johnson to launch a "Downtown Lunch and Learn" program. He was elected to the board of directors at the YMCA of the Chesapeake and appointed chair of the board at the Easton YMCA.
Support for Scouting has been a huge part of Rabbi Hyman's life since he earned his Eagle Scout award, as did his two sons. That is an achievement that has been earned by only 6% of all Scouts since 1912.
He has served as a scoutmaster and a chaplain at Scout World Jamborees in Thailand, England, Sweden and Japan and a National Jamboree in the United States. He was the first national chair for the Messengers of Peace Program, BSA, after having served as a national chair of the Jewish Committee on Scouting and as national Jewish chaplain — Boy Scouts of America. He was the keynote speaker at a national annual meeting of the BSA "Duty to God Breakfast" in Washington, D.C.
He is a recipient of the Silver Buffalo Award for distinguished service to youth awarded by the National Council of Boy Scouts of America. He is also a recipient of the Bronze Wolf Award, which is the Scouts' highest honor. It is presented by the World Scout Committee to recognize the service, commitment and contributions of volunteers to the Scout movement. Not surprisingly Hyman received the award for his interfaith activities and his lifelong commitment to "building bridges between people and nations."
Rabbi Hyman represented the BSA in Saudi Arabia at Saudi Nation Day when they received an award for the work of the BSA with the Messengers of Peace Program. This program promotes service projects through social media in effort to achieve world peace.
Hyman recalls that trip as the most amazing experience of his life because he was welcome in a Muslim country.
While the news of Rabbi Hyman's impending retirement is bittersweet, there is some good news.
He is not planning to leave the Eastern Shore.
Whether he stays here for the short term or long term, one thing is certain. He has made countless selfless contributions to help make Easton, Talbot County, and our world a better place.
Each one of them has earned Rabbi Hyman a well-deserved thank you and Godspeed.
David Reel is a public affairs and public relations consultant based in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Frederick Douglass Day Continues to Share Abolitionist's Legacy
author: Wendy Weitzel wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
Frederick Douglass Day continues to share abolitionist's legacy

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Wendy Weitzel wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 577
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The first time Harriette Lowery heard that Frederick Douglass had grown up in Talbot County was when she moved back to Easton with her husband in the early 2000s.Lowery was surprised to hear of Douglass' local origins. She had grown up in Talbot County, but she had never known it was the famed abolitionist's birthplace.
"The historical society had put a notice in the paper asking for people to respond to a question — 'Is anybody interested in honoring Frederick Douglass in some way since he's our native son.' And I read that and thought, 'I knew a lot about Frederick Douglass, but I did not know he was from Talbot County,'" she said Saturday, surveying the crowd outside the Talbot County Free Library that had assembled for the annual Frederick Douglass Day celebration.
"... I was a little embarrassed by that but more interested in doing something because of that," Lowery said.
Lowery and her late husband became founding members of the Frederick Douglass Honor Society, the group that spearheaded the process of having a statue of Douglass erected on the Talbot County Court House lawn. The statue was unveiled to a crowd of thousands in June, 2011, after years of sometimes tense back-and-forth between the honor society, members of the community and local governments.
Frederick Douglass Day evolved from that unveiling ceremony in an effort to continue the honor society's mission of educating the community about Douglass.
"Since 2011, the Frederick Douglass Honor Society decided that it wanted to continue efforts to continue the legacy of Frederick Douglass," said Walter Black, another founding member of the Frederick Douglass Honor Society. "So the main thing that we concentrated on is the Frederick Douglass Day."
On Saturday, Frederick Douglass Day filled downtown Easton with a parade, a ceremony, a lecture, a children's village and a city block filled with vendors, nonprofits and live entertainment.
"The event gets bigger and better every year," said Debbi Dodson, the Frederick Douglass Day event coordinator. "More people get involved and more people attend, so that is a sign that people appreciate it and really support it."
The keynote speaker for this year's event, Keidrick Roy, said that although this was his first time visiting Talbot County, he has been working with the Frederick Douglass Honor Society for several years.
Keidrick Roy, a fellow at Harvard University, signed copies of his new book, "American Dark Age: Racial Feudalism and the Rise of Black Liberalism," at the event. Roy said Douglass is heavily featured in the work.
"I've always wanted to be in the place where Frederick Douglass walked and talked and had many of his formative experiences, so it's very special for me to be here to do this," he said. "I loved the celebration this morning, seeing so many people from different parts of the city, different parts of the town come out and honor Douglass in a variety of ways."
In holding the event every year, Lowery said the honor society hopes to ensure that all members of the community are aware of Douglass's ties to Talbot County and of how the principles of equality and freedom that Douglass espoused are still relevant today.
"What we wanted was for everybody to look at Douglass as an American hero and not an African American hero," Lowery said.
On Saturday, Lowery remarked that Talbot County had made progress toward that goal since 2011.
"We're always growing and getting better, or we should be anyway," she said. "Every year, I know that there's progress." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Understanding Latinidad: Educator speaks to Chesapeake College students
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Understanding Latinidad: Educator speaks to Chesapeake College students

 October 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 639
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Dozens of students, faculty and community members gathered at the Wye Mills Humanities Cadby Theatre and enjoyed jamaica (hibiscus) agua fresca, fresh fruit, piles of spicy chips and an encouraging message of embracing their native cultures.In celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month, Chesapeake College's Hispanic/Latino Student Union hosted advocate, educator and teacher Samantha Martinez to speak on what her Latinidad means to her.
Lindsay Velasquez, president of the Hispanic/Latino Student Union, said she was excited to bring Martinez as a speaker and loved the encouragement she shared with students in attendance to feel empowered by their cultural identity.
"I just feel like all of us feel like we can do it, and that little doubt that we had of not being able to do something, like, we can do it," Velasquez said. "And she's an example of anything that is possible if you put your mind to it."
Latinidad is a particular experience that contains the complexities of immigration, race, color, class and language. Martinez said her story stems from an immigration story.
"I'm really proud of that because of (my parents') struggle, and their survival and their grit, I'm able to stand here in front of you today," she said.
Her mother migrated from Mexico and her father from El Salvador. She grew up in Chicago, which she describes as "a city that really appreciated and celebrated what it means to be Latina," though the city was heavily segregated.
After meeting her husband and getting married, she moved to New York and became a teacher in the South Bronx, known as the poorest school district in the country. There, Martinez learned of excellence.
She said she was expected to perform at a level of excellence that she had never been asked to before, and in turn she learned to expect it from the people and students around her.
She said the South Bronx "will forever be a part of my story and my legacy."
After spending her time in the South Bronx, Martinez moved to Talbot County. It was a culture shock, but to her surprise, she found a growing Latino population. Her new home also forced her to affirm and challenge her own identity as a Latina.
Martinez worked for Talbot County Public Schools and then founded Mid-Shore Scholars, a college prep program that serves first-generation college students.
When leading the program, she decided it was time to focus on the marginalized student population. The program was meant to target a population of students who had the potential to go to Ivy Leagues, but she pushed for a different perspective. Martinez said it was important to focus on the students who lacked the resources to get to college.
"It's these students who don't have any help at home, who don't have any representation, whose parents want to give them the best life but didn't go to college here, who don't know the ropes or don't know how to navigate the system," Martinez said.
During the pandemic, she decided to focus on building an institution to better assist marginalized communities and helped create the Polaris Village Academy. Martinez said the academy centers joy, celebrating culture and empowering students and families, making them feel safe and seen.
Martinez ended her presentation with photos of her family visiting their native countries and the importance that focusing on her roots allowed her the opportunity to help those around her to grow.
"My superpower is that I am bicultural, that I have roots in (El Salvador) and in Mexico, and I have roots here, and that I can be both from there and from here, and then it's not 'and/or.' I could bring my whole self," Martinez said. "And I encourage all the students here who are questioning their identity or wondering if they can be authentically themselves when they go to class or when they step into white institutions that yes, you can." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton town hall meeting delves into expectations for LGBTQ+ community in new administration
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Easton town hall meeting delves into expectations for LGBTQ+ community in new administration

 January 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 521
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In the final days before President-elect Donald Trump is sworn into office, Maryland's LGBTQ+ community is preparing for what could lie ahead."With the upcoming change in administration, the United States is poised to experience significant rollbacks in federal protections for LGBTQIA+ people, with transgender people squarely in the crosshairs," Delmarva Pride Center Board Chair Tina Jones said during a town hall event Wednesday evening.
Jones said that although state laws in Maryland provide more protections to LGBTQ+ people compared to many other states, protections in Maryland vary based on where people live, attend school and seek healthcare.
The town hall, which was held at the Waterfowl Building in downtown Easton, brought together a panel of experts to share their expectations for the next four years as well as their thoughts on what the state can do to ensure and expand protections for Maryland's LGBTQ+ community. Along with the Delmarva Pride Center, the event was hosted by DoCo Pride and the Maryland Legislative LGBTQ+ Caucus.
The four-person panel — which included Del. Kris Fair (D-Frederick), Fair's Chief of Staff Camila Reynolds-Dominguez, FreeState Justice Executive Director Phillip Westry and Maryland Office of the Attorney General Civil Rights Division Chief Jonathan Smith — answered questions related to schools and workplace, health care and family law.
Caleb Holland, an attorney and the chair of DoCo Pride, who moderated the town hall, said the goal of the event is "to prepare, not scare."
On the topic of education, Smith said he expects the Trump administration will try to push through executive orders around funding schools that are based on sports issues, bathrooms or the ability to deadname or misgender students. But Smith said there are "very significant responses" states can make.
"There's been a body of law that's developed that says the United States government cannot, through its funding powers, coerce states to take policy decisions that are not for the function of funding," he said.
Westry said organizing and getting active in politics, like school boards, is a good way to get involved.
Although part of Wednesday night's conversation focused on bracing for what could happen in the country, the panelists also talked about what gives them hope.
Fair, who is the chair of the Maryland Legislative LGBTQ+ Caucus, recalled the 2018 midterm elections. He said the country elected more women, more queer people and more people of color than ever before.
"In 2018, we figured out that in order to protect our rights, we need to do everything we can to put as many people who look like us into positions of power," he said. "What I am hopeful for is that 2026 looks just like that."
Reynolds-Dominguez, who was previously a policy advocate and legal impact coordinator at FreeState Justice, said that in the last couple of years, the state has taken an "aggressive stance" on doing everything possible to anticipate rollbacks. She said Maryland is "situated to weather this storm" and that should be used as a catalyst for doing long-term work.
"The core of all of this is shifting people's hearts and minds," she said. "And if we're not doing that work, we're spending our time in the wrong place." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Icy Weather Does Not Keep Caroline County From Honoring Martin Luther King
author: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Icy weather does not keep Caroline County from honoring Martin Luther King

 January 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ahmad Garnett agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 379
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Snowy and icy conditions did not stop a crowd of locals showing up to Lockerman Middle School for the 13th annual Martin Luther King Jr. Day ceremony.Although the march was cancelled due to inclement weather, locals packed the school's cafeteria for a program that honored the civil rights hero's legacy.
"We're just so happy and proud that all the community has come together," event organizer Wanda Molock said. "We get a lot of community involvement, the schools, the churches and individuals. So we're so thrilled that it's going to keep on going because we all have a dream."
Some individuals were not able to attend due to the weather, but the organizers quickly improvised to keep the program going as scheduled.
The Lockerman Middle School chorus and band offered multiple selections, which attendees enjoyed.
Caroline County Commissioner Frank Bartz spoke on behalf of the Caroline County Commissioners, explaining the importance of King's legacy.
"While we honor Dr. King's life, we also acknowledge that the work he began continues in Caroline County," Bartz said. "We are trying to build a community, and inclusivity is more than just a word, it's a commitment ensuring that every person, regardless of background, is treated with dignity and respect."
Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derrick Simmons spoke on behalf of the district, explaining the importance of what King did and how Caroline County brings that mentality into its schools.
"I believe education is one of the most powerful tools in achieving Dr King's dream," Simmons said. "Every day in our schools, we strive to create environments where diversity is celebrated, all voices are heard, and discrimination has no place."
A mother and daughter duo from Metropolitan United Methodist Church offered poetry reciting of "Reverend Martin Luther King" written by Dr. Maya Angelou from mother Nikeisha Ogletree and a dance selection from daughter Laila Ogletree.
Closing out the program, Sammy Scott from New Beginnings United Methodist Church Division of Maryland recited King's "I have a dream" speech.
The most amazing part of the 13th annual Martin Luther King Jr. Day program for Molock was the participation of the local youth.
"Oh, it does my heart well," Molock said. "I'm a former educator, so to see the kids here and not home in bed, but getting out that student involvement is just so special."

title: Cambridge Woman's Club Hosts Presentation About Obtaining Citizenship
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge Woman's Club hosts presentation about obtaining citizenship

 February 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 492
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Seeing herself as a voice for Federalsburg's Haitian community, Gelard Merilus Loulou attended the Cambridge Woman's Club Friday to gather helpful information that she can take back to Federalsburg.Friday afternoon, the club hosted Lindsay Waite, a retired attorney who currently volunteers at the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center in Easton to help those who are applying for United States citizenship prepare.
Merilus Loulou said Federalsburg's Haitian community is "in crisis," with many fearful about what could happen in the county in the coming months when it comes to immigration.
With a new administration in the White House, there has been a push to crack down on illegal immigration, which has caused concern among migrants in the United States.
During her presentation, Waite spoke about the process for naturalization in the U.S. She explained that to gain citizenship, a person must file a Form N-400 application for naturalization, have their biometrics taken, pass a background check, pass the citizenship test and complete an interview with U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services. If the person is approved after these steps, they will need to take the Oath of Allegiance at a naturalization ceremony.
Waite said she believes the process costs about $800 to complete.
At the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, Waite and other volunteers help prepare those with green cards who want to obtain citizenship. She said volunteers help go over the Form N-400 application, review questions that could be on the test and practice reading and writing.
Waite said the citizenship test includes an English portion and also asks questions about democracy, the constitution, history and geography.
Offering some of the more difficult questions to the audience at the event, Waite said the people she works with come in for about 10 weeks to review questions and practice English.
"They learn a lot more than I think my nephew, who went to high school and college, could probably know," she said, causing people in the audience to laugh.
Claudia White-Cooke and Joyce Dowling, who attended Waite's presentation, said after hearing some of the questions on the test, they weren't sure if they'd be able to pass it. White-Cooke said the process to become a citizen seems complicated and the people who apply are really committed.
When one person at the event asked if the new presidential administration has affected the naturalization process at all, Waite — who said she is not an expert on what's happening at the national level — said she did notice a change in priority for legal entry into the U.S. from Venezuela.
"To a limit, a certain number of people from Venezuela were being given entry legally and now that's stopped," she said.
Waite said she believes the naturalization process in the U.S. will continue, however. She said people still want to be American citizens.
"And I and others will do what we can to help," she said.
Those who are interested in volunteering with the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center or want to learn more can call 877-772-9832 or visit chesmrc.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: State, County Leaders Join Frederick Douglass Descendants to Unveil New Plaque
author: Konner Metz
content:
State, county leaders join Frederick Douglass descendants to unveil new plaque

 February 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 482
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Exactly 130 years after Frederick Douglass' death, the Talbot County-born abolitionist and civil rights leader was honored for his lasting impact on freedom, equality and education.Descendants, county leaders and state transportation officials gathered to unveil a historical marker honoring Douglass at the Talbot County Courthouse Thursday morning. They were joined by Lt. Gov. Aruna Miller.
Miller spoke at the unveiling, noting that Douglass' calls for justice still demand answers to date. She pointed out the crucial role he played in advancing education for Black Americans during a time when it was not widely accepted.
"Frederick Douglass dared to see beyond the chains that bound him," Miller said. "He knew that true liberation was not just freedom of the body, but freedom of the mind."
The marker, one of nearly 800 official historical signs created by the Maryland Department of Transportation, will be placed at Tappers Corner Road and Route 303, just northeast of Cordova and near Douglass' birthplace.
Julie Schablitsky, cultural resources chief for the Maryland Department of Transportation, said after working with Douglass family descendants and community members, an addition was made to the text on the historical marker: Anna Murray.
Murray, Douglass' first wife, was "strong" and "loyal," Schablitsky said. Many speakers Thursday maintained that Murray's fight for equality and justice was just as important as Douglass'.
Schhablitsky noted Murray was crucial in Douglass' escape from slavery, sewing the sailor suit he used to disguise himself while fleeing north.
Kenneth Morris Jr., Douglass' great-great-great-grandson, called Murray an "equal partner" to her husband.
"It was Anna who made his escape possible," Morris said. "Her strength, sacrifice and unwavering support ensured that his journey to freedom was not just his alone, but part of a greater fight for justice that continues today. I'm just as proud of her as I am of him."
"Her story reminded me that during difficult and challenging times, we must rely on each other and sometimes risk our own safety for the ones we love," Scablitsky said.
Other local and state officials spoke during the event, including Department of Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld, Talbot County Council President Chuck Callahan and Easton Mayor Megan Cook.
Edward "Boots" Robinson, president of the Frederick Douglass Honor Society, and Tarence Bailey, Douglass' five-time great nephew, provided words as well.
"No place is more important to mark his footsteps than where Frederick Douglass experienced his first taste of freedom while living with his grandparents, enjoying those few spiritful, joyful years," Robinson said.
Bailey said that when he was growing up in Easton, many of his elders didn't openly discuss the history of slavery in the area. Descendants of Harriet Tubman weren't allowed to talk about Tubman outside their houses, Bailey said.
The roadside marker will give the younger generations a chance to learn about that history and the local legacy of Douglass, Bailey said.
"We didn't have this," Bailey said. "So to be able to give it to the next generation is really special." 

 © Copyright 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Harriet Tubman Museum Responds to NPS Website Changes
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Harriet Tubman Museum responds to NPS website changes

 April 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 372
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Following the removal and restoration of Harriet Tubman content from the National Park Service's webpage about the Underground Railroad, the Harriet Tubman Museum and Educational Center in Cambridge has vowed it will not change or reframe anything about Tubman at its center."Under no circumstances will we modify, reframe or change any facet of her life or history as the greatest conductor of the Underground Railroad," the center's Director of Events and Programs Linda Harris said in a statement.
Harris said the Harriet Tubman Museum and Educational Center "proudly" promotes Tubman's legacy.
"Her courage, valor, determination and faith exemplify the very essence and pursuit for living free and contributing to the healing and wellness of this country," Harris said.
In February, the National Park Service webpage titled "What is the Underground Railroad?" was altered. According to the Associated Press, changes to the webpage included the removal of a photo of Tubman from the top of the page and text edits that removed references to slavery and changed descriptions.
The changes to the site came amid the efforts to remove diversity, equity and inclusion policies in the federal government.
Last week, it was announced that changes to the webpage had been reversed.
According to the Associated Press, a National Park Service spokesperson said the changes were made without approval. The spokesperson said the agency celebrates Tubman.
In her statement, Harris said she is "saddened" to know the current administration "is making a concerted effort to rewrite and erase history."
Harriet Tubman, an abolitionist and social activist who was born into and escaped from slavery in Dorchester County in the 19th century, became well known for her work on the Underground Railroad, a network of routes and safe houses that helped slaves escape to their freedom. At the Harriet Tubman Museum and Educational Center in Cambridge, visitors can learn about the legacies of Tubman and other influential African Americans from the Eastern Shore.
Harris said that along with Tubman's legacy, the center will never forget Frederick Douglass, William Still and others who "documented and informed the nation of the atrocities of slavery."
"Tributes shall be given to freedom seekers, abolitionists and the many who endured and fought to end slavery in America!" Harris said. "We are evermore emboldened to tell their stories." 

 Copyright  2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Harriet Tubman Museum's response to changes in a federal website that affect how African-American history and slavery are presented, highlighting concerns about rewriting history and the impact on diversity and inclusion narratives.

title: Turning back the clock? Five years after George Floyd’s death, race in America faces Trump-driven changes and crossroads
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Turning back the clock? Five years after George Floyd’s death, race in America faces Trump-driven changes and crossroads

 May 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: National 
 
 1397
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the aftermath of the killing of George Floyd in May 2020, Irving Joyner and Rob Carpenter saw some signs of change when it came to race relations in America.Police agencies were pressed for more transparency and greater ability to charge officers accused of wrongdoing. Major employers, federal agencies, universities and progressive communities launched diversity and inclusion initiatives.
Five years after Floyd's death and ensuing protests and unrest, Joyner, a law professor at North Carolina Central University, is less optimistic.
"Now the opposite is occurring," Joyner said. "There is a retrenchment."
He points to efforts by the Trump administration and other conservatives to dismantle diversity, equity and inclusion programs and affirmative action hiring requirements, the directions of policies related to immigration and refugees and rollbacks of legal oversight sought by the Biden administration with the Minneapolis and Louisville police departments after the killings of Floyd and Breonna Taylor in 2020.
"The playbook seems to be pretty clear. There is an effort to undermine all the racial progress," Joyner said, contending DEI programs criticized by conservatives aim to be pathways to seeing the benefits of a pluralistic society.
"We see the parallels and the perils," Joyner said of the current landscape and America's history with race.
'PROTECTING COMMUNiTIES' Since returning to power in January, President Donald Trump has shut down DEI programs (including in the U.S. military) and affirmative action hiring requirements for federal agencies and contractors.
Trump argues for a "merit-based society" and conservatives say DEI and affirmative action policies disadvantage white people and continue to classify people along racial lines.
The U.S. Justice Department on May 21 said that it is dismissing federal lawsuits and proposed consent decrees with police in Minneapolis and Louisville in response to the Floyd and Taylor incidents.
"Overbroad police consent decrees divest local control of policing from communities where it belongs, turning that power over to unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats, often with an anti-police agenda," said Assistant U.S. Attorney General Harmeet Dhillon of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division.
Dhillon said the moves aim to end the Biden administration's "failed experiment of handcuffing local leaders and police departments."
A White House spokesperson said Trump is focused on safety and prosperity "for all Americans" and empowering law enforcement.
"President Trump is tirelessly enacting policies to ensure America's safety, prosperity, and success for all Americans. Through his Make America Safe Again agenda, the Trump Administration is committed to stopping crime, upholding justice, protecting communities, and empowering federal, state, and local law enforcement," said White House spokesperson Harrison Fields.
The White House said the president is not considering a pardon of Derek Chauvin, the Minneapolis police officer convicted of killing Floyd in May 2020.
Trump has pressed the District of Columbia to remove Black Lives Matter street murals near the White House and wants to restore names of military bases that bore the names of Confederate generals.
Joyner and Carpenter, an author and communications professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, feel undercurrents to Trump's rhetoric and agendas.
They see cultural and racial undertones to Trump's hard lines on immigration (including his efforts to end birthright citizenship), his nostalgia for a "Golden Age" of America and his administration's cuts to foreign aid and refugee programs for developing countries while launching a new one for white Afrikaner farmers from South Africa.
"Trump is perceived as turning back the clock," Carpenter said.
'HUMAN NATURE'S SCRIPT'Carpenter sees societal swings after Floyd's death went viral on social media, highlighting police misconduct and America's complicated history of racial and social inequities.
"I do think there has been some progress," Carpenter said, noting some of the efforts related to policing.
But Carpenter said plenty of challenges remain citing research showing 75% of white people do not have friends of color and 66% of Black people don't have any white friends.
Carpenter said African Americans still face obstacles and discrimination with jobs, noting a 2024 study that found job applicants with 'white-sounding' names were 50% more likely to get callbacks from employers than 'Black-sounding' names.
"It's an ongoing trauma. It's still a daily experience," Carpenter said of America's racial challenges.
But he also said the experiences of race in America and the current pushback to diversity and affirmative action programs have global and historical parallels.
"It's all throughout history where a majority population tends to favor themselves and dismiss the complaints of minorities," Carpenter said.
He said when minority rights are focused on, majority populations tend to feel they are being aggrieved.
"It's nothing new under the sun," Carpenter said. "They are just following the human nature script."
ECHO CHAMBERSOthers on the frontlines of the social landscape see a mixed bag with the current state of race in America.
Erica Williams, executive director of A Red Circle, a St. Louis-based racial equity group, welcomed post-Floyd police changes such as body cameras and civilian review boards, but said the community distrust of law enforcement persists.
She said the economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic "deepened every pre-existing divide — especially in food access, education and health care."
Her group has launched community food programs to help with post-pandemic inflation with U.S. prices up 25% since the pandemic.
"We grew more produce, hired youth interns, launched workshops and distributed thousands of pounds of fresh food to families," she said.
Adanté Pointer, a California-based civil rights attorney, sees ups and downs with policing since 2020.
"We are seeing officers prosecuted more frequently than before," he said. "However, police shootings and killings have gone up."
Last year, police killings of civilians totaled 1,365 persons, the highest on record, according to Mapping Police Violence.
There were 1,159 police-involved deaths in 2020.
White people made up 42.7% of the 2024 deaths while accounting for 59% of the total population. Black people accounted for one-quarter of fatal police incidents while making up 13% of the population.
Pointer said the dominance of social media in contemporary discourse offers an opportunity to learn more about others and their paths. But it also mirrors societal biases and beliefs and technology algorithms allow users to stay in their ideological and social lanes.
"It becomes an echo chamber," he said.
GOODBYE DEI?Donald Nieman, a history professor at Binghamton University in New York, sees racial pendulums throughout American history.
He said there has been progress in narrowing racial income, education and employment gaps but worries about Trump "appealing to white grievance."
Neiman said. "It also assumes that Black people have used racism as a weapon to win special privileges at the expense of whites .. It is dangerous: It diverts attention from the real racial disparities in our society and from developing policies to address them."
The U.S. poverty rate stands at 11% with 18% of African-Americans, 17% of Hispanic Americans, 19% of immigrants and 8% of white Americans living in poverty, according to U.S. Census data and FederalSafetyNet.com.
Some of the companies and organizations that embraced DEI efforts after Floyd's death have jettisoned those efforts amid pushback from Trump and conservatives.
Others have faulted DEI programs as patronizing and self-serving.
"DEI is embraced by the business community when they think it will enhance their bottom lines," Pointer said. "They are more than willing to walk away when it's not popular."
Several large U.S. businesses, brands and technology firms have sought warm relations with Trump since he returned to power, attending and bankrolling his inauguration and attending other White House events.
Muneer Panjwani, CEO of Engage for Good (which connects businesses and nonprofits) said DEI programs have driven "meaningful progress."
"Companies have become significantly more aware of systemic racism and structural barriers faced by marginalized communities, taking actionable steps toward equity," he said.
But Panjwani acknowledges Trump has leveraged feelings of alienation among some white people. He also said equity conversations have sometimes been framed too narrowly, overlooking class, gender and other factors.
Carpenter said white working-class Americans, who have seen stagnant wages and high inflation, have felt unheard in contemporary discourses.
All that comes amid post-pandemic financial strains and concentrations of wealth.
"Economic inequality has reached alarming levels, with the richest 1% holding over 31% of the nation's wealth while nearly half of Americans still struggle with unexpected financial burdens," Panjwani said.
Williams said her Missouri-based stays focused on its local work, including a community farm that grows its own food and is looking to offer its own grocery store and food production kitchen.
"We've seen an escalation of rhetoric and policymaking that undermines inclusive education, equity initiatives and even basic access programs. In that environment, I stay focused on building what my community needs," she said
Carpenter agrees that it takes popular and grassroots changes in mindsets to move the needle.
"Politicians never lead," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

It also touches on national policy and policing, but the central theme is racial issues.

title: DEI is about giving everybody an opportunity
author: STEPHEN RIDEOUT
content:
DEI is about giving everybody an opportunity

 June 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEPHEN RIDEOUT | Section: Columns 
 
 600
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I am reading "How We Learn to Be Brave" by Bishop Mariann Edgar Budde, the Episcopal bishop of Washington.In her book, she writes about Thurgood Marshall and the challenges that he faced during his life.
"When he was denied admission to the University of Maryland School of Law on the basis of race, he reluctantly applied to Howard University School of Law, which he considered a far less reputable institution," she writes.
That interested me because I was aware that when he became a lawyer, he and the NAACP successfully sued the University of Maryland Law School in the case of Murray v. Pearson for denying Black students admission because of their race. It also interested me because of conversations I had with two men who had similar experiences.
One was a retired judge, who told me that he had gone to Howard and graduated as valedictorian. Thurgood Marshall asked him to apply to the University of Virginia Law School thinking that they would deny him admission, despite his qualifications, so that he could be Marshall's plaintiff in a lawsuit against the university.
When he applied to UVA, he was not denied admission. Rather, he was approached by a wealthy benefactor of the university with the offer to pay for his law education at any other law school that would accept him. The retired judge accepted the offer, went to law school in New York, and had to tell Mr. Marshall that he would not be the plaintiff in that lawsuit.
Gregory Swanson became the successful plaintiff in that lawsuit against the rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia brought by the NAACP with Thurgood Marshall being one of the lawyers where Mr. Swanson was granted admission to the law school.
Several years after my discussion with the retired judge, I had a chance meeting with Rep. Alcee Hastings from Florida. I sat near him on a plane trip and told him the story of the experience the retired judge had as a student. Interestingly, Congressman Hastings told me that it was not an isolated event, as the same thing had happened to him and had also happened to African Americans who had applied to medical schools in the South.
Schools and alumni offered to pay their way to a graduate school in the north to avoid the litigation that might come from the denial of admission to the school to which they applied. While some may have been denied admittance, others were offered some benefit to go elsewhere such as the payment of their tuition at a law school or medical school elsewhere in the U.S.
When I hear complaints about diversity, equity and inclusion, I never hear the full story of the background or reasoning for these complaints. I see the DEI effort not as promoting unqualified people to a position but rather giving all people the opportunity to be considered for a position who might otherwise be excluded from being considered. Giving everyone the opportunity to compete and learn from the experience, whether hired, admitted or not, seems to me to benefit everyone.
Colleges and universities have done something similar for many years for the children of alumni of their institutions where the child might not be considered the most qualified candidate but is admitted. How is that not favoritism based on connections rather than on skills and past accomplishments? In Cambridge during my time in city government, the search for qualified city employees included anyone interested and always tried to find people who were a good fit for our community who had the potential to become great and long-term workers for the city. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
