title: 'Still Matters Today': Community to Read Famous Frederick Douglass Speech on Saturday
author: Konner Metz
content:
'Still matters today': Community to read famous Frederick Douglass speech on Saturday

 July 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 499
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On July 5, 1852, Frederick Douglass asked a burning question in front of hundreds of abolitionists in Rochester, New York: "What to the Slave is the Fourth of July?"The Talbot County native, often considered the most important abolitionist and civil rights leader of his time, delivered an address that described why enslaved African Americans weren't afforded the same freedoms and liberties that could allow them to celebrate the anniversary of the Declaration of Independence like the rest of the nation.
Douglass' famous speech is still popular 173 years later. On Saturday, the Easton-based Frederick Douglass Honor Society is hosting an annual community reading. Local officials, community leaders, residents and children are reading aloud portions of the address on the lawn of the Talbot County Courthouse starting at 10 a.m.
Vickie Wilson, the society's treasurer, says this year's calendar couldn't have worked out any better, with the event falling on the same day Douglass spoke to the Rochester Ladies Anti-Slavery Society.
"What's really exciting for us this year is that the first time Douglass read this speech was on July 5, 1852," Wilson said. "And now, it falls again on July 5."
The Frederick Douglass Honor Society has held the reading annually since 2018, though it was put on pause last year for a separate event. Wilson says this year's return is exciting due to the diversity of people — in age, race, occupation and more — participating in the reading. Fifty-nine people are expected to step up to the podium.
"We live in a diverse community," Wilson said. "It's going to show the love that we have for this community as well."
Douglass in his 1852 speech explained the significantly different perspective enslaved people had on the Fourth of July holiday.
"What, to the American slave, is your 4th of July? I answer; a day that reveals to him, more than all other days in the year, the gross injustice and cruelty to which he is the constant victim," Douglass said.
He continued: "To him, your celebration is a sham; your boasted liberty, an unholy license; your national greatness, swelling vanity; your sounds of rejoicing are empty and heartless; your denunciation of tyrants, brass fronted impudence; your shouts of liberty and equality, hollow mockery; your prayers and hymns, your sermons and thanksgivings, with all your religious parade and solemnity, are, to Him, mere bombast, fraud, deception, impiety, and hypocrisy — a thin veil to cover up crimes which would disgrace a nation of savages."
Wilson says the Talbot County tradition during the week of Independence Day is a moving one. She encourages people, no matter how they celebrate the holiday the rest of the week, to attend on Saturday.
She said the speech is a "lot to unpack," but extremely powerful. It still resonates with her today, and she believes it does for many Talbot County residents.
"It still matters today," Wilson said. "And I often think it matters more today in the climate that we're in right now. Everything here about this speech is still relevant." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community event reading Frederick Douglass's anti‑slavery speech, highlighting historical and contemporary issues of race, civil rights, and diversity in the local community.

Frederick Douglass — Abolitionist and Civil Rights Leader

title: Hiding the past leads to mistakes
author: Staff Writer
content:
Hiding the past leads to mistakes

 August 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 435
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Some time ago I drove down to visit Point Lookout State Park, having previously read about the Union prison camp that confined prisoners of the Confederacy in inhuman circumstances. This, even then, very narrow spit of land was entirely too small for the imprisoned population and must have collided with winter cold and intense summer sun.The recent efforts to alter our country's historical failings is, in my opinion, very dangerous. How many times have you heard parents say to their children, "Remember, we learn from our mistakes."
Should we not teach children about the Trial of Tears, where Native Americans were driven off their land and forced to relocate hundreds of miles from their homes?
Should we not talk about the fear that drove the U.S. government to relocate Japanese men, women and children into interment camps? The officials who made the decision to move this population thought at the time that these individuals posed a real threat to the general population, particularly on the West Coast of the U.S.A.
I grew up in the 1950s and 1960s. During my youth the country was trying to deal with Civil Rights issues. Every night on the news we saw demonstrations regarding this issue and heard Congress debate segregation versus integration. A decade later the Vietnam War was underway, and the country was split in many directions that were reflected in homes and on college campuses.
Like many people my age I had to earn a living, and so I had to focus on the here and now as an employee. The daily tasks did not leave much time for debating politics with friends.
I have seen in my lifetime people try to scapegoat the realities that both harmed and glorified our past.
We are an imperfect nation. Our forefathers created an engaging experiment. They created the greatest democracy ever witnessed on this planet.
We now have the opportunity to learn from our previous mistakes. I despise the fact that the Union Army starved and mistreated Southern soldiers, but that is a fact. I think it was a moral miscalculation to force Japanese families into prison campus, but that is a fact. The American Indian was relocated and forced to walk hundreds of miles from their land, but that's a fact. And old men and women can debate whether we should have ever placed ourselves in Vietnam, but we did, and that's a fact.
The role of the historian is to gather facts and tell us what took place and to provide the various options governments and individuals had when they made those decisions.
Hide the past, and it will only repeat itself.
GILBERT MASTER
Prince Frederick 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses historical injustices affecting Native Americans, Japanese Americans, and civil rights, focusing on how these issues relate to societal attitudes and memory, which aligns best with the Race & Diversity topic.
